Chapter 384: Old Friends

Fortunately, the bill that Сильвертид [he] left them with was only a gold – but still, for tea, that was a pretty ridiculous amount. Мокси [she] had ended up covering the tab, but Ной [he] suspected it was mostly so she’d have an excuse to make him speak with her at some point in the future.

For someone as rich as Сильвертид [he], there’s no way he’d actually need to stiff anyone from a single gold. Old bastard was just screwing with us. Do we not know anyone that doesn’t have a completely screwed up sense of humor?

“I want some tea,” Ли [she] said.

“Sure, but you can’t eat the kettle,” Ной [he] said absently, only half paying attention.

“Oh. Never mind, then.”

“Well, that was enlightening,” Мокси [she] said with something between a sigh and a laugh. “At least Сильвертид [he] will show the dagger to the others. The Исполнители should have access to a lot more information than I do, so hopefully they figure out something useful.”

“It’ll be nice to have someone else do something for once,” Ной [he] agreed.

“To be fair, I’m pretty sure we’ve gotten ourselves into most of the shit we’ve had to deal with,” Мокси [she] pointed out. “Not that I’m arguing. But… what now? Do we just wait around and wait for news on the dagger to come back to us?”

“That is exactly what I plan to do,” Ной [he] said, rising from the table. “Визен [he] has a whole bunch of people on his ass now, and I’ve got no desire to stick my nose further into his business until the time comes to deal with him. We’ve got a group of students that still need training – not to mention that competition we’re running.”

“And patterns to practice,” Ли [she] added. “I still need to work on mine.”

“Isn’t your pattern basically just eating?” Мокси [she] asked.

“It’s valid. If you chew in the right way, it’s a pattern.”

Huh. I wonder if that pattern would actually have anything to do with Ли [she]’s Demon Rune. If it’s actually Gluttony overlaid with the Broken Master Rune, then mastering the pattern of eating might actually be pretty beneficial. I don’t know if encouraging Ли [she] to eat any more than she already does is a good idea, though. She might end up popping.

“Patterns are patterns. Getting back on track isn’t going to hurt anyone. Just don’t eat too much,” Ной [he] said. “I need to get some practice in myself. I still need to push my Formations farther, and I got interrupted the last time I tried to work on them. I imagine the продвинутая группа will start doing things fairly soon as well.”

“Probably,” Мокси [she] agreed with a nod. “Especially since the puppets have been dealt with. I doubt they’re going to want to sit around and waste time when exams are already creeping up around the corner. I wouldn’t be surprised if some of the professors were already practicing together.”

“Well, we’ll get around to that whenever it happens. We’ve got our own training to handle,” Ной [he] said. “But that can come tomorrow, after I find Тим [he] and help him fix up his Runes. For today, I think the only thing I want to do is relax.”

And figure out what I can do for a date. I can’t take Мокси [she] out to a restaurant – Ли [she] would feel left out, and I’m not sure she’d actually understand the concept of a date if it involved food and didn’t involve her. Are there movies on this world? Plays, I guess?

That seems kind of lame.

“Is something wrong?” Мокси [she] asked. “You look kind of troubled. Are you thinking about Визен [he]?”

“No,” Ной [he] replied honestly. “Don’t get me wrong, it’s not that I’m not concerned about dealing with that crazy bastard – I just have other things I want to do. I can’t afford to worry about all the powerful assholes we’ve somehow managed to piss off, since that number seems to grow every time I turn around.”

“That’s probably because you’re flipping them off as you turn,” Мокси [she] said with a wry smile. “But I certainly wouldn’t say no to a little relaxation before we really get into the swing of the year. A rest day sounds great, especially after… well, you know.”

“Yeah,” Ной [he] muttered. “Same. Let’s go home.”

“Oh, I’m looking forward to this. Perfect timing, really,” Декрас [he] said, a grin pulling across his lips. “Wouldn’t you agree?”

“You’re an asshole,” Renwewal said. “I want to see them do something cute. Can’t you keep your stupid surprise held off for a little longer? You could at least wait until after Ной [he] takes Мокси [she] on a date. He’s clearly planning on it.”

“Are you kidding? No. It’ll be far more interesting if I speed my surprise up so it shows up during the date. Think of the drama,” Декрас [he] said, spreading his arms wide. “I can’t time it that perfectly, unfortunately. My influence is constrained, but this should be more than enough to give us entertainment.”

“I was going to get entertainment already,” Возрождение [she] said with a cross frown. “Not everything has to be death and slaughter, you know.”


“Says the woman who was perfectly thrilled to see the surprise just a few short blips in time ago,” Декрас [he] pointed out. “You change your mind like the seasons.”

“What’s the point of having a mind if you can’t change it? I forgot how cute it can be to watch mortals play around. They’re so… innocent. Their stakes are so infinitesimally small in the grand scheme of things. So unimportant. And yet, they place such value on those worthless stakes. It gives those moments of peace a lot more meaning than the endless sea of nothing that we’ve got to deal with.”

Декрас [he] leaned back in his chair and sighed. “Have you already forgotten that you’re mad at the stupid little thief? He took our Runes, and he took your avatar.”

“Maybe he’s going to put them to better use than we would,” Возрождение [she] muttered, sinking into her chair. “Don’t you ever get exhausted of this shit, Декрас [he]? There has to be more to the universe than what we have.”

“Oh, every single day,” Декрас [he] replied. “But I’ve learned that there’s nothing I can do about it. Compared to those little specs running around on the world we’re watching, we’re the peak of power. But… in the grand scheme of things? Nobody would notice if we vanished, Возрождение [she]. If you really want to challenge the way things work, then go push your Rune farther.”

Возрождение [she] gagged. “Oh, yeah. Lovely. Spend all the energy I’ve gathered and lose an enormous amount of time for what – a promotion to watch a bigger line of mortal souls? The real freedom only comes with power greater than what my talent will ever let me claim.”

“And yet you won’t abandon your line,” Декрас [he] observed, interlacing his fingers and kicking his feet back. “Do you care about your job or not? You could always just leave. Become a rogue god.”

“I’m not nearly strong enough for that,” Возрождение [she] said. Her eyes drifted to the shimmering image, where Ной [he] was walking back toward his room with Мокси [she] and Ли [she]. “But things might change. This mortal has been progressing at a ridiculous rate. He may actually discover something that I can use.”

“If he survives,” Декрас [he] put in.

Возрождение [she] sighed. “Yes. If he survives. But do you really think it likely he runs into anything that can actually kill him? His companions are the ones at risk. As long as he isn’t captured, he’ll be fine.”

“Does it matter?” Декрас [he] asked. “There’s more than one way to die. Because of his little bout of thievery, Ной [he] kept all his memories of the afterlife. He’s not mentally stable. If he loses the others – he’ll snap.”

“Which is why he’ll protect them,” Возрождение [she] said. She went to say something else, then paused and sent a look at Декрас [he]. “Wait. You just used his name.”

“What? No I didn’t.”

“Yes you did,” Возрождение [she] said, a grin stretching across her lips. “You’re just as invested as I am, aren’t you?”

“I most certainly am not. That’s why I’m doing my utmost to kill him in an entertaining way,” Декрас [he] snapped, crossing his arms in front of his chest and glaring at Возрождение [she]. “Unlike you, I’ve never been a fan of this sappy garbage. The only thing that forces mortals to grow is their greatest fear. Death.”

“That’s a miserable outlook on life. I can see why you can’t advance your Rune any farther.”

“Says the one who can’t advance hers.”

“I’m probably still farther along than you are.”

“Do you want to find out?” Декрас [he] asked, his eyes narrowing. “I’d be happy to oblige.”

“If you want me to chop your hand off again that badly, you can just ask,” Возрождение [she] said, not even looking over to Декрас [he]. “Be honest with yourself and admit you’re just jealous of Ной [he] and Мокси [she]. Their relationship is cute.”

“Your brains must have gotten rattled loose over the years,” Декрас [he] said, flopping back into his chair and rolling his eyes. “You’re like a child playing with dolls. If you really care that much about them, you really shouldn’t have let me send them that surprise.”

“It’s not going to be that big of a threat, is it?” Возрождение [she] asked. He didn’t respond. Возрождение [she] glanced at him out of the corners of her eyes. “Декрас [he]? You just said it would be a challenge. How big of a challenge is this?”

“Well, one of them might survive.”

“Show me the damn creature you sent their way,” Возрождение [she] snapped. “I swear, if you kill Мокси [she] and Ли [she] in such a stupid way, I am going to be pissed.

What’s the fun in watching Ной [he] on his own?”

Декрас [he] reached out toward the screen and the image rippled. Ной [he] and the other mortals vanished, replaced by a grassy field. A huge figure strode through it, a wicked double-bladed axe strapped to his back and a dark hood pulled low over his face.

“You sent one of your apostles?” Возрождение [she] said, her voice raising in disbelief. “I thought you said you were going to send a challenge that would give them a good gift if they managed to survive!”

“I did!” Декрас [he] said defensively. “If they actually managed to beat him, think of the Runes they’d get!”

“He’s Rank 7!” Возрождение [she] exclaimed. “Are you an idiot? They’re going to die! Call him off!”

“I can’t,” Декрас [he] said, rubbing the back of his head. “The idiot isn’t talented enough to hear my voice. I can only communicate to most of my apostles through their head. The rest of them are a little… tone deaf – and Гарина [she] is ignoring me. Can’t you contact your bald churchgoer?”

“He barely even follows me. He’s too busy flirting with your little temptress,” Возрождение [she] snapped. She nearly rose out of her chair before she caught herself. It wasn’t like she could actually interfere herself.

Not without drawing the attention of the other gods – and that was the absolute last thing she wanted to do. But, as she watched the screen, a frown crossed her lips.

“Wait. Why is he walking? Shouldn’t he be at Арбитраж [he] already?”

“I told him to go slowly so he wouldn’t arrive too early,” Декрас [he] said. “It’s not going to change anything. An extra day or two won’t save them.”

“Damn it,” Возрождение [she] muttered. She glared at the screen, strongly considering splattering the apostle, consequences be damned. It had been so long since she’d found something of interest that even the ridicule of the other gods felt like it wasn’t as bad as losing the flower blossoming before her.

The apostle skidded to a halt in the grass. Возрождение [she] let out a relieved sigh.

“You managed to get through to him?”

“No,” Декрас [he] said, confusion muddling his words. “I didn’t do anything. I–”

A shadow stretched out across the ground before the apostle, and a scythe carved up from within it. From within it rose a man with a shit-eating grin plastered across his face.

“Hullo,” the man said, slinging his scythe across his shoulders and draping his arms over it. “Care to direct that murderous stride of yours somewhere else? I’m conducting an experiment in that direction.”

“Who is that, Декрас [he]?” Возрождение [she] asked. Декрас [he] didn’t respond. He was too busy staring at the screen.

“Ревин [he],” the apostle said, his voice a mixture of derision and poorly hidden unease. “What are you doing here?”

“Oh, come on now.” Ревин [he]’s grin widened, revealing his pointed teeth. “That’s no way to greet an old friend, is it?”
==========
Chapter 385: We All Get Hungry

“We are anything but friends,” the large apostle spat. “I don’t know why you’re here, Ревин [he], but this is the only warning you’re going to get. Leave.”

“Anything?” Ревин [he] arched an eyebrow. “Don’t tell me you’re already ready for the next step. I’m not sure I can see you as anything more than a friend, though. I’m afraid I’ll have to refuse.”

“Out of my way, Ревин [he].”

“Oh, it’s just my luck that you’re the one that comes bumbling along my way,” Ревин [he] said with an exasperated sigh. “Why couldn’t it have been someone interesting? How’s Гарина [she] these days, Одрен [he]? She was always fun.”

“She never recovered after the damage you did to her,” Одрен [he] said. “She had so much potential, and you ruined it by turning her into a nutjob, just like yourself. Step down. I’m on a mission from the Master himself, and that means I’m allowed to cut right through you if I need to.”

“You?” Ревин [he] exclaimed, taking a step back. “Cut through me? Oh, no. I don’t think that’s very likely. How long has it been since we last saw each other, Одрен [he]?”

“Not long enough.”

“I won’t disagree with that answer, but I believe you’ve skirted the question. If I’m being honest, I’ve forgotten myself. I don’t tend to remember people that don’t draw much of my interest, and the only reason you even got a spot in my memory is because of those lovely sounds your body makes when I slam it against walls. You could never beat me, Одрен [he]. Not then, and not now.”

“You used to be a real threat,” Одрен [he] said, reaching back to the large axe on his back. He hoisted it at his side, baring his teeth in challenge. “But not anymore. You couldn’t handle the power that the Master gave us. It broke your weak mind and burned what remained of it away like kindling.”

Ревин [he] glanced down at himself, then back up at Одрен [he]. “I’m right here, you know. If I burned away, would I really be standing around wasting a perfectly good day by speaking to a walking bag of rocks?”

“You got your warnings,” Одрен [he] snarled. His body blurred as six streamers of black smoke erupted from him, streaking out through the air. Ревин [he] brought his scythe down, carving the smoke apart before it could reach him.

“I really do hope you’ve learned to do more than that in the time since we last had the misfortune of meeting,” Ревин [he] drawled, spinning the scythe and driving its butt into the ground. “Because that was disappointing, Одрен [he]. I already don’t expect much from you, but it’s been years since I left your group. If I’m being honest, the costumes were a bit too much for me. I mean, come on. Dressing up in dark clothes and meeting in caves? How can you say I’m the one that’s insane when you manage to make the Church of Repose look legitimate?”

Одрен [he] wasn’t goaded so easily, but the flurry of axe swings he unleashed on Ревин [he] had considerably more anger behind them than they needed. Every single strike whistled harmlessly past Ревин [he] as he stepped around, his lips pursed in disappointment.

“The others will thank me when I take your head.” Одрен [he]’s axe hummed with power as he lunged, narrowly missing Ревин [he] as the other man stepped out of the way again.

“The others will thank you when you take a bath,” Ревин [he] replied. “Or perhaps you just forgot to wash your costume. You know, if you want to be all secretive, shouldn’t you meet in really plain clothes in a plain building? Nobody would ever suspect that. Now, a bunch of hooded mushroom eating idiots? That’s definitely a cult.”

“Why are you here?” Одрен [he] screamed. His axe split apart, dozens of afterimages carving through the air with keening howls. The grass all around them was carved to shreds and the earth collapsed, falling out from under the pressure of Одрен [he]’s domain.

“Is that really all you can do?” Ревин [he] asked with a wry smile. “Or are you restricted? You can’t use your full force, can you? Worried that Гарина [she] will come spank you if she realizes that a Rank 7 is strolling around in her domain?”

“Гарина [she] is one of the Apostles,” Одрен [he] snapped. “She’s on my side, not yours.”

“If you’re so sure about that, why aren’t you using more power?” Ревин [he] asked. “You’ve attacked me with nothing that a Rank 4 couldn’t have done. As a matter of fact, I know a Rank 4 that could probably do it better. Maybe two.”

Одрен [he] ground his teeth. His eyes flicked around the clearing, clearly searching for some form of escape, but wherever they landed, Ревин [he] seemed to stroll into view a second later. It wasn’t like Ревин [he] was omnipotent – he just seemed to know exactly wherever Одрен [he] was going to look before he did.


“Are you this dead set on interfering with our duties?” Одрен [he] asked. “Even if you can hold me off, do you really believe you could hold off all of the Apostles when they come for you in retaliation for standing in the way of our holy mission?”

“Is that what you’re calling it now? I kind of figured you liked getting bossed around by a mysterious figure. You know, I figure I could probably do that. If I put on a cloak and tell you to get lost, will you do it?”

“You dare disrespect the Master?” Одрен [he] asked. “I am no fool, Ревин [he]. I know your mouth runs like a river to distract your opponents – but are you really stupid enough to believe you can stand against a god?”

Ревин [he] heaved a sigh. The grin fell away from his face and he leaned against his scythe. “Одрен [he], for old times’ sake, I’ll give you one honest answer in the form of another question. Do you really think this Master gives a shit about you? I mean, I don’t blame him. He gets free labor. Who says no to that?”

“He gives us power! You’re nothing without the Rune he gave you,” Одрен [he] said. “If it wasn’t for his mercy, you’d be a crippled husk by now. I suspect he just enjoys watching your antics, but he specifically ordered that I kill two weaklings – weaklings that I suspect you are stopping me from getting to.”

“Look at that. You can get smarter,” Ревин [he] said with an overexaggerated nod. “Good job.”

Одрен [he]’s axe carved through the air, whistling harmlessly past Ревин [he] once more. Ревин [he] stepped past the considerably larger man, rapping him on the back of the head with his scythe.

“Stop with your delay tactics!” Одрен [he] demanded. “Fight me or leave. This is ridiculous. We are not children.”

“Funny you say that. If you don’t start taking this fight seriously, you’re going to die,” Ревин [he] said. “It’s time to make up your mind. Either commit to your god given orders and use those powers that you’re hiding – prove that your Master really did order you here, and what do you have to lose? Against both you and Гарина [she], I’m sure I’d struggle.”

Одрен [he] grit his teeth, and Ревин [he]’s grin grew wider.

“Unless you’re concerned that Гарина [she] would turn against you. Or are you more worried that she won’t show up at all?”

“She’ll show up,” Одрен [he] said. “She always does. It’s the one damn thing she held onto from before joining us, and not even the Master could get her to stop. It’s a waste of time, but she’s obsessed with it.”

“That’s because she’s smarter than you are,” Ревин [he] said. “Last chance to turn around and walk away, big man.”

“Eat shit.”

“Ah, well,” Ревин [he] said. “Can’t say I didn’t try.”

***

“What am I watching?” Возрождение [she] asked in disbelief, staring at the fight – if it could be called that – playing out on the rippling image before her and Декрас [he].

“Ревин [he],” Декрас [he] replied. It was impossible to tell if the tone of his voice was annoyed, impressed, or a mixture of the two. “He was one of mine, at one point. One of the strongest.”

“Something tells me that isn’t true anymore. He doesn’t seem to think much of you. Maybe he should join up with me.” Возрождение [she] snickered.

“He’d rip your church apart from the inside,” Декрас [he] said. “And you’re right. Ревин [he] is mad. Одрен [he] wasn’t wrong about that.”

“He doesn’t seem mad. Just annoying. Driving your enemy up a wall in a fight is a perfectly valid strategy,” Возрождение [she] observed. “I wouldn’t say it’s a respectable one, but it’s a strategy nonetheless.”

“Does anything you see right now look even remotely sane to you?” Декрас [he] asked.

Возрождение [she] turned back to the screen. Одрен [he] was stumbling around, swinging his axe and shouting obscenities at nothing. Ревин [he] sat on a rock about a hundred feet away from him, his chin resting in his palm and a bored expression on his face.

He hadn’t moved once from that spot. Not once had Одрен [he] actually spoken to his real form, and the answer was the very same one that Ревин [he] had been pushing Одрен [he] to take. Ревин [he]’s domain was out – and in full force.

Invisible energy wove out from him in a huge globe, working into every single thing around him. Ревин [he] hadn’t ever pulled his domain back. He was strolling around with it practically pouring out power at such an intense wavelength that a lesser mage wouldn’t have even noticed it – but Гарина [she] certainly should have.

“Гарина [she] is choosing to ignore him?” Возрождение [she] asked, her eyebrows lifting. “

She made an exception?”

“It’s not that Гарина [she] chose to make an exception,” Декрас [he] said. “She didn’t have a choice. Ревин [he] has long since twisted himself into something that he should not be. Just like Ной [he] to you, Ревин [he] is my own experiment gone awry. One that may bear fruit one day, but for the time being, does nothing but annoy me.”

“All of your Apostles have some of your energy,” Возрождение [she] said with a shrug. “That’s not really that much of a surprise.”

“You don’t understand.” Декрас [he] shook his head. “Yes, the Apostles have some of my power – but Ревин [he] doesn’t. Not anymore.”

Одрен [he]’s eyes went wide. He doubled over, coughing violently and clutching at something invisible in his chest.

“Ревин [he] got rid of the magic you gave him?” Возрождение [she] blinked in surprise. It was rare to find a mortal that would actually throw power away in exchange for freedom, but there was a lot to respect there. “That’s actually quite interesting.”

Одрен [he] spun, running in the opposite direction as fast as he could without drawing enough power to pull Гарина [she]’s attention.

“Ревин [he] didn’t get rid of it,” Декрас [he] said, as if the words were bitter in his mouth.

Возрождение [she] pulled her eyes away from Одрен [he], frowning. “What are you talking about?”

“The magic. He didn’t get rid of it.”

“What did he do, then?”

“The annoying bastard consumed it.”

Chapter 386: Ревин [he] Problems

Ревин [he] slung his scythe back over his shoulder and sank into the shadow of the rock he stood beside, disappearing and leaving the grassy plain silent. Возрождение [she] struggled to keep a laugh from bursting out from her mouth.

“Декрас [he]?”

“What?” Декрас [he] asked irritably.

“Your Apostle kind of sucks. That was pathetic.”

“Don’t pretend like anyone from your church would be any better,” Декрас [he] said with a grunt. He stole a chocolate from the bowl before Возрождение [she] could stop him. “Damn it. I can’t tell if I like watching Ревин [he] or get fed up with his constant interference.”

“Don’t you think we should be at least a little bit concerned that our experiments have found each other?” Возрождение [she] asked, the smile fading from her face.

“Experiments? Don’t group that little thief in with Ревин [he],” Декрас [he] said with a scoff. “He’s not an experiment. He just stole some Runes.”

“Right,” Возрождение [she] said dryly. “Well, whatever he is, he’s working together with Ревин [he].”

“Doubt it. Ревин [he] doesn’t work together with anyone. Not anymore. The thief just managed to catch his attention for a little while. I wouldn’t concern yourself about it because that’s not going to last long.”

“You sound really certain of that,” Возрождение [she] observed, waving her hand and dismissing the image as she turned to face Декрас [he]. “What if it does?”

“Bah. It’ll be fine. What are you worried about?” Декрас [he] asked, leaning forward and bracing his arms against his knees. “Do you think they’re going to form a union or something?”

Возрождение [she] blinked. “A union? You think they’ll get married? They better not. Ной [he] and Мокси [she] go together too perfectly.”

“What? No.” Декрас [he] let out an exasperated sigh. “The mortals of some other planets have unions where they all get together to try and get more rights for themselves against their masters. Forget it. Either way, Ревин [he] is just mildly interested. Even if it was more, they’re mortals. We don’t have anything to fear.”

“I’m not sure fear would even be the right word,” Возрождение [she] said. “I’m not scared of Ной [he]. Even if he managed to ascend to godhood, I don’t think he’d actually be a threat. More like an ally. His goals will align with ours.”

“Hold on,” Декрас [he] said, his eyes widening as he matched Возрождение [she]’s posture. “You think that he’s going to make it to godhood? Someone from that shitty little planet? They understand absolutely nothing, and there are millions of people with more potential than average.”

“He has our Runes.”

“The Apostles have had my runes for centuries. Fat load of good it’s done most of them.”

“That’s because you gave it,” Возрождение [she] said. “Ной [he] took his, and he’s changed them. He’s changed yours too.”

“Just like Ревин [he],” Декрас [he] muttered, his eyes narrowing. “Fine. Perhaps he makes it to godhood. Do you really think the first thing he did wouldn’t be to come after the rest of the power he’s taken? I say we kill him the instant he ascends.”

Возрождение [she] tilted her head to the side. “It’s hard to say. He’s certainly power hungry when the time comes, but his concern is more about his friends than it is about himself. I don’t think he’d go picking fights that they won’t all survive. A new god isn’t going to be able to defeat us.”

“You’re only saying that because you’re attached.”

“If you truly wanted to kill him, you’d have already done it yourself,” Возрождение [she] pointed out. She crossed her arms and arched an eyebrow. “You’ve always skirted the rules, Декрас [he]. This wouldn’t have been any different. You were secretly happy when Ревин [he] showed up, weren’t you? You’re having just as much fun with this as I am, even if you’re too cocky to admit it.”

“Your head is full of delusion and pink fluff.”

“And yours wishes it was. Better to be honest and have fun than to keep being stuffy,” Возрождение [she] said. “Why do you think the other gods don’t even so much as say hi to you? They’d be friendlier if you stopped being such a dick.”

“I have no need for worthless people. The majority of the other gods in our area of the universe barely scraped their ways to godhood and care for nothing but telling each other how great they are.”

Возрождение [she] cleared her throat. Декрас [he] wasn’t exactly wrong. It was hard to believe how much more enjoyable his company was than that of the other gods, especially given how much of a prick he was.

“Okay, I’ll give you that,” Возрождение [she] said. “But I still think that you could stay true to yourself without using fighting as your main excuse to see people.”

“Fighting is what makes us grow.”

“So is deep conversation.”

“Whatever helps you sleep at night,” Декрас [he] said through a yawn. “Turn the spell back on. Do you think Ной [he] is doing anything interesting?”

Возрождение [she] flicked her hand and the image bloomed, shifting to Мокси [she]’s room. Her eyes widened and she hurriedly waved it away, banishing the spell before it could even fully take form.


“Maybe we can look at other people for now,” Возрождение [she] suggested, coughing into her fist.

“That might be a wise idea,” Декрас [he] said. “What about some of his students?”

“His students?” Возрождение [she] tilted her head to the side and raised an eyebrow as the embarrassment faded from her cheeks. “That’s the first time you’ve shown even the slightest amount of interest in them. Which one?”

“The crippled one,” Декрас [he] said. “She’s taken to the fundamentals of Runes better than most. In any normal circumstances, it wouldn’t even matter. She’d have no chance of making it past Rank 3 because of those Body Runes… but Ной [he] changes things.”

“Aha! You used his name again!”

“Make up your mind on what you want me to do,” Декрас [he] snapped.

“I – ah. Well, I suppose that’s a fair request,” Возрождение [she] said with a frown. “Fine. Sorry. Let’s take a look at Александра [she], then. She’s got some spirit to her. I’m personally looking forward to how she deals with the members of that little club Ной [he]’s group joined. There are some decent mages in there – for their Rank, at least.”

“I hope she kills them.”

“The solution to everything does not have to be killing.”

“I still hope she kills them.”

***

Александра [she] lowered her sword and opened her eyes, letting the outside world slip back into awareness. The sun had traced through the sky overhead – it had been hours since she’d started practicing for the day.

Not enough. I feel like I’m so close, but I’m still not there. When I was fighting with Геро [he], I think I had it for a moment. But, no matter what I do while training, I just can’t recapture whatever it was that I did there.

Maybe I should go find Изабель [she] and see if she wants to spar.

Александра [she] sheathed her sword and headed out of the small dirt circle that had been serving as her training area. It was just a short walk back to her dormitory, where she quickly rinsed off before setting off to Изабель [she] and Тодд [he]’s room.

She only made it down a single turn in the corridor before having to jump back, having nearly walked straight into Тодд [he].

“Whoa,” Тодд [he] said. “Sorry. Didn’t see you there, Александра [she]. I was just going to try and find you.”

“We must have had the same idea. Is Изабель [she] busy? I was hoping to do some sparring with her.”

“She’s out training somewhere, actually,” Тодд [he] said. “She just headed out thirty minutes or so ago, so I don’t think she’s going to be back anytime soon.”

“Ah, damn it,” Александра [she] said with a frown. “Maybe I should ask Вермил [he], then. I’ve been stuck on this for too long. I need to advance already.”

“That’s actually why I came looking for you,” Тодд [he] said. “You’ve been working on your pattern a lot, right?”

“Yeah,” Александра [she] said with a nod. “I was making great progress at first, but it feels like I’ve hit a wall. No matter what I do, I don’t get better. It feels like I understand the pattern perfectly, but I logically know I don’t. I’m missing something and I don’t know what it is. What about you? Have you been having any luck with your pattern?”

“Some,” Тодд [he] said. “I’m honestly not sure if I’m headed down the right path with it. That’s why I was going to look for you. I’d ask the professor, but I don’t want to wait until next class.”

I suppose it can’t hurt. Maybe I’ll find what’s wrong if I have to explain it to someone else.

“I can try,” Александра [she] said.

“Awesome! Thank you,” Тодд [he] said, turning and heading back down the hall toward his rooms with Александра [she] at his side. He pulled a bracelet out of his pocket as they walked, running a thumb along the runes carved into its surface. “I’ve been trying to figure out exactly what my pattern is, you know?”

“Wait, you don’t know?” Александра [she] asked, blinking in surprise as they reached the door and Тодд [he] pushed it open. “How can you practice if you don’t know your pattern?”

“Well, that’s the problem.” Тодд [he] waved Александра [she] over to Изабель [she]’s chair, then sat down in his own and rocked onto its back legs. “Your pattern is like a single thing, right?”

“I’m trying to embody the changing nature of wind.”

“Right. A single thing. I’m trying to improve my imbuing,” Тодд [he] said, nodding to the band in his hands. “But that can’t just be ‘embody fire’ or whatever. It needs to be a conceptual understanding. But how do you summarize understanding наполнение [he]s as a whole? I don’t want to just figure out how to make better fire наполнение [he]s or the like – I want to improve my imbuing overall – but I can’t just make my pattern being better.”

“That is a problem,” Александра [she] admitted. “I didn’t really think about trying to expand a pattern to such a large concept. Are you certain it’s even possible?”

“I’m not sure. Вермил [he] said it was promising, and he obviously knows what he’s talking about. The problem is that he doesn’t know imbuing that well. Of the group, I’m the one that knows it the best.”

Тодд [he]’s tone made it clear that he wasn’t bragging. He was just being completely honest. It felt a bit odd for a student to claim they were better than their teacher at anything, but everything about Вермил [he]’s class was strange.

“Is it possible you’re too deep?” Александра [she] asked after thinking for a few moments.

“Deep? What do you mean?”

“Well, the more you know about a subject, the further you enter it,” Александра [she] said. She tapped the sword at her side. “Like swordsmanship, for example. It’s much more than just swinging a blade around. It’s the mindset, the footwork, everything around you.”

“Right, that makes sense. But what does that have to do with patterns or imbuing?”

“Have you ever focused so hard on a problem that you’ve been stuck on for ages, but then someone who knows absolutely nothing about it walks over and gives you the answer almost by accident?”

Тодд [he]’s brow furrowed and he gave her a slow nod. “Yeah. All the time, actually.”

“Maybe it’s that. You could be trying to get so deep into наполнение [he]s that you’re focusing on them instead of the pattern. Have you considered toning it back instead of pushing farther?”

Тодд [he] tapped his foot on the ground, chewing his lower lip. “Huh. That’s a really good idea, actually. Easier said than done, but it gives me something to work with. Damn. Now I feel stupid.”

“Having an outside perspective can help.”

“True,” Тодд [he] agreed. “Is that why you were looking for Изабель [she]? Maybe I can help in her place.”

“I was going to try to spar with her.”

“Ah. Well, I can do that.”

Александра [she] gave Тодд [he] a doubtful look. “You can use a sword?”

“Barely. I’m worse than she is. But why are you only fighting someone with a sword? Didn’t you say your pattern was wind? That has nothing to do with your sword. You’re just using it as the way to express the wind.”

Александра [she] blinked. Then her eye twitched. Тодд [he] burst into laughter.

“You did the same shit you just told me about, didn’t you?”

“Yes,” Александра [she] muttered, but she couldn’t stay distracted for long with the building excitement. Тодд [he] was right, and now that she knew, it was so obvious that it was painful. She’d figured out how to embody wind with her sword, but her pattern had to be far more than just swordplay. “In that case, I’ll take you up on your offer. Can we spar hand to hand?”

“With pleasure,” Тодд [he] said with a grin. “Let’s go.”

Chapter 387: Fixed Up

Ной [he] headed out of Мокси [she]’s room early in the morning, adjusting his jacket and combing his hair out of the way as he headed down the hall. His grimoire was slung over a shoulder, and the large book thumped against his back with every step.

He’d been slightly waylaid after he’d woken up, but he was determined to find Тим [he] and repair his runes before the day was over. The only question was if Тим [he] would be back in the tower by the time he got there and – if he was – how Ной [he] would be able to justify what he could do.

I wish there was a way I could do this without revealing the existence of Разлом [he]. Actually – what happens if I knock him out while we’re in his soul space? Or, what if I knock him out before the Mind Meld’s potions take effect?

That kind of feels like assault with extra steps, though. Damn. Maybe Тим [he] will give me permission to bludgeon him with a heavy object. That would make it fine.

Ной [he] arrived at the base of the Transport Cannon a short while later. There was a small line built up at it, which was a good sign as to Тим [he]’s whereabouts. After a few minutes of waiting in line, he found himself standing on the lift as it rattled up to the top floor.

Тим [he] sat at his desk, stroking his beard and reading a book as Ной [he] arrived. He glanced up, the skin around his eyes crinkling as he smiled. “Вермил [he]! What brings you here? I don’t see your students.”

“I’m here to see you, actually,” Ной [he] said. “I heard about what happened yesterday.”

Тим [he]’s smile faded and he nodded. “Yes. It could have been a horrible thing. I was relieved to hear that they were all safe, but I heard that speaking about it was a bad idea. The person responsible may have had some dangerous ties.”

“Yeah. Don’t worry, that’s not why I’m here,” Ной [he] said. “Not specifically, at least.”

“Oh? Headed somewhere, then?”

“Not that either,” Ной [he] said. He glanced through the window. The majority of the line had already gone through the transport cannon, but there were still a few more people waiting. “Do you think you’ve got a little while? About half an hour or so?”

“I suppose so,” Тим [he] said. “Let me just handle the rest of the crowd and then I’ll shut down for a little while.”

“Thanks,” Ной [he] said, moving to stand in the corner of the room. The lift rattled back down, and Ной [he] waited as Тим [he] spent the next few minutes sending everyone off to a variety of different areas.

Once he’d finished and the line had dried up, Тим [he] pulled a lever at the corner of his panel and pressed his hand against the desk. A small wave of energy ran throughout it, racing through наполнение [he]s. The lift rattled up, locking in place at the top floor.

“All closed up for the time being,” Тим [he] said, sitting back down. “I’m not sure how much I’ll be able to help, but I’d be glad to hear what I can do for you.”

“It’s more the other way around,” Ной [he] said. “Some time ago, you told me about how you ended up here.”

“Did I?” Тим [he] asked, rubbing the back of his neck. “My memory isn’t what it used to be, but I suppose I must have. What does that have to do with anything?”

“Well, you mentioned that you landed this job because your Runes weren’t good enough to let you advance, right?”

Тим [he] grunted. “Yeah, but I haven’t been beat up about that for years. You learn to deal with your lot in life as you get older.”

Ной [he] reached into his bag and pulled out a Mind Meld potion, setting it on the counter. Тим [he] tilted his head to the side, studying the vial with a confused look. “Is this alcohol? It’s quite… shimmery.”

“No,” Ной [he] said with a laugh. “It’s a potion. One that’ll make it easier for us to speak privately.”

“Alcohol does the same thing when you use enough of it,” Тим [he] said with a cackle. He pulled the wax seal off the top of the potion and sniffed at it, then shrugged before draining his half.

Ной [he] took the bottle and removed the other seal, draining the rest of the bottle before returning it to the table.

“Stay sitting,” Ной [he] said. “You might feel a bit dizzy.”

Even as Тим [he] nodded, a buzz enveloped Ной [he]’s mind. He quickly lowered himself to lean against the wall, keeping one hand on his grimoire as the potion yanked him out of his mind and into Тим [he]’s.


When Ной [he]’s eyes opened once again, he found himself standing on a plain grassy hill. Seven Runes floated in the air around him, and Ной [he] wasn’t surprised to find that they were all horrendously bad.

They were all Rank 2, and even though they’d been filled, Ной [he] could tell that not only were there constituents probably horrible, but they’d been combined rather poorly as well. But, despite that, the hill was probably one of the most hospitable souls that Ной [he] had been to.

Gentle rays of sunlight warmed his back, and a brilliant blue sky rose overhead. Тим [he] stood at the top of the hill, looking around in surprise.

“Is this a Mind Meld potion?” Тим [he] asked. “I’ve never used one before, but it appears that we’ve entered my soul.”

“Yeah,” Ной [he] said. “You drank that without realizing what it was? I thought you were joking.”

“I’m afraid not,” Тим [he] said with a laugh. “I’m much too old to care about what gets put in front of me now. I doubt poison is going to kill me much faster than anything else, and I can’t imagine you’d try to poison me anyway. So, what is it that you wanted to talk about?”

“This,” Ной [he] replied, gesturing vaguely around himself. “But first, I’m going to need a promise from you. Everything that I say and do here needs to stay between us. Nobody can ever find out what happened.”

Тим [he]’s smile faded as he took in the intensity in Ной [he]’s voice. “This sounds serious.”

“Incredibly so,” Ной [he] said. “And it’s dangerous enough to get all of us killed if the wrong person finds out.”

“Do you want a Rune Oath?” Тим [he] asked.

Ной [he] almost refused on the spot but paused to think for a moment. He did trust Тим [he], but as kind as the old man was, the information he was about to share had dire consequences. If anyone stronger than him found out about Разлом [he], infinite lives would do nothing for him. They’d torture him until he gave them the rune or imprison him for its powers.

Except making an oath here really doesn’t even do that much in solving the actual problem. The only thing it helps is if Тим [he] was going to rat me out intentionally, and I don’t think he’s got any plans to ever do something like that. It’s more likely that someone figures out he knows something and tries to get information from him forcefully. A Rune Oath would do nothing there. Either Тим [he] says nothing, or his runes get shattered and he tells them anyway. But therein lies the problem with Rune Oaths. If I made it so strong that it killed Тим [he] if he broke it, he might just get killed and give my information away anyway.

“No,” Ной [he] said. “I don’t want a Rune Oath. They’re flawed tools. I will take a normal promise, though.”

“I can do that. I swear I’ll keep anything you tell me to myself, no matter what happens or who it involves.” Тим [he] paused for a moment, then cleared his throat. “Unless it brings threat to a student. I take my job as a worker at Арбитраж [he] very seriously. If you’ve got issue with any students, it may be best that you do not tell me.”

Ной [he] smiled, even more confident that he’d made the right choice. “I’ve got nothing like that. This is entirely about you, Тим [he].”

“Now I feel like I’ve done something wrong.” Тим [he] laughed. “Just tell me, would you? What is this about?””

“Your runes.”

A flicker of shame passed over Тим [he]’s features as he looked out at the poorly constructed runes circling them. “Ah, yes. They’re not much too look at, are they?”

“No,” Ной [he] admitted honestly. “But that’s why I’m here. I can help you fix them.”

Тим [he] coughed into a fist, hiding a smile. “That’s very kind of you, Вермил [he]. I’ve had the offer before, but I appreciate it every time. Unfortunately, I can’t accept. No matter how much I would be thrilled to repair some of the damage my younger self did to me, it’s impossible. At my age, the soul damage would tear me apart.”

“I can circumvent that,” Ной [he] said. “I have a way to handle the soul damage, and I have Runes as well. Not an infinite supply, but I have a lot of the basic ones. Even though you’ll probably get sent back to Rank 1, I can give you another chance at this.”

Тим [he] lowered his hand, narrowing his eyes in confusion. “I’m sorry? You’ve found a potion that’ll heal soul damage?”

“Err… something like that,” Ной [he] said. “And a way to remove the runes from your soul without being too invasive. It’s safe, so long as you actually want me to do it.”

“This isn’t a joke, is it?” Тим [he] asked.

“Not at all. I’m completely serious. Just say the word. I don’t know if I’ll be able to handle everything at once, but I can do a lot of it.”

“Just like that?” Тим [he] stared at Ной [he], letting his hands drop by his sides. “How?”

“I think we should probably focus more on if you want it or not,” Ной [he] said. “The exact details are… well, I’d prefer to keep them as close to chest as possible. It won’t be relevant to its effectiveness, though. I’d be willing to show you with a single rune if you’d feel safer that way.”

“I – no, I don’t doubt you,” Тим [he] said hurriedly and shaking his head. “I just – well, it’s hard to believe. You’re claiming the impossible, Professor Вермил [he]. Nobody can remove runes without soul damage. If you’ve gotten a potion that lets you do that, is it really wise to waste it on me? It would be worth millions. Maybe more. You could retire for the rest of your life and never worry about another thing.”

“Sounds boring,” Ной [he] said. “If I was going to sell it, I would have. It’s up to you. Don’t feel pressured if you aren’t comfortable with it, but the offer is there.”

Тим [he] swallowed. “Show me.”

“What kind of Rune did you want?” Ной [he] asked. “I may not have it, so I’d have to go get my hands on it.”

“Er… an Earth Rune, perhaps?” Тим [he] asked hesitantly, still sounding like he couldn’t tell if Ной [he] was playing with him or not.

“Ah. That, I can do,” Ной [he] said. This had been a long time coming, and he was eager to get started. “Ah… could you turn around? The less you see, the better.”

Тим [he] turned to face away from Ной [he]. “Is this fine?”

“Perfect. Just stay there for a minute.” He cracked his knuckles. “Let’s get you fixed up, shall we?”

Chapter 388: Busy Man

Ной [he] extended his senses to the grimoire pressed against his hand in the outside world, sending it a mental request for an Earth Rune. He knew he’d gotten a fair number of them from all the monsters he’d killed during vacation with Мокси [she] and Ли [she], but he wanted to make sure the book hadn’t decided to eat any of them before he started cutting anything of Тим [he]’s up.

Fortunately, the book responded, albeit reluctantly. Energy gathered at Ной [he]’s palm and he traced his hand through the air, forming a Rank 2 True Earth Rune in the air before him. It only took a few moments for him to create the relatively simple Rune.

It was roughly half full, and though Ной [he] couldn’t remember the exact amount the rune had been filled when he’d put it into the book, he was pretty sure it was less than what it had now – though not by much.

The book seemed to like taking the energy from the runes and distributing it amongst them. As to why, Ной [he] still hadn’t managed to find out. The artifact was clearly far more than just a storage item.

Perhaps it just liked screwing with his runes, or maybe there was some purpose to what it did. For the moment, all that mattered is that he had the rune that Тим [he] needed. Ной [he] turned his attention to Тим [he]’s existing runes.

Тим [he] already had an earth-based rune that he’d pulled closer for Ной [he] to work on while he’d been drawing the True Earth Rune. The mere sight of Тим [he]’s rune made Ной [he] grimace. There was no word to describe it but horrendous.

Shattered Craggy Earth – Rank 2

Part of Ной [he] was surprised that the rune was even holding itself together. He wasn’t sure he’d seen such a poorly crafted rune before. Not all of Тим [he]’s runes were this awful, though most weren’t much better, but this one seemed like a great spot to start the repairs to Тим [he]’s soul.

After one more glance to make sure that Тим [he] wasn’t watching, Ной [he] called on Разлом [he]. He didn’t want to wait around with an extra Rune in Тим [he]’s soul for long. With how weak his runes were, there was a good chance his soul wouldn’t be able to safely contain an extra high-quality Rank 2 Rune without a lot of undue stress.

Ной [he] carved his hand downward, and a streak of black light carved down the center of Тим [he]’s pathetic rune. It shattered instantly, a tiny sputter of wispy energy rising up from its remains. Seven Rank 1 Runes flew out from it its sputtering remains.

The ground beneath Ной [he]’s feet bucked and he stumbled as a thick white crack split through the grass just a short distance from him, pouring glowing light into Тим [he]’s soul. Behind him, Тим [he] let out a wheeze of pain and stumbled, falling to his knees.

Holy shit. His soul is so weak that even Разлом [he]’s much more surgical removal still managed to damage it?

Ной [he] hurriedly released Разлом [he] and summoned the Fragment of Возрождение [she]. The crack in the ground was massive – far larger than anything Ной [he] felt was remotely safe to let stick around.

Gentle pink smoke poured out of his palms, infusing itself into the crack. The damage started to knit itself immediately. To Ной [he]’s relief, the weakness of Тим [he]’s soul worked to his advantage instead of his detriment.

Because of how little soul there was to heal, the Fragment of Возрождение [she] worked at a remarkable speed. It knitted around the damage, pulling the grassy field back together and sealing over the white light in just a few seconds.

Now that the damage was averted, Ной [he] turned to the seven Rank 1 Runes that had come out of the one he’d just destroyed. They were still part of Тим [he]’s soul, but they were going to cause trouble if he left them floating around – Тим [he] didn’t have a large enough soul to store too many extra runes.

Also, it might be wise to avoid letting him know exactly how I took his rune out. If he sees seven Rank 1s, he might be able to realize that I’m not just changing runes, but I’m splitting them apart.

Ной [he] extended his senses to the seven rank 1 runes. They shuddered at his mental touch. Their connection to him felt weak and feeble. Ной [he] paused, a thought striking his head. The remains of the Fragment of Возрождение [she]’s energy were still twisting within Тим [he]’s mind, leaving him room to do a little extra work.

Cutting the original rune with Разлом [he] must destabilize them. I think I can just…

Ной [he] summoned the runes to him, then pressed his hand to the first one. He felt the grimoire warm against his touch in the real world. There was a soft pop, and the rune disappeared. The grimoire had eaten it through Ной [he].

Тим [he] didn’t seem to be too pained by the theft, so Ной [he] did the same to the rest of the Rank 1s. The grimoire sent Ной [he] a warm, satisfied feeling of approval. Something told him that none of the Rank 1 runes had survived the trip out of Тим [he]’s mind.


Whatever. I need to feed it anyway, and those weren’t particularly important.

Several small cracks formed in the grass from the removal of the already-destabilized runes, but the remaining energy from the Fragment of Возрождение [she] handled them before they could go anywhere.

“Тим [he],” Ной [he] called. “You can turn around.”

Тим [he] spun, his eyes going wide as he saw the Rank 2 Rune floating before Ной [he]. His eyes darted around his mindspace, searching for any traces of his original rune, but they were gone.

“I – how?” Тим [he] stammered.

“Worry about drawing this first,” Ной [he] suggested, sending the Rank 2 Rune toward Тим [he]. He tried to keep the smug grin from his face, but he wasn’t so sure he’d succeeded. The expression of delighted disbelief on Тим [he]’s face was difficult to ignore.

Тим [he] hurried to comply. He placed a hand on the Rune, then started tracing it with his other. It took him a lot longer than it would have taken Ной [he], but Ной [he] had more experience drawing Runes than most people.

Тим [he] managed to get the Rank 2 Rune secured in his soul after about two minutes of work. His hand dropped in relief, his eyes sparkling as the new rune drifted back through the air, joining the rotation of the other six.

“I can’t believe it,” Тим [he] muttered, swallowing heavily as he turned to watch the rune’s slow flight through the air. “I never thought…” He trailed off, not even able to finish his sentence. Shaking his head, Тим [he] looked back to Ной [he]. “Thank you. I don’t know why you did this, but I never thought I’d have such a nice rune. I’ll cherish it. With this, I may actually have a chance of pushing to Rank 3.”

“What, with the rest of what you’ve got here?” Ной [he]’s eyes widened as he gestured to the other runes around them. “We still need to get you six more, Тим [he]. One good one isn’t going to do you any good. Even if you managed to cobble this into a Rank 3, it would be terrible.”

“You can fix my other runes?” Тим [he] asked, his mouth hanging agape. “All of them?”

“Well, yes. Why would I just fix one and leave it at that?”

“I just didn’t think…”

“Don’t think,” Ной [he] suggested with a grin. “The less you think about what I’m doing here, the better it will be for the both of us. The best way you can thank me is to completely forget that I’m the one that helped you at all. Just think of this as the universe paying you back for your kindness.”

Тим [he] chewed his lower lip, clearly uncomfortable with all the help Ной [he] was giving him. It wasn’t like he could refuse – Ной [he] wasn’t just offering him power. The stronger runes would expand his lifespan and open up countless opportunities. New runes were quite literally a new lease on life.

Finally, Тим [he] nodded. “I don’t know if I can forget it completely, but I can assure you that not a word of anything that happened here will ever so much as grace my thoughts. It will be banished to the deepest recesses of my memory and I will die twice before I speak of it.”

“Or live once,” Ной [he] offered. “I’m not doing all this shit so you can get yourself killed.”

Тим [he] let out a laugh. “I think I can do that, Professor Вермил [he]. Are you…”

“Going to do the rest now?” Ной [he] finished. “No. I’d like to, but your soul is really fragile. It wouldn’t be able to handle more modifications today. We’ll have to come back to it tomorrow, or on whatever day you’ve got some time.”

“I’d make time in the middle of the night if that was what it took,” Тим [he] said with a bark of laughter. “Whenever you can slot me in will be perfect. It’s not like I have a very busy schedule. It’s just me and the transport cannon.”

“Tomorrow, then,” Ной [he] said. He’d have to get another Mind Meld Potion, as he was keeping the extra one he’d bought for Ли [she] in case her Rune became too problematic and he had to Разлом [he] it for her safety. “We’ve got a little more time before the potion wears off, so you might as well get used to your new Rune.”

Тим [he] didn’t need to be told twice. Energy curled around his hands as he called on the True Earth Rune, and Ной [he] couldn’t help but smile as he watched the old man play with the magic like a child that had just gotten a new toy.

It’s strange how much a Rank 2 Rune has changed for me. There would have been a time when getting one would have been an enormous change. Now, I can harvest them at will with almost no effort.

I hope Тим [he]’s future combinations are much better once I get him all fixed up. It would be a shame if he ends up having a bad Rank 3 combination. I’ll talk to him a bit about combination theory after I replace all his runes so he can avoid that.

If Ной [he] was honest with himself, Тим [he]’s situation sat poorly with him. The man was clearly hard working – he basically never left the transport cannon and always kept it running. An attitude like that should have served him well in school.

He was failed. His teachers should have ensured that he had the tools to succeed, but they didn’t because he wasn’t a noble. And, because he wasn’t a noble, he wasn’t able to get good runes either. Compound that with no guidance on combinations and it’s no wonder he got stuck at Rank 2.

How many other people are like this? It’s such an enormous waste. The noble houses are literally crippling everyone by suppressing information and runes just for the sake of keeping their power.

Ной [he] wasn’t sure if there was anything he could do about it. Squaring up against every noble house sounded like a great way to get his students killed. And, if Ной [he] was honest with himself, he didn’t properly care about anyone other than the people close to him.

I’m not putting any of their lives at risk for someone I don’t know. It’s just not worth it. But, one day, it would be nice to find a way to help everyone that deserves it. Just… not at the cost of anyone’s safety.

Ной [he] sat as Тим [he] tested his new Rune, waiting out the rest of the Mind Meld potion’s time until he felt a buzz building in the back of his head.

“That’s time,” Ной [he] said, rising to his feet. “As more of your runes get repaired, we should be able to fix them faster. I’d say this should only take two or three more sessions.”

“Thank you,” Тим [he] said. “I’ll make time whenever you’re ready, but don’t feel pressured. I’m sure you’re a busy man.”

Ной [he] nodded, and the buzzing intensified. His soul slipped out of Тим [he]’s and into a sea of darkness as it shot back toward its proper body.

Chapter 389: Traumatize

Like Ной [he] had requested, Тим [he] didn’t mention a word of what had happened the moment they both awoke in the outside world. Ной [he] rose to his feet and helped Тим [he] up. The old man stared at his hand for a second, then finally nodded to Ной [he].

That was all he had to say. Ной [he] returned the nod and stepped onto the lift. The floor bucked beneath him and the chain rattled as the platform lowered. Light flickered in the room above him as Тим [he] reactivated the transport cannon.

Even after everything that happened, it didn’t look like Тим [he] had any plans of taking a break. Ной [he] suppressed a laugh. The lift reached the top of the stairwell and he stepped out, heading for the T building.

It felt like a large weight had been lifted from his shoulders. He’d been telling himself that he’d fix Тим [he]’s runes for nearly as long as he’d been at Арбитраж [he]. It wasn’t like he couldn’t have done it before, but the risk had just been too significant.

The wait had likely helped Тим [he] in the long run. Only recently had Ной [he] gotten enough runes in his grimoire to really be able to hand them out. Before, he’d have had to seek out the runes Тим [he] wanted after confirming that Тим [he] wanted help.

That’s not to say I’ve got an infinite number of runes. I still need to get more. A lot more. And not just for other people. I’ve been at Rank 4 for a little bit now. I’m starting to get pretty used to Natural Disaster.

It should be just about time to figure out what I should get for my next Rank 4 Rune. Something that synergizes with it – that’s a no brainer. The problem is what. I still feel like working some space magic into whatever I’m doing would be clever. Being able to teleport is insanely useful. Брейден [he] showed me that much.

Ной [he] arrived at the entrance of the T building and paused at the steps. A frown crossed his lips and he tilted his head to the side.

Huh. Speaking of Брейден [he], I wonder where he is. Didn’t Ли [she] say that he would be out last night? I guess he had other things to do than come straight to us. It would have been odd if he showed up in the middle of the night.

Ной [he] headed inside. He hadn’t spoken to Брейден [he] in person since he’d revealed that he wasn’t actually his brother. The fact that Брейден [he] hadn’t cut them off forever had been a huge surprise. He hadn’t thought there was all that much he cared about in this world. That hadn’t been true.

Брейден [he] had proven to be a true friend and losing him would have hurt. But now that he was somewhere in the area, Ной [he] wasn’t sure what to feel. They couldn’t just pick things up the way they were.

I suppose I could try to tell him the rest of the story. I think I can trust him enough for that. This is probably going to be awkward either way. Oh well. Nothing I can do about it but deal with things when the time comes.

Мокси [she] was alone in the room when Ной [he] got back. She was hunched over her desk with a book open in one hand and a quill in the other. It scratched furiously against the paper as she copied something down. Ной [he] closed the door behind him with a soft click to avoid distracting her.

He craned his neck back to check the ceiling for Ли [she]. The rafters were, however, devoid of demon. The open window was a strong indication that she’d yet to return from her nightly adventures.

Ной [he] walked up behind Мокси [she] and waited until the quill stopped leaning in to wrap his arms around her. She pressed her head against his.

“How’d things go with Тим [he]?” Мокси [she] asked as she set the quill down in its holder.

“Really well. His soul is completely screwed,” Ной [he] said. “I was only able to modify one rune before I had to use the Fragment of Возрождение [she] to keep him from splitting apart. That was the worst soul damage I’ve seen from such a little change – not counting Ли [she], that is.”

“I suppose it makes sense if his runes are really that bad,” Мокси [she] said. “The soul expands if there’s a lot of pressure within it. If there isn’t, then it’s only logical that it shrinks. He’s pretty old and his runes are awful. That’s not conducive to having a very healthy soul.”

“Yeah. Either way, I think it should start going smoother soon. I gave him a True Earth Rune. Next time, we’ll have to figure out exactly what it is he’d like to do in the future. I might have to get specific runes if I don’t have what he needs.”

“By hunting?”

“Maybe. Maybe a class trip,” Ной [he] said. “I need to get more runes either way. I bet the students would all like to start getting more of their own as well.”


“That’s a good idea. They’ve been fighting each other a lot recently. It would be nice to see how far they’ve grown with some hunting. Maybe we can work it in between продвинутая группа meetings – whenever those normally are.”

“I figure Улия [she] or someone else will roll up soon enough to tell us,” Ной [he] said. “It feels like they’ll probably meet in the evenings or have announced events. I’m sure we’ll get more than enough warning. Nobody is just sitting around and waiting for them to show up.”

“Yeah. I’m more expecting a letter, but I digress.” Мокси [she] picked up the paper she’d been working on touched the ink to make sure it was dry. She tucked the paper into the pages of the book and closed it.

Ной [he] let go of Мокси [she] and stepped back as she rose to her feet. “I saw Тодд [he] and Александра [she] sparring early this morning when I was heading back after doing some training with Изабель [she] and Эмили [she].”

“Oh?” Ной [he] asked. “I take it something was out of the ordinary?”

“Well, I don’t know if I’d say it was out of the ordinary. They’re both quite talented. But Александра [she] was fighting without her sword and it looked like Тодд [he] was holding his own. It was pretty clear Александра [she] was keeping her power limited to his level since she’s a whole Rank up on him, but still.”

“Huh,” Ной [he] said. “Was it just hand to hand combat?”

“No. I think they were trying to use patterns,” Мокси [she] said. “Александра [she] definitely was. Тодд [he] was using his bracers. But, considering his pattern has to do with imbuing, I suspect that he was doing the same.”

“And?” Ной [he] asked. “How’d it seem like they were doing?”

“You’ll have to see for yourself, but I think it might be time to move them to the next stage of what you’re teaching.” Мокси [she] shook her head and smiled. “Александра [she] definitely has it down. I felt like I was watching a butterfly fight. And, considering Тодд [he] wasn’t completely getting crushed, I think he’s brought himself close to her level.”

“Speaking of patterns, how’s yours doing?” Ной [he] asked. “I haven’t had time to see how you’ve been progressing there recently. Have you been having any luck?”

“A lot,” Мокси [she] said. “I had to adjust my angle a little bit to understand it better. I think some of my sparring sessions with Изабель [she] actually helped.”

“Изабель [she]? Really?” Ной [he] raised an eyebrow. “How so?”

“Her pattern is basically mounting pressure. I know it’s meant to be a landslide or the like, but it feels like she’s steadily growing more and more aggressive as fights lengthen. It gave me a lot of insight into the plants I was trying to focus on. Instead of just plants, I’ve been focusing on their growth. That seems to have gone a really long way.”

Ной [he] considered her words for a moment. Growth seemed like a pretty solid pattern to focus on. It was definitely versatile. There were a lot of different ways he could see it being applied both in and out of a fight, and it meshed very well with her current Runes.

“That seems to suit you really well,” Ной [he] said. “And what of Ли [she]? Do you happen to know if she’s been making progress?”

“If you count eating things as progress, then yes.”

Ной [he] snorted. “I’m assuming she’s probably out terrorizing the local wildlife right now. If that includes eating it, then I assume it would technically count. You know, in some ways, Ли [she] reminds me of Джеймс [he].”

Мокси [she] squinted at Ной [he]. “How? I don’t think I can think of a single similarity between them.”

“Their patterns. Джеймс [he]’ pattern is literally doing nothing. Ли [she]’s is stuffing her face. They’re both ridiculously outlandish and really feel like they shouldn’t work. And they do. Джеймс [he] has already demonstrated he’s actually quite good at embodying his pattern. Ли [she]… well, I have full faith in her. I don’t think she’s ever failed to do anything she set out to.”

“Okay, I see it now,” Мокси [she] admitted. “To be honest, I think everyone in the class has really gotten a good handle over their abilities in recent days. And, especially after the fight in the Windscorned Plateau, I think everyone is eager to get stronger. Do you think the students are ready to move on to the next step?”

“They very well might be. What about Эмили [she]? I remember she was having some trouble.”

“That was the next thing I was going to mention,” Мокси [she] said with a wince. A note of disappointment intertwined with her words as she continued. “She is. She’s made great progress, don’t get me wrong, but she’s really fighting to catch up with the others. I wanted to ask if you could privately tutor her sometime today so she doesn’t fall too far behind. I’d do it myself, but… well, I don’t really understand enough to.”

“Are you sure Эмили [she] would want that?” Ной [he] asked. “We’re at a point where I think we both understand each other, but I still don’t think Эмили [she] likes me much.”

Мокси [she] snorted. “Эмили [she] doesn’t like anyone. Not externally, at least. She’s scared to show any feeling because of how the Торрин [he]s are. Connections are weakness when you aren’t strong enough to defend them. Trust me, she thinks rather well of you. If she didn’t, she’d be telling me how much she hated you every single time we met.”

“Noted,” Ной [he] said with a laugh. “In that case, I can try to find her today and see what I can do. Maybe you can handle the normal class while I do that?”

“That would work,” Мокси [she] said with a smile. “And, speaking of which, we should probably head out to meet the kids. We’re probably late.”

Ной [he] looked out the window and cursed. “Oh, shit. I forgot. I hope they don’t think class is canceled.”

Мокси [she] grabbed the book with the paper that she’d been working on and stuck it under her arm. “Yeah. I know. Let’s go. If I had to guess, Ли [she] is probably distracting them right about now.”

That was a sobering thought. Ли [she]’s distractions a tossup between mandatory stretching sessions or handing everyone half-eaten squirrels to snack on. They hurried out of the room and set off for the transport cannon to meet the kids before Ли [she] could use the lack of supervision to traumatize anyone too badly.

Chapter 390: Enlightening

Ли [she] was indeed with the students. It seemed that she’d decided to attempt to further their practice of patterns through a demonstration of her own. That had spared them all of a session of stretching, though Ной [he] suspected that the assortment of objects, both living and non, that Ли [she] had shoved into her mouth were having considerably less fun.

He and Мокси [she] arrived just as Ли [she] swallowed and somehow managed to make something around two or three pounds of food vanish down her gullet and disappear as if it had never been there. Тодд [he] gave her a hearty round of applause that drew looks from everyone else.

“What?” Тодд [he] asked as he lowered his hands and glanced around at the attention he was getting. “I’d rather she eat other things than decide to see what something more intelligent tastes like.”

That might be one of the smartest things you’ve ever said.

“Good to see everyone’s having fun,” Ной [he] said. Everyone had been so focused on Ли [she] that they hadn’t even noticed him or Мокси [she]. They turned toward him in varying states of surprise and Ли [she] turned her gaze from a plump bird on the top of a nearby building. If the bird had any sort of guardian angel, Ной [he] suspected that it had been the one hastening his steps.

“Fun’s certainly a word for it,” Эмили [she] said as she covered a laugh and turned to make sure Тодд [he] couldn’t see the flicker of a grin passing across her lips. “Do you think I could learn that pattern? If I could eat that much and not puff up like a ball of dough, I think I’d swap on the spot.”

“Yeah!” Ли [she] said with a wide grin and a nod. “You definitely could. I’ll teach you.”

“I’m not so sure that particular pattern is going to work for anyone other than you,” Ной [he] said with a laugh. As usual, Ли [she] had covered for his ass. Nobody had so much as noticed that he was late.

Honestly, Ли [she] is the absolute master of completely distracting people to the point where they don’t even realize they’re being distracted.

“No, you can definitely do it,” Ли [she] told Эмили [she] with such confidence that Ной [he] almost believed she knew what she was talking about. “You just have to build up to it. It’s like training your muscles. All you have to do is eat until you can’t eat anymore and then have some more after that.”

“That is not how you train your muscles,” Ной [he] said, though Ли [she]’s words did give him quite an insight into why her stretching sessions were the way that they were. “But I digress. We’ve got some work to get to and, according to what Мокси [she] has told me, you’re all just about ready to move to the next step.”

Ной [he] didn’t say what the next step was – he didn’t know who was in the area, but speaking in terms that a normal teacher would use was going to make it pretty hard for anyone other than his students to figure out exactly what it was that he meant.

Everyone’s eyes – other than Эмили [she]’s, whose eyes flicked to the side and broke contact with Ной [he]’s as her face creased with a flash of concern – lit up. It looked like Мокси [she]’s warning had been right. Эмили [she] didn’t feel like she’d progressed her pattern enough to take it any further.

No point making her suffer.

“But, before we get around to that, we’ve got some slightly more mundane things that we’ll be working on,” Ной [he] said, starting toward the transport cannon. Everyone fell in line behind him and he continued to speak. “Мокси [she] and Ли [she] are going to lead some sparring and combat practice.”

A round of grimaces passed over the students’ faces – particularly those of Александра [she], Джеймс [he], and Тодд [he]. That was another one of Мокси [she]’s theories proven correct. They were the farthest along in formations and likely wanted more.

Well, Джеймс [he] was probably disappointed because he was going to have to do actual work, but that was just Джеймс [he].

“Whoever shows the most improvement from the last time is going to get points in our competition,” Мокси [she] added, and all of a sudden, there wasn’t a single person who looked even vaguely reluctant.

After a short walk up the transport cannon’s stairs and a ride up its elevator, the group reached the top. Тим [he]’s face creased in a smile and he raised a hand in greeting.

“Professor Вермил [he], Мокси [she]. Good to see you and your students again. Have anything fun planned today?”

“Just some boring practice, that’s all,” Ной [he] said with a shrug. Тим [he] wasn’t acting even slightly differently than he normally did. That was what Ной [he] had asked him to do. If anything, Ной [he] was somewhat surprised to find that Тим [he] was this good of a liar.

I guess he probably overhears a lot of stuff while working the transport cannon. It might take a degree of discretion to keep a job where you interact with so many different people.


“Of course, of course,” Тим [he] said. “Well, where can I send you? Just give me the word.”

“Windscorned Plateaus, please,” Мокси [she] said. Ной [he] sent a quick glance over his shoulder at the students. The plateaus were definitely a good training area, but after what had happened just a few days ago, he wasn’t so sure either Эмили [she] or Александра [she] would be keen on returning.

“It’s fine,” Александра [she] said, catching Ной [he]’s look. “We’re students, not children, Professor Вермил [he]. We can handle going back to train in an area where something dangerous happened. It’s not like anyone died.”

The others nodded. It was pretty clear that Александра [she] and Эмили [she] had let them know what had happened. Ной [he] suppressed a smile and turned back to give the older man a nod. Тим [he] set about adjusting the direction of the transport cannon.

The more the kids share with each other, the better. They’re in this together. It’s a relief to see that Александра [she] is meshing better with them than I initially thought she would. The divide between her power and theirs is pretty significant, but I think their worries and goals are close enough that it doesn’t matter.

The transport cannon shuddered as the tube adjusted its angle and set in place. Тим [he] raised his hands from the control panel and gave them an encouraging nod. “Go on, then. We’re all set.”

“Thanks, Тим [he].” Мокси [she] headed over to the cannon and laid down on it. A moment later, she was gone. Ли [she] followed after her and the rest of the students trailed. Ной [he] was the last to lie down on the cannon’s cold metal surface.

“Have a good trip, Professor Вермил [he],” Тим [he] said, raising a hand in farewell. Ной [he] only had time to utter a single syllable of thanks before the cannon activated and he was gone in a streak of blue light.

He slammed down in the Windscorned Plateau just a few moments of mind-numbing travel later. The others had all already gathered themselves and were waiting patiently in a semicircle before him.

Ной [he] adjusted his jacket. Despite his words just a few moments earlier, he glanced around the area to make sure there wasn’t anyone lying in wait for them. As far as he could tell, the plateaus were as plain and desolate as they normally were.

“Let’s go ahead and get started, then,” Ной [he] said. “Ли [she], if you do any stretching, make sure to leave everyone with enough mobility to spar without falling on top of each other like two piles of wet noodles.”

“That’s the point of stretching, though.”

“Well, maybe a little stretching,” Ной [he] said, much to the horror of everyone else. A grin pulled at the corners of his lips and he held himself back from laughing. It wasn’t like he was going to be the one stretching. Ли [she] would make a great distraction so that nobody was too focused on what he was –

“I’ll make sure you catch up and get an extra stretching session later, since you’ll be missing this one,” Ли [she] said.

Ной [he]’s smile fell away. “Ah, right. Lovely.”

It was everyone else’s turn to grin. Ной [he] just sighed and shook his head. “Эмили [she], you’re up first. Let’s go see what you can do.”

A look of panic flashed across her face and she sent a discreet glance at Мокси [she], who gave her a small nod of reassurance. It didn’t seem to do much. Эмили [she] swallowed and stepped away from the others. She walked over to join Ной [he] and stood as stiff as a board by his side.

Ной [he] drew his flying sword from its spot at his waist and tossed it to the ground. He got onto it first and Эмили [she], after a second of delay, stepped on behind him. She put her hands on his shoulders to keep her balance.

“Good luck. Call out if you need me for whatever reason,” Ной [he] said. He nodded up to the plateau above them. “We won’t be far. Just at the top of that.”

“Sounds good,” Мокси [she] replied. She glanced at Ли [she]. The demon was practically vibrating with excitement at her side. Heaving a sigh, Мокси [she] sat down. “Everyone else, find somewhere to sit. I’m going to give Ли [she] a little while to get the stretching out of her system before she pops. I don’t want to hear any complaints. Just be glad I’m having her do this first so we have an excuse to stop when we need to get to the rest of class.”

Ной [he] activated the flying sword while the students moved to follow Мокси [she]’s directions. Wind hummed through the air around his feet and it lifted into the air. He waited for a moment to make sure that Эмили [she] had a good hold of him before taking the sword up and over to the plateau above.

He landed gently on the grass. A flicker of memory passed through his head at the thought of his old flying sword. As chaotic as it had been, landing it anywhere successfully had made him feel pretty accomplished.

“Magus Вермил [he], I–” Эмили [she] started.

“Magus Вермил [he]?” Ной [he] asked, aghast. “Why the hell are you being so formal? I’d get professor, and I’m certainly not asking you to call me Teacherman, but

Magus?

Relax, Эмили [she]. Мокси [she] talked to me. I’m not here to make you do something you aren’t comfortable with.”

The tension flooded out of Эмили [she]’s shoulders and escaped her lips in a relieved sigh. “Oh.”

“I’m here to help, you know,” Ной [he] said. “I want all of you to succeed. If you’re struggling with something, you can find me after class or something. It’s not like you don’t know where to look.”

Эмили [she] shifted from foot to foot. Her gaze moved to land anywhere other than where she could see Ной [he]. “I know. I just… I don’t know. I want to do it myself.”

“There’s nothing wrong with that, but you can’t brute force everything.” Ной [he] paused for a second and scrunched his nose. The moment the words came out of his lips was the moment that he was reminded that he had quite literally brute forced everything he knew. “Actually, scratch that. I suppose you can brute force everything. It’ll take way longer than asking for help, though. Why ignore resources when you have access to them?”

“I – yeah. I guess you’re right,” Эмили [she] admitted reluctantly. “I just don’t like it.”

“That’s fine. For now, it doesn’t matter. Just show me where you are and what you’re having trouble with.”

Эмили [she] nodded. “Okay.”
