“Not personally, but I was Эвергрин [she]’s aide. It’s possible he was going to try to use me to get access to something. I just don’t know what – and I don’t know why Арбитраж [he] would have anything to do with the Торрин [he]s. We don’t have anything that rare here as far as I can tell – but that’s what I’m checking for.”

“Smart,” Ной [he] said. He thought for a few seconds to see if there was anything that would come to mind with regard to Визен [he]’s motivations, but he came up blank. Nothing in his fight with Сильвертид [he] had revealed his motivations. “Any thoughts, Ли [she]?”

“Not really,” Ли [she] said with a shake of her head. “But don’t a bunch of noble families all have things they donate to the neutral grounds to keep them neutral or whatever? Like the Линвик [they]s gave the Hellreaver.”

“Yeah,” Мокси [she] said. “I was thinking the same thing.”

“No record of what the Торрин [he]s gave?” Ной [he] guessed.

“Yep. Guessed it in one shot.” Мокси [she] sighed. “Hence the research I’ve been doing. They had to have given something to the school. It would have had to be pretty important as well. I just don’t know what it would be.”

“I can try to help you look later,” Ной [he] offered.

Мокси [she] sent him a surprised look. “Seriously?”

“What? You don’t have to look so surprised. I know how to read.”

“Yeah, I’ve just barely ever seen you voluntarily choose to go to the library when there was literally any alternative available,” Мокси [she] said with a laugh. “I won’t turn down help, though.”

“I can come too.” Ли [she] offered. She paused for a second, then frowned. “Wait. Can you eat in a library? I think I saw a sign on the door saying I couldn’t.”

“No,” Ной [he] said. “They don’t want you getting the books dirty.”

“Oh, that’s fine. I won’t. I’m very clean when I eat.”

A thought struck Ной [he] and his eyes narrowed. “You can’t eat the books either.”

“What?” Ли [she] exclaimed, her eyes going wide. “That’s stupid. They’re all just sitting around on shelves like pastries.”

“What part of a book even vaguely resembles a pastry?” Мокси [she] asked through a laugh. “I don’t think they could possibly be more different.”

“They’re flaky.”

“Ли [she] probably has more experience than you do with eating books,” Ной [he] said. “I’m inclined to believe her.”

“Thank you,” Ли [she] said.

“That doesn’t mean you can eat the books, though.”

“Aw. Are you sure?”

“I’ll find some other books for you to eat later. Just settle for actual pastries or something in the meantime.”

“Oh, yeah. That’s a good idea.” Ли [she] grinned and nodded; the topic completely forgotten. Ной [he] snuck a glance back at the book under Мокси [she]’s arm. A small frown crossed his lips. If there was an artifact sitting around Арбитраж [he] that was strong enough for Визен [he] to put this much effort into getting… it didn’t take a genius to tell that it was bad news.

But what does it have to do with any of what he’s done so far? Why all the clones and extra shit? Stealing something feels more like an espionage angle, not this.

What is Визен [he] playing at?
==========
Chapter 398: Last Warning

Once class ended and they had all returned to Арбитраж [he], Ли [she] joined the students in returning to their lodgings, having gotten stuck in an intense conversation with Тодд [he] over what breakfast foods were the best.

Ной [he] was pretty sure Тодд [he] was fighting a losing battle, as Ли [she] was insisting that pancakes were crunchy. He’d probably figure out that she was including the texture profiles of the plates and utensils as part of her meal at some point, but until then, it was hard to argue with something that you couldn’t even properly comprehend.

Interesting strategy, actually. If you can’t surprise them with your brilliance, baffle them with your bullshit.

“Is there a reason we’re standing around at the base of the transport cannon instead of heading back?” Мокси [she] asked, breaking Ной [he]’s thoughts.

“Huh? Oh, not really. I was just thinking about Ли [she]’s argument strategies.”

Мокси [she] followed his gaze and snickered. “She’s certainly unique. Тодд [he] has no chance.”

“Absolutely none,” Ной [he] agreed. He looked over his shoulder at the transport cannon above him. A small line had formed to use it. Other professors, from the looks of it, taking their students to practice.

“It’s not all that long before the first of the exams. They’re getting ready,” Мокси [she] said.

“The Retrieval Exam, right?” Ной [he] asked. “I take it they’re not going to tell us what monster the kids have to hunt down?”

“Probably not. I wouldn’t be surprised if the Продвинутая Группа makes sure they get assigned a more difficult monster,” Мокси [she] said. “Speaking of, I do wonder when they’ll actually get around to doing anything. Has Улия [she] shown up to tell us when the next meeting is and I just missed it?”

“Not as far as I’m aware. We can ask Контесса [he] and Карина [she] if she came by my old room,” Ной [he] said. “I’ve got to help Тим [he] out as well. He’s still got a few Runes to get around fixing.”

“Did you want to do that now?” Мокси [she] asked. “There’s a bit of a line.”

“Yeah. I’ll probably wait around until it dwindles away and then head up after he’s not swamped by people. I’ve got a Mind Meld potion on me.” Ной [he] patted his bag, then looked over his shoulder again. “This is unrelated, but have you seen Брейден [he] since he showed up to help you out?”

Мокси [she] tilted her head to the side, brow furrowing in thought. She shook her head after her second. “No, I don’t believe I have. I thought he’d seek you out. Has he not?”

“Nope. Haven’t seen him at all,” Ной [he] said. “You don’t think he’s avoiding me, do you?”

“That doesn’t really sound like him, but I can’t say anything for certain.” Мокси [she] gave him a shrug. “He could also be busy. Father did send him here to help stop Визен [he]. Maybe he’s researching.”

Мокси [she] didn’t seem too certain of her words. It definitely didn’t feel like Брейден [he] was the kind of man to skirt around addressing his problems, so Ной [he] was inclined to believe her – but he wasn’t sure if that was just his mind tricking him into optimism.

“Well, I’m sure I’ll find him soon enough,” Ной [he] said. “Were you going to head back and keep reading on the artifacts and stuff?”

“Yeah. The most dangerous part of Визен [he] is that we don’t know what he wants or what motivates him. Nobody knows what his next move is. Once we figure that out, we can deal with him.”

“Agreed. Let me know if there’s anything I can do to help.”

Мокси [she] laughed bumped her shoulder into his. “Sure. I’ll be sure to send you into the library to leaf through books for the rest of the day.”

“Hey. I can read, you know. Just because there was a time when I was more focused on flinging myself from problem to problem without stopping to think about what I was actually doing doesn’t mean that’s my only state.”

“So you do want to hunt through the books in the library for all the records of all the artifacts that the Торрин [he]s have had?”

Ной [he] gagged. “Absolutely not. I’d do it if you really needed me to, though.”

“I’ll spare you that fate, I think. I’ve got enough books to sort through already. I think it’s more a question of figuring out which one Визен [he] would actually want.” Мокси [she] flashed him a grin as he let out a relieved sigh.

“Thank God. Well, don’t work too hard. Don’t forget we’re meeting Сильвертид [he] sometime tonight to talk to the Исполнители – and try to leave some space sometime tomorrow morning?”

“I remember the Исполнители, but what’s happening tomorrow morning?” Мокси [she] asked, her nose scrunching in thought. “I don’t remember having anything planned for then.”


“Oh, we don’t. I was thinking we might get breakfast.”

Мокси [she] squinted. “We get breakfast basically every single day.”

“Just the two of us.” Ной [he] rubbed the back of his neck. “You know. A date. I know we’ve been together for a little, but we haven’t had all that much time to just do… normal things, I guess.”

Мокси [she] blinked and her cheeks reddened. “I – oh. Yeah, I’ll make time. I can make time for that.”

“Thanks,” Ной [he] said with a grin. “I’ll catch up with you tonight. Come find me if anything interesting happens, though. After Тим [he], I’m probably just going to go practice some Formations in the garden. The kids are catching up to me, you know.”

“Somehow, I’m not so sure about that. And I want to book a personal session for some pattern work as well. Think you can make time for that after breakfast?”

“I suppose something can be arranged, but we’ll have to see. I’ve got a busy schedule, you know.”

Мокси [she] rolled her eyes and leaned in to give him a kiss on the cheek. “I’ll see you tonight, idiot.”

She strode off, and Ной [he]’s gaze followed her until she turned at a corner of the road and disappeared from sight. He shook his head, realizing a smile was still on his lips, and turned back to the transport cannon to wait for the line to die down a little.

***

The flow of professors slowed after an hour and a half. Ной [he] knew – he spent the time counting the seconds, drumming his fingers on the grimoire he’d pulled off his back and leaned against his side.

He waited a second to see if anyone else would suddenly pop up, but when it became clear that everyone who’d been waiting for the transport cannon had finally gotten to use it, he headed up the stairs to the lift himself.

It rattled up, and Ной [he] arrived in the room at the top of the cannon a few seconds later. To his surprise, it was empty. He glanced around, just to see if Тим [he] was hiding somewhere, but the he was nowhere to be found.

Ной [he] walked up to the older man’s desk, spotting a small metal placard sitting on top of it. The placard was facing the wrong way, so he couldn’t see what was written on it. He picked it up and turned it around.

Temporarily out for maintenance.

“Maintenance?” Ной [he] muttered to himself, setting the placard back down with a frown. He looked around the room. This wasn’t the first time Тим [he] had randomly gone missing. It wasn’t like something obligated him to be in the transport cannon literally every second of his life – but he definitely didn’t seem to like leaving it.

I didn’t see Тим [he] actually head out either. That means he’s still in the transport cannon. The door would have to be somewhere up here, since I had view of the elevator and there were people heading up it just a few minutes ago.

It might have been a bit of a breach of privacy, but Ной [he] had never prided himself on being particularly respectable. He walked around the room, kneeling by the corners and running his hands along the floor to see if he could find a trapdoor or some other way to get around the cannon other than the lift in its center.

He made his way around the entirety of the cannon’s top floor – it wasn’t like there was all that much ground to cover – and arrived back at Тим [he]’s desk. There was nothing. It was like Тим [he] had just vanished into thin air.

A thought struck Ной [he]. He paused, then leaned forward to peer over the desk at the only spot in the room he hadn’t touched yet. Ной [he] took care to avoid accidentally touching any of the Наполнения [he] or levers on it. He had absolutely no idea what screwing with the transport cannon would do, and he had no desire to find out.

Oh, you’ve got to be kidding me.

Resting on the ground was a large, cashmere rug. It was covered with colorful swirling designs that looked like they were meant to symbolize runes without actually drawing any of them.

“A rug?” Ной [he] asked aloud. “Is there really not a better spot to hide something?”

Then again, it did take me like ten minutes of looking literally everywhere else. Maybe a rug is more than enough.

He hopped over the table and reached down, pulling the corner of the rug back to reveal a trapdoor. Ной [he] repressed the urge to let out a heavy sigh.

Well, I found it. Now what?

A few seconds passed. It was one thing to snoop, but it was another to literally follow Тим [he] down into – well, whatever he was doing. It wasn’t exactly polite. Then again, if Тим [he] had a more private area where they could use the Mind Meld potion, there was no reason not to use it.

This is for his greater good, not because I’m curious to see what he’s doing.

Ной [he] pulled the trapdoor back. It opened soundlessly to reveal a long, dark slide that ran at a steep angle. He could just barely see rungs running along its top. It didn’t look like climbing in – or out – would be particularly enjoyable.

He held his grimoire out, making sure the huge book actually fit into the confined space, then returned it to his back. Pulling the trapdoor up, he adjusted the rug so that it was draped over the top and stepped down into the hole, hanging from rungs of the ladder. It was at such an angle that he was nearly upside down.

Ной [he] lowered the trapdoor and the light in the tunnel vanished. He looked down into the darkness, tempted to just drop and use wind magic to slow his fall. Instead, he started to climb down normally. There was far too high of a chance of him slamming ass-first into a turn or corner and having to hobble the rest of the way.

He continued into the darkness, clinging onto the ladder as it twisted and turned. It was impossible to see where he was actually going. The passage went a lot deeper than he’d thought it would. The tunnel eventually righted itself and let him return to climbing the ladder straight down like a normal human being.

Just about fifty feet below him was light, dim and yellow. His angle only let him make out a few muted spots of bronze pipe and purple smoke bathed within the light.

But the light wasn’t all he found. With it came voices. Ной [he] froze in place. He hadn’t expected Тим [he] to have company.

Maybe I should leave. I don’t want to intrude–

“Get out of my way. This is your last warning,” a woman’s voice said.

Ной [he]’s eyes narrowed.

Never mind. Anyone causing Тим [he] trouble should have chosen somewhere to do it where there were witnesses.

He released the rungs of the ladder. Wind swirled past his face as he plummeted through the darkness and rapidly approached the light.
==========
Chapter 399: Heated Барба [she] Moment

Ной [he] used a swirl of wind to slow his fall a few moments before his feet hit the ground. His jacket fluttered around him as he landed safely, eyes adjusting to the sudden light. The room around him was surprisingly large – far too large to fit anywhere in the transport cannon’s body.

Metal pipes ran along the walls and twisted past each other like the pattern of a woven scarf. They crisscrossed beneath his feet and jutted up, all covered by наполнение [he]s and obscured by inscriptions that ran alongside them.

Shimmers of purple energy swirled at cracks in the pipes and curled up in twists of faint smoke that made the room smell like a mixture of sulfur, brass, and sweat. All the pipes congregated at a single glass pillar in the center of the room. It was so heavily etched with Наполнения [he] that it may as well have been opaque. Something deep within it flickered with muted energy.

Standing before the pillar was, rather than Тим [he], Брейден [he]. The large man leaned on his sword, streaks of blood running down his arms and his shirt ripped to shreds to reveal seeping wounds beneath.

Across from him was a woman. She wore a flour-stained apron and was a little portly around the waist. The woman spun toward Ной [he]. Her eyes were creased with wrinkle lines from smiling and her cheeks were plump. Several ragged cuts ran through her clothes, but her body was unharmed.

She looked more like a baker than a warrior. A baker that was somehow winning the fight against Брейден [he], one of the strongest Rank 4 mages that Ной [he] knew. He called on Natural Disaster instantly, letting its power course through his body like a raging river.

“The hell is going on here?”

“Oh goodness,” the woman said. “I wasn’t expecting company so soon. You wouldn’t happen to–”

A thick bolt of lightning roared as it split the air, ripping out of Ной [he]’s hands and slicing out for her. The air around the woman shimmered, waves of heat rolling off her body as the lightning bolt vanished about ten feet before it could reach her.

Shit. She’s got a domain, and it’s stronger than mine.

“That was rude,” the woman said. “Wait your turn, son.”

“Go get help,” Брейден [he] growled. He pulled his sword from the ground and raised it before himself. “She’s a multi-Rune Rank 5. One of Визен [he]’s. Uses fire.”

The air around the woman ignited with a whoomp and a wave of heat slammed into Ной [he]. He raised his hands defensively, his domain pressing back against her power as he grit his teeth.

“Don’t go chatting while we’re having a fight,” the woman scolded. Fire rolled out across the floor before her and slammed into Брейден [he]. An instant before it could connect and push through his domain, he flickered and vanished in a flash of purple.

He stumbled as he reappeared beside Ной [he], his breath coming out in ragged bursts. “Come on. You need to go. Now.”

“Wait. Where’s Тим [he]?”

“The old man is fine. He’s hiding somewhere in the room,” Брейден [he] said through a cough. “They’re not after him. There’s an artifact in the transport cannon. I think–”

Another wall of fire rolled toward them. The woman’s power sputtered and faded as it drew close to Ной [he] and Брейден [he], unable to push through both of their domains. But even though it didn’t connect, the waves of heat that rolled through the air were enough to singe Ной [he]’s eyebrows.

“I told you to stop talking. Don’t you realize it’s rude?” the woman asked.

“Talk about rude. I don’t even know your name,” Ной [he] said, his eyes darting around the maze of pipes in search of Тим [he]. He didn’t give a shit about who the woman was or what he wanted.

“Барба [she],” the woman said. She flicked her hand and a bolt of fire ripped out, streaking toward Ной [he]. He dove to the side and it screamed past him, slamming into a pipe at his back. A loud hiss escaped it and a stream of purple smoke started to pour out. “And don’t lecture me on manners when you’re the one that attacked me mid-sentence.”

“I got impatient waiting for an answer,” Ной [he] said as he came to his feet.

“She’s got a healer somewhere here,” Брейден [he] said, grinding his teeth and raising his sword again. “Don’t overextend. He’s got light magic that obscures his location and has something that’s letting him hide from my domain.”

“How strong?” Ной [he] asked.

“Not as strong as the old lady.”

“Old?” Барба [she] demanded, her eyes narrowing. “I’ll have you know I’m barely scratching my golden years.”


She snapped her fingers. Fire coiled around her body with a roar like a dragon. Roiling heat slammed into Ной [he] and he called on Combustion, trying to snuff out the fire. It did nothing – the Master Rune was completely outclassed, and Барба [she] wasn’t relying on combustion to create her fire. It was coming straight from her Runes. He released Combustion and swapped to Natural Disaster, drawing from the moisture around him. There wasn’t much to work with, but he managed to form a rippling barrier an instant before Барба [she]’s flames slammed into it.

The water boiled and evaporated, but it bought their domains enough time to dissipate Барба [she]’s power. She was strong, but she wasn’t powerful enough to completely overwhelm both of them through brute force.

“You seem to be evenly matched against two of us,” Ной [he] said, letting power build in him as he continued to search the room. Even if Барба [she] couldn’t overwhelm them, he didn’t have a way to easily get back at her without using Разлом [he] or a Formation. “What’s your goal here? Why are you attacking Брейден [he]?”

“I don’t care about him. If you both stood out of my way, my quarrel with you would be over.”

“Don’t give her the artifact,” Брейден [he] said. “I know what it is.”

“Then you’re going to have to do a bit more than stand there,” Ной [he] said, lowering his tone and speaking out the corner of his mouth. “Can you hold her off?”

“What does it look like I’ve been doing?”

“Well, do more of it.”

Flame erupted around Барба [she] and washed across the room toward them. Брейден [he] dashed forward and swung his sword. A wave of purple energy followed the weapon’s tip. It cut through the roiling fire and Брейден [he] dashed through the flames as they faded. He lunged at Барба [she] and she raised her hands to send out another torrent of fire – only for Брейден [he] to vanish.

He reformed beside her, his huge sword already hurtling for Барба [she]’s side. The woman leaned back, vaulting out of the way and narrowly avoiding getting carved in two. She landed on her feet and skidded a foot back, her teeth gritting.

“Bah. Sword users. Can’t you just use magic like a normal mage?” Барба [she] complained, pulling her hands through the air. Flame screamed through the air and ripped through pipes, filling the room with even more purple smoke. Брейден [he] teleported away from the attack and formed before Барба [she], his sword crashing down once more.

She was forced to retreat once again, but her attention was occupied once again. Ной [he] summoned his violin to his hands and started to play. He hadn’t forgotten Брейден [he]’s warning that Барба [she] had a healer somewhere in the area, so it wasn’t like he could completely forget the rest of the world as he played, but he’d been practicing since the fight against Эвергрин [she].

Notes of magic swirled around Ной [he] and filled his song as he started a Formation. The violin muted the sounds of his music to keep it from being too obvious, but it would only be a matter of time before Барба [she] noticed that he was playing a soundless violin.

Before she could do anything, she’d have to throw Брейден [he] off. He was clearly exhausted and running low on magic, but his attacks were relentless. Over and over again his sword fell, forcing Барба [she] to retreat before someone a full rank beneath her.

Ной [he] had no delusions of Барба [she]’s strength. He’d felt the heat of her magic. She’d been summoning flame from nothing. That was something only a Rank 5 could do, and it was clear she was no stranger to it.

Fire was only good if it could connect with its target, though. Брейден [he]’s form slipped through the fire in swirls of purple magic. His features were clad in stone and his blade an advancing wall of metal.

Not for the first time, Ной [he] was grateful that Брейден [he] was on his side. His domain prickled with pulses of magic that washed across it, and Ной [he] let it play into his music. A roaring inferno danced to protect its heart from the wounded hound. The beast’s pursuit was dogged, but while it could nip at the fire, the battle could only end in one way – unless something changed.

The violin grew louder. Energy poured out of Ной [he]’s body as he drained power from Natural disaster to make the housing of the Formation. Whoever Барба [she]’s backup was had yet to strike, but–

A shimmer bent the air at Ной [he]’s side, right at the edge of his domain as it destroyed the magic trying to enter it. From within the magic came a short man wearing white robes and bearing a wooden staff.

Ной [he] recognized him. It was Richard – the healer that he’d seen the day he’d arrived at Арбитраж [he]. Surprise played across Richard’s features but he carried forward, sprinting at Ной [he] and rearing back with his staff.

Not a Rank 4, so he can’t use magic in my domain.

Twisting, Ной [he] dodged out of the way of the strike. His music grew faster as he moved around Richard, deftly avoiding the strikes of the man’s staff.

You can’t use my own trick against me, especially when it looks like you’ve never tried to hit someone without magic in your life.

Барба [she]’s eyes flicked over to Ной [he] as his music approached a crescendo. The moment of distraction cost her a deep wound across her shoulder as a line of purple energy carved out of Брейден [he]’s sword and she failed to fully avoid it in time.

Flame erupted around her like a blooming flower, detonating with a brilliant explosion. Брейден [he] flew back, his arms crossed and smoking before his face. He slammed into a nest of pipes and dropped down. Purple smoke hissed out around him from the pipes.

Richard turned to run over to Барба [she]. He took one step before Ной [he] hooked his foot forward, still playing, and yanked the healer’s legs out from under him. He poured Разлом [he] into the Formation building in his song.

“Stop him already!” Барба [she] yelled, pain in her voice as she turned toward Ной [he] and gathered fire around herself.

Richard rolled over and tried to jab his staff up at Ной [he]’s throat. Ной [he] leaned back, avoiding the strike, and kicked the healer in the side of his head. He played faster still. Adrenaline and magic intertwined within his veins.

The violin sang with Ной [he]. Elation grew within it as the song drew closer to its conclusion. Richard groaned and lunged from his spot on the ground, only to catch a heel to the nose. His nose shattered with a crunch and his head slammed back into the ground.

Fire roared toward them from Барба [she]’s hands, the power rippling within the curling sea of red and orange far too great to be held back by the dam of his domain. Heat bit at his face and prickled against his skin. He played one more note.

The violin fell silent.

The Formation came to life.

Chapter 400: Portals

A crescent of black tore out from the notes of magic that Ной [he] had laid, streaking out to meet the immense torrent of flame bearing down on it. The wall of fire curled like a wave as it made to crash down on top of Ной [he], screaming like a scorned god.

Разлом [he]’s arc touched the flames.

The room fell quiet. Барба [she]’s magic was swallowed, sound and flame alike, up by a devouring silence and an endless black. Firelight blinked out. All that remained was Разлом [he] and its advance toward Барба [she].

Her eyes widened and she flung herself to the side, three glistening Shields erupting around her body preemptively. Разлом [he] didn’t even register their existence. They were beneath it, so pathetic that they weren’t even worth destroying.

Its black blade continued on, disappearing into the wall without a sound. Барба [she] hit the ground with a pained grunt and rolled to her feet. Fear gripped her face for the first time as she looked back at where Разлом [he]’s power had gone. Her shields still shimmered around her, waiting in silent anticipation.

“What was–”

Барба [she]’s shields shattered. Three rings fell from her fingers, their power completely spent, and clinked against the ground. Even as she looked down in shock, a wet squelch split the silence. Her arm hit the ground before her, severed right above the elbow, the blood only just starting to come as it realized that it had been cut.

The pipes behind Барба [she] screeched. Purple smoke hissed out in a deluge, curling around her body as she clutched at the stump of her arm and took a stumbling, terrified step back. Blood poured out of the brutal wound as her vessels finally remembered that they were meant to be bleeding.

Барба [she] grit her teeth and fire erupted from her remaining hand. The smell of burnt flesh filled the air as she cauterized the wound. Before Ной [he] could try to draw on his powers again, Барба [she] thrust a palm toward him.

A spark caught in the air, then detonated. Брейден [he] rolled over and sank into the ground with a shimmer of magic, then reformed before Ной [he], slamming his sword into the ground. Purple energy erupted from his blade and swirled up into a shimmering wall an instant before the room disappeared in a flash.

Fire roared past Ной [he] and pipes shattered all around them under the force of Барба [she]’s magic. His domain shuddered and desperately tried to hold strong. Even with Брейден [he] by his side, the fire licked hungrily past them. The only patch of the room that wasn’t completely devoured in its hungry grasp was a small cone behind them.

Брейден [he]’s purple magic cracked. His grip tightened around the hilt of his blade and he snarled in defiance. Ной [he] tried to call the moisture in the room to create water, but there was almost nothing left to work with. Барба [she] had evaporated almost all of it. He quickly gave up and turned his attention to the flame, trying to push it back with Natural Disaster.

It was like trying to fight a brick wall. There was so much magic coiling within the fire that it was completely untouchable. All Ной [he] and Брейден [he] could do was stand there and bear the brunt of the attack, hoping it would end.

After what felt like minutes but was truly only a few seconds at best, the fire sputtered out. Брейден [he]’s grip on his sword slacked and he pitched forward. He caught himself just before he could fall face first, bracing a trembling arm against the ground.

There was no sign of Барба [she]. She’d vanished in the flames – but she hadn’t gone alone. The glass cylinder had melted to slag. Any наполнение [he]s that had once been on it had been reduced to nothing but molten trash. And, of the artifact that had been hidden within it, there was no sign.

There was something far more important missing than any artifact.

“Тим [he]!” Ной [he] yelled. “Where are you?”

“Over here. I’m fine, Professor.”

The relief struck Ной [he] with such intensity that he nearly dropped on the spot. He turned around as Тим [he] rose from behind a cluster of pipes, his hair badly singed but otherwise unharmed. Тим [he] brushed soot of his arms and walked over to them on shaky legs.

“Thank God,” Ной [he] said, grabbing the older man by his shoulders. “I thought you’d gotten fried.”

“I almost did,” Тим [he] said. “That healer had me by the neck. I was waiting for a good time to fight back, but when you knocked the life out of him, I figured it would be best to hide and avoid drawing any of your attention.”

“Probably for the best.” Ной [he] turned back to scan the room. None of the purple smoke that had been pouring out of the pipes remained. It had been completely burned away by Барба [she]’s magic – along with just about everything else.

The floor, and ceiling where Барба [she] had been standing strongly resembled the Scorched Acres. Pipe and bronze had blackened and turned partially to ash. The damage lessened the farther it got from where she’d been, but the room was still thoroughly torched. A grimace passed over Ной [he]’s lips as he spotted Richard. Or, more accurately, as he spotted what remained of Richard.

The narrative has been taken without permission. Report any sightings.

It looked like he’d tried to run while Ной [he] and Брейден [he] were distracted with Барба [she], but he’d only made it a few steps away from them and toward Барба [she] before her spell had gone off. His lower half was mostly in one piece, but the entire top of his body was nothing but a pile of soot on the ground.

“You okay, Брейден [he]?” Ной [he] asked. He kept Natural Disaster at his beck and call as he spoke. There wasn’t much area left to hide in the room, but he wasn’t going to take any chances in case she was biding her time somewhere.

“Alive,” Брейден [he] said with a grunt. He grabbed his sword and pulled himself up with a groan. “She’s gone.”

“You sure?”

“Yes. I felt spatial magic a moment before she disappeared. Визен [he] pulled her back. We figured out what they were after too late. I only just caught on a short while ago and raced over here, thinking I could grab the key and move it elsewhere before Визен [he]’s people arrived. Evidently, I wasn’t fast enough.”

“That was a Rank 5,” Ной [he] reminded Брейден [he]. He couldn’t lie – he didn’t really give much of a shit about what Визен [he] wanted. If it wasn’t Мокси [she] and it wasn’t him or anyone he cared about, Арбитраж [he] could eat dirt. Their secrets weren’t worth dying for. “You did everything you could. But… what happened here? Was Арбитраж [he] seriously keeping some super-weapon just… sitting around in the transport cannon?”

“It wasn’t a super weapon,” Тим [he] said. “And it wasn’t just sitting around. That’s how the transport cannon operated. Magic doesn’t come from nowhere, and Space Runes are incredibly difficult to get to high ranks. For an operation this powerful, normal наполнение [he] would have been almost impossible.”

“So you drew magic from a spatial artifact to power the whole thing?”

Тим [he] nodded. “Yes. It wasn’t any sort of weapon, though. Not as far as I’m aware. The Торрин [he]s donated it some time ago because they couldn’t figure out how to use it, and Арбитраж [he] set it up as a transport service. That’s all I know. That woman – Барба [she] – she had an Арбитраж [he] researcher badge, so I paused operations on the cannon to show it to her. You saw most of the rest.”

“She had an inside agent,” Брейден [he] said. He nodded to the remains of Richard’s body, then grimaced and swayed. He braced himself against his sword again. “This idiot. Probably got paid off. It’s not your fault, old man. Father is going to be furious – or elated. I can never tell. He might actually be more of the latter. The Торрин [he]s, on the other hand, will definitely be furious.”

“I’ll be honest with you. If Blancwood was on fire, I wouldn’t piss on it to help,” Ной [he] said. He glanced around the room again, then slowly let Natural Disaster slip from his grip. It didn’t look like Барба [she] was still around. “Most of the Торрин [he]s can rot. They get whatever comes to them.”

“I don’t care about them either, but Father gave me orders to interfere with Визен [he]. He won’t be happy about this.”

“I’ll deal with Father,” Ной [he] said with a wave. “Have you really been running around this entire time trying to find what Визен [he] was after? You should have worked with Мокси [she]. She was already doing the same thing. If you’d told her, you probably would have found it earlier.”

Брейден [he] coughed into a fist and wiped his mouth with the back of his hand. “Yes. That probably would have been advisable, but I didn’t consider that she’d actually be doing anything. I’ll apologize to her later.”

“You’re not too badly injured, are you?” Ной [he] asked as a flicker of concern passed through him.

“I’m fine.” Брейден [he] let out a dry laugh. “What about the old man?”

“Alive,” Тим [he] said through a sigh. He wiped some of the soot from his face. “And probably in better shape than you. We should go find help immediately. Someone needs to report what happened to Арбитраж [he].”

“I agree,” Брейден [he] said. “Do you think you can go do that? I need to have a talk with Вермил [he].”

Тим [he] glanced at Ной [he], who gave him a small nod in response.

“I’ll be back with aid soon,” Тим [he] promised. He hurried over to the ladder. It had been mostly warped and destroyed, but some of the metal had managed to hold its structure. He jumped and grabbed onto the lowest rung that hadn’t been completely destroyed before pulling himself up and into the tunnel.

“So,” Брейден [he] said wearily. “You just cast a Formation with music.”

“So I did,” Ной [he] said.

“You’re Rank 4 now, and with a pretty strong domain. Midway through it, if I had to guess.”

Ной [he] nodded.

“I’ve never seen the Rune you were using as its head. That might have been the most oppressive Rank 4 Rune I’ve ever seen. Even with a Formation, cutting straight through the domain of a Rank 5 and nearly killing her in a single blow is almost unheard of. I take it there’s a reason I’ve never heard of the magic you were using?”

Ной [he] nodded once more. “Yes. I’d prefer to keep any information on it completely wrapped up.”

“Would I be remiss in guessing this is somehow connected to the way you can’t seem to stay dead?”

Ной [he] gave Брейден [he] a noncommittal shrug. He trusted the large man, but the truth of Разлом [he] and how it worked was something he had no plans to give any more information on than he absolutely had to.

“Fair enough,” Брейден [he] said. “I wouldn’t tell anyone if I were you. I’ll avoid mentioning it to the Исполнители and anyone else that comes to look. I don’t think Тим [he] understood the magnitude of what he saw, but we can play this off as you being a Formation master. I’ll avoid mentioning just how powerful that final attack was. Acceptable?”

“More than.” Ной [he] gave Брейден [he] an appreciative nod. “Thank you.”

“Thank you

,” Брейден [he] corrected. “Saved my ass. I would have been dead if you didn’t show up.”

“Any time. But… before anyone else gets here, do you have any idea what that artifact actually was?”

Lines of concern creased Брейден [he]’s face and he drew in a deep breath, letting out in a sigh. “Yes. I do.”

“And? Is it something we have to be worried about?”

“I don’t know,” Брейден [he] admitted through a grimace. “It was a key that opens a very long-distance portal.”

“To where?”

“The Damned Plains.”

Chapter 401: The City Of Gold

One day ago.

Визен [he] let out a rattling breath. He leaned back in his stone chair, his hand tightening at his side as the connection to his puppets sputtered and wheezed. Сильвертид [he] had done a lot more damage to Эвергрин [she]’s runes than he’d initially thought.

The old woman wouldn’t last much longer. He’d already ripped every shred of power that she had to spare from her body. It was only right. She’d cheated him. The key hadn’t been on her.

Perhaps I should have seen that coming. I can only blame myself. Why would the puppet of the Торрин [he] family be carrying around an artifact like that? I should have gone after one of the important ones – but it hardly matters now.

The information flowing from the puppet sputtered to a stop. The last thing Визен [he] saw through its eyes was the plant matter filling its core seeping out and souring the Торрин [he] Family’s library.

“I knew it,” Визен [he] breathed. His fingers twitched at his sides and old wounds burned his back. He ignored the pain and rose to his feet, stepping past the cracked bulbs and striding out of the room.

The darkness pulled away from him, as if in fear of his shadow. He strode down the hall, turning the corner and pushing through an old doorway to enter a kitchen. A middle-aged woman stood at the counter, her hands covered in flour and a ball of dough on the counter beside her.

Several finished pastries laid on the wooden table between them, stuffed full of glistening cherries. The woman’s hair hung around her face in a bob, and her face was slightly rotund. She smiled and brushed her hands off on the apron hanging from her neck.

“Визен [he], honey. How have you been doing? You’ve been working really hard lately.”

“I have,” Визен [he] agreed with a dry laugh. He took one of the pastries from the table and bit into it, a delighted expression pulling across his features as the bright, sugary flavor of the fruit mixed perfectly with the flaky pastry. “And it seems you have as well, Барба [she]. You’ve outdone yourself once more.”

“Oh, you flatter me,” Барба [she] said with a soft laugh. “I’d be honored if it was my cooking that brought you out of your hole, but I suspect that I haven’t gotten that good.”

Визен [he] polished off the rest of the pastry before responding. “I’m afraid not. Something far more important gives my feet flight.”

Барба [she]’s eyebrows lifted. “You found it, didn’t you?”

“I found it,” Визен [he] said. His smile stretched even further across his face and he picked up another pastry. “At no cheap expense, mind you. Hundreds of puppets. An entire set of Rank 6 Runes, wasted.”

“Wasted? I’d hardly say that,” Барба [she] said. She stepped around the counter and took one of her pastries, taking a bite from it. After chewing for a moment, her lips pursed and she shook her head. “Too sweet. I need less sugar.”

“I rather like them sweet,” Визен [he] said. “And perhaps wasted is the wrong word. They did what I needed them to. I just didn’t expect to lose so much at this stage. Сильвертид [he] is stronger than I thought.”

“He’s an old codger. What did you expect?” Барба [she] shook her head and laughed. “It’s unfortunate that he’s going to be in our way. I’ve met Сильвертид [he] before. He’s a good man.”

“Most men are,” Визен [he] said. He finished his second pastry and wiped his mouth off with a napkin. “But good men turn blind in the plight of those they care not for. We have no need for good men.”

“Everyone can be used,” Барба [she] said. “You’re just too black and white, hon. Learn some shades of gray.”

“I’ll leave that to you and the others,” Визен [he] said. “For now, all I care about is the key. As I suspected, it is within Арбитраж [he].”

“It is? Well, color me a dunce,” Барба [she] said with a sheepish smile. “I was convinced they’d never let something like that out of their sight. What a stupid move.”

“The more you know of the Торрин [he] family, the more sense it makes. They claim to be warriors, but they are rats. They hide their strength and lurk in the shadows, hoping to take their opponents by surprise. It is ironic that the Линвик [they] family somehow has more honest men than they do.”

“That’s saying a lot,” Барба [she] said. “Are you sure about that?”

Визен [he] snorted. “You speak of Father? He is honest. He does not lie. Words are a weapon which must always be wielded when in his presence, but he does not lie. I respect him.”


“He’s a codgery old asshole who should be rotting in a grave. The world would be better off without him. He sent you a black primrose, Визен [he]. He–”

“Cannot get on my nerves that easily,” Визен [he] finished. “Father seeks to anger me. It will not work. The only thing that matters is results.”

Барба [she] flashed Визен [he] a smirk. “Are you sure? I saw you speaking to Сильвертид [he] and those brats with him. That didn’t look like pure results.”

“There was a purpose to it.” Визен [he] coughed into his fist. “And some conversation may have not been remiss. It has been some time since I’ve spoken to people other than those within our circle. Proper ones, that is.”

“Oh, I understand. It can be quite the downer,” Барба [she] said. She walked back to the counter and started to work the dough again. “But I still can’t believe the Торрин [he]s sent the key away.”

“It makes sense. The key holds no power for a coward. It may not hold power for a bold fool either. It is nothing but an opportunity,” Визен [he] said. “But it is the opportunity I have been searching for.”

“So how are you going to get it? Your puppets are all gone, and I don’t think you’re going to wring any more magic out of Эвергрин [she]’s old husk. Сильвертид [he] gave you a ringing slap, hon.”

Визен [he] let out a small laugh. “He removed my puppets from the play, but I have far more pieces on the board than just them. Surely you don’t think so lowly of me to only have a single plan, Барба [she]. Even Father knows better. He sent someone to guard the key and stand in my way.”

“Father did? Who, the one that killed Джентил [he]?”

“No. His brother,” Визен [he] replied. “He arrived at Арбитраж [he] some time ago and I haven’t seen him since. There’s no doubt in my mind that he watches over the key – but he will not be able to stop my agent.”

Барба [she] raised an eyebrow. “Brother… Брейден [he], was it? Big man. Beautiful muscles. I just want to squeeze his cheeks.”

“Please keep your fantasies to yourself,” Визен [he] said with a weary sigh. “But yes. The Space Rune user. He likely lies in wait for us to make our next move. Брейден [he] should not be underestimated. He may seem to be a lumbering idiot, but he is intelligent and capable. If he was not, he would not have survived this long in Father’s presence.”

“So I see. And where is this key?” Барба [she] asked. “A vault beneath the academy? Locked deep in their rune research rooms so that only their best mages can gaze upon it and attempt to discern its function?”

“No,” Визен [he] said with a dry laugh. “That was where I believed it would be as well. It is honestly quite ingenious. I must give the Торрин [he]s credit. They know how to hide. That is the only way they evaded me so long. I shared your beliefs, Барба [she]. Come.”

Барба [she] glanced down at her dough, then back up at Визен [he] as he headed for the door. With a huff, she walked after him. The two returned to the room with the bulbs, where Визен [he] lowered himself into a chair.

Dirt rippled at his feet, rising up into a chair for Барба [she] across from him. She sat down as the dirt continued to bubble, forming into a perfect replica of Арбитраж [he].

“Арбитраж [he] is my favorite of the bastions,” Визен [he] said, a smile drifting across his face. “So many different goals, all of them competing. Their schooling is inadequate. Their teachers are fools. Their researchers are greedy and horde knowledge instead of sharing it. They steal from even their own families.”

“Визен [he], hon, did you forget what favorite means again?”

Визен [he] let out a huff. No matter how strong he got, Барба [she] never seemed to enjoy wallowing in arrogance for too long. It was good. She kept him grounded.

“The reason Арбитраж [he] exists is not for any of the reasons above,” Визен [he] said. “Арбитраж [he] is a storage. It exists to give the top noble families a location to put their artifacts – the ones they want studied, but the ones they don’t want near their actual homes. They send their children – the ones that look important but lack true value – as a cover. In truth, nearly everyone in Арбитраж [he] is replacable. A few rise above the rabble, but the rest are only there to take up space. Арбитраж [he] is not a sanctuary or a school. It is an agreement between the top noble families to designate an area where they could store the weapons that proved too great a threat to keep close to chest. It is an armory.”

“So they all pitch in some garbage to make it seem like a proper school, then stick all the bad news into it somewhere in hopes that the problem becomes someone else’s issue to deal with when it goes wrong?”

Визен [he] nodded. “Yes. They obviously want some students to be successful as well, but they take no risks in their training. Those who have talent occasionally succeed, but their purpose is merely to keep the attention of other noble families – and even some members of their own families – averted from the Bastion’s true purpose.”

“So… where’s the key?” Барба [she] asked. “A vault?”

“Hidden in plain sight.” Визен [he]’s smile returned. He waved a hand and the buildings faded away until only a single one remained. A thin tower, cannon at its top pointed to the heavens. “What better place to store a spatial artifact than a cannon that uses its powers as a battery?”

“Clever,” Барба [she] said. “You’re sure? That’s… bold. Even for them.”

“The information lines up. I am certain. You will go.”

“I figured as much,” Барба [she] said. She pulled her apron off and folded it up, setting it down on the arm of Визен [he]’s seat. “You’ve got things arranged to get me into campus?”

“Of course. Be hasty. Do not let yourself get caught up in a long fight. Арбитраж [he]’s students may be largely worthless, but its protectors are not. You will not survive a fight if they all come down on you.”

“I can handle myself, hon. Don’t you worry,” Барба [she] said. “I might need a little help if things go south, though.”

“Already handled. I’ve had an agent in Арбитраж [he] for some time now.”

“Is there anywhere you don’t have an agent?”

“No,” Визен [he] replied with a dry laugh. “Finish your preparations, Барба [she]. The key will be mine by nightfall.”

Барба [she] gave him a sharp nod, then headed out of the room. Визен [he] watched her leave, then drew in a deep breath and let it out slowly. Twinges ran down his back, but he ignored them. He was so close. After all these years, everything was finally sliding into place.

“Count the days, old friend,” Визен [he] breathed. “The City of Gold awaits us.”

Chapter 402: Smoking

Барба [she] dropped through the portal, smoke curling up from her body. She dropped to the floor of the cold cave and let out a heaving cough that racked her entire body, expelling soot from her lungs.

“Барба [she]!” Визен [he] exclaimed, rushing to her side. His fingers flew to his side and pulled a vial full of glistening green liquid free, popping the wax seal off in the same movement. He brought it to her mouth and tipped it in.

Барба [she] drank greedily, wrapping her lips around the lip of the bottle to keep herself from spilling any of it. Magic worked its way through her body and she let out a relieved breath. The burns that covered her body quickly started to turn pink and pull back.

“What in the Damned Plains happened?” Визен [he] demanded. “It was meant to be a fast in-and-out! How did you get so badly injured?”

“Father figured us out,” Барба [she] said through a cough. She wiped her lips with the back of a hand and grimaced. “His kids were there. Both Вермил [he] and Брейден [he], though it seemed that Вермил [he] was acting on his own volition.”

“Children gave you this much difficulty?” Визен [he] asked, trying and failing to contain the shock in his voice. “A Rank 4 and – what was Вермил [he]? A Rank 3 at best?”

“Rank 4,” Барба [she] said grimly. The wounds covering her body continued to heal and she pushed herself upright. A frown crossed her lips and she looked down at her missing right arm. The burn at its stump was fading, but the arm showed no sign of regrowing. “What kind of potion did you give me, Визен [he]? Am I not worth better than this drivel?”

“Drivel? That potion was over fifty thousand gold,” Визен [he] said. His eyes followed Барба [she]’s and his brow creased in disbelief and confusion. “What happened to you? Did they have an Исполнитель [he] lying in wait? Брейден [he] is competent, but not that competent. You shouldn’t have had any trouble.”

“It wasn’t Брейден [he]. It was Вермил [he]. He was the stronger of the two, and by an enormous margin.”

“Вермил [he] was? Impossible. He barely beat Джентил [he].”

“He’s a Formation master,” Барба [she] said flatly. The last of her wounds faded away. Her missing arm made no moves to return. It was as if the potion had registered her ‘whole’ state as missing an arm. “And he’s got one of the most wicked Formations I’ve ever seen. His domain put him at mid Rank 4, but he cut straight through my own domain and would have killed me if I hadn’t dodged in time.”

“Impossible,” Визен [he] said. His mind spun as he searched through all the information he’d gathered. Вермил [he] had been an anomaly. Father’s least favorite child and a lecherous pervert. Something had changed in the man some time ago and he’d started growing in power, but nothing had indicated the rate of growth was this intense.

There was a chance that he’d met with someone strong enough to feed him Runes, but as to who, Визен [he] didn’t know. His closest allies were an exiled servant from the Торрин [he] Family, his students with an all-too-common vendetta against the nobles, and an over-eager girl with an appetite far too large for her body.

Even if Джален [he] himself had decided to step in and deliver runes straight to Вермил [he], this result shouldn’t have been possible. Mastering Formations in mere months, not to mention having such a Formation strong enough to nearly kill someone a whole rank above him… the chances of that happening were astronomically low.

Which means one of two things. Either Вермил [he] has been a plant from the start and has been hiding his power this entire time, or he got his hands on one of the most powerful Master Runes to ever exist. I can’t think of anything else that would let him challenge Барба [she].


Between the two options, the former was the most likely. Father had always liked sowing his seeds far in advance. This one had just slipped under his nose. Визен [he] cursed under his breath. He’d been convinced that he’d gotten the upper hand on Father, but the cunning bastard had been a step ahead.

“Damn it all,” Визен [he] cursed. “I’m sorry, Барба [she]. I was confident–”

“I don’t blame you, hon,” Барба [she] said with a curt laugh that contained all the anger that her words lacked. “Can’t predict everything. It’s a miracle everything has lined up as well as it has this far. An arm is a small price to pay.”

“It is not. Things will be harder now than they ever were,” Визен [he] said. “You’re one of my strongest warriors. I can’t afford to waste your power like this. We don’t have anything to spare. Арбитраж [he] will doubtlessly have moved the key now. I will have to act myself. It’s the only way to keep anyone else from–”

Визен [he]’s words died on his lips as Барба [she] opened her remaining hand. Nestled within it was a glistening golden key. Thin purple inscriptions ran along its surface and glistened in anticipation. The power within it was so faint that he could barely feel it, but the key’s appearance was undeniable.

“You got it,” Визен [he] breathed.

“Barely,” Барба [she] said with a chuckle. “Had to torch the entire room and nearly kill myself in the process. I’m not immune to my own fire when it’s hot enough to rip through my domain. I knew we weren’t getting another shot at this. Not an easy one, at least. There was too much on the line to fail.”

“Have I ever told you how much I love you?” Визен [he] asked, taking the key from Барба [she]. His throat tightened, the hand of the past wringing it dry. The key was so light. So small. So powerful.

It had been the only thing he’d thought about for years, to the point where he’d started to wonder if he’d ever actually get his hands on it. The power the artifact represented was immense. It was spatial magic perfected – something that humanity had failed to achieve for years upon years.

His studies had shown him countless ways to turn it into a deadly weapon. It possessed the ability to level entire cities, were it properly connected to a few other choice artifacts and controlled by the proper wielder.

Визен [he] couldn’t have cared less. There was only one thing he wanted the key for, and it wasn’t any power that could be claimed on this plane of existence.

“Rest, Барба [she],” Визен [he] said. He pulled a chain out from his pocket and threaded it through the key. He hung it around his neck and tucked it into his shirt. “You have done well. I will find a way to deal with your arm. The rune that did that somehow completely severed your arm, both body and soul. It is a powerful one, clearly aided by its Formation.”

“Are we going to go after it?”

“Want it for yourself, do you?” Визен [he] let out a dry laugh. “Perhaps. But not now. We must keep sight of our goal. Father is a deadly opponent, and it seems Вермил [he] is a card that we did not place. We cannot afford any distractions or roadblocks. There is only one thing that matters.”

Барба [she] gave him a sharp nod. “I suppose so. I’ll hold you to that promise about my arm, Визен [he]. I can’t bake with one arm. Not as well as I could with two, at least.”

“The Damned Plains will possess all which we seek. Even if there is no cure, there will be an acceptable replacement.”

Барба [she] brushed her burnt clothes off and rose to her feet with an unsteady wobble. She adjusted her shirt and let out a sigh. “I’m going to need a new apron as well.”

“It will be arranged for. Go rest.”

“And you?”

“I will do what I always do,” Визен [he] replied. His hand lifted to the key resting against his chest and his eyes darkened. “I will prepare. This phase of our work is complete. Now that we have the key, I will gather the rest of the five. We must move quickly. Father will doubtlessly set his own plans into motion when he discovers the key is lost. He must not be allowed to interfere.”

“Something tells me that he will anyway.”

“Most likely,” Визен [he] said. He spun and started for the exit of the cave. “But he always has, and it has not stopped us yet. This time, the reason for that is you. But, from here on out, I will be taking a much more aggressive position. We will not be caught off guard once more. The Damned Plains will open to us, and I will take what is mine.”

Chapter 403: Plans In Plans

It didn’t take the Исполнители long to arrive. Just a minute after Барба [she] had vanished, while he and Брейден [he] were still getting their bearings again, a ripple of energy passed over the transport cannon. They both stiffened, but instead of Барба [she] or another one of Визен [he]’s men, the one who stepped through was an old man in an Арбитраж [he] uniform.

He held a staff in one hand, his eyes scanning over the room before he’d even set foot in it. Behind him came Нейр [he] and another man that Ной [he] recognized – Годрик [he], the head of the Продвинутая Группа. Тим [he] stepped out after them and walked back over to rejoin Ной [he] and Брейден [he].

“You again,” Нейр [he] said, his eyes locking onto Ной [he] as Тим [he] passed him. “Why is it always you?”

“Professor Вермил [he],” Годрик [he] said. “What in the Damned Plains happened here? Who is this?”

Ной [he] let out a breath and let his hands lower, releasing his hold on his Runes. This wasn’t a threat that flinging magic around was going to solve. He forced himself to bite back a sarcastic laugh. It didn’t seem like Арбитраж [he]’s enforcers could ever show up on time.

They were late when he’d killed the Hellreaver, and now they were late to getting their artifact stolen out from right beneath their noses. Тим [he] must have had some way to get their attention at the top of the transport cannon.

“Визен [he] attacked,” Ной [he] said.

“One of his people, more accurately. A Rank 5 woman by the name of Барба [she],” Брейден [he] corrected. “My name is Брейден [he].”

The old man didn’t bother exchanging any words. He made a beeline over to the melted glass, stepping over shattered pipes with a distasteful frown on his lips.

Нейр [he] massaged his temple with two fingers. “I’m familiar with both people present. They’re from the Линвик [they] Family. Брейден [he] is a Rank 4 space magic user. Вермил [he] is a Rank 3… well, something. I don’t know what he does other than get his nose stuck into problems.”

“He’s not Rank 3,” the old man said from the far side of the room, turning to look over his shoulder at them. “He has a domain.”

Нейр [he] blinked. He did a double take, then squinted. “Wait. I thought that was Брейден [he]’s. How are you Rank 4, Вермил [he]? You were Rank 1 a few months ago.”

“A few months is an exaggeration. I’ve been working hard, and I’ve got connections.”

“His rank is irrelevant to the matter at hand,” Годрик [he] said. His eyes swept over Тим [he], who had yet to speak, but didn’t stop moving. He drummed his fingers on his thighs, irritation evident on his features. “What did Визен [he] take? The expressions on your faces tell me we didn’t win this particular confrontation.”

“A key to the Damned Plains,” Брейден [he] said. “Визен [he]’s operative was severely wounded, but she appears to have survived. We have no reason to assume otherwise.”

“A key to the Damned Plains?” Нейр [he] repeated. He sent Брейден [he] a baffled look. “Who in their right mind would want that?”

“This may be news to you, but I don’t suspect Визен [he] is in his right mind,” Годрик [he] grumbled. “How did you know he would be here, Вермил [he]? And why did you not warn anyone else? If the продвинутая группа had known, we could have–”

“I only stumbled into this on accident,” Ной [he] said. He nodded over his shoulder at Тим [he]. “I was looking for him and thought it strange that nobody was manning the transport cannon, so I went looking around. I showed up while Брейден [he] was fighting Барба [she].”

“And why did you tell nobody? Or did you also stumble into this on accident?” Нейр [he] pressed Брейден [he].

Брейден [he] shrugged. “I don’t work for Арбитраж [he]. I work with it. There’s a difference. Father told me he had some suspicions as to what Визен [he]’s goals were. Барба [she] showed up shortly after I arrived to investigate.”

“There are traces of powerful spatial magic here,” the old man said, walking back over from the melted glass tube to rejoin them. He tapped his staff on the ground as he came to a halt. “Rank 6. Beyond anything these two could create.”

“Ridiculous. I can’t believe a lone Rank 6 manage to steal from us. It doesn’t matter how strong he is. This is unbelievable,” Годрик [he] said.

“You think that’s bad?” Ной [he] asked. “Визен [he] had an agent in the school.”

“Another clone?” Годрик [he]’s eyes dropped to the burnt body on the ground behind Ной [he].

“No. As far as I could tell, this one was just a guy. Someone by the name of Richard. A healer. Брейден [he] probably could have held Барба [she] off if it hadn’t been for him.”

“What-ifs are irrelevant,” the old man said. His grip tightened on the staff and he knelt beside Richard’s body, studying its remains with a growing frown. “Were you able to determine anything about why they wanted the key?”

“No. Барба [she] never mentioned it,” Брейден [he] said. “It seems very likely that this key was their end goal, though. I believe all those clones Визен [he] was spreading across Арбитраж [he] were likely him digging for information by taking the bodies of people with access to hidden information. That’s why he was targeting a mixture of people with access to archives belonging to the Торрин [he] Family and members of the Продвинутая Группа.”

And it explains why he was after Мокси [she] as well, not that I’ll be telling these jokers any of that. The less involved they are with me or anyone I care about, the better. In a way, I’m glad Визен [he] got the key. I don’t know what his goals are with it, but now he’s not going to be after Мокси [she] anymore.


“A logical theory,” Годрик [he] allowed. He crossed his arms in front of his chest and frowned. “We’ll have to run damage control. Again. We can’t have word getting out that Арбитраж [he] can be easily robbed.”

“Don’t you care about anything other than appearance?” Нейр [he] asked. “There’s a madman with a key to the Damned Plains strolling around who knows where. He’s got access to a Rank 6 Space Rune on top of things. Do you even realize how much of a threat that is? Do you know how many Space Runes are well made enough to make it to Rank 5, much less Rank 6?”

Now that he mentions it, I do recall Space Runes being really rare and difficult to rank up. Maybe I should pull Брейден [he] aside at some point and help him with his combinations and advancement to Rank 5. He already knows about some of my secrets, and we’re pretty much in this together at this point.

“Appearance controls the public. It is a powerful weapon, even if you find it distasteful.” Годрик [he]’s wide jaw clenched and he shook his head. “Am I remiss in assuming the transport cannon won’t function without that artifact? I gather the key was powering everything.”

“It was,” Тим [he] said from behind Ной [he]. “The cannon is a big tower without it. I suppose we could temporarily reactivate it with enough space magic, but the costs would be enormous. I don’t know where we’d find space magic users that powerful that would be willing to lend themselves to powering a tower for any amount of time.”

“There are some members in the продвинутая группа that can help,” Годрик [he] said. He turned his eyes toward Брейден [he]. “And you – you’re a space mage, yes?”

“I take it this is for the upcoming exams?” Брейден [he] guessed. “If so, I can help. You’re correct. If we have people start going into a panic now, Визен [he] will thrive off the chaos. We need to keep a united front.”

“Figure the logistics out later,” the old man said. He straightened back up and shook his head. “Вермил [he] is correct. Richard was not a puppet. I also failed to sense any magic lingering on him beyond his own Runes. He was working on his own volition. Not mind controlled.”

“Meaning Визен [he] could have more people here working for him,” Нейр [he] finished. “Shit.”

“It only matters if he needs more from Арбитраж [he], and I doubt that to be the case. We will be vigilant, but this may be someone else’s problem. Годрик [he] is correct. Our first priority is making sure nobody loses doubt in the sanctity of Арбитраж [he].”

Ной [he] nearly bust out laughing. The old man had said his own thoughts almost exactly, but he hadn’t expected them from someone who was supposed to have a responsibility to protect the entire school. Maybe he had more in common with the Исполнители than he’d thought.

“That said,” the old man continued, his eyes narrowing. “We must retrieve the key. It is not a weapon, but it is an immense power source. It is too dangerous to be left in the hands of a monster.”

“We’ll have to find him first,” Нейр [he] said. “Unless you’re strong enough to rip that portal back open.”

“It would be possible, but it would also be an ill idea,” the old man said with a shake of his head. “Визен [he] is powerful enough to give me pause. I would not barge into his home ground like a fool. It would not end well for us.”

“Визен [he] won’t be able to use the key for whatever he’s planning anytime soon,” Годрик [he] said. “It’ll take him time to figure out how to draw power from it. I have to assume it was a difficult artifact to operate considering how it was being used.”

The old man nodded. “Yes. The inscriptions on the glass were incredibly complex and took months to create. Брейден [he], Вермил [he] – did Барба [she] get a look at them? A long one?”

“No,” Брейден [he] said. “She never had a chance. She might have gotten a glance during the fight, but not enough of one to memorize anything.”

“Good,” Нейр [he] said. “We’ve got time then. Two months, if we assume he’s faster than we were.”

“Likely,” Годрик [he] said. He ran his hands through his hair and adjusted his uniform, letting out a huff. “I came here ready for a fight, not a political disaster. No matter. I will handle things with the rest of the Продвинутая Группа. Вермил [he] – I hope you’re ready to field questions. You already had interest on you. The other professors are going to be even more interested.”

“Are you going to mobilize them to find Визен [he]?” Нейр [he] asked. “We could use the help.”

“No. Their duty is to their students. Unlike the rest of Арбитраж [he], we actually care about teaching our charges. There are more than enough Исполнители to handle searching for Визен [he], and I’ll help you with any domestic issues, but finding the madman is your problem. He is not an immediate threat to anyone’s safety.”

Ной [he] caught himself before he could nod in approval. Годрик [he] actually seemed like he was genuinely interested in the wellbeing of his students. That was ironic as, according to Сильвертид [he], he quite literally didn’t have a heart.

No need to support him too publicly in front of Нейр [he]. I’m surprised he’s not frothing at the mouth. I have to look ridiculously suspicious at this point. If Брейден [he] wasn’t here, I’d be screwed.

“Figures,” Нейр [he] muttered. “I’ll need Сильвертид [he]. Possibly Вермил [he] as well.”

“Their schedules are theirs, not mine.”

“Great. There was going to be a meeting with the Исполнители tonight, but it’ll have to be postponed to tomorrow morning so we can gather more information. Вермил [he], you can come report–”

“I’ve got something scheduled, I’m afraid,” Ной [he] said.

Нейр [he] blinked. “What? What are you on about? We’ve got more important things to do than whatever it was that you were planning. You were a witness. I need to know everything that happened.”

“Брейден [he] knows more than I do,” Ной [he] said without a flicker of shame. “But we already told you almost everything. I’m more than willing to help figure this whole shitshow out and track Визен [he] down, but not at the cost of what I’m already doing. It’s like Годрик [he] said. Визен [he] isn’t a threat to anyone’s safety right now. I have duties to the продвинутая группа, my fellow professors, and my students.”

I have a date with Мокси [she]. I’m not missing it for this shitshow. Визен [he] is Арбитраж [he]’s problem, not mine. I really don’t care if he decides to screw off to the Damned Plains.

Годрик [he] gave Ной [he] a small nod of respect and Нейр [he] let out a huff of annoyed breath.

“Figures. What about tomorrow night?”

“That’s the продвинутая группа meeting,” Годрик [he] said. “They’re every three days.”

Ah. I finally learn the schedule. Right on time, buddy.

“Day after tomorrow?” Нейр [he] tried.

“That will work.”

“Good,” Нейр [he] said. “Thank you. I suppose that works better regardless. Gives me time to gather more information – and to vet the Исполнители. We need to make sure Визен [he] doesn’t have any more spies in our midst, even if all his puppets are gone. Годрик [he], even if your group is busy, I hope you’ll make sure they aren’t working against us.”

“We already had a re-vetting process recently. Nobody in the продвинутая группа is working with Визен [he],” Годрик [he] said. “There’s no reason to sit around here any longer. Julius, will you handle sealing the cannon down and come up with an explanation as to why it’s broken until I can get a replacement running?”

The old man nodded.

“Good,” Годрик [he] said. He heaved a sigh, then shook his head. “More work. Let’s get to it then. With any luck, Визен [he] has what he wanted and will leave us alone from here on out. We’ve got exams to prepare for.”

Ной [he] couldn’t agree more, but he got the feeling that he wasn’t quite done with Визен [he] quite yet.

I wonder if Ли [she] could get any use out of that key he took. I don’t think she’s going to want to go back to the Damned Plains, but I should probably let her know what’s going on.
