Chapter 404: Lizards

Everyone headed out of the Transport Cannon. Ной [he] wanted to hang back to speak with Тим [he], but he didn’t have any way to do it without coming off as suspicious. He’d have to pick the time he chose to repair the rest of the man’s runes carefully. There was a good chance someone from the Исполнители would be watching over him in the near future.

He headed off across the grass alongside Брейден [he] while the others all split off in separate directions and Тим [he] remained behind, presumably to explain that the cannon was temporarily out of commission to anyone that came by to use it.

“So,” Ной [he] said after a few seconds of walking in silence. “Now that Визен [he] managed to steal what he wanted and you don’t have anything that needs to be guarded, what’s the plan?”

“Help the Исполнители figure out what he’s doing, I suppose,” Брейден [he] said with a shrug. “Father told me to interfere with Визен [he]’s plans. I would have preferred to cut them off at the head, but I got too cocky. You were right. I should have tried to work with you,” Брейден [he] admitted with an embarrassed sigh. “I thought my Runes would let me handle whoever Визен [he] sent. I just wasn’t expecting them to have backup in the form of a healer.”

I know Space Runes are strong, but I wonder if I’ve been seriously underestimating them. Брейден [he] was able to hold off someone a whole rank above him – and he nearly won the fight. To do that without Разлом [he] or any of the other unfair advantages I have… damn. I think I know the direction my next rune is going to go in. Some form of space-related disaster, perhaps?

“You did better than anyone else in your position probably would have,” Ной [he] said. “Nobody could blame you for that. But does this mean you’re going to stop avoiding me now?”

Брейден [he] let out a snort. “Has anyone ever told you how much of a little shit you are?”

“Мокси [she] tells me all the time.”

“Never thought I’d say this, but that Торрин [he] has a good head on her shoulders,” Брейден [he] said. “And yes, I’ll be around. You lot always seem to have something interesting happening. Wouldn’t mind swinging by some of your classes to see how those kids of yours are doing. Изабель [she] and Тодд [he] were pretty interesting. They’ll be good mages one day.”

Ной [he] nodded in agreement. There was a note of awkwardness to both of them that hadn’t been there the last time they’d truly spoken, but if anything, Ной [he] was surprised it wasn’t worse. They hadn’t truly had a chance to interact ever since he’d revealed that he wasn’t actually Вермил [he] and was actually just puppeting his body around.

I’m really glad Вермил [he] was a burning piece of shit. If I’d taken the place of somebody who was actually a good man, I don’t know if I’d ever have been able to forgive myself.

“You’re more than welcome to swing by a class. The next one will be tomorrow. It might be a bit of an odd once since we normally use the transport cannon to get around. That obviously isn’t going to be happening.”

“Probably not,” Брейден [he] agreed. “I’ll come back tomorrow morning, then. Until then, there’s still some work I need to handle for Father. I’ll have to let him know what happened as well. What a bother.”

“Good luck with that. Let me know if there’s anything I can do to help. I have a way with Father.”

“A way with pissing him off, more like.” Брейден [he] snorted and shook his head. “I can handle him myself, I think.”

Fair enough.

“Good luck, then. You know where to find me. Oh – go to Мокси [she]’s room, not mine. I kind of gave mine to Контесса [he] and Карина [she].”

Брейден [he] started to nod, then froze. Confusion passed over his features as he did a double take and turned to fully face Ной [he]. “You what?”

“Oh, did you know them?” Ной [he] asked.

“Yes,” Брейден [he] said, his voice taut. “I know Карина [she]. Why in the world is she staying in your room? Did Father not let her out of the contract? I’m surprised you’re tolerating her presence.”

“Oh no, he did. I’m not entirely sure why she’s sticking around,” Ной [he] admitted, rubbing the back of his head. He shrugged. “I don’t really care, though. She and Контесса [he] seem to get along well enough. I’m already letting Контесса [he] use the room, so there’s not really a reason to complain if someone else is as well.”

“And who is Контесса [he]?”

“Мокси [she]’s handler and go-between between her and Эвергрин [she]. Well, she was. That was before Эвергрин [she] met her, ah, untimely end.”

Брейден [he]’s eyes narrowed. “I heard. The news of a Линвик [they] that just happened to be visiting Blancwood being the reason that a coup failed wasn’t as suppressed as they would have liked it to be. What a… beneficial coincidence for you and Мокси [she].”


Ной [he] just grinned. “She won’t be missed.”

“No, I don’t suppose she will be.” Брейден [he] shook his head and let out a laugh. “Sometimes it baffles me that Father tolerates you when he’s had people ripped limb for limb for doing half as much as you do. Then I remember that you somehow walk out of every situation with the upper hand. The more I learn, the less I think I actually understand.”

“That tends to be how knowledge works anyway.” Ной [he] shrugged. “Generally, I’ve just found that bullshitting through every situation ends pretty well for me. It’s an effective strategy.”

“For you, maybe.” Брейден [he] looked at Ной [he] out of the corners of his eyes. “The rest of us aren’t insane.”

“Well, you should give it a try sometimes. It seems to work pretty well. By the way – unrelated question. Is it really that hard to successfully combine Space Runes?”

Брейден [he] came to a stop and Ной [he] did the same.

“Why do you ask? Planning on trying to form some yourself?”

“I’m strongly considering it. You’re an absolute menace. I don’t think I’d try to form the exact same ones since they probably wouldn’t fit my current path, but adding space to my abilities would definitely be useful.”

“It’s a very powerful form of magic, but it’s every bit as difficult to combine as people say. Think about it this way – can you think of fire in your head? Can you picture it and what it does? What causes it, and what makes it snuff out?”

“Yeah.”

“Now do that for space. What is space?”

That… huh. I don’t think he just wants me to say something that literally just takes up space. How would one actually describe space, not something that takes up space?

Ной [he]’s brow furrowed as he thought. A few seconds passed as he dug for the words to answer Брейден [he]’s question. It was surprisingly frustrating. He knew what space was. Everyone did. And yet, despite that, he couldn’t actually find words to describe it. The harder he thought, the less he could actually explain.

“Okay,” Ной [he] admitted. “I think I see what you’re getting at. I’ve got no damn idea what space is.”

Брейден [he] chuckled. “And that’s the problem. I could tell you. It wouldn’t change much. Logically knowing something isn’t quite enough. You have to completely understand it. That’s why space runes are so difficult to form.”

“So how in the world did you figure it out?”

Брейден [he]’s grin faded. “Practice. A lot of it. Father wanted to see what would happen when someone grew up entirely focused on understanding a rune that few could completely comprehend. I’ve been learning about these runes since I was a child, but even that has only taken me so far. I’m not sure what I’ll do at higher ranks. I’m reaching my natural limit.”

Разлом [he] could help a lot with that. Even if you don’t perfectly understand what you’re doing, you could just put them together and break them over and over.

“Where do you think that limit is? Rank 5?”

“Probably. I suppose I’ll find out when I reach it. I’m not too far from forming my last Rank 4 Rune. I’ve been taking it pretty slow to ensure my understanding of everything is as extensive as possible. That said, are you still considering getting into space magic?”

“Probably,” Ной [he] said.

“I’d warn you off of it, but somehow I doubt that would do anything. Feel free to ask me if you need help with anything, but I suggest you try to test things out a bit yourself first. Buy a Rank 1 Space Rune and feel it out. If that doesn’t completely turn you away from the idea, then talk to me again.”

“I’ll take you up on that,” Ной [he] said with an appreciative nod.

Брейден [he] clapped him on the shoulder. “I don’t doubt it. Until tomorrow, then.”

“Just not too early. I’ve got a date with Мокси [she], so I’ll be busy in the morning.”

Брейден [he] snorted. “Rub it in, will you?”

Ной [he] tilted his head to the side. “Wait, are you looking for someone? I never really thought about it, but…”

“Don’t try to set me up.” Брейден [he]’s eyes narrowed. “I am more than capable of handling all aspects of my love life myself.”

“Right,” Ной [he] said. “Well, I won’t push. I don’t think I really know that many single people anyway. You could try your luck with Контесса [he] or Карина [she], but I’m not so sure–”

Брейден [he] blanched before Ной [he] could even finish the sentence. “I think I’m quite all right. I’d sooner pursue a leprosy-ridden lizard than Карина [she].”

Ouch. Cold. Not that I blame you, but cold.

“Not Карина [she], then. Well, maybe Мокси [she] knows someone.”

“I already told you that I don’t need any help in my damn love life. Go back to focusing on those space runes, will you? That’ll be a better usage of your time. Or, more accurately, you might want to try to start saving up. Space Runes aren’t cheap. I could probably part with one of mine, but–”

“No, it’s fine. You already gave Ли [she] one, and she really needed it. This is just passing fancy for me, so I don’t want to take your hard-earned energy.”

It wouldn’t feel right just constantly using Брейден [he] for free stuff. Besides, I can just wait for that bloke who bought the last Monster Rune from me to reveal himself so I can scam the bugger for another shitload of gold. That’s just as easy and it gives me time to think about what kind of rune I’d actually be making with space in it.

“If you’re sure.” Брейден [he] shrugged. “Good luck. Feel free to change your mind and let me know. It really isn’t that much of a hassle.”

“Thank you. I’ll keep that in mind. Thanks for all the information.”

“No problem. Just don’t waste too much time on this stuff until you’re completely certain it’s right for you. Space Runes aren’t rare for no reason.”

When it comes to Разлом [he], I don’t think there are a lot of Runes that can really cause me trouble. But now that Брейден [he]’s hyped these things up so much, I think I’ve got no choice but to find out. I think Ли [she] actually said that she had some space runes she could share with me at some point. I’ll see if I can take her up on that.

Ной [he] nodded. “I’ll keep that in mind. Until tomorrow, then?”

“Tomorrow.” Брейден [he] raised a hand in farewell and headed off toward the center of campus while Ной [he] made for the T building to meet back up with Мокси [she].

Space Runes were important, but there was a more pressing matter that had to be handled first. He had to find out how to explain to Мокси [she] that he’d somehow managed to get into a fight with one of Визен [he]’s people just hours after heading off without her.
==========
Chapter 405: The Groundbreaking Question

“Well,” Ной [he] said as Мокси [she] stared at him over the top of her book, “at least you don’t need to try to figure out what Визен [he] was after anymore.”

She let out a mixture between a long-suffering sigh and a laugh. Shaking her head, Мокси [she] closed the book and tossed it onto her bed. “How do you do this? Are you cursed? Do you just have a nose for trouble and a burning desire to follow after it?”

“I wanted to see where Тим [he] went.”

“And so logically your first thought was to break into restricted Арбитраж [he] property.” Мокси [she] burst into laughter. “I suppose that tracks. It sounds like it’s a good thing you did. Nobody was seriously injured other than Барба [she]?”

“Yeah. Брейден [he] and Тим [he] are both okay. It didn’t look like Барба [she] was trying to kill Тим [he] and Брейден [he] had some nasty cuts but nothing too significant. He basically shrugged all of them off when we walked out of the tower. They weren’t anything a healing potion won’t handle.”

Мокси [she] rose from her chair and ran a hand through her hair. “And the artifact that Визен [he] was after… a key to the Damned Plains?”

“Yeah. I couldn’t even begin to hazard a guess as to what he wants with it. There’s no way he’s after the same thing that Father was with when he tried to summon Азель [he] and got me instead, right?”

“If he was, this would be the absolute worst way to go about it. There are much easier methods to summon demons,” Мокси [she] said. “Such as the one that Father had Вермил [he] try. Вермил [he] only barely screwed up. If he’d been more competent or actually knew anything about demons, there’s a decent chance he might have pulled it off.”

“I was thinking something along the same lines. It doesn’t really make sense to get a whole ass key straight to the depths of hell just to go knocking on the door of a random demon to ask them to come help out,” Ной [he] said. He hesitated for a moment as a disturbing thought struck him. “Unless Визен [he] is after a demon that’s too powerful to summon normally?”

“That could be a possibility. I don’t know why he’d even bother with something like that, though. It seems like an enormous amount of overkill. If he needs the key to speak to the demon in the first place, chances are the demon will be stronger than him – and all Визен [he] will get for his efforts is killed.”

They were both silent for several seconds. Then Ной [he] clapped his hands against his knees and cleared his throat as he rose to his feet.

“Whelp. At least we know one thing.”

“And that is?”

“He probably doesn’t care about you anymore.”

Мокси [she] burst into laughter. “You really do have a one-track mind on certain issues, don’t you?”

“Yes.”

“Are you not even slightly concerned about the greater effects of this? If Визен [he] is completely insane, he could be planning to just release all the demons in the Damned Plains into the mortal realm or something like that. I mean, that seems ridiculous, but who knows. He could want anything.”

“I don’t feel like that’s his goal. Who knows. I could be wrong – but Визен [he] strikes me as someone with a plan. I don’t think he’s just trying to destroy things for the sake of it. Барба [she] was… fairly decent, actually.”

Мокси [she]’s brow furrowed and she tilted her head to the side. “Decent? What’s that mean?”

“She didn’t seem insane. Or evil, for that matter. She was just determined. I mean, she never tried to hurt Тим [he] even though she could have probably used it against us. The only time she did anything that could have hurt him was when she basically blew the entire room up to buy herself time to get away.”

“You’re saying you don’t think she’d be working with Визен [he] if he was a madman? You haven’t forgotten the part with the mind control runes, have you?”

“No, of course not,” Ной [he] said. He rubbed his chin. “But you remember how Александра [she] was, don’t you? She was forced to be there. It was clear she didn’t have a choice. Барба [she] was completely in control. It was voluntary.”


“Interesting,” Мокси [she] said. She rocked back in her chair and drummed her fingers against her knee. “That isn’t really complete proof that Визен [he] isn’t insane, but I see where you’re going with it. It doesn’t change the fact that Визен [he] now has an immensely powerful artifact that could do a lot of damage.”

“Oh, definitely not,” Ной [he] agreed. “But it does mean he’s probably not going to bother us in the near future. We’ll probably have to work on getting rid of him once the Исполнители actually find something marginally useful to work with, but at least we won’t be getting jumped by puppets in the middle of the night – or whatever else it is that Визен [he] would have done to get the information he wanted from you.”

“That’s true.” Мокси [she] let a small smile cross her lips. “All we had to do was let him make off with an important artifact. Though, to be fair, Арбитраж [he] were the idiots keeping it sitting around almost completely undefended. What were they thinking?”

“Probably that the best defense was being forgotten,” Ной [he] said. “Did you find any information about a key while you were looking through artifacts?”

“No. Granted I wasn’t looking for anything along those lines, but it certainly wasn’t somewhere easy to find.”

“Брейден [he] only found it shortly before Барба [she] showed up, and I suspect he didn’t do it entirely as legally as he made it sound. It sounds like Арбитраж [he] went through a lot of steps to try and make sure it was forgotten,” Ной [he] theorized. “Not that I’m saying that was the best way to store something that powerful, but it gives me a slightly different thought. Maybe we’re thinking about things the wrong way. What if it isn’t that Арбитраж [he] is keeping its best artifacts just sitting around relatively undefended, but…”

“That wasn’t their best artifact at all,” Мокси [she] finished. She ran a hand through her hair and blew a puff of air out from her lips. “Shit. It makes sense, but that’s pretty concerning. It would definitely explain a lot. You think Арбитраж [he] is holding onto a ridiculous amount of powerful artifacts and the key was basically overflow?”

“That’s the only thing that comes to mind. Maybe stuff that was made before the – what was the event where the super strong Great Monsters showed up and caused the Bastions to be made?”

“The Long Night.”

“Yeah. What if they’ve got a bunch of stuff from before the Long Night stored away in Арбитраж [he]? That could be why it’s such a shit school. It’s not really meant to be a school at all. If they’ve actually got a ton of weapons and stuff, the school might just be a front to keep idiots from trying to steal things.”

“Having noble families send their students here would also be a good way to make sure none of them tried to make a move on everything,” Мокси [she] mused, her face losing a shade of color. “The kids aren’t here for training. They’re collateral.”

“How is it that I dislike this place more the more I learn about it?” Ной [he] asked.

“We don’t know for sure that we read it right,” Мокси [she] said, starting to pace around the room. “We could just be making things up. We’re drawing quite a bit from just a single piece of information.”

“I don’t think hunting around to find more would be very wise. It seems like a good way to get on Арбитраж [he]’s shit list.”

“Визен [he] would probably know. If he found out about the key, then I bet he’d know if there was more.”

Ной [he] shot Мокси [she] a sharp look. “You’re spending too much time with me if you’re starting to think we should approach him and ask for advice.”

“I wasn’t thinking that. But when we inevitably do run into him again while trying to take the key back, it can’t hurt to ask. Wasn’t he pretty talkative in the fight against Сильвертид [he]?”

“That’s a good point,” Ной [he] allowed, some of the tension leaving his shoulders. “Yeah, he was. And speaking of which, Сильвертид [he] might know something as well. He strikes me as someone who has a good grasp of things behind the scenes.”

“You can ask him before the meeting with the enforcers, maybe?”

“It got pushed off until day after tomorrow, but yeah – I’ll ask him then.”

Мокси [she]’s pacing finally came to a stop beside her bed. She picked up the book she’d tossed onto it and moved it back to her desk.

“That works. Honestly I don’t even know what I’d do with the information if we had it. I’ve just been starting to wonder what Арбитраж [he] actually offers. I’m hoping the продвинутая группа will start providing more value than trying to attack us randomly.”

“I reckon we’ll find out tomorrow night with the next meeting, but I’m in agreement. It feels like the only thing Арбитраж [he] has provided is housing and exams that we could do ourselves. It’s not like they’re even giving us resources – though the продвинутая группа has mentioned that’s on the table. We should focus on making sure everyone is ready to handle that first exam coming up so they perform well against the other продвинутая группа students.”

A grin passed over Мокси [she]’s face and she held back a laugh. “Can you imagine the looks on their faces if our students completely walk all over the kids that have been in the продвинутая группа for a while longer?”

“I’d much prefer to see it in person than imagine,” Ной [he] replied. “We’ll have to scope out what we’re up against tomorrow night – but that’s a problem for tomorrow night.”

“Which implies there’s something more important that we have to deal with first?” Мокси [she] tilted her head to the side. “I don’t really need any more groundbreaking revelations today, but now you’ve got my curiosity. What is it?”

“We have a date tomorrow, and I haven’t figured out where you wanted to eat.”
==========
Chapter 406: Chairs

As it turned out, Мокси [she] hadn’t really considered where they were going to eat either. The pair of them spent about twenty minutes trying to figure out somewhere to go get food before they both promptly gave up and decided it could be handled the following day.

There would be class tomorrow, so the most important thing to handle for the time was letting all the students know that it would be slightly delayed. There was a brief instant where Ной [he] wondered if he was meant to feel marginally guilty for delaying class purely so he could go on a date with his girlfriend.

He dismissed that notion. There was no point to have power if you didn’t abuse it. That was where all the fun came in. And it wasn’t like the students would be alone. Ли [she] was going to be bored while he and Мокси [she] were out, which meant there were likely some stretching sessions with the students’ names written in blood on them.

Ной [he] and Мокси [she] didn’t have any trouble letting everyone know about the delay. They didn’t mention the reason, but chances were that the kids had figured it out considering that both of their teachers were both suddenly planning a delay at the exact same time.

After their brief stint around campus, they returned to their room. It was still relatively early in the evening. There were several hours left before night fell, which left them with two options. Either they could sit around and try to brainstorm where they were going to get food tomorrow, or they could do quite literally anything else.

“If we’ve got a few hours with nothing happening, it feels like now might be a pretty good time for me to try and get some help with my pattern,” Мокси [she] said. “It’s kind of hard to encapsulate it with just motions. Do you think we’d be able to use a Mind Meld potion so I can show you what I’m doing in an area where I can’t accidentally risk blowing anything up?”

“That’s a good idea,” Ной [he] said. He reached into his bag and frowned. “I’ve only got one left right now, though. Do you–”

Мокси [she] pulled a blue vial out of her own bag. “Have one.”

“Nice. Good thinking.”

He set his bag down and sat down on her bed, moving over to the back to make room for Мокси [she]. She followed suit, but followed after him and wasted all the space he’d left. Мокси [she] scooted up until her back was pressed to his chest and her hair was tickling his nose.

“Ready?” Мокси [she] asked, popping the seal off the potion.

Ной [he]’s reply was lost in a cough as her hair got into his mouth. She snickered and drank her half of the potion before handing it over her shoulder to him. He craned his neck back to free himself from the prison of red hair for just long enough to remove the second seal and pour the potion down his throat.

He set the vial down and wrapped his arms around Мокси [she], holding her as a familiar buzzing enveloped his mind. A blanket of darkness rushed up and swallowed him whole, and then he was flying.

A few moments later, Ной [he] found himself standing in the forest of Мокси [she]’s soul. He shook off the last effects of the potion as the vines beneath him twisted up into a chair and pushed themselves into his legs, forcing him to sit.

Мокси [she] stepped out from behind him, a twisting knot of vines in her hands. She held it up, then paused as a thought struck her.

“Wait. We can shape our souls pretty much how we want to as long as we don’t go against anything core to us, but there’s no way the pattern could somehow damage me from within, is there?” Мокси [she] asked.

“I… don’t think so,” Ной [he] said slowly. He wasn’t quite so certain that he’d bet on it. Magic had some odd effects, but he couldn’t recall ever getting soul damage from anything other than death or splitting runes. “You should be fine. If worse comes to worst, I’ll just use the Fragment of Возрождение [she] to patch you up. Realistically, any soul damage you take is actually safer than normal damage. I can only heal the former.”

“Good point. In that case, I’m going to start. My pattern is growth, right?”

“Are you asking me or telling me?” Ной [he] asked, trying to keep the teacher from entering his voice and failing miserably. Мокси [she]’s eyes narrowed and a vine coiled at Ной [he]’s elbow, poking at his side threateningly.

“Don’t make me waste the potion tickling you. Vines are really good at it,” Мокси [she] warned. “And I have enough money to blow on another potion.”

“Okay, okay,” Ной [he] said with a laugh. “Go on, then. Show me.”

Мокси [she] held the ball of twisting plant matter in her palms up. He wasn’t actually sure if the ball was something she could form in the normal world – it was just spinning above her palm like a little planet.


“This is basically what I want to do,” Мокси [she] said, answering Ной [he]’s question before he could even ask it.

She held the ball up and vines erupted from it. They rushed out like a wave, falling over each other in their haste to erupt into the sky and blanket out the sun. Midway through the explosion, they froze.

Ной [he] squinted up at the vines. It only took him a few moments to see what Мокси [she] was trying to do. There were patterns in the literal growth. Every vine in the deluge had its own purpose and was acting like a line within a rune.

It was… painfully complex. When it was still, there was no problem. The issue was that Мокси [she]’s vines were all moving at once. If she wanted to completely bring this pattern under her control, she’d need to be able to control every single one of them at once.

“This is… a lot,” Ной [he] said slowly.

“Yeah,” Мокси [she] said. “You see my problem?”

“I see why you aren’t trying this in the real world,” Ной [he] said with a nod. He chewed his lower lip. “What have you been doing to practice the pattern without magic?”

“I’ve mostly been doing this,” Мокси [she] admitted. “The problem is that growth in the real world is ridiculously slow. I spent some time accelerating the growth of random plants to see how they grew, but the problem is that I don’t just want growth. I want to make the growth into a Formation itself.”

Ной [he] walked in a circle around the frozen canopy of vines. Мокси [she] was clearly serious about this. Even if it was just in her head, he wasn’t finding any issue in the actual shapes and lines that she’d formed with the vines.

There was definitely a pattern in them. There was no denying that. Ной [he] was somewhat sure that even if Мокси [she] brought this out and tried to do something similar, as long as she did it like this, it would work.

He just didn’t know what would happen if she put magic into it. There was a subtle but significant difference between what she was aiming for and what the others were doing. They were putting magic into a nonmagical pattern.

She was using magic to make the pattern and would then be putting magic into it again. It was functionally skipping an entire step. Ной [he] would have preferred to tell Мокси [she] that she needed to find an intermediatory, but the issue arose in choosing what that would be.

She’s right. Growth is really slow. She can accelerate it with her magic, but everything about her plants is inherently magical. It’s not like Мокси [she] can just carry around a flower on her shoulder and ask her opponent to wait a month for it to bloom when she’s fighting.

“You haven’t made this easy on yourself,” Ной [he] observed.

“I’ve never been one for easy things, but I’d rather not waste time if you think it’s completely impossible.”

“It’s not impossible,” Ной [he] said. “Just difficult. I suppose I should start by asking where exactly it is you are in terms of the pattern and what you’re most worried about. Then I can give my thoughts after that.”

Мокси [she] waved her hand and the vines vanished. The ground beneath her feet rose up into a chair and she sat down. Ной [he] headed over to his own chair, then changed course and headed over to Мокси [she] to pull her to her feet. She sent him a confused look for a second as he took her spot.

“What are you–”

Ной [he] pulled her back down to sit in his lap. “Okay. Now you can talk.”

“You’re so cheesy,” Мокси [she] said as she leaned back into him. She made absolutely no moves to get up. “There are a few problems. The first is that I don’t know what’ll happen if I try to make a pattern with magic plants. Will it have a chance to blow up?”

“It should actually be pretty safe,” Ной [he] said. “Your runes can only do a single thing at once, and you can only use one rune at a time. For once, that’s actually useful. If you’re using your magic to make plants, the pattern will literally only be a pattern.”

“Well, shit.” Мокси [she] said with an embarrassed laugh. “I’m an idiot. I didn’t think about that. Maybe I’m spending too much time around you.”

“If that was true, you would have tried it and ended up blowing yourself up somehow anyway.”

“Oh, yeah. That probably would have been more likely. So I can try to make a pattern with the plants and it should be fine.”

“Yeah. You might want to be careful with your Master Rune, though. If you end up letting magic slip out of that and into the pattern – you’ve got the same issue. Granted, you don’t have it Imbued into your soul so I don’t think that should be possible, but be aware of it.”

“Okay. That leads me to the second question. Let’s say I manage to get the pattern out of the plants – growth logically means I have to keep getting bigger. Does that mean I’d have to keep an enormous number of vines all in the exact same shape and continue to constantly add more of them if I want to keep the pattern going?”

“Depends on your view of growth, probably,” Ной [he] said after a few seconds of thought. “But that seems possible. Maybe you could try to add a second half to the pattern?”

“A second half?”

“Yeah. Something to temper the growth, like a cycle. Cycles are patterns. A while ago you told me that you like flowers. Could you try to go for the whole life cycle of the flower as your pattern rather than just the part where it gets bigger?”

“Like from where it sprouts as a seed to where it dies?”

“Exactly. I don’t really know if that fits what you were thinking, but it’s got growth in it. It would let you have a pattern that has some elements of what you wanted without having to worry about it getting out of hand.”

“You think that would work? Just a flower?”

“I mean, simple isn’t bad. Flowers are nice – and I can already think of some pretty nasty combinations you could do with a full life cycle if you can really find a way to boil that down into a pattern and eventually a Formation.”

“Me too,” Мокси [she] said. Her voice drifted away as she lost herself in her thoughts for a second. She twisted so that she was sitting sideways in Ной [he]’s lap. “Well, damn it. I’m going to need to completely change the way I think about this. I think it’ll go a lot faster this time around though.”

“Well, you’ve got like… twenty-five minutes left in the potion.”

“Yeah, but I’ve got other plans for those now. You should have stayed in your chair.” Мокси [she] flashed Ной [he] a grin.

It didn’t take him long to decide that he most certainly did not regret stealing her chair.
==========
Chapter 407: Specific Type Of Charm

The effects of the Mind Meld potion soon wore off, returning Ной [he] and Мокси [she] to their room. They were still alone, which was something of a surprise. Ли [she] must have been out doing something – most likely running pest control on the entirety of Арбитраж [he]’s ecosystem.

That was something of a disappointment. Ной [he] had hoped to talk to Ли [she] about the key, but he suspected they’d see her before the next class. Nothing was going to happen with Визен [he] in the next day or two, so he decided to let it lie.

It was late enough in the day that it was justifiable to avoid trying to do anything else so long as nobody thought about it too hard, so he and Мокси [she] remained in bed to wait out the night. They also – very pointedly – did not attempt to figure out what they would be doing tomorrow morning.

That seemed like all too much effort, and it could be handled by their future selves.

The night passed and the sun rose once more. Rays of light crawled through their window and warmed the plant bed, pulling both of them out of their sleep like a nagging mother. Ной [he]’s nose scrunched and he blinked as he slipped back into the land of the living.

Мокси [she] laid on top of him, her face against his chest. She sent a glare up at the sun. “It’s morning.”

“We could pretend it isn’t,” Ной [he] offered, but they were both already sitting up.

They both took a short while to prepare for the day. It was a little too early to say much else. Reconvening in the center of the room, Ной [he] and Мокси [she] both turned to look out the window again.

“You know, we probably should have figured out where we were going to get food yesterday,” Мокси [she] said.

“Probably.”

“You might be rubbing off on me.”

“Probably.”

They looked at each other again.

“Want to just get some meat pies?” Ной [he] offered.

Мокси [she] grinned. “Sounds better than sitting around in a restaurant this early in the morning. We’d get so many looks.”

“You know, I always tend to get a lot of looks.”

“That’s because everyone still thinks you’re a pervert. It’s going to take a while for that reputation to fall away,” Мокси [she] said, laughing at the peeved expression on Ной [he]’s face. “It’s fine. The people that matter know. Who cares about the rest?”

“Good point,” Ной [he] said with a nod. “Let’s go get some pies.”

***

“Admit it. That was cute,” Возрождение [she] said.

Декрас [he] eyed the bowl of chocolate on the table between them. His hand snaked out, but Возрождение [she] grabbed the bowl and lifted it before he could reach in. His eyes narrowed in annoyance.

“Stop being a brat. Let me at the food.”

“It’s mine. Admit it was cute and you can have some.”

Декрас [he] rolled his eyes. “I will admit that it was cute in the same way that watching two small furry animals can be amusing. Satisfied?”

Возрождение [she] smirked and lowered the bowl and let Декрас [he] take a piece of chocolate from it. Her expression flickered a second later as she properly registered the words that her fellow god had said.

“Hold on. You think small animals are cute?”

“I am not completely inhumane, Возрождение [she].”

“By definition, you quite literally are.”

“Look at you. A loving goddess of reincarnation, judging by outward appearance.” Декрас [he] kicked his feet back on a black stool that formed before him and he rocked back in his chair, arching an eyebrow at Возрождение [she]. “You should be ashamed of yourself.”

“There’s no outward appearance being taken into account here.” Возрождение [she] crossed her arms. “Your body was literally reforged – inside and out – by your Divine Rune. There isn’t a single mortal or humane part of you left. I’m not even so sure you started off as a human in the first place.”

“And you may never find out,” Декрас [he] said. He waved a hand at the screen. “They’re just eating now. I don’t find that nearly amusing enough to watch, but they’ve already got themselves into quite the situation. Pull someone else up.”

“What am I, a glorified playwright?” Возрождение [she] asked, but she sent a command to the glowing image. It rippled. Ной [he] and Мокси [she] faded from it as the colors shifted to a forest. Ferdinand and Гарина [she] sat on a blanket in the forest, a wicker basket in front of them. Their shoulders were just barely close enough to touch as they ate and watched the scenery.

“When I said pull someone else up, I was hoping you’d show me the little demon girl or someone who actually has their motivations in order,” Декрас [he] said wearily. He gestured vaguely at the screen. “Is this the only thing you care about?”


“Yes,” Возрождение [she] said. She paused for a moment, then amended her statement. “Well, I also care about getting my hands on whatever it is Ной [he] knows about my Rune that I don’t – but that can come when it comes. I’ve got all the time in the world, and he’ll keep improving upon it in the meantime.”

“You know what?” Декрас [he] asked rhetorically. “I think you’re a bit lazy.”

“And I think you’re more than a bit rude.”

“I suspect we may both be correct.”

Возрождение [she] let out a snort of laughter before she could stop herself. She clapped a hand over her mouth. Encouraging Декрас [he] to be an asshole was probably the absolute worst thing she could have done, but it was too late. He just arched an eyebrow in her direction.

You win this round.

“You can’t tell me that you aren’t at least a little bit jealous,” Возрождение [she] said with a nod to the screen.

“Of that ? They can barely even look each other in the eye,” Декрас [he] said. “Тим [he]e may have become of marginal worth to me, but Гарина [she] is ancient by mortal standards, and your bald priest isn’t all that much younger. How would I be jealous of that?”

“Okay, they might be a little bit stunted in a few social aspects,” Возрождение [she] admitted. She rose from her chair and let out a slow sigh. “But that’s not what I meant. They’re doing what they want to. Ferdinand left the church, even if he hasn’t done it officially yet. When they find out, they’re going to try to kill him.”

“They are not strong enough to kill Гарина [she],” Декрас [he] said flatly. “Unless your avatar makes a move, he will live. She is fiercely possessive of her belongings.”

“He’s a man, not an object,” Возрождение [she] said idly. She walked to the edge of the glistening pink platform they stood on and looked out on the endless void stretching in every direction around them.

“To Гарина [she], there is no difference. She has gone through some surprising growth, but I know her,” Декрас [he] said. “The things she cares about belong to her and she’ll never give them up. Even if I showed up myself to demand Ferdinand’s head, she’d spit in my face.”

“That seems like a respectable feature to me.”

“I never said it wasn’t. I liked her for a reason,” Декрас [he] said with a throaty laugh. He dismissed the stool and rose as well, walking to stand beside Возрождение [she]. “But I assume you were referring to the fact that they are making a choice that they both know will put them at great risk.”

Возрождение [she] nodded. “That’s the fun part about being mortal. Risk. Choice. All the things that I’ve complained about not being able to do for the entire time you’ve been here. I know you’re going to say I can just do what you do – but be honest with me for a moment. Do you really have that much more control? Or are you skirting the rules whilst still obeying their exact lettering?”

Lips formed into a thin line, Декрас [he] shook his head. “I think you know the answer to that. I am still walking around in this portion of the universe. That would not be possible if I was completely breaking the laws we have placed upon us. I am bold but not stupid. The safest way to achieve what you desire is to slowly gather power and then advance when the order allows it.”

“Right. Millenia upon millennia of nothing, only to inch our way up the grand scale and achieve… what, exactly?”

The lines of souls twinkled beneath them, and Возрождение [she]’s eye traced their golden paths. A near infinite number of mortal souls, all on an endless journey. Most of them would return to the place beyond time over and over again, never to become anything more.

She could see into their past lives – and the ones that had come before that. They were laid bare before her, as clear as glass.

A few would achieve minor success. They’d lived hundreds or thousands of years – only to arrive right back here.

Some had been more. Upon occasion, Возрождение [she]’s eye would fall upon someone where she could only see herself. A section of their memories was like a mirror, the power within them once lost but still enough to prevent her from peering deeper.

Gods. Some stronger than her, some weaker. They too rejoined the line when their time came, though it was rare. Anything that could kill a God generally didn’t leave enough of them behind to let them come back.

That was the fate of those who went against the laws. A return to the beginning if one was lucky – and infinite nothing if they weren’t. Возрождение [she]’s fists tightened at her sides. Between that and utter boredom, she couldn’t tell which was worse.

“Are you genuinely considering taking the chance to rejoin that?” Декрас [he] asked, nodding to the line below them. “Fights are one thing. I love them. It gives me something to do to pass the time. I’d be more than happy to entertain in that regard.”

“I don’t see the value in fighting for no reason,” Возрождение [she] said, not pulling her gaze away from the line. “I prefer it to have a purpose. To have a way to actually change something. If a fight ends and nothing is different, was there even a point?”

Декрас [he] didn’t respond to that. They both stood in silence. It was hard to tell for exactly how long they did that – the passage of time was a shaky thing at best when it functionally didn’t even exist in the void around them.

Finally, Декрас [he] broke the stillness.

“I think you might want to change the image to something else. They’re holding hands. I don’t know why, but it makes me feel like I’m seeing something I shouldn’t.”

Возрождение [she] let out a bark of laughter. She snapped her fingers and the image flickered, swapping over to Ли [she] just as the tail of an unfortunate squirrel vanished between her lips. She slipped into the shadows at the base of the tree she stood in, reappearing down the road before zipping off in the direction of the transport cannon.

“Better?” Возрождение [she] asked with a wry smile.

“Somehow, yes,” Декрас [he] replied. He paused for a moment before letting out a low chuckle. “Say that girl somehow had our power. What do you think she’d do in this situation? Faced with neigh guaranteed death or boredom, which would she–”

“She’d never have paused for long enough to even consider boredom, I think,” Возрождение [she] said.

They both looked back to Ли [she]. She’d found the students waiting in the shadow of the transport cannon and was sneaking through the darkness toward them, a devious grin on her face.

“I suspect you might be correct,” Декрас [he] said. “Maybe there is more to learn from mortals than I believed.”

He turned and walked back to his chair, sitting down and crossing his legs. Возрождение [she] followed him back and looked up to the screen. Ли [she] wasn’t quite as fun to watch as Ной [he] and Мокси [she] were, but she certainly had her charm.

Ли [she] sprung from the shadows, drawing a round of surprised curses and yelps from the students.

“I’m here!” Ли [she] proclaimed. “And class today is stretches.”

“…that’s it?” Тодд [he] asked weakly. “No sparring, or…”

“Nope. All stretches. You can spar once you’re flexible.”

A shudder ran down Возрождение [she]’s spine as she pulled an arm across her chest to check just how flexible her own body was – something told her the results wouldn’t have pleased Ли [she].

A very specific type of charm.

Chapter 408: It'S Тодд [he]in Тим [he]e

It took Ной [he] and Мокси [she] a little while to figure out where Ли [she] had taken the students. After their date – which consisted mostly of sitting and chatting on her bed while eating meat pies – had ended, they’d hurried off to the transport cannon.

There was nobody there. It was odd to see the area completely empty. Ropes had been put up around the base of the cannon to keep anyone from trying to ascend it. The cannon was their normal meetup location, but it obviously wasn’t much use if nobody could actually go anywhere with it.

The two professors had directed their attention to the nearest restaurants, but to their surprise, none had seen Ли [she] or their small class. That had been quite the problem. Арбитраж [he] was a huge area and there were countless different locations that everyone could have gone.

Ной [he] dug through his memories in search of where Ли [she] might have taken the kids, stumbling into a thought nearly on accident. They changed courses and hurried over to the arena. It had been so long since Ной [he] had been there that he’d nearly forgotten about its existence.

The last time he’d come had been just shortly after he’d first met Изабель [she] and Тодд [he] and they were showing him their abilities. It wasn’t really a private training area, but it seemed like it might have fit the bill.

And, sure enough, as they stepped out onto the sand and scanned over the sparse groups scattered across it, Ной [he] caught a flash of Эмили [she]’s telltale silver hair. Their entire group had taken over a small portion at the far side of the arena and were flopped out in every direction like drying leather.

“I think Ли [she] might have decided that today was a stretching session,” Ной [he] said as they walked over to join the others.

“When does she not?” Мокси [she] asked with a shudder.

Тодд [he] pried his head up from the sand, relief shining in his eyes as he spotted Ной [he] and Мокси [she] approaching. He rolled over with a groan and pushed himself upright.

“We’re free, guys.”

“Free from what?” Ли [she] asked. “Do you know how many muscles there are in the human body?”

“No,” Тодд [he] said.

“Neither do I, but I’ve been counting,” Ли [she] said. “And I’m pretty sure you haven’t stretched all of them yet. You don’t want to be lopsided, do you?”

“Just a question. Do you think bones are muscles?” Изабель [she] groaned from beside Тодд [he]. “Because they aren’t.”

“Anything is a muscle if you try hard enough.”

“I’m not so sure that’s how it works,” Ной [he] said, tussling Ли [she]’s hair. “Thanks for covering for us, though.”

“No problem. I can finish class today. We just have a few more things to stretch.”

The panic in everyone’s eyes was so intense that Ной [he] couldn’t even bring himself to make a joke about it. “That’s kind of you to offer, but we’ve got some other stuff we need to cover before tonight.”

“Tonight? What’s tonight?” Александра [she] asked.

“Another продвинутая группа meeting,” Ной [he] replied, sitting down in the sand and crossing his legs beneath him. “A real one, this time around. I imagine we want to make a good impression.”

He thought back to the first meeting. Ли [she] had certainly made an impression with his body, all right. She’d eaten just about everything on the table, silverware included. He repressed a sigh.

“As good of an impression as we can still salvage.”

“Does our reputation matter? All that matters is outperforming them so we can get the resources,” Александра [she] said.

“You’re not wrong, but this is an opportunity to do what we wanted to do the first time around,” Мокси [she] said, crossing her arms in front of her chest. “And that is to check out what the students of the other professors are capable of. Take their measure.”

“Invisible dick measuring contest,” Тодд [he] concluded.

Мокси [she] rolled her eyes. “That’s one way to put it, sure. Whatever the reason. We want to see if these idiots are actually worth our time and what they’re capable of. Don’t forget we know very little about them. Just because the rest of Арбитраж [he] is a little bit pathetic on average doesn’t mean they will be.”

“Do you really think they’ve got anyone stronger than Александра [she]?” Джеймс [he] asked. “I mean, she’s a Rank 3. That’s the same as a few professors.”


Now that I think about it, didn’t Ревин [he] claim to be a Rank 3? Hm. You know what? I’m not so sure I buy that. Now that I know more about Formations… well, I haven’t seen him since reaching Rank 4. I suppose I’ll find out if we run into each other and I can tell he’s got a domain.

“Don’t overestimate me,” Александра [she] said. “I have Body Runes. Even if I win in certain circumstances, I’m at a severe disadvantage against anyone that can keep me at a range. I don’t have a way to attack anyone outside the reach of my sword.”

“You could throw it,” Джеймс [he] offered.

“And then I would have no sword.”

“Tie a string to it?” Тодд [he] added in.

Александра [she] took a page out of Мокси [she]’s book and rolled her eyes. “Thank you, guys. I’ll strongly consider tying a string to the hilt of my sword so I can fling it at anyone who isn’t kind enough to come into its range.”

“You’re welcome,” Джеймс [he] said without a hint of shame. He yawned, then pushed himself upright. “So what are we doing in class today? More patterns?”

Ной [he] looked around the arena. It wasn’t exactly a discreet area. There were other students, some alone and some in groups, milling about. Practicing patterns or Formations here was going to be a little too exposed. Even if nobody was too close to them right now, it could end up drawing more attention than he wanted to get.

That was unless they changed what the others could see.

“I don’t want people looking at us while we practice anything even slightly unique,” Ной [he] said. “Изабель [she], do you think you could…”

She picked up on Ной [he]’s line of thinking before he finished the sentence and rolled to her feet. Изабель [she] pressed her hands to the sand and a faint tremor ran beneath Ной [he]’s feet. An eight-foot-high wall of stone jutted up behind him, curving overhead. Several more walls rose up in succession, making a barrier that blocked out anyone’s view of the section of the arena they were in.

It was the exact same strategy they’d used in the Windscorned Plateau to make sure they didn’t accidentally draw the scorn of too many Fluffants at the same time. Ной [he] gave her an approving nod.

“Perfect. Thank you, Изабель [she].”

“Why didn’t we do that before?” Тодд [he] asked.

“Because nobody in their right mind is going to get near Ли [she] when they see what she’s doing to us,” Изабель [she] replied. “It was a more effective deterrent than anything I could ever do.”

“Another benefit of stretching,” Ли [she] proclaimed proudly. “It is a multifaceted activity with an ever-growing range of positive aspects.”

Is she trying to pitch it to a company or something? Now that I think about it, Ли [she] would make a great motivational speaker. One of those people that shows up to the schools and tells all the teachers that there’s one quick trick they can do to improve their days. It’s just that her trick is borderline shattering every bone in your body in a stretch that really shouldn’t even be possible.

Somehow I do always feel better after her stretching sessions, though. Just… not better enough to voluntarily do one.

“Well then,” Ной [he] said, coughing into a fist and shaking his head to draw himself back to the matter at hand. “I should bring you all up to speed on some stuff that happened recently.”

Тодд [he]’s eyes flicked from Ной [he] to Мокси [she]. “You mean why you and Мокси [she] were late? We kind of figured that out.”

“No, not that,” Ной [he] said hurriedly. “Yesterday.”

“We really don’t need to know what–” Изабель [she] started, a small grin pulling across her lips.

“Арбитраж [he] was attacked,” Ной [he] said before Изабель [she] could finish. “The transport cannon, specifically.”

That got everyone’s attention.

“What? I heard it just broke down,” Эмили [she] said. “It was sabotage?”

“Not sabotage. It was housing an artifact. The person that was controlling all those plant puppets was behind it. For anyone not aware, his name is Визен [he]. He’s probably a Rank 6 if not stronger, and it turns out that the thing he was after this whole time was the artifact powering the transport cannon.”

“This seems like major news. If it isn’t out already, it’s being suppressed,” Александра [she] said with a frown. “Are you sure you should be telling us?”

“Yes. Understanding what you’re up against is very important. Визен [he] is powerful, but I don’t think he’ll have any more interest in us – but that’s not enough for me to make a bet on it. The item he took was a key to the Damned Plains.”

“A key? Why?” Изабель [she] asked.

“We haven’t figured that bit out yet,” Ной [he] replied. “But I want you to all be aware of it. Just make sure you’re more aware of any demonic activity of the malicious kind.”

He watched Ли [she]’s expression as he spoke, but she didn’t seem any more interested or disinterested in the key than any of the others. She had a slight worried crease in her brow and nothing more.

“Any questions?” Мокси [she] asked.

“What kind of questions are we even supposed to ask?” Эмили [she] replied. “Can we do anything about it?”

“Not really,” Ной [he] said. “Not other than working on getting stronger, that is. The Исполнители are already looking into Визен [he] and what happened. Your job is to just make sure you’re as powerful as possible to make sure that you can protect yourself when the time comes. Oh – and don’t tell anyone else. I wasn’t supposed to share this, but I’ve never really cared much for rules.”

Nobody looked even the slightest bit surprised at that.

“So the rest of today is more sparring, I take it?” Александра [she] asked.

“I’d say so, yes. Can’t ever have too much of that and it’ll also be good practice for the meeting with the продвинутая группа tonight.”

“You think we’ll be fighting?” Джеймс [he] asked.

“Who knows, but I tend to find myself fighting more often than not when meeting new people.”

“I think that speaks more to your personality than anything else,” Эмили [she] informed him.

“Thank you,” Ной [he] said without missing a beat. “Now, Тодд [he], I believe I promised you we’d have a match. Yesterday got a bit… hectic, so why don’t we start with you? I trust you’ve got your newly imbued stuff on you to show off?”

Тодд [he] grinned and held his hand up, letting the sleeve roll down to reveal a metal bracelet on his wrist. “Always.”

“Good. Let’s see what you’ve got, then.”

Chapter 409: Finding Out

Ной [he] tossed his bag and gourd to the side, then pulled the grimoire off his back and set it down beside them. He and Тодд [he] headed over to the center of the makeshift ring they’d made inside the arena and stood several paces from each other.

“What are the rules?” Тодд [he] asked. “Am I just going all out?”

“I would certainly assume so. Should I be worried about that?” Ной [he] asked. Тодд [he] had positioned himself at the edges of his domain, likely determining its range by trying to call on his magic until he felt the suppression fade. “If you are, please try to avoid catching anyone else in the crossfire.”

“Nah. I can control myself,” Тодд [he] said. He paused for a moment, then nodded. “Yeah. I can.”

“That definitely wasn’t convincing,” Ной [he] said. “What exactly are the наполнение [he]s that you’ve got on there?”

“Nothing too crazy. I wanted to keep things pretty light considering I really haven’t used them much yet. Don’t know if it’ll all go up in flames.” Тодд [he] thumbed a small red vial hanging from his belt. “Got this just in case, though.”

“I thought you said this wasn’t dangerous,” Изабель [she] said from the sidelines with a frown. “Are you sure everything is ready to test?”

“I’ve done extensive practice,” Тодд [he] said. “Александра [she] helped.”

“I’m not sure help is the word I’d use. All we did was talk,” Александра [she] said, raising her hands before herself. “And then we sparred a bit. He didn’t use any of the new наполнение [he]s.”

“Well, I can’t start using them on other students. Even if you’re a whole Rank up on me, Teacherman would have my head.”

“Correct,” Ной [he] said.

“See?” Тодд [he] shrugged, then turned back to Ной [he]. “I’m more than capable of handling my own work at this stage. Don’t worry.”

“I trust you. Come at me when you’re ready and let’s see what you’ve been working on. Just be ready to stop at the drop of a hat if something goes wrong.”

Тодд [he] held his hands up. The metal bands on his wrist glistened as he struck them together and ribbons of orange light ignited within the metal, racing throughout it in a myriad of minuscule patterns.

A dull hum rose up from the bands and Тодд [he] nodded to himself. He clicked his heels together and a grin flickered across Ной [he]’s face as a second set of hums filled the air.

Far from home, Dorothy?

Ной [he] suspected that his brilliant joke would likely be lost on everyone around him. He opted to keep it to himself. In the time it had taken him to compliment his own brilliance, Тодд [he] had formed stone armor around his arms and legs.

The rippling lines that had covered his bands expanded to trace over the stone. Molten lines glistened with power and he hopped from foot to foot before giving Ной [he] a nod.

“Okay. That was the scary part. Everything is synchronized and running properly. You ready?”

“I generally am.”

Тодд [he] didn’t wait for a second confirmation. The stone armor at his feet exploded and he bounded foreword. Flames rippled on the ground where he’d been standing as he crossed the distance between himself and Ной [he] in an instant.

Ной [he] twisted out of the side, narrowly avoiding a stone-clad fist as it whistled past his face. He dipped out of the way as Тодд [he] twisted into a spinning kick that passed narrowly over his head.

Ной [he] slammed his hand into the ground and drew on Natural Disaster, ripping a wall of stone up to cover himself an instant before the stone encasing Тодд [he]’s leg exploded with a loud crack.

He jumped back as Тодд [he]’s other fist drove into his wall. Flames roared up as the stone crumbled from the force of his blow and he sprinted through them, stone already rushing to reform around his limbs. He stood at the outside of Ной [he]’s domain until they’d gathered, then charged in again.

Clever. The Наполнения [he] are all running internally, so he can use them while in my domain. He has to form the armor outside my domain, though. But… I could have sworn the actual explosions he generated required intentional activation. How is he using them inside my domain?

Ной [he] slipped out of the way of Тодд [he]’s attacks as they ramped in speed. They weren’t quite as fast as some of his other students, but he had a unique advantage in that he didn’t actually need to hit anything. He just had to get close.

Water swirled around him and formed into a shield, catching Тодд [he]’s fist as it detonated. Fire and shrapnel bubbled through the water and it dissipated in a thick cloud of steam. Ной [he] shifted to the side as Тодд [he] launched himself through the vapors.

He’s certainly got aggression. Let’s see how he handles things when I start fighting back.


Ной [he] drove his foot into the ground and abruptly stopped backpedaling. He sent a wave of energy out through Natural Disaster right as Тодд [he]’s foot hit the ground before him. The tremor made the boy stumble and Ной [he] lunged forward, driving his palm for Тодд [he]’s chest.

Тодд [he] clapped his hands together. A brilliant wall of fire erupted from his palms and blocked off any path of attack. Ной [he] skipped back to avoid getting toasted, his eyebrows lifting as the flames curled away.

He’s got quite a bit of energy. I recall him having difficulty using this for too long. Doesn’t it require like three or four different наполнение [he]s running at all times? Interesting.

Ной [he] called on Natural Disaster and ripped a wave of jutting stones up from the ground in Тодд [he]’s direction. They ripped through the last of the flames to reveal that there was nothing behind them. Ной [he]’s eyes flicked up.

Тодд [he] was in the air. He’d used the fire as a curtain to launch himself upward. He held his hands out behind him and detonated explosions in both of his palms at the same time, launching himself toward Ной [he] like a human missile.

There was no point even trying to block an attack like that. Ной [he] launched himself out of the way and hit the ground in a roll. Another small explosion rang out as the boy’s feet slammed into the ground, sending up another curl of flame around him.

Ной [he] spun as he rose, extending his senses to the fire that Тодд [he] had just generated and ripping it from the air to send back at him. Тодд [he] had already used all four of his explosions and had yet to regenerate the armor for them yet. It was the younger man’s turn to fling himself to the side to avoid the attack.

His dive took him outside of the domain and stone formed back around his arms and legs. Ной [he] could have pressed forward to stop it from happening, but he was still trying to figure out just what it was that Тодд [he] had modified about his наполнение [he]s.

His fighting style was roughly the same. Sure, it was effective against a domain, but as far as he could tell, nothing Тодд [he] was doing was actually something that he couldn’t have done before.

Тодд [he] dashed at Ной [he] again. Drawing more moisture from the air, Ной [he] used a shield of water to catch the boy’s next strike. They slipped into a dance of blows. Nothing Тодд [he] did could quite actually land on Ной [he] beyond, but he’d still yet to figure out exactly what it was that Тодд [he] had figured out in regard to his pattern.

It’s got to have something to do with how he’s been fighting for this long. Did he find a way to optimize his наполнение [he]s? That would be powerful, but I don’t feel like it would be that dangerous either.

Тодд [he] was making it sound like he’d figured out something really significant that could be a threat if it went wrong. Maybe it’s just really difficult to optimize наполнение [he]s this well. He really is using a lot more magical energy than he used to be able to.

Ной [he] dodged another series of strikes and Тодд [he] disengaged to reform his armor once more. They’d been fighting for a few minutes now. Even though Тодд [he] hadn’t made any progress in getting closer to hitting Ной [he], there was a satisfied expression on his face. He was pleased with how the test was going.

Which means I’ve missed something entirely. He was never satisfied with mediocrity.

“Alright,” Ной [he] said, lowering his hands with a shake of his head. “That’s enough of this for now. I could kick up the heat and start pressing you harder, but there’s no point until I figure out what the hell it is that you’re doing. Why are you so smug and how do you have so much more energy than you used to?”

Тодд [he] let his own hands fall and grinned. “You noticed?”

“It’s hard not to when you could only hold up a fight for a minute at most before. You don’t even look winded or low on energy. Did you find a way to make the наполнение [he]s run a lot more efficiently?”

“No,” Тодд [he] said. “Actually, if anything, they’re even less efficient than before.”

Ной [he] squinted at him. “If that’s the case, then how were you fighting that long?”

The stone sloughed off Тодд [he]’s body and he clinked his bracelets together again. The glowing lines shut off with a dull hum and he repeated the same motion for the on his legs. “Because I figured out something far more important than efficiency. Sustainability.”

Everyone sent blank stares at him. Тодд [he] sighed.

“I found a way to renew energy in an наполнение [he], and not from killing things.”

Ной [he]’s eyes widened. “Wait. Like… indefinitely? An infinite наполнение [he]? Is that even possible?”

“No, not indefinitely. And definitely not infinite,” Тодд [he] said with a laugh. He held a wrist up and jangled the bracelet on it. “It’s two things. The first works because of the kind of наполнение [he] it is. Explosions generate a lot of energy, right? And most of that is wasted.”

“Sure,” Ной [he] said. “So you basically put in a way to absorb some of the energy that gets wasted?”

“Yeah, that’s one part of it. I can recycle a good portion of the wasted magic and that goes a pretty far way. That bit was easy, though. The hard one was finding a way to linking energy generation to nonmagical sources.”

“Тодд [he], are you trying to say that you made an наполнение [he] that generates power from something mundane?” Мокси [she] asked slowly. “Because that…”

“Isn’t possible?” Тодд [he] arched an eyebrow and grinned. “Well, it is. Energy is energy. That’s what I realized. Different types of energy, sure. But there’s a way to convert between. So I take all the energy that comes from my movements as well as the physical force of the explosion and channel a portion of that back into the наполнение [he]s on the bands and poof – it renews itself. The conversion rate isn’t perfect but I really can’t complain. I think I can push it a bit farther with some time too.”

“Shit,” Ной [he] said, shaking his head in disbelief. “That is impressive. Can it work for other applications?”

“Eventually, probably. It’s really difficult,” Тодд [he] said, rubbing the back of his head. “It took me all this time just to figure out how to convert the energy for this one specific application. It’ll probably be faster for other stuff, but I don’t know if it’ll work for anyone other than me. Not yet, at least.”

“And you used patterns to do it?”

“Yep. I can explain later, but we probably shouldn’t do it in any degree of a public setting. This isn’t something I want getting out.” Тодд [he]’s features darkened. “I know what happens to people with powerful secrets if anyone finds out about them.”

“Nobody here will be saying anything,” Ной [he] said, not even bothering to give the other student a sharp look – he trusted all of them. Nobody here would be screwing each other over. “I know I can’t help you as much as I can the others, but great job. You’ve pulled off some really impressive work.”

“Thanks,” Тодд [he] said with a grin. “Think we’ll hold up against the продвинутая группа students tonight?”

Ной [he] grinned in response. “I look forward to finding out.”

Chapter 410: Scam & Audiobook Announcement

Now that his promise to Тодд [he] had been handled for the day, Ной [he] and Мокси [she] broke the other students up into pairs to start sparing, rotating between each other once their matches were over.

“Remember not to use all your energy up,” Ной [he] warned before they got started in true. “We’ve got a meeting with the продвинутая группа later today and I want all of you to be able to absolutely crush anything that they throw at you, no matter what it takes.”

“Aren’t you supposed to be telling us to play above the board and that it’s more important that we make friends with them… or something like that?” Александра [she] asked. “I’m pretty sure that’s what a teacher is meant to support.”

Ной [he] looked down the bridge of his nose at Александра [she]. “At what point have I ever said anything like that? Friends are great. You’ve got some all around you. If you can make more, please do. But the продвинутая группа isn’t going to sit around and try to make friends. We pose a threat. Don’t forget it’s a competition.”

“Besides, from what I saw last time, they’re pretty much all a bunch of nobles.” Тодд [he] rubbed the side of his neck. “Present company excluded, I don’t have interest with associating with them unless they’re completely different from the rest of their ilk.”

“You never know,” Изабель [she] said, but she didn’t sound even slightly convinced of her own words. “It’s possible that they’ll be better because they’ve actually been the ones working for their power.”

“Probably won’t do anything to lower their elitist attitude,” Джеймс [he] said through a yawn. “Trust me. Been there, done that.”

“You have?” Эмили [she] asked.

“Ревин [he]’s had me do a lot of stuff. Much to my displeasure.” Джеймс [he]’ nose scrunched in distaste and he sighed. “Professor Вермил [he] is right. If someone there wants to make friends with us, then we can deal with it when the time comes. But until then it’s better to focus on preparing to completely crush anyone in our way. Come on. Let’s get to this already. We’re wasting time.”

“Whoa. You’re suddenly motivated. Haven’t seen that before,” Тодд [he] said. He squinted at Джеймс [he]. “Did something happen?”

“Do you realize what the продвинутая группа resources are?” Джеймс [he] asked. “Runes and power. For free. All we have to do is beat up some other kids that don’t have anywhere near the advantages we do.”

“They’re nobles. They’ll have advantages,” Александра [she] pointed out.

Джеймс [he] bit back a laugh. “Sure. But we’re us . We have all the advantages we need to handle them as long as we take things seriously. You’re a Rank 3 with Body Runes that should put you at the peak of anyone in our age group. We’ve all got patterns, even if we can’t use them with magic during fights yet.”

“I agree, but is there a reason you’re excited for resources all of a sudden?” Изабель [she] asked.

Джеймс [he] made a noticeable effort to keep his eyes from moving, but Ной [he] got the feeling that he’d been just moments from glancing at Эмили [she].

“Yeah. Three reasons. First, the faster I get work over with, the sooner I can go back to doing nothing. Second, power means I can be lazy later. If they’re going to feed me runes and just about anything else, that saves a huge amount of time in the future. I’ll do work now to be lazy in the future.”

“That’s two reasons,” Тодд [he] said.

“Is it?” Джеймс [he] sent him a blank stare. “I must have lost count.”

Careful there, bud. I think your actual goals are starting to come out. Not that I can complain. It’s going to be interesting to watch Джеймс [he] actually trying at something for once. I get the feeling he’s going to be looking to show off a bit for Эмили [she] with the продвинутая группа tonight.

I can’t believe I’m thinking this, but I really do hope there are at least a few pricks in there. If every продвинутая группа student is suddenly super welcoming and polite and none try to pick a fight, this is going to be really awkward.

“Right then,” Ной [he] said, clapping his hands together to get everyone’s attention. “We all know what we’re working for. Just remember to keep enough energy to fully regenerate by tonight. Now, get to it.”

Everyone nodded and turned back to their partners to begin preparing to spar. The stone arena that Изабель [she] had made wasn’t exactly huge, but it was enough for them to fight if nobody moved around all too much. It would be a good way to practice fighting in relatively enclosed quarters.

Ной [he] made his way over to Ли [she] while the students got started. She’d taken a seat at the edge of the wall, leaning her chin on her knees. He sat down beside her.

“All good? Are you worried about the key?”


“I don’t know. Not on a personal level,” Ли [she] replied with a shake of her head. “There have always been a lot of ways to get into and out of the Damned Plains. Not easy ones, though. Summoning is the most common, but there are pathways. Places where the energy separating the planes is thinner.”

Ной [he] nodded along. “Right. But you’re still concerned? Or are you just a bit worn out?”

“Maybe some of both,” Ли [she] admitted. “I’ve been thinking about my runes a lot.”

“Nothing’s changed, has it?” A flicker of worry passed through Ной [he] and he sat straighter, but Ли [she] quickly shook her head before he could say anything else.

“No. I’m fine.” She gave him a wide smile and bumped her shoulder into his. “Thank you. I feel like they’re under control for the time being. I’m just worried about what will happen if we get into a serious fight. The bindings might collapse if I start drawing on the runes a lot.”

“Just stay out of any major fights right now. We’ve got a lot of firepower on our side between me, Брейден [he], and Мокси [she]. Maybe even Джален [he] as well, depending on the day. You can be our secret weapon – the one that we’re not going to use until your runes are safe.”

“Yeah. I’ll do my best.” Ли [she] didn’t sound all that convinced, but it was clear she appreciated the effort. “Really, I just don’t understand why Визен [he] would want a key to the Damned Plains.”

“So you are worried.”

Ли [she] gave him a sheepish look. “A little. Who would want to go there?”

“Someone trying to deal with a demon that’s far too strong to safely summon, maybe?”

“Maybe,” Ли [she] allowed. She’d gone back to sounding completely unconvinced. “But any archdemon that powerful is just going to crush you if you can’t summon them. What’s the point? Визен [he] is either strong enough to handle them or not. The key doesn’t sound like it changes anything, so I don’t know if he’s just trying to summon something.”

“So you think he’s trying to actually get something else from the Damned Plains?”

Ли [she] shrugged. “I have no idea. I just don’t like the thought of the place at all. I never want to think about it again. That probably isn’t possible, but it would be nice. Even the idea of a passageway back to the Damned Plains stresses me out.”

“After Визен [he] is dealt with, you won’t have to,” Ной [he] said. “You’re not going back there, Ли [she].”

“Thanks.” Ли [she]’s smile strengthened. “By the way, you’ve been missing a lot of stretching lessons. Are you keeping up on your own?”

Alarm bells started going off in Ной [he]’s head and he glanced at Ли [she] out of the corners of his eyes. “Er… enough.”

“How much is enough?”

“I am a very flexible man. Some would say I am the most flexible.”

“Show me,” Ли [she] said.

“We should be watching the students right now,” Ной [he] said quickly. “The role of the teachers is to ensure they pass him, even when it means passing up on time for himself. I am willing to accept the sacrifice of falling behind if it means they advance.”

“You can stretch while they practice,” Ли [she] said. She blurred, and then she was standing behind Ной [he]. She poked at his back. “Lean forward. Touch your toes.”

Ah, fuck.

***

Ной [he] wasn’t sure how class went after that. All he knew that was, after it finished, Ли [she] had re-stretched all the parts of his body that he’d been slacking off on. She’d decided to catch up on everything he’d missed at once rather than working him back up to it.

He was pretty sure more than a few limbs would never work properly again, but he’d also never felt more limber in his life. For not the first – or the last – time, he mused that her stretches were actually quite effective.

Just… not nearly effective enough to ever do voluntarily.

He held up an arm. Even his bones felt like they’d gotten a thorough stretching. He was pretty sure they weren’t meant to feel droopy.

“Stop looking like that,” Ли [she] said. “Now you can touch your toes.”

“Anyone can touch their toes if you rip their hamstrings in the process of pushing them down,” Ной [he] informed Ли [she]. “It does feel better, though.”

“Good.” Ли [she] beamed at him, and Ной [he] spotted Тодд [he] grinning from the corner of the class. The little brat wasn’t even trying to hide his smug expression. It was probably pretty fun watching Ли [she] stretch anyone other than yourself out like a wash rag.

“Hey, I think Тодд [he] is looking a little stiff,” Ной [he] said idly.

Тодд [he]’s eyes widened. “I’ve got to go. I left the fire in our kitchen on. See you guys tonight for the продвинутая группа.”

He grabbed Изабель [she] by the wrist and darted off, using his Stone Rune to push the wall surrounding them apart like putty. Ной [he] bit back a laugh as the two of them beat a hasty retreat.

“Maybe we should all break so we can get some rest before the meeting,” Мокси [she] said. Ной [he] couldn’t help but notice she was very pointedly avoiding eye contact with Ли [she]. She hadn’t been stretching any more than he had, but someone had needed to supervise the class while they sparred.

“I think that is a splendid idea,” Александра [she] said. “I believe I had dinner plans.”

“I don’t know,” Джеймс [he] murmured, rubbing his eyes with the back of a hand and yawing. “I–”

“As did we,” Эмили [she] said, tugging Джеймс [he] to his feet before he could try to start sleeping on the ground. “See you tonight!”

She herded him out of the arena and Александра [she] followed after them, leaving just Ной [he] and Мокси [she] with Ли [she].

“We can go make sure we’re all stretched out for the meeting,” Ли [she] offered.

“I think I’d rather get food,” Мокси [she] said. “I’ll pay.”

“Okay! That’s a good idea too. You can’t fight if you aren’t on a full stomach.” Ли [she] nodded happily. “Let’s go.”

Diversion strategy. Nice. I should keep that in mind for the future.

Ной [he] walked over to the walls that Изабель [she] had erected, ignoring the twinges that ran through his legs with every movement, and pressed his palm against them. A brief thought sent a flicker of energy from Natural Disaster ripping through them and sending them crumbling back into the sand.

“Food sounds good, and it’ll give us a chance to come up with a plan.”

“A plan?” Ли [she] asked. “For what?”

“The kids aren’t going to be the only ones being evaluated. Улия [she] mentioned a good portion of the professors in the продвинутая группа think we don’t belong there,” Ной [he] said. He grinned. “And I want to see just how much we can scam them for before they realize that we do.”
