Брейден [he] nodded sagely. “Early stage Space Runes are almost useless. I don’t know why it’s so hard to use them, but that ridiculous power draw is normal. It’s like that, even for me. I just deal with it by having quite a number of them and trying to make them the highest quality I can manage.”

Damn. I was really hoping he’d have some kind of trick or pointer that would let me optimize Crumbling Space, but I guess that’s asking too much. The rune is more than powerful enough to justify its ridiculous power draw.

“So, is there a reason your students are pushing themselves so hard right now? They can’t treat every lesson like this, can they?” Брейден [he] asked.

Ной [he] looked back down just in time to catch Тодд [he] and Эмили [she] walking back to take their seats on the sand while Александра [she] and Джеймс [he] stood for the next match. It looked like Мокси [she] was keeping tabs on everything and leaving things open for him to speak with Брейден [he].

“I’d say they do. They’re all very motivated,” Ной [he] said. “Both for this particular lesson and in general.”

“What’s special about this lesson?”

“Whoever demonstrates the most improvement from when we started a training exercise a few classes ago is given a rune,” Ной [he] said.

Брейден [he] nodded his understanding. “Ah. A reward. That’s clever. Good way to get them to push, and it’s good timing. That first exam is coming up on us pretty soon. There will be a lot of eyes on their performance.”

“What do you think of their chances of winning the whole thing?”

“It’s hard to say. This is an impressive performance, but there are a lot of very talented students in the Продвинутая Группа,” Брейден [he] said slowly. “I’m very curious to see how it plays out. By the way, how did you motivate all of them with a single Rune? Do they all have one in common?”

“Oh, no. The reward is just a Master Rune.”

Брейден [he] nearly fell off the wall as he spun to Ной [he] surprise. “It’s a what ?”

Chapter 436: Celebratory Stretching

“Don’t get so worried,” Ной [he] said, raising his hands defensively and laughing. “It’s not a great Master Rune. Well, it’s pretty good, but it really doesn’t fit the direction I’m trying to progress in. If I wanted an Earth-based Master Rune, I’d look for a different one. Мокси [she] didn’t want it either, so there was no reason for us to keep it.”

“There go my chances of hoping I’d misheard you,” Брейден [he] said, rubbing the bridge of his nose and letting out a slow sigh. He looked down on the students, then back to Ной [he]. “For a moment, I thought you were giving away the Combustion Rune you spent so much effort stealing.”

“Oh, no. I’ve still got that one. Haven’t had a chance to use it much recently, but I’ve got it. This is a new one.”

“When did you get a new Master Rune?”

“Мокси [she] and I just grabbed it while we were out screwing around near Dawnforge,” Ной [he] replied with a shrug.

“And you’re just… giving it away?” Брейден [he] asked, disbelief etched into his features. “Did you charge your students a ludicrous amount to learn from you?”

“No, of course not. It’s the reward for their training.”

“You’re giving away hundreds of thousands of gold in exchange as a reward?

” Брейден [he] grabbed Ной [he] by the shoulders and squinted into his eyes. “You weren’t dropped on your head, were you?”

“I can just get another one if I need to. Rune prices are inflated,” Ной [he] waved Брейден [he]’s hands away. “Let’s be real, Брейден [he]. They’re not actually that difficult to get. Sure, the monsters are strong, but everything in regard to rune prices is fake. The nobles pumped the price up. Those kids don’t have a way to get the really strong runes, but nobles do. How is me giving them a Master Rune any different than some spoiled brat’s dad buying him all his runes?”

Брейден [he] let out a sigh and scooted back. He turned his gaze back to the students and was silent for several seconds. Then a sad smile pulled across his face and he shook his head. “The way you put that makes it seem so logical. You aren’t wrong… but that changes nothing. You’re giving away a ridiculous amount of power and gold for no reason. I’m jealous.”

“What, of the kids? You could totally kill a Great Monster and get yourself a Master Rune if you wanted to.”

“Not of the kids,” Брейден [he] said. “Of you.”

It was Ной [he]’s turn to blink in surprise. “Me? Why?”

“You view things in such sharp shades of black and white. Either you want to do it or you don’t, and you don’t care in the slightest about anything else. I suppose some could frame that as sheer dumb stupidity.”

“Thanks,” Ной [he] said dryly. “Better be careful. I’ve been told my brand of stupid is contagious.”

“That said,” Брейден [he] continued, “It feels like you live the way you want to. No fear. No overthinking about if your choices are the right ones. You just do them. Even if rune prices are inflated, what idiot would throw away hundreds of thousands of gold? Your logic is sound, but it requires literally not giving a shit about anything other than what you want.”

Ной [he] shrugged. “That really isn’t all that hard to do.”

A few thousand years waiting around in the afterlife will do wonders in reworking your views of what’s important. Money is just a way to get runes. If they need the rune and I don’t need anything at the moment, I don’t see why I wouldn’t just give it to them. If there was ever a rune I really needed to buy, I’d just go try to get funding from Отто [he]. No point sitting on a crapton of money — or a useless rune — and letting it rot.

“Harder for some than you might think,” Брейден [he] said. He chuckled and pushed himself up to his feet to stand at the top of the wall. “It’s rather funny. If I hadn’t known that you’d killed Вермил [he] and taken his body, this conversation would have revealed it.”

“He could have just become very altruistic.” Ной [he] craned his neck back to look up at Брейден [he]. “Taking on students has a way of teaching the teacher.”

“Perhaps, but no self-respecting Линвик [they] would ever be caught dead with that view. Our family came to power by clawing for strength with every scrap we had to give. Giving so much … nobody who grew up in our family would be so foolish.”

“Bah. You’re a good man. You’d have done something similar if people were relying on you.”

“No,” Брейден [he] said softly. His eyes drifted up to the sky, lost in thought. “I don’t think I would have.”

“I notice you using past tense there,” Ной [he] pointed out. “That means you’re thinking about it. Just you watch. In a short while, you’ll be just as much of an idiot as I am. Maybe you need to take on some students.”

Брейден [he] let out a bark of laugher. “Perhaps. It was nice speaking with you again. I’d stay longer, but I have work to handle. Just one more thing — this wasn’t just a social visit.”

“It wasn’t?”

“Well, it mostly was,” Брейден [he] admitted. “But I did also promise to deliver a message. Джален [he] says that Тим [he] has been sitting around in his house, bored out of his mind. Apparently you’re somehow able to help with that?”

I do need to find Тим [he] and finish what I started with his —

“Wait,” Ной [he] said, speaking before his thoughts could even finish forming. “Джален [he]? What the hell does he have to do with Тим [he]?”


“Don’t ask me,” Брейден [he] replied with a shrug. “Джален [he] just showed up out of nowhere and told me to get you. I don’t know why he didn’t do it himself. Probably because he was lazy. Crazy old bloke. Crazy, but terrifyingly powerful.”

“I see,” Ной [he] said, shaking his head to clear away the confusion. Тим [he] and Джален [he] were both old, but that was like comparing an ant to a dragon. Джален [he]’s version of old was ancient, while Тим [he] couldn’t have been all that old due to his limited runes. “Well, where’s Тим [he]’s house? I’ll find him.”

Брейден [he] wordleslly handed Ной [he] a slip of paper. It was strikingly familiar to the one that Father had given him some time ago to get his attention, but it only took one look to tell that it was different.

The scrap of power Imbued into the paper was considerably more powerful than Father’s. It was definitely a Space Rune, but Ной [he] couldn’t even begin to figure out what it actually represented.

“This is Джален [he]’s,” Ной [he] said.

“Very astute.” Брейден [he] chuckled. “Use that and Джален [he] will come knocking. He said to use it soon.”

“That’s because he’s impatient.”

“I wouldn’t tell him that to his face. Джален [he] is a madman. I’m not sure how you got wrapped up with him but be careful. I nearly choked on my own heart when he showed up at my door. The rumors surrounding him can’t all be wrong, and none of them are good. He’s a monster, through and through.”

We play darts on the weekends.

“I’ll keep that in mind. Thanks for the warning,” Ной [he] said. “You’re headed off, then?”

Брейден [he] nodded. “Too much to deal with and too little time. Give Мокси [she] my best wishes. I’ll be around, so if anything progresses, come find me. And let me know if you need help with those Space Runes of yours.”

“I will. I need to fill it up a bit, but after that, I’ll definitely seek you out,” Ной [he] said with a smile. He rose to his feet and held a hand out. Брейден [he] took it and they shook. A ripple of purple passed over the larger man’s body and he vanished on the spot, sending a small wave of faint, tingling energy over Ной [he]’s hand.

Okay, that’s a pretty sick way to leave. I’m stealing that.

Ной [he] glanced down from the wall. Брейден [he] had reformed just a short distance from the base of the wall and was heading out of the arena, keeping to the shadows. Ной [he] held back a laugh.

Right. Long range teleports are hugely draining. That was entirely just to look cool. I respect it.

He turned back and hopped down to the inside of their mini-arena, using a small gust of wind to slow his fall before he landed. Every single one of the students looked completely winded. They all sprawled across the ground at Мокси [she] and Ли [she]’s feet, battling desperately for breath.

“Looks like you’ve all been busy. I couldn’t have been up talking for that long,” Ной [he] said.

“You made me work,” Джеймс [he] said through a groan, pushing himself up just enough to look at Ной [he]. “I hate working.”

“Nobody’s making you do anything,” Эмили [she] said between breaths. “You could just give up.”

Ной [he] smiled and leaned in to whisper into Мокси [she]’s ear. “So who’s winning? Any changes?”

“You’re the one that understands patterns the most. In terms of actual effort, every single one of them has been putting in everything they have. Александра [she] is still the strongest, but that makes sense.”

Ной [he] nodded. That matched up to what he’d seen from up on the wall beside Брейден [he]. This was exactly what he’d hoped for when they’d decided to give the Master Rune away. Everyone was throwing themselves completely into their training. The rune was just a bonus. It wasn’t even the real reward. Ной [he] almost laughed at that thought.

If Брейден [he] heard that the Master Rune wasn’t actually the important bit of this whole thing, his ears would probably start bleeding.

“I’m proud of every single one of you,” Ной [he] said. “We’re all well on our way to using patterns to their fullest extent, and Formations aren’t long beyond that. I think it’s just about time to decide who gets the Master Rune.”

That ripped everyone out of their stupor. The students all shot upright, though none of them actually stood up.

“There’s just one thing,” Ной [he] said.

“There was never a Master Rune, and this was all just a clever ploy to get us to work?” Тодд [he] guessed.

“No, there’s a Master Rune. I’m not that much of an asshole,” Ной [he] said. “But I—”

Джеймс [he] raised a hand. Ной [he] paused, then nodded to him.

“I’d like to withdraw from the running. I don’t think I won, but just in case, please don’t consider me,” Джеймс [he] said. “I have no use for an earth-based Master Rune.”

“What?” Эмили [she] twisted to look at Джеймс [he]. “Why in the Damned Plains were you trying so hard if you didn’t want it? We spent so much time training!”

“I was trying because you were.”

Эмили [she]’s cheeks went bright red and her mouth snapped shut. A second passed. Then she gave Ной [he] a sheepish smile. “Please remove me too. I need to be mobile when I fight, so the Master Rune would be wasted on me if I got it.”

Ной [he] smiled. “I can do that. Turning down something that you don’t need but could still use is very respectable.”

And not bad, Джеймс [he]. Much better than pretending to be incompetent.

That only left 3 students. Neither Изабель [she] nor Тодд [he] were going to give up — they’d already promised each other that they’d go all out to win. Александра [she] was unlikely to step down as well, as she was desperate to grow stronger due to her body runes.

Between the three… I think Изабель [she] has probably advanced the most from where we started. It’s a bit hard to judge exactly how much Тодд [he] has improved with patterns, but he developed what may be the most powerful ability in the long run. And Александра [she] has probably taken to patterns the best out of everyone, which means she’s probably the one that spent the most time practicing. Bah. There’s a really good argument for each of them winning.

Ной [he] turned to Мокси [she] to ask where the points sat. But, before he could say anything, Тодд [he] and Изабель [she] both raised their hands in unison.

“We’re out,” Тодд [he] said with a grin.

Ной [he] was taken aback. He hadn’t been expecting that. And, judging by the shocked expression on Александра [she]’s face, she hadn’t been either.

“Both of you?” Ной [he] asked.

“Yeah,” Изабель [she] said. “I think it would have been pretty useful on us… but Александра [she] was practicing every single day, with basically every moment of free time she had. On some days I heard her coming back when I woke up.”

Александра [she]’s mouth worked, trying and failing to find words as Тодд [he] nodded in agreement.

“I trained with her a good bit, and it was clear she’s really been throwing everything she’s got into this. She was going to win this regardless of if we withdrew or not, but Изабель [she] and I decided that we’ve already gotten everything we wanted. We’ll get our own Master Runes later.”

“Cocky, much?” Изабель [she] asked, bumping her shoulder into Тодд [he]’s with a smirk. “But he’s right. You earned this, Александра [she].”

Александра [she] swallowed. “I—”

“Won,” Ной [he] finished Александра [she]’s sentence for her. This was the best-case scenario, and it meant nobody had hard feelings over losing. It couldn’t have gone better. “Did I say how proud of all of you I am?”

“As am I,” Мокси [she] said. “And I think this calls for something.”

They all looked to her.

“What is it?” Ли [she] asked. “Celebratory stretching?”

“No,” Мокси [she] said with a grin. “It’s time for a pizza party.”

Chapter 437: Party Тим [he]e

There was just one thing left to do before anyone could head out to a pizza party. Мокси [she] had a Master Rune with Александра [she]’s name on it. Ли [she] hopped up onto the top of the walls to make sure they weren’t getting any undue attention while Ной [he] took the huge grimoire off his back and set it down on the sand.

“Don’t even think about eating this one,” Ной [he] informed the grimoire as he flipped it open to a blank page. “It’s not ours.”

“I’m not eating anything,” Ли [she] said from the top of the wall. “Why would I eat a rune?”

“I was talking to my book. Don’t worry, Ли [she]. I know you wouldn’t try to eat a rune,” Ной [he] replied absently, making a mental note to ensure that his grimoire and Ли [she] never got an extended period of time alone together. They’d be a terrible influence on each other.

Everyone gathered around the grimoire and waited expectantly. Мокси [she] set her hand against its pages, then glanced to Ной [he].

“Ready?”

“Yep. Go ahead,” Ной [he] said.

Мокси [she] nodded and closed her eyes. Her face creased with concentration for an instant and a ripple passed over the page. Lines traced themselves into the paper as the Earthen Muster Master Rune appeared upon it.

It took Мокси [she] a little under a minute to imbue the Master Rune. The paper around it crackled with energy as the grimoire locked its power up within its Catchpaper. The students watched with bated breath as the lines finally came to a stop and Мокси [she] lifted her hand from the paper with a nod.

“It’s ready, Александра [she]. Take it.”

“Is there something special I have to do?” Александра [she] asked breathlessly, staring down at the rune with wide eyes. “I’ve never seen a Master Rune with my own eyes.”

“Just put your hand on it and draw it into your soul like any other rune,” Мокси [she] said.

Александра [she] nodded. She steadied her emotions and followed Мокси [she]’s suggestion. They all waited silently as she closed her eyes and her brow furrowed in concentration. Seconds passed by.

The paper crackled. Then, with a pop, the Master Rune vanished. It was nearly a minute before Александра [she] opened her eyes again.

“Did it work?” Джеймс [he] asked.

“Where do you think the rune went?” Изабель [she] asked with a snort. “It’s not like it vanished into thin air. Congratulations, Александра [she].”

Everyone else chorused their agreement.

Александра [she] smiled, her cheeks flushing at all the attention being directed her way. “Thank you, everyone.”

“Can you test it out for us?” Тодд [he] asked. “I want to see how it works.”

“Maybe later?” Александра [she] offered. “As tempted as I am to try to learn how this works right now, I think it can wait a little bit. I think there was something else we were going to be doing next. I don’t want to hold that up.”

“Pizza parties are a sacred practice. That is very wise of you,” Ной [he] said with a sage nod. “Being late to them is a grave sin. There will be time for more work soon enough. For the next hour or so, put that out of your mind. Let’s go get some pizza.”

***

A little bit under half an hour later, after taking down the walls they’d erected in the arena, everyone gathered in Ной [he]’s classroom. Ной [he] and Мокси [she] had split off shortly after Александра [she] had claimed her Master Rune to get the pizza and bring it back. They’d also wisely left Ли [she] along with the others to make sure the pizzas actually survived the trip back to the scene of the party.


Room G100 hadn’t seen use in quite some time and had started to pick up a layer of dust, but nobody was particularly bothered about that when they had pizza to eat. Ной [he] handed Ли [she] a stack of personal pizzas and then distributed the rest of the food amongst everyone else.

A smile pulled across his lips as he watched the students move the tables into a small ring and sit down as a group. Excitement and motivation were so thick in the air that he could practically taste it — though that might have just been the pizza.

Ли [she] deposited her stack of pizzas by the kids and hopped up to the supporting beams on the ceiling and hung from them like a bat.

“Throw me something!” she called down. “I want to see if I can eat upside down.”

Джеймс [he] obliged, grabbing a pizza and flinging it up at her like a frisbee. His aim was surprisingly good and it sailed out on a direct collision course with her gullet. Ли [she] caught the flying disk of dough with her mouth and quickly stuffed it in, but not without losing a pepperoni in the process.

It plummeted back to the earth, abandoned by its comrades as they set out on their final pilgrimage into Ли [she]’s stomach, and landed right on Джеймс [he]’ right cheek. The students all burst into laughter and Эмили [she] took the slice of meat off his face, wiping it clean with a thumb.

“It’s funny to think about what this room was like just a short while ago, isn’t it?” Мокси [she] asked as she took a seat beside Ной [he]. “I never would have thought I’d be seeing something like this.”

“It’s incredible,” Ной [he] agreed with a smile. He took a bite of a pizza that he’d saved for himself. “I can’t really take credit for any of their personalities, but turning down a Master Rune is a huge sacrifice for people who don’t have any backing from a noble family. We’ve got some damn good students.”

“I think you’re missing something. They don’t have the backing of a noble family, but they do have you. Part of the reason they’re so comfortable passing up on power is because they know you’re there for them,” Мокси [she] said, leaning against Ной [he]. “You’re reliable, even if you’re batshit insane. Better than any noble family anyone could ever ask for.”

“It’s not just me they have. They’ve also got you and Ли [she]. I couldn’t do any of this on my own. Hell, they did the majority of it themselves. All I did was show them a few things I figured out while killing myself. I can’t wait to see what they’re doing in the future. They’ve all got so much potential.”

“And I can’t wait to see it with you. Teaching is so much more enjoyable when I’m actually doing it of my own volition,” Мокси [she] said. “I was really worried about how things would go after I got out from Эвергрин [she]’s thumb, but I’ve found myself liking it more and more with every day. You’re a big part of the reason for that. I haven’t ever met someone that cared as much about their students as you do.”

“The biggest lesson I learned from my last life is that the only mark you truly leave on the world is what you give to others,” Ной [he] said, moving his hand to cover Мокси [she]’s. “I don’t plan on ever dying for good again, but that statement still holds true.”

She leaned in and gave him a kiss on the cheek, then settled in against his side. Even though the room had six other people in it, everyone else was caught in energetic conversation and, for at least that brief moment in time, none of them were paying attention to Ной [he] and Мокси [she].

“I love you, Ной [he],” Мокси [she] whispered into his ear.

“I love you too,” Ной [he] said, his hand tightening around hers.

For that instant in time, the rest of the world didn’t quite matter. They sat there in silence, and nothing possibly could have made the moment better.

Then a pepperoni landed on Ной [he]’s forehead.

“Sorry,” Ли [she] called down from the ceiling. She hesitated for a moment. “Are you going to eat that?”

Ной [he] burst into laughter. He picked the pepperoni off his face and popped it into his mouth. “I am now.”

“Shall we go join the others?” Мокси [she] asked with a snicker. She wiped the tomato sauce off Ной [he]’s face with her thumb and licked it clean. “I think Ли [she] might have thrown that pepperoni intentionally.”

“I would never do something like that,” Ли [she] said, closing one eye and squinting at Мокси [she] as she reared back, another pepperoni pinched between two fingers. “But, for unrelated reasons, please don’t move.”

Everyone started to laugh again. Ли [she] seemed to remember that throwing the pepperoni would mean she wouldn’t be able to eat it and opted to throw it into her mouth instead of sacrificing it.

Ной [he] and Мокси [she] walked over to join the circle of students in their celebrations and Ли [she] dropped down beside them. Room G100 soon descended into energetic conversation once more. For as long as the party lasted, any challenges the future held couldn’t have been farther from their minds.

For just a short while, all their worries could wait. When the time came, they would handle them. Ной [he] had been in a number of pizza parties in his life. But, as far as they went, this was definitely the best one he’d ever had.

Chapter 438: Tea With Джален [he]

The pizza party eventually came to an end. No matter how much fun they were all having, there was still work and preparation that had to be done — and Александра [she] would probably spontaneously combust if she didn’t get her daily practice time in.

With full bellies and satisfied smiles, everyone bid each other farewell. The students headed back to their dorms in a group. Ной [he] and Мокси [she] remained in the room beside Ли [she], who had draped herself over Ной [he]’s right shoulder like a sack of potatoes and was fast asleep.

“That was a nice break,” Ной [he] said. “Pizza parties really are magic. It’s good to take a moment to sit back and celebrate when we achieve something. Motivation is a powerful thing.”

“Trust me, I’m more than sold on their effectiveness,” Мокси [she] said. “We should invite some more people next time. Брейден [he], if he’s got time. Тим [he] too. Maybe Улия [she] or Джален [he] depending on how things go.”

“Джален [he]?” Ной [he]’s eyebrows rose. “Something tells me he’s the kind of guy to show up to a party with a keg of alcohol or ten.”

“Sounds like a fun party,” Мокси [she] said with a wry grin. “And if he’s going to hang around us like a vulture, we might as well get to know him better. Don’t get me wrong. I don’ t like him. But, if he’s going to be a constant presence in the near future, then I’d rather know him better.”

There was no arguing with that. It was a good point. Ной [he] inclined his head in agreement, then slipped his hand into a pocket and pulled out the slip of paper that Брейден [he] had given him. “I’ll let him know he’s invited to the next one. I’ve got a pretty good opportunity to do that now.”

“He’s around?”

“With Тим [he], apparently,” Ной [he] said. He caught the baffled look on Мокси [she]’s face and shook his head. “I don’t know either. Тим [he] never told me he knew Джален [he] or vice versa, but all I can do is head over to find out. Using this will get Джален [he] to come grab me.”

“Where’d you get that? Брейден [he]?”

“Yeah.”

“Well, I suppose I can’t complain too much. At least Джален [he] gave you a way to contact him instead of showing up and kidnapping you.” Мокси [she]’s tone sharpened and her eyes narrowed. It didn’t look like she’d completely forgiven Джален [he] for how their first meeting had gone, and Ной [he] didn’t blame her.

“I suppose even withered dogs can learn new tricks,” Ной [he] said. He put the paper back into a pocket and shifted his shoulder, carefully sliding Ли [she] off and holding her up before him like an elongated cat. She let out a murmur and her fingers twitched, but her eyes didn’t open. “Could you take Ли [she]? If I call Джален [he], I get the feeling he’s just going to yank me and drop Ли [she] on the floor.”

“Is she really still asleep?” Мокси [she] asked, but she took Ли [she] from Ной [he]’s arms and draped her over her own shoulder.

“Probably not,” Ной [he] replied. He poked Ли [she] in the side and she squirmed, letting out a muted snicker before following it up with an exaggerated snore. The corner of his mouth quirked up. “But good luck convincing her of that.”

Ли [she] let out another snore.

“You don’t snore when you sleep, you know,” Мокси [she] pointed out with a defeated yet amused sigh. “You just kind of lie there.”

Ли [she] abruptly stopped snoring. Мокси [she] rolled her eyes and both she and Ной [he] held back a laugh. Ной [he] scooped the paper back out of his pocket and took a quick look around the room to make sure he wasn’t about to leave anything behind.

“I’ll try to be back by tonight. I don’t think this is going to take long,” Ной [he] said. “Er… actually, is now a good time for me to go find them? This is important, but if there’s something else going on, I can delay.”

Мокси [she] smiled and leaned in to give him a quick kiss on the cheek. “Your thought is appreciated, but now works. I can’t say I wouldn’t like it if you were able to get back before I went to bed, so I’ll stay up as long as I can, but don’t worry if you can’t. I’m more than aware of how Джален [he] is. Just let him know that I won’t be pleased if he holds you for too long.”

A Rank 3 threatening a Rank 6 should have been ludicrous. There really wasn’t anything that Мокси [she] could have done to give Джален [he] any pause. But, for some reason, Ной [he] felt like the old man would take her words seriously.

“I’ll pass that along. Thanks, Мокси [she]. I’ll see you soon,” Ной [he] said. He pulled the paper out of his pocket and unfolded it, letting a finger brush across the space rune imbued into it. He sent a shimmer of energy across the paper.

Tingles raced up his hand as the rune activated. Purple light ignited within the rune like a flashlight, with such intensity that Ной [he] was forced to blink furiously and turn away from the paper. There was a loud crackle and a surge of power.


Ной [he] caught a glimpse of an annoyed, slightly concerned expression on Мокси [she]’s face an instant before he felt a hand wrap around his arm. Then it gave him a sharp yank and he flew through the portal, leaving the classroom behind him.

Ной [he]’s foot landed on wooden floor. He stumbled and caught himself, turning just in time to see the portal snap shut behind him.

“Took you long enough,” Джален [he] said irritably. He stood across from Ной [he], his arms crossed. It wasn’t hard to tell who had pulled him through the portal. They were both in a small, quaint room.

There was a wooden table right behind Джален [he] with three chairs set up around it. A bookshelf sat in the corner of the room covered with a thin layer of dust and a door at the end of the room led into what looked to be a small kitchen.

“Oi,” Джален [he] said, stepping in front of Ной [he]. “Are you ignoring me? That’s a bit cold. I just teleported you for free. That normally costs a lot of money.”

“I’ll have you know I was having a very good time before I used that paper,” Ной [he] said, matching Джален [he]’s tone and meeting his eyes. “We’d just had a big party to celebrate how far my students had come, and I was spending some quality time with Мокси [she]. This better be important.”

“Ah. Now I see. The only thing that can capture a man’s heart more than the plea of his brother.” Джален [he] let out a snort. “A pretty woman.”

“If you consider handing me a slip of paper through my literal brother and then telling me to come pay you a house visit at another one of my friends’ houses, I am not going to assume that is a plea. A plea means you’re in danger — and let’s be real. There isn’t anything in Арбитраж [he] that could ever put you in real danger.”

A smirk played across Джален [he]’s lips and he clapped Ной [he] on the shoulder before guiding him over to one of the chairs. “Snarky little shit. I suppose I can’t complain too much. You aren’t wrong.”

Ной [he] sat down and Джален [he] took the chair across from him. The head of the Линвик [they] family then yawned and picked up an empty teacup, examining it with a critical eye. Ной [he] waited for a second, then glanced around expectantly.

“So… is there a reason you called me here? And where’s Тим [he]? He’s not in trouble, is he?”

“Тим [he]? Oh, no. He’s fine,” Джален [he] said with a dismissive wave of his hand. He leaned back to peer into the kitchen, then nodded to it. “Ah. There he comes now.”

Тим [he] stepped out from the kitchen bearing a plate with three cups and a teapot on it. He walked over to the table and set it down, giving Ной [he] a smile as he took a chair for himself and set about pouring cups of tea for all of them.

“It’s nice to see you again, Вермил [he],” Тим [he] said. He slid a cup over to Ной [he] and then handed Джален [he] another one.

“Much appreciated, Тим [he],” Джален [he] said as he took the cup and sipped from it, letting out a satisfied sigh. “That hits the spot. You’ve always been damn good at this.”

Ной [he] stared at them in disbelief. He tried to muster words but found that none were immediately coming to mind. Тим [he] and Джален [he] definitely knew each other, and it seemed like they’d known each other for some time.

Тим [he] took his own cup and tasted it, then nodded to himself. “The brew went well today. Good leaves. Thank you for delivering them.”

“It wasn’t too hard. I just nicked ‘em from a tea shop when they weren’t looking,” Джален [he] said with a dismissive wave.

Ной [he] opened his mouth, then glanced down at the tea. He raised the cup to his lips and took a sip. A familiar pleasant sensation greeted his tongue and he almost burst into laughter. There was no doubt about it. This was the tea from the store that Сильвертид [he] had been at.

“So,” Ной [he] said as he lowered his cup and set it on the table. “Does someone care to inform me what in the world is going on? You two know each other?”

“For around forty years now, I’d say,” Тим [he] said, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. “Джален [he] came by to use the Transport Cannon some time ago and we got into an interesting conversation.”

“Interesting conversation, he says.” Джален [he] let out a snort and shook his head. “I tried to fiddle around with the cannon and figure out if I could take it apart and he got mad at me. I’ve never been yelled at by an old man with the power of an ant before.”

Do you literally make all your friends by getting people pissed at you and seeing how they react? Bold. Maybe bordering on a fetish, but I won’t judge. It’s hard to imagine Тим [he] getting pissed about anything, but if he was going to get mad, the transport cannon definitely would have been the reason why.

“Yelled is a strong word. I just gave you a small scolding. The cannon is very fragile. The magic is not to be tampered with.” Тим [he] took a sip of his tea, then let out a sigh and shook his head. “Or at least, it shouldn’t have been. It’s back up and running, but only because people are manually running it.”

“We’ll get the key back soon enough,” Ной [he] promised. “Don’t worry. We’ll get the transport cannon to its former state as soon as we can.”

Тим [he] smiled and took another drink of his tea, then gestured for Ной [he] to do the same. He did. It was good tea, after all. There was no reason to waste it.

“I suppose we should cut to the chase,” Джален [he] said. His voice was more serious than normal. “As amusing as you are, I didn’t call you here for no reason, Вермил [he].”

Ной [he] set his cup back down on the table. “I figured as much. What is it, then? Something tells me it isn’t for a game of darts.”

“Maybe after,” Джален [he] said, a flicker of amusement passing through his eyes before his features grew focused again. He nodded to Тим [he]. “As I said, I’ve known Тим [he] for some time. I won’t lie and claim to be the greatest ally one can have. I’m a rather distracted man. Things don’t tend to keep my attention for long, but when they do, I pay close attention to them.”

“And?”

Джален [he] leaned forward and braced his arms against the table. “Тим [he] hasn’t gotten stronger in years, Вермил [he]. He’s been stuck in place, unable to advance since the day I knew him. And yet, when I found that he was caught up in a fight with Визен [he] and came to check on him, do you know what I found? Strength, Вермил [he]. Not much, mind you. Тим [he]’s strength has always been his mind, not his runes, but the pressure coming from him increased by a very, very slight margin. For a man that hasn’t changed in all the years I knew him, that’s quite the change indeed — and I think you’re responsible for it.”

Chapter 439: Figured It Out

Ной [he] didn’t let any shock show on his features. He raised the cup of tea to his lips, blocking out as much of his face as possible as his mind raced. He’d only repaired one of Тим [he]’s runes. The change shouldn’t have been significant enough for anyone to notice.

He hadn’t even thought Тим [he] knew anyone all that powerful, much less Джален [he]. The Линвик [they] family head was the last person Ной [he] would have expected to give a shit about Тим [he].

How goddamn sensitive is he if he could tell the difference between a Rank 1 and a Rank 2 Rune for someone he barely spends any time with?

Ной [he] had the cup of tea to his lips for so long that he ended up completely draining it. He kept his face straight as he lowered the cup back down to the table. Half of his attention was directed to keeping every part of his posture and body perfectly calm. If his heart so much as started racing, Джален [he] would probably be able to notice.

It wasn’t that he didn’t like the Rank 6 mage. While Ной [he] wouldn’t have exactly called Джален [he] trustworthy, he was very straightforward. That did not mean he was willing to share the secrets of how Разлом [he] worked with him.

What the hell do I tell him? I don’t think Тим [he] would have spilled the beans. Maybe I can claim I got some form of really powerful soul healing potion? How would I excuse wasting something like that on anyone other than myself or Мокси [she]?

“Your silence is telling,” Джален [he] said with a chuckle. He took another sip from his tea and leaned forward, eyes boring into Ной [he]’s head. “No need to look like a deer in the torchlight, Вермил [he]. You really shouldn’t be shocked. After all, you literally showed me how it was done.”

Ной [he] blinked. “I’m not so sure I follow.”

I most certainly did not.

“Come on now, Вермил [he].” Джален [he] shook his head and tapped a finger on the table. A smug smile stretched across his lips as his tone grew increasingly confident. “During that class I observed. You were literally teaching your students steps to learning Formations, and that makes you a Formation Master. You’ve found the intricacies of how Runes work and discovered a way to work them out of the soul without shattering it.”

Ной [he] stared at Джален [he]. He sounded quite satisfied at his discovery of Ной [he]’s secret, even though he was completely wrong about it. There was no need to point that out, though. Ной [he]’s attention went from trying to keep the stress from showing on his features to trying to hold back relief.

He’s really damn perceptive, but nobody would ever be able to so much as take a guess at the existence of Разлом [he]. I was hoping to keep the extent I get Formations under wraps, but it looks like that was too much to ask for when he literally swung by a class. It looks like Тим [he] also kept his mouth shut. Good man. He didn’t say anything, even though he’s friends with Джален [he].

I can work with this.

Ной [he] held his hands up and let out a defeated sigh. “Okay. You got me. I was really hoping it wasn’t that obvious.”

“It wouldn’t be to most. You’ve done a very good job of appearing to be completely incompetent,” Джален [he] said with a smirk. “My kind of man. Managed to hide yourself from the family for all these years… though I don’t blame you. They’ve turned into a hive of villains and scum.”

Isn’t it literally your job to keep that from happening?

Джален [he] caught the look on Ной [he]’s face. His smile slipped away and he let out a huff. “I know what you’re thinking, Вермил [he]. But let me ask you something. Let’s say you stumbled into the responsibility of taking care of a group of rats. All of the rats hate you, and they do their best to fling themselves into every pot of boiling water they find. When you try to stop them, they bite your fingers. What do you do?”

“Build a cage?” Ной [he] guessed, pretty sure he was missing the point but more than happy to let the conversation steer away from his abilities for as long as possible. It would certainly wrap back to them soon enough, but the more time he had to try and figure out some answers, the better.

“If only I could, but no. The rats don’t like being caged and find ways out.” Джален [he] shook his head, then sent a pointed glance at the empty cup before him. Тим [he] picked up the tea kettle and filled it once more. Джален [he] nodded in appreciation and took a sip of scalding tea before continuing. “You have to choose between trying to herd them or let them do what they want.”

“I’d probably do my best to herd them if I was responsible for their wellbeing, I guess.”

“And that’s what I did. For years, I tried to keep them on track. Actually did for a few periods of time as well, but in the end, it’s impossible. Not without ruling over them like a lord. So I stepped back. Did less. Cared less. It made things easier, Вермил [he]. There just wasn’t anything to keep my attention on anymore.” Джален [he] finished his tea in one swig, then waved the cup like a wand. His eyes locked with Ной [he]’s and the corner of his lip quirked up. “Until you. I’ve had a few blips that caught my eye, but nothing in the way of true strength. No insult meant, Тим [he]. You aren’t strong.”


“None taken,” Тим [he] said with an easygoing smile. He took another sip of tea. Between the three of them, he seemed to be the least concerned. Ной [he] supposed that made sense, as he was the one that knew them both the best.

“I’m honored,” Ной [he] said. “I do my best.”

“I’d say you do a whole lot more than your best. You’ve accomplished something that every single noble family in the entire kingdom is doing their best to figure out.” Джален [he] let out a bark of laughter. He rose to his feet and crossed his hands behind his back, starting to pace around the room. “How is it that a Rank 4 managed to work out what our combined forces couldn’t?”

“Technically not combined,” Ной [he] pointed out. “Nobody works together.”

“Fair point,” Джален [he] admitted. He came to a stop beside Ной [he] and shook his head. “But the question remains. You’ve unearthed some degree of understanding with regard to runes. I want to hear you admit it with your own words.”

“I have,” Ной [he] said after a second of hesitation. If Джален [he] pushed any deeper, he wasn’t quite sure how he’d expand the lie. He had figured out a lot about how runes worked, but that wouldn’t do anything to help remove them from anyone’s soul without Разлом [he]. Not yet, at least. Before he could open his mouth to say anything else, Джален [he] snapped his fingers.

“No!” Джален [he] barked. “Not another word.”

“I — wait, what?”

“I don’t want to hear how you did it,” Джален [he] said. His eyes gleamed with excitement and he let out a delighted cackle. “That would spoil the fun completely. I just want to know it’s possible. There’s something about runes we don’t know, and it’s simple enough that a Rank 4 can discover it. This is hilarious. If you say a single blasted word about how this is done to anyone other than your students, I’m ripping your head off. That includes me.”

Ной [he] stared at Джален [he] as he practically pranced around the room, muttering to himself with a massive grin plastered across his face. He looked like a spring deer that had been just set loose into a field of the freshest grass. Ной [he] couldn’t help himself. He started to laugh.

I should have known Джален [he] would be like this. He doesn’t give a shit about getting stronger for the reasons that the rest of us do. He’s already powerful. All he wants now is to find something interesting to do, and I’ve confirmed that there’s more to discover that he doesn’t know. That bit isn’t even really a lie. There’s a lot to runes that people don’t seem to understand.

Тим [he] wordlessly poured Ной [he] another cup of tea, then refilled Джален [he]’s cup as well. Джален [he] paused his prancing for just long enough to grab his cup and drain it.

“Thanks,” Ной [he] said as he took a drink of his own tea. “While Джален [he] is distracted, how have you been?”

“Well enough, I’d say. I feel better than ever,” Тим [he] said. “I’m a little disappointed about the transport cannon, but I’ll be back to running it today. It’ll just be much more restricted than it used to be due to the limits it’ll now have.”

“How much more?” Ной [he] asked. “I was hoping to use it to send me out to fight some monsters.”

“For you? I’ll make an exception as long as you aren’t trying to go too far. Are you hunting for runes?”

“No. Energy, mostly.”

“Ah. There’s an area with some Rank 3s in it if that would work? I could send you there for a few hours after our meeting with Джален [he] is over.”

“That would be perfect,” Ной [he] said with a grin. “Thanks, Тим [he].”

And I can fix up more of your runes before I head out. I just can’t do that while Джален [he] is here. It would be asking for a bit too much trouble, even if everything was done inside your soul with a Mind Meld potion.

Джален [he] finally came to a stop at his chair again. He slapped his palms down on the table and leaned over it. “Why are you not excited, Вермил [he]? This is groundbreaking.”

“Because I’m the one that discovered it?”

“Ah, right.” Джален [he] pursed his lips. “So you did. I forgot.”

He sat back in his chair and pressed the tips of his fingers against each other. Then Джален [he] pursed his lips and fell silent. Several seconds passed as Ной [he] and Тим [he] watched him.

“So—” Ной [he] started.

“Okay, you win,” Джален [he] said irritably. “Give me a little hint.”

Ной [he] blinked. “What?”

“I want a hint. Where do I start?”

“Er… I suppose—”

“Wait! I changed my mind!” Джален [he] held his hands up and jumped back to his feet, muttering under his breath. “That’ll run the fun. No, Джален [he]. No trading something interesting for a blip of momentary satisfaction. That was how you lost your first wife.”

You know, sometimes it’s easy to forget Джален [he] is batshit insane. Thank god this guy is kind of on my side.

Джален [he] ground to a halt and turned back to Ной [he]. “Okay. I’ve figured it out.”

“You have?”

And what exactly is it you’ve figured out? There’s no way he actually worked out how runes work just by striding around the room for a few seconds.

“Yes. I have discovered that I have absolutely no idea as to how you’ve figured this out. Could you at least tell me if it’s something that can be discovered on its own, or did someone tell you how it worked?”

“It was me,” Ной [he] said, holding back a laugh. “I don’t have a teacher.”

“I see. Very good. Very good.” Джален [he] nodded slowly. “Then it is possible. I have much to consider. I know I called you here, but with my suspicions confirmed, I can hold myself back no longer. There is too much to do.”

With that, Джален [he] vanished. Ной [he] and Тим [he] stared at where he’d been standing. Тим [he] opened his mouth — and Джален [he] popped back into existence.

“I’ll be back in a few days for our darts match,” Джален [he] said, thrusting a finger in Ной [he]’s direction. “Prepare yourself to lose.”

Then he vanished once more. Ной [he] waited for a second to see if he’d return, but it looked like the enigmatic man had left for good this time. There wasn’t a single thing he could think of saying with regard to what had just happened, so he took the next best option and decided to ignore it entirely. He slowly turned to Тим [he], then cleared his throat.

“Care for a trip to the transport cannon?”
