Chapter 447: March

It had been a few minutes since Улия [she] had headed over to the secret room and there really wasn’t any reason that Ной [he] could see to make her wait any longer. Nobody was paying him much attention at the moment, so he had a great opportunity to slip away.

He stepped into the crowd and made his way over to the hidden room that Отто [he] had brought him to the previous продвинутая группа meeting. Ной [he] slipped into it to find Улия [she] sitting in one of the chairs, waiting for him.

He slung the grimoire off his shoulders and set it down beside a chair as he lowered himself into it. “Right. Let’s get this underway, shall we? I’m a bit limited on time and I have no idea what Якоб [he] and Верруд [he] are planning today.”

“Well… how does it work?” Улия [she] asked. “And if it helps, my puppet is in the other room keeping an eye on things. Верруд [he] hasn’t shown up to the meeting and Якоб [he] isn’t anywhere near your people. Neither are his students, though it looks like Юлина [she] has been looking in their direction.”

Юлина [she]? She seemed relatively intelligent. Could she be waiting for some sort of signal?

Ной [he] shook his head. Sitting around in a secret room and wondering wasn’t going to do anyone any good. The sooner he got back out to rejoin the others, the better. He tapped the top of his grimoire. “It works by you telling me what runes you want and me seeing if I can get them to you.”

“That’s it?” Улия [she] blinked. “Nothing else?”

“I mean, if you ask for something I don’ t have, I can’t give it to you. I’d recommend sticking mostly with Rank 2 Runes if you can. I’ve got one or two higher rank ones floating around, but I’d really rather not give those away.”

Улия [she] squinted at Ной [he] as if trying to find the trick in his words. His tapping grew faster as he waited for her to come to a decision.

“How many?” Улия [she] finally asked.

“They’re Rank 2s. I don’ t know. I’m not trying to give away my whole collection.” The grimoire trembled in approval at that, but Ной [he] ignored it. “How many do you need?”

“It’s more about the type than the number. Сильвертид [he] gave me enough to rebuild. I’m trying to do more than just that now. I’m trying to improve. Do you have anything earth, metal, or crystal related?” Улия [she] asked after a moment of thought. “I could use all of those. The more, the better.”

“I’ve got nothing with crystal. I don’t think I’ve got metal either, but I have a stupid amount of earth.” Ной [he] pulled the grimoire forward to rest it against his knees and placed a hand on the cover to pull it open.

Then he paused. His eyes narrowed and he leaned down to look at the grimore’s cover. “Runes, you hear me?”

The grimoire remained still.

“If I see a pair of tits, I’m ripping you in half,” Ной [he] said. He leaned back, ignoring the baffled look on Улия [she]’s face, and flipped the grimoire open. Its pages rustled and Ной [he] was relieved to see that it landed on one covered with a variety of Earth Runes.

He’d gotten quite a few of them during his hunting session before returning to Арбитраж [he], and Мокси [she] hadn’t ended up needing help making hers. Улия [she] had quite a selection to choose from. Her eyes widened as she read over the runes and she looked up to Ной [he].

“I can take any of these? Are you really just showing them to me?”

“I never fully got the thing where it’s taboo to show people a rune,” Ной [he] said through a sigh. “I mean, if you’re going to copy its shape with one of your own runes, you’re going through a ton of work. You can have the damn thing if you want it that badly. They’re only Rank 2s.”

“Don’t let anyone in your family catch you saying that if you want to keep your blood where it is right now,” Улия [she] muttered. She leaned closer to the book and read over it for several seconds. “How many of these can I have again?”

“Four?” Ной [he] offered, testing the waters to see how Улия [she] reacted. He still wasn’t fully sure where the value of runes actually landed when dealing with nobles. For people without an insider to speak to, runes were prohibitively expensive.

Улия [she] was part of a noble family, though. At least, Ной [he] was pretty sure she was. He didn’t actually know. Now that he thought about it, there was a chance she wasn’t. It was a bit late to worry about that.

Her expression hadn’t changed too much at the number he’d offered, so he’d probably landed his guess roughly in a ballpark where it was reasonable.

“Deal. I’ll take these then,” Улия [she] said. She pointed to four of the Rank 2 Runes on the page. Ной [he] couldn’t help but notice she’d chosen some of the ones that were the closest to perfect. He didn’t blame her — he would have done the same. He had enough runes to not be particularly concerned about the loss.

“Feel free. Don’t worry about damaging the grimoire. It can take it. Damn thing probably likes it.”

Улия [she] didn’t comment on that. She pressed her palm to the paper and closed her eyes in concentration. One after another, she drew the Earth Runes into her mindspace. One she finished, she looked back to Ной [he] and rocked back.

He closed the grimoire and moved it out of the way again. “Good. Now that that’s over, before I head back to the others, do you have anything interesting or important for me? If I’m paying you, I expect results.”

“There really isn’t much to report yet. I’m keeping an ear to the walls,” Улия [she] said apologetically. “From what I can tell, it really seems like Якоб [he] isn’t doing anything. He hasn’t looked in Мокси [she]’s direction a single time. As I mentioned before, the only one paying any attention to anyone is Юлина [she].”

“Have you noticed her doing anything aggressive? Maybe looking to other people?”

Uyla shook her head. “No. It’s curiosity more than anything else. She’s started to stand and sat back down like four times this meal. Марли [he] is beside her, but he’s more focused on his meal than anything else. From what I’ve heard of their conversation, the only thing they’ve talked about is preparing for the exam coming up.”


“No mention of my students? And how damn perceptive is your puppet?”

A grin flickered across her lips and she rose to her feet. “Very. And no, nothing. It’s as if they’re completely ignoring you.”

Ной [he] rubbed his chin and stood as well. It was possible that Якоб [he] and Верруд [he] had backed off because of how badly things had gone during the previous meeting. It was the smart move to do. Throwing yourself over and over again into a fight you’d lost multiple times generally wasn’t a strategy that worked for anyone other than him.

That’s a bit concerning. It means they’re a lot smarter than I was hoping. Even if Верруд [he] hasn’t realized I know what he’s up to, if he’s toning down how overt his attempts are, then it’s a lot more likely he’s going to try to really screw us during the actual exam. This could be just to lull us into a false sense of security.

Ной [he] pressed his lips together. It was so much easier to just cause chaos and distract people than it was to actually deal with scheming planners. Part of him was tempted to somehow pull Father into things, just to see the shitshow it would cause.

That was a godawful idea, but it was an amusing one. A small grin pulled at the corners of Ной [he]’s lips and he shook his head before nodding toward the door. “Stay here for another minute or so. I’m heading back to the others. Pleasure doing business with you — and I hope you don’t expect runes every meeting. I’m not made of money.”

Улия [she] coughed into her fist. “I’m not delusional. This is useful, even if I just end up using them for energy alone. Power is hard to come by. I’ll hold my end of the deal up.”

Ной [he] inclined his head once more before stepping out of the room. The muted roar of the room hit him all at once as he closed the door behind him and worked his way through the crowd to rejoin Мокси [she] and the others.

Улия [she]’s information looked to be correct. Nobody was really bothering his group. One student was off to the side, speaking with Тодд [he] at the edge of their little pack, but the conversation seemed to be polite at best and nobody else was close enough to make anything of it.

“Anything interesting happen?” Ной [he] asked as he joined Мокси [she].

She shook her head. “Nothing. It’s kind of boring if I’m going to be honest. Not that I’m complaining. I was just prepared to deal with a whole lot more bullshit. I highly doubt they just gave up, though.”

“Same,” Ной [he] agreed. “I’m leaning toward them having decided that it wasn’t worth trying at the продвинутая группа meeting so soon after the last one. Unless they’re doing something that we’ve completely missed, I think they might be holding off until the next meeting or the exam itself.”

“The exam is the best time to try anything if that’s their plan. We won’t be there to interfere… but Александра [she] beat Юлина [she]. Unless Марли [he] is considerably more powerful than her, they shouldn’t have a chance.”

“We don’t have any way to know if they’ve got more backup or not,” Ной [he] said, his gaze scanning over the room. Aside from them, the majority of the other professors were moving around and mingling while their students sparred. “And we really aren’t getting that many of our own.”

“We’ve got Сильвертид [he].”

“True,” Ной [he] said. “I haven’t seen Tyler fight, but if he’s Сильвертид [he]’s student, I’m sure he can hold his own. Wouldn’t hurt to have a bit more backup on our field if we can get it, though.”

Мокси [she]’s eyebrow arched. “You want to start mingling with other professors? Look at you. You’re actually starting to act like a noble.”

“Don’t insult me.” Ной [he] gagged and Мокси [she] snickered.

“It isn’t a bad idea. If we could get George and Фиона [she] on our side, that wouldn’t hurt. They’ve got a lot of respect from the other students. Nobody has even tried to challenge Фиона [she].”

“Nobody is challenging our students either,” Ной [he] pointed out.

“Do you really think anyone would so soon after the last meeting? If it had been anyone, it would have been someone with Якоб [he]. It’ll take other people a bit more time to feel things out and try to get a better understanding of everyone’s strength before they try more. It’s hard to do that when we’re standing behind the kids like a brick wall.

Мокси [she] had a point. Ной [he] scrunched his nose in annoyance. No matter how much he wanted to protect them, the kids needed to handle some things on their own. He couldn’t get allies for them and if they were constantly floating around, no random students would approach. Especially not with Вермил [he]’s reputation.

“Maybe we should back up a bit,” Ной [he] said. “Give them room to breathe — but not too far.”

Мокси [she] nodded. “I wanted to wait until you got back, but I’m in agreement. Ли [she]’s still next to them, but she’s a lot more approachable than we are as long as you don’t plan to challenge her to an eat-off.”

They both took a few steps away from the kids, letting their conversation fall off as they headed toward the crowd. Finding a tall table nearby, the two of them settled in to watch.

A few minutes passed and the crowd started to tighten. Nobody had approached their students yet, but Ной [he] didn’t miss a few glances being thrown in their direction. He and Мокси [she] had definitely been scaring the other kids off.

Ной [he]’s vibration наполнение [he]s warned him of someone walking up behind them and he turned, tapping Мокси [she] on the shoulder as he did. He was prepared to face off against Якоб [he] or Antony — but it was Сильвертид [he] that stood before them.

“Вермил [he]. Мокси [she].” Сильвертид [he] inclined his head in greeting. His face was deadly serious. “I’m afraid I come bearing news.”

“Just news?” Ной [he] asked, pushing away from the table with a frown. “What is it?”

“The Исполнители that went out looking for Визен [he] have found him. He’s figured out how to use the key and has been preparing a ritual to activate it.” Сильвертид [he] replied grimly. “We will be leaving in thirty minutes, when the mass portal our Space Mages are making has breached his defenses.”

Ной [he] nearly choked on air. “I — what? That fast?”

“They are Исполнители, Вермил [he],” Сильвертид [he] said dryly. “Their title is not earned by chance. Исполнители are some of the most competent mages in Арбитраж [he].”

It was sudden, but he had known the Исполнители were searching for Визен [he]. He just didn’t think they’d find him this quickly. Ной [he] shook the reeling surprise away. It wasn’t going to help anyone. If anything, it was a good thing that Визен [he] had been located this early on.

At least they caught him before he managed to pull off whatever he’s trying to do with the key.

“Right. I know why you’re here, then.” Ной [he] did a quick check of his belongings, but he had everything he needed. “I promised Брейден [he] I’d back him up.”

“Not just you,” Мокси [she] said. “I’m coming.”

“As am I.”

Ной [he]’s senses tingled at the same time as he heard Ли [she] speak. They all turned as she emerged from a shadow at their side.

“How good is your hearing?” Мокси [she] asked in disbelief.

“Really good,” Ли [she] replied. She nodded over her shoulder to the kids. “I already let the others know something was going on. They’re going to head back early. Don’t worry.”

Ной [he] blew out a breath. There was no point arguing with Ли [she] or Мокси [she]. They were both Rank 4s and more than capable warriors — and neither of them were going to turn back when they set their mind to something.

“Just make sure to leave the really dangerous stuff to me, yeah?” Ной [he] asked.

“Don’t worry. I’m not trying to get myself killed,” Мокси [she] said with a snort. “I’ll leave the worst of the fighting to the people who are meant to do it. Extra backup isn’t going to hurt, though.”

“It most certainly won’t,” Сильвертид [he] agreed. “I trust the three of you are coming, then?”

Ной [he] took one last look around the party, then blew out a breath and gave Сильвертид [he] a firm nod. “Yeah. We’re coming.”

“Then we march,” Сильвертид [he] said, spinning to stride out of the room. “Визен [he] must be stopped.”
==========
Chapter 448: The Hunt Begins

Сильвертид [he] led Ной [he], Ли [she], and Мокси [she] out of the продвинутая группа meeting at a brisk pace. He made a beeline for the transport cannon, moving surprisingly fast for a man that relied on a cane to walk.

They reached it just minutes later and ascended to the top. The control room was more packed than Ной [he] had ever seen it. Брейден [he] and Нейр [he] stood by the control panel and Тим [he] hovered behind the controls, his face creased in concentration as he adjusted them.

Dozens of other Исполнители that Ной [he] didn’t recognize milled around the room, readying their gear and speaking in hushed, professional tones. Годрик [he] was among them — Ной [he] hadn’t been looking for him during the meeting, but it looked like the large man would be joining the mission.

“There are a lot more people here than I thought there would be,” Мокси [she] said as they cut over to join Брейден [he] and Нейр [he].

“Визен [he] is a major threat, but not everybody here will be attempting to breach his sanctum,” Сильвертид [he] said. “We need to make sure he doesn’t send people back into Арбитраж [he] while we’re trying to attack him. About half of these Исполнители will be ensuring Визен [he] can’t open our portal back up or counterattack.”

“Is it easier to open a portal when there’s been space magic used in an area?” Ной [he] asked.

“Yes,” Брейден [he] answered for Сильвертид [he], turning to give them a nod of greeting. “Considerably easier. Space Magic is its own greatest weakness. The more of it someone else uses in an area, the easier it is for other people to do the same.”

Interesting. It’s not like using Space Magic leaves behind more space to work with… does it have something to do with how Space Runes are hard to use naturally? Maybe using them weakens whatever limit is restricting them normally.

“Are we expecting Визен [he] to try to counterattack?” Мокси [she] asked with a concerned frown. “Is he actually strong enough to divert his forces like that?”

“It’s hard to say. Визен [he] is difficult to predict,” Нейр [he] said with a shake of his head. “We can’t say what he’s going to do or how he’ll react. It’s best to take precautions regardless. What I want to know is why we’re inviting Rank 3 — wait. Weren’t you Rank 3?”

Мокси [she] shrugged in response. “People don’t stay at the same rank forever, Исполнитель [he] Нейр [he]. Circumstances changed.”

Нейр [he]’s eyes narrowed and he crossed his arms in front of his chest. “Both of you reached Rank 4 within just weeks of each other. It can’t be the Торрин [he]s… do you have a noble family sponsoring you?”

“I don’t see how that’s relevant to the task at hand,” Брейден [he] said gruffly. “They’re both capable mages, and we need backup. Исполнители can’t do everything on their own. Вермил [he] has dealt with Father and Джентил [he], one of Визен [he]’s men. He’s more than capable of holding his own, as are the rest of his group.”

“True enough. At the bare minimum, more bodies wouldn’t go awry.” Нейр [he] let out an explosive breath and shook his head. “How long until the cannon is ready?”

“I’m expecting an hour at the minimum.” Годрик [he] stepped through the crowd, squeezing his large body between the other mages with a grimace. He adjusted his coat and sent a look over to Тим [he]. “Визен [he] knows what he’s doing. His spatial defenses are incredible from what I’ve been told. I’ll be honest, I’m surprised it’s moving this fast at all. That old man knows his way about a transport cannon better than anyone I’ve ever met. If he wasn’t navigating where we were going, I don’t know if we’d be able to get within a league of Визен [he].”

A flush of pride washed through Ной [he] even though he had absolutely nothing to do with any of Тим [he]’s accomplishments. It was just nice to hear someone actually acknowledging Тим [he]’s talents.

Almost as if Тим [he] could tell that they were speaking about him, he straightened up and gave a nod to an Исполнитель [he] that Ной [he] didn’t recognize. They exchanged a few brief words before the Исполнитель [he] broke away.

Тим [he] spotted Ной [he] in the crowd and he pushed away from the desk, hurrying to join them. Lines of worry creased his weathered face.

“You’re going to be going after Визен [he]?” Тим [he] asked, raising his voice to be heard over the dull roar of conversation filling the room.

“Yes. I promised Брейден [he] I’d back him up,” Ной [he] said. “Don’t worry. I can handle myself, Тим [he].”

“I have no doubt of that,” Тим [he] said. “And you’re in good company. Just be careful. That woman that attacked the tower was powerful, and if she was just one of the people working for Визен [he], I shudder to think what he’s capable of.”

If you knew half of it, you’d do a whole lot more than just shudder.

“Are all the preparations for the cannon complete?” Годрик [he] asked. A doubtful frown passed over his features. “It hasn’t been long.”

“I don’t need long,” Тим [he] said. “The space in the caverns is warped, but I was able to find a pathway through. The more I fiddle with it, the more Визен [he] will be able to locate that something is penetrating his defenses. Right now, unless he’s just waiting for us to make a move, it doesn’t seem like he knows. All that remains is for the Space Mages to gather enough energy to power the cannon enough to send everyone over at once.”

“How long will that be?” Брейден [he] asked.

“About forty-five minutes from what I was just told. The cannon is already locked in position. There’s nothing else I can do, even if I want to,” Тим [he] said. “Don’t forget this is a one-way trip. I won’t be able to pull you back.”

“Wait, what?” Ной [he] asked. “That’s news to me. Why not?”

“We’re going outside of the Transport Cannon’s effective range,” Нейр [he] answered for Тим [he]. “It doesn’t have enough power to pull us back at that range. We’re already supercharging for a one-way trip, and the cannon uses more energy summoning people back than it does sending them out.”


“Ah. Fair enough. How are we getting back, then? If it’s this far, I really don’t relish flying back on a sword.”

“Once we’ve dealt with Визен [he], the spatial distortion will fall and we should be able to use the same principle that is currently working against us to make the return easier,” Годрик [he] said. “The reduced space resistance around his area will allow us to gather at the top of his sanctum and Тим [he] will re-activate the cannon once it gets enough power, pulling us back.”

“Assuming we win, that is,” Нейр [he] added with a grim laugh. “Of the Исполнители that went to investigate Визен [he], only a quarter of them were able to get us any word. The others have gone missing. He’s either killed or captured multiple Rank 5 Mages.”

“He hasn’t been hit in a full-on attack yet,” Годрик [he] said, crossing his arms. “He is a Rank 6, but we have Rank 6s of our own. Don’t start sowing doubt before we even arrive at the location.”

Нейр [he] held his hands up to signal surrender. Ной [he] glanced around the room. The tension was definitely high. The Исполнители were stressed. Whatever they’d dug up about Визен [he] had given them a lot of pause, but leaving him with the artifact just didn’t seem to be an option.

Брейден [he] moved closer to Ной [he], leaning down and lowering his voice so people couldn’t overhear him. “Sorry for dragging you into this, Вермил [he].”

“It’s fine,” Ной [he] replied with a shake of his head. “Визен [he] and I weren’t on good terms. As much as I’d love to let you do all the work, I’ve got some chickens in the coop as well. We can’t leave him with that key.”

Speaking of which, we need to get it back in the cannon — with better defenses this time around — so Тим [he] can keep doing what he loves.

And Тим [he]… I don’t know how long this is going to take. God forbid something goes really wrong, I’d feel like shit if I actually just left him with one un-repaired rune.

“Remind me how long we have before things get started?” Ной [he] asked.

“A bit more than half an hour,” Годрик [he] said. “Do you have something you need to collect? I would hurry up if you do.”

Ной [he] shook his head. He dug through his bag, then located his last Mind Meld potion. He pulled it out and nodded to Тим [he]. “Come on. That’s enough time.”

Тим [he]’s eyes widened. “Here?”

Ной [he] had already popped the cork off the potion. Годрик [he] tilted his head to the side in confusion but said nothing.

“Nothing says I won’t get myself killed doing this,” Ной [he] said, thinking quickly. There were too many people around him to even bother hiding that he was taking the potion — but that didn’t mean he had to give away what they’d be doing with it. “Now is the only time you’re going to get. I need someone that knows what I do to handle my affairs if something goes wrong.”

“What kind of affairs would you even have?” Нейр [he] asked.

Ной [he] ignored him and held the potion out to Тим [he]. The old man swallowed, then took the vial from his hands and downed half of it. He returned it and sat down as Ной [he] did the same.

“I’ll be back in half an hour. Drag my body through the portal if you need to,” Ной [he] said, a familiar buzzing enveloping him.

Then he was gone, sucked into Тим [he]’s soul.

As soon as his body took form beside Тим [he], he shook off the fading potion’s effects and gave the old man a sharp nod. “Let’s move quickly. Bring your last Rune over.”

Plans rarely go exactly how you want them to. I don’t know when we’ll get back to Арбитраж [he], but I don’t want to leave Тим [he] without a way forward.

Тим [he] gave him a sharp nod. They both knew that now wasn’t the time to hesitate. Every second was of the essence. He held his hand out and a broken Fire Rune floated over to him — the last of his old runes.

They’d already replaced and healed his Keystone Rune in one of the previous sessions, so Ной [he] had high hopes that this one wouldn’t go too poorly. Тим [he]’s soul looked far better than it ever had. The cracks had completely faded and it was spacious for a Rank 2 Mage, with more than enough room to hold a little extra if he needed it.

“Are you ready?” Ной [he] asked. “And what do you want for your last Rune?”

“Yes. And a Wind would go fantastic.”

“Then let’s get to it.”

Тим [he] turned around, averting his gaze so he wouldn’t see exactly what Ной [he] did to break and repair his runes.

Ной [he] got to work.

***

Half an hour later, Ной [he]’s eyes opened in the Transport Cannon once more. The conversation had grown considerably louder, but nobody had left yet. He sat up and Тим [he] rose beside him.

For a moment, neither of them spoke. Then Ной [he] rose to his feet and held his hand out, helping Тим [he] up as well.

“You’ll follow through if I don’t come back, right?” Ной [he] asked.

“Of course I will,” Тим [he] said. He swallowed, then inclined his head slightly lower than he’d needed to for a simple nod of understanding. “You can count on it.”

Ной [he] pulled his grimoire around and whispered into it, then found an old piece of Catchpaper in his travel bag. He really didn’t have much need for them anymore, but it would come in handy today.

Energy crackled against his palm as the Grimoire provided him with the rune he’d asked for and Ной [he] quickly traced it into the paper, folding it over once he was done. None of the other mages in the room were paying him enough attention to care what it was.

He handed the folded paper over to Тим [he].

“What’s this?” Тим [he] asked, blinking in surprise.

“Something that I think will go a long way with you,” Ной [he] replied. “Put it to good—”

“We’re connected!” A mage yelled. “All Исполнители, prepare for the cannon to activate!”

Тим [he] stuffed the paper into his pocket. “Thank you, Вермил [he]. Stay safe.”

“You too,” Ной [he] said.

Тим [he] hurried into the crowd. All around them, the Исполнители started gathering into ranks. Ли [she] and Мокси [she] moved to stand directly beside him, and Сильвертид [he] took up the position to Мокси [she]’s right.

“I have to say, your choice of pre-battle distraction is not what mine would be,” Сильвертид [he] said with a wry smile. “You seem more relaxed than I’d expect someone to be when they’ve never entered a major battle before. Are you prepared? We’ll be up against mages, not monsters.”

“They might be mind-controlled, right?”

“It’s possible,” Сильвертид [he] said with a troubled frown. “But we won’t have room for mercy until Визен [he] falls. This is not a battle we can take lightly. If it makes you feel better, it is unlikely that Визен [he] has many people controlled actively. That would take an immense amount of magical power that I doubt even he has. I doubt he would waste so much when he has far better ways to fight us off.”

“Then we’ll be up against people that chose to stand in our way,” Ной [he] said, setting his jaw. “In which case, they die all the same as monsters do. All that matters is stopping Визен [he] and getting out alive.”

“Spoken like a true Soldier.”

“Prepare yourselves,” Годрик [he]’s voice echoed through the room. A loud hum filled the air as energy prickled against Ной [he]’s skin. “The transport cannon is activating! We don’t know what we’re up against, but your goal is to stop Визен [he] at any costs. Destroy or remove the key from his possession. Collateral damage is irrelevant. Do not engage Визен [he] directly unless you have no choice.”

Not exactly a rousing speech, but certainly to the point.

The roar of the energy grew louder. Purple sparks flashed all around the group of Исполнители and, out of the corner of his eye, Ной [he] spotted Тим [he] on the lift as it rattled down, bringing him out of the range of the Transport Cannon’s magic.

Then there was a brilliant flash. The world disappeared in screaming purple light, and they were all gone.
==========
Chapter 449: Resolution

It was the longest trip with a transport cannon that Ной [he] had ever experienced. Purple stretched and swirled around him. Energy prickled furiously all along his skin and, somehow, inside of him as well. His stomach clenched and flopped back and forth — and still the sensation continued.

He could have sworn that they spent nearly ten minutes hurtling through the ether before the ground finally and rudely made itself known once more. Ной [he] hit it feet first with a grunt and stumbled, only getting lucky enough to catch himself on a wall. They’d arrived somewhere pitch black.

Other mages popped into existence all around him and a wave of disorientation passed its way through all of them. It was a few seconds before Ной [he] could think properly again. The others came too around the same time, and someone sent an orb of light into the air to illuminate their surroundings. He quickly spotted Ли [she] and Мокси [she] beside him before letting his attention drift farther outward.

They’d arrived in a large cavern. Four large tunnels led out from it and stalactites hung from the ceiling. Heavy notes of mildew and moss hung in the air around them and he could just barely make out the distant vibrations of dripping water somewhere below them.

Nobody made a noise. The Исполнители quietly gathered themselves into ranks and stood still as Годрик [he] made his way to the front. Several mages closed their eyes, likely scanning the surroundings to see if anyone had noticed their arrival.

Ной [he] did the same. He focused on his body наполнение [he]s and dialed up their sensitivity, searching for vibrations in the stone that would indicate the presence of one of Визен [he]’s men. Aside from the dripping water beneath them, he found nothing.

That said, that didn’t mean nobody was there. The information he could pick up on was hindered by the presence of everyone in the room around him and the natural vibrations of the earth itself. Someone could have easily been near the edges of where he could sense. Ной [he] waited to see if anyone else would detect something, but it seemed that nobody did.

“Right,” Годрик [he] said, his gruff voice muted as it broke the silence. “It doesn’t seem like any of Визен [he]’s men are in this area. That probably means we’ve made it in undetected, but we have no way to know for sure.”

“Where exactly are we,” an Исполнитель [he] beside Ной [he] asked. “How far is Визен [he] from us?”

“We’re quite close. We should be below his sanctum,” Julius said, emerging from the crowd to stand beside Годрик [he]. He leaned against his staff, the six bands on his jacket glistening in the light of the orb above him. “We can’t dismiss the possibility that Визен [he] knew we would arrive here, but the lack of a trap in the area makes it likely that he either doesn’t know we’re present or doesn’t care.”

“He’s not stupid enough to ignore an entire group of Rank 5 and 6 mages,” Сильвертид [he] said. “Визен [he] is arrogant, but he didn’t come off as an idiot when I spoke with him. If he didn’t have something here, it’s likely we actually managed to get in undetected.”

“The plan is the same either way,” Годрик [he] said. He nodded to the pathways behind him. “We have to get the key — but to do that, we need to take fights on our terms. My team will actively seek out Визен [he] and bide our time for as long as possible while doing our best to avoid being spotted. Everyone else — kill as many of his men as you can on the way up. If he gets enough reinforcements, we could get overwhelmed. Our numbers are an advantage we can’t afford to lose. If Визен [he] starts using the key, my team will delay until everyone can make it.”

Everyone nodded. There wasn’t much more to say, and Годрик [he]’s plan sounded solid in theory. If they picked Визен [he]’s people off on the way up, they’d have the advantage of surprise and would hopefully be able to swarm him when the time for the final fight came.

“We’ll have to be fast,” Julius warned. “Surprise is on our side, but I doubt Визен [he] will be caught off guard for long. Move quickly and do not linger. Remain in groups whenever possible but remember that our ultimate goal is getting or destroying the key no matter the cost. Now break off!”

The Исполнители burst into hushed motion. They split into teams of four and shot disappeared down the tunnels. Сильвертид [he] stayed behind as the other thinned. Soon, he, Брейден [he], and Ной [he]’s group were the only ones left in the cave.

“I’ll follow you all at a delay,” Брейден [he] said. “I fight best on my own. My magic doesn’t take well to other people being too close, so it’ll be best if I can protect our flank until we run into something where I’m needed to back you up.”

“A sound plan. Shall we?” Сильвертид [he] asked, nodding to the leftmost tunnel. “I doubt we’ll be finding anyone particularly interesting early on. Визен [he] is going to have his strongest members closer to the core of his sanctum.

“That makes it sound like you’re actively seeking out the strong ones,” Ной [he] said as they all set off into the tunnel. Сильвертид [he] ran his hand along a thin bracelet that had been hidden by his jacket sleeve. It lit with light, illuminating the tunnel around them.


“Of course I am,” Сильвертид [he] said. “There aren’t all that many things I get to do in my old age. A good fight is one of them — especially against someone that deserves a whooping. I didn’t become a soldier for no reason, Вермил [he].”

“Fair enough,” Ной [he] said. He glanced around the cave. It really didn’t look like anything special. It was just a cave. That was probably the point. There was no reason to have a secret base if it had a glowing neon sign that gave it away. “Be careful, Брейден [he].”

“You too.” Брейден [he] nodded to them as they headed out.

They walked at a brisk pace for several minutes, continuing down the tunnel as it sloped upward.

“Smell anything interesting, Ли [she]?” Ной [he] whispered as they walked. If anyone had senses they could rely on down here, it was her.

“Lots of stuff,” Ли [she] replied, a pensive look on her face. “It’s weird. I can’t place any of the smells. There’s something masking them. I can tell they’re there, but…”

She trailed off and shook her head, unable to find words to properly describe her thoughts. Сильвертид [he] tilted his head slightly to the side but mentioned nothing else. They continued on, their steps marked by the faint tap of his cane on the stone.

Several more minutes passed. The tunnel stretched on and they came to a branch. Сильвертид [he] set off along the leftmost path without hesitation and they followed after him. Ной [he] didn’t know if the old soldier actually had a plan or if he was just confident about everything he did.

Ной [he] couldn’t think of a better strategy, so he followed along and kept his runes at the ready. The tunnel branched out several more times before it ended its upward slope and flattened out, continuing straight for another minute. Ли [she] stiffened and put a hand to Ной [he]’s arm, looking ahead. Сильвертид [he] seemed to notice something at roughly the same time.

They all slowed, focusing on silencing their steps even further. Сильвертид [he] suddenly seemed to stop needing his staff to walk and he held it at his side as they approached whatever he and Ли [she] had picked up. Ной [he]’s vibration sense caught movement just a short while later in a small chamber a short distance ahead of them.

Сильвертид [he] snuffed the light from his bracelet as they drew up to torchlight flickering from around a bend before them. They turned the bend and found themselves standing at the end of a much nicer hallway.

Tiles lined the ground and there were several openings along the walls that led into what Ной [he] presumed to be other rooms. His tremorsense told him that there was a single person in the room just in front of them and to their right. The person was hunched over something and didn’t appear to be aware of their presence.

Сильвертид [he] didn’t even break his stride. He walked straight up to the room, forcing the others to hurry to keep up with him. Ной [he] stepped into the doorway just moments after Сильвертид [he] had, readying Natural Disaster.

A dark-robed man was already midway through turning toward him when Сильвертид [he] ran a finger along the edge of his staff. Ной [he] caught a glimpse of pale lips parting beneath the man’s hood in surprise an instant before a thin ribbon of blood bloomed at his neck.

The man’s body pitched forward and his head rolled back. Сильвертид [he] stuck his staff out, catching the body and grabbing the man’s head by the hair before it could hit the ground. The scraps of his hood fluttered down and landed silently on the floor as blood started to pour from the corpse.

Holy shit. What the hell is Сильвертид [he]? I didn’t even see him move or notice him casting any magic.

Сильвертид [he] lowered the body to the ground and jerked his chin back toward the hall. “Come. We can’t be wasting our time. It seems none of the others happened to go in this direction.”

“Has anyone ever told you that you’re terrifying?” Ной [he] muttered as they stepped back into the hall. “You didn’t even stop to check who you killed.”

“Has anyone ever told you that you are quite the conundrum, Вермил [he]?”

Ной [he] tilted his head to the side. “How so?”

“You carry yourself like a soldier. Your attitude and fighting style reflect that to the point where I sometimes start to think that you’ve walked the line between life and death more than I have. Then you go and say something like that.”

“Like what?”

“Being concerned about the enemy,” Сильвертид [he] replied. “We are at war, Вермил [he]. The individual life does not matter. Визен [he] is not just a single mage. You’ve seen what he’s capable of at a massive range when he isn’t even interested in fighting. He’s now got a deadly artifact and is in the seat of his power. We can’t afford to think about who we’re killing. You have an odd mixture of willingness to kill and do whatever you need to in order to accomplish your goals as well as a reluctance to actually put those ideals to the test.”

Ной [he]’s brow furrowed as he thought over Сильвертид [he]’s words. “It’s not that I’m reluctant to kill. I just don’t want to kill anyone innocent.”

“Neither do I,” Сильвертид [he] said. “If someone lays their weapons down the instant we arrive, then perhaps they can be spared. But we cannot take risks. We only live a single time, and a blade to the back will kill me as surely as anyone else. You are going to have to choose which of your ideals you will stick to if you want to avoid losing either your life or those of your allies. You cannot have both, and you’ll learn that the easy way or the hard way.”

With that, Сильвертид [he] fell silent and they continued down the hall once more. His words echoed through Ной [he]’s mind as they headed deeper into Визен [he]’s sanctum. By the time they’d reached the end of the next bend, Ной [he]’s jaw had set.

Сильвертид [he] had probably meant for his words to be pondered over, but he’d been right about one thing in particular. Ной [he] was a whole lot older than he was — and he knew himself more than well enough to know which sins he could bear.

Losing Ли [she] or Мокси [she] wasn’t an option. If that landed innocent blood on his hands, then so be it. There was no room for mercy or caution when the danger was this high. Any threats would either be killed or get him first — and then he’d come back and kill them anyway.
==========
Chapter 450: Визен [he]

With Сильвертид [he] at the lead, they continued deeper into the heart of Визен [he]’s sanctum. There were surprisingly few people in it, and the caves were… well, just caves. Ной [he] wasn’t fully sure what he’d been expecting.

The tiled path led them past several rooms, but almost all of them were empty. The ones that did have anything in them only possessed furniture that Ной [he] would have expected to find in a normal house.

Something about it almost felt wrong, but it was hard to place what. With everything Ной [he] knew about Визен [he], he’d fully expected to find something that would have fit into a supervillain’s lair. Some dungeons. Chains, screaming prisoners. Anything.

Instead, it just felt like he was invading someone’s underground house. That wasn’t to say that Ной [he] felt bad about it, but it struck him that he would probably find half of the things he was expecting to find under Father’s house rather than here.

They ran into another one of Визен [he]’s men on their path deeper into the lair, but he met the exact same end as the first under Сильвертид [he]’s impossibly fast magic. The man didn’t even get a chance to notice that they were there.

“What’s up with this place?” Мокси [she] muttered as stepped over the dead man and continued down the hall. “There’s no way nobody has noticed we’re attacking yet.”

“It is a bit odd,” Сильвертид [he] allowed. They turned down a sloping corner and stepped into a slightly wider hall. It was equally as deserted as the ones before it, but several branching paths stretched off from a dozen doors on each side of it. Сильвертид [he] let out a grunt. “That is a lot of paths.”

“This feels more like a maze than someone’s hideout,” Ной [he] said. “And what’s the point of having so much space if you don’t use the majority of it? Every room just has random furniture in it but he doesn’t seem to have anywhere near enough people to fill the rooms.”

“Perhaps its purpose is to confuse,” Сильвертид [he] said. His features darkened. “Or perhaps Визен [he] has far more men than we were led to believe. I did not think he had an entire army down here.”

“Nobody we’ve run into so far has been all that strong,” Мокси [she] said. “If it’s an army, it isn’t a powerful one. And an army doesn’t do you any good if you’re not actually using them when you’re under attack.”

Сильвертид [he] pursed his lips, then shook his head. “There is nothing to be gained from speculation. Do any of you have an inclination toward any of the rooms before us? They are all the same to me.”

“I thought you knew where we were going,” Ной [he] said. “You chose all the other paths so confidently before.”

“That would be because I was searching for people. There isn’t anyone left alive anywhere near us.”

Seriously? How does Визен [he] have so few people? Сильвертид [he]’s senses are nearly as long ranged as Ли [she]’s are, and she can pick people out from so far. Is this place really that big?

“Ли [she], any thoughts?” Ной [he] asked. “You’re the one with the best senses here.”

It was a few moments before Ли [she] replied. “I’m not sure. Сильвертид [he] is right. I can’t really smell anyone close by. It’s weird, though. There definitely were people here. A lot of them. But everyone is gone.”

“They left the sanctum entirely?” Мокси [she] asked. “Or are they just not here?”

Ли [she] shook her head. “The sanctum is big enough that I can’t tell without sniffing around more. But…”

She trailed off and they all looked to her expectantly.

“All information is important right now,” Сильвертид [he] said gently, putting a hand on Ли [she]’s shoulder with the patience of a man that had dealt with a lot more than most ever had the misfortune to see in life. “Even if you think it isn’t or don’t want to bother us with idle thoughts. You’d be surprised what the subconscious mind can pick up on.”

“I think I know where Визен [he] is,” Ли [she] said. “He’s probably with the key, right?”

“Almost certainly,” Сильвертид [he] said. “You located the key? How?”

“I smell it,” Ли [she] replied. She hesitated for a second longer, and a flicker of fear passed through her eyes before she quashed it. “And it’s getting stronger. I think Визен [he] is using it.”

“Where is he?” Сильвертид [he] asked. “We cannot allow that artifact to be used. It doesn’t matter if it’s for the portal to the Damned Plains or another purpose. It’s too dangerous in his hands.”

Ли [she] pointed down one of the corridors to their right. They all exchanged a look, then set off down the corridor at a brisk pace that quickly went from a fast walk to a jog. Ной [he] occasionally heard footsteps behind them that marked Брейден [he]’s presence, but the large mage continued to keep his distance and hold up their flank.

The hall wound deeper into Визен [he]’s sanctum, but it was just as empty as the rest of the ground they’d covered.

“Wasn’t the other team meant to find Визен [he] first?” Мокси [she] asked as they accelerated into a run. “Can we really handle him on our own?”

“We will analyze the situation once we are in position to act. If the other Исполнители have met equally low levels of resistance, then there will be others that locate him soon enough. Many of them have very apt sensing capabilities,” Сильвертид [he] replied. They skidded down a corridor and came up to a branching path. Ли [she] thrust her finger down the right path and they shot away again.

The slap of their shoes against the ground was the only sound in the caves as they raced through the empty stone halls. Ной [he] scanned the surroundings with his tremorsense, but there really was nothing. It was like the entirety of the caves were just abandoned.


Minutes passed. There was one thing that was for certain. Визен [he]’s sanctum was enormous. He practically had an entire underground village, and given how little they’d seen of it, it was probably more of a city.

Ли [she] led them through the twisting tunnels, pausing occasionally to sniff at the air before taking back off. She was doing a good job of hiding it, but Ной [he] didn’t miss the growing concern on her face.

They were heading right toward the thing in life that she probably feared the most. After everything she’d done to escape the Damned Plains and how desperately she wanted to avoid returning, Ной [he] couldn’t even begin to imagine how little she actually wanted to be here.

Ли [she]’s hand shot up and Ной [he] nearly tripped over her at the abrupt halt. They stood before a normal seeming tunnel, but her expression was deadly serious as she raised a finger to her mouth and nodded down it.

“He’s really close,” Ли [she] whispered. “And so is the key. I think they’re both just down this hall.”

Сильвертид [he] concentrated for a few moments. His brow furrowed and he tightened his grip on the walking cane that he held at his side, unused. “I cannot sense anything. He must have a way to cloak himself very effectively.”

“He’s there,” Ли [she] said firmly.

“We believe you,” Ной [he] said.

Брейден [he] drew up in the tunnel behind them, picking up on their abrupt silence and muting his steps as he walked to join their group. He sent a look into the hall, then tilted his head to the side.

“Визен [he]?” Брейден [he] asked in a low tone. “Or a group of enemies?”

“Визен [he], probably,” Ной [he] replied before looking to the old soldier. “What’s the plan, Сильвертид [he]? I’m not keen on trying to fight Визен [he] on our own. I don’t think he’s going to go down very easily. Not to a group of Rank 4s and a Rank 5.”

“He may already be fighting,” Сильвертид [he] said. “If his cloaking is this good, it could include physical sound. We press onward to determine the situation and then make a decision once we have more information.”

It was hard to argue with that. Nobody said anything else and they fell silent, creeping into the corridor. A faint pressure built in Ной [he]’s ears as they headed in. He swallowed to clear it — and a faint pop echoed through his mind.

The corridor changed. Firelight washed over what had been a dark path and he found himself beside the others standing at the edge of an entrance to a large cavern. Braziers ringed its edge. A brilliant crack of magic caused Ной [he] to flinch, instinctively pushing the others back — but it wasn’t directed at him.

There was a thud as an Исполнитель [he] fell to the ground on the far side of the room, his body ripped apart by hissing gray energy. A cloaked man lowered his hands, the gray energy fading from his hands as he looked off to his left, toward something Ной [he] couldn’t make out.

The man stood on a dais covered with blood and bodies. There must have been dozens of them. Визен [he]’s men and Исполнители alike were intertwined in the embrace of death. It looked like Визен [he] had lost a whole lot more than the Исполнители had, but Ной [he] recognized at least four Исполнители that had been in the transport cannon with him, though he didn’t know their names.

Magic still smoldered from huge scorch marks along the walls. Massive cracks split the ground and the temperature in the room was just a step below scorching. There was no sign of the key anywhere, but the look on Ли [she]’s face told Ной [he] that it was definitely close.

“Визен [he].” Нейр [he] stepped out into the room, his face cold.

“You didn’t bring enough men,” the cloaked man said, and Ной [he] recognized his voice instantly. It was Визен [he]. “I’m disappointed you thought so little of me.”

Нейр [he] didn’t respond. He made to lunge forward, but a hand shot from behind him and slammed down on his shoulder, halting the Исполнитель [he] before he could move. Годрик [he] stepped out, blood trickling from a wound on the side of his head. His shirt was ripped apart and he sported several nasty cuts.

“Годрик [he]!” Нейр [he] exclaimed. “I thought—”

“Визен [he] didn’t send enough men,” Годрик [he] said, the corner of his lip curling into a grim smile.

“Can you really be so bold when the majority of the ones you brought with you already lie dead?” Визен [he] asked. “One survivor is nothing to be proud of.”

“You’ve been spending magical energy this whole time at an enormous rate,” Годрик [he] said, ignoring Визен [he]. “There’s only so much power any one man can have, and no Исполнитель [he] went down without a fight. You’re on your last legs.”

“Are you going to ask me to surrender? To give the key over?” Визен [he] asked, tilting his concealed head to the side. “Are you that certain that I cannot handle two more rats?”

He doesn’t notice us yet. This is a really good opportunity for a sneak attack, then. If we time it together with Годрик [he] and Нейр [he]…

Ной [he] glanced to the others behind him. Сильвертид [he] inclined his head slightly. They’d both come to the same idea. Amongst all of them, Сильвертид [he] was the fastest. He had to be the one to move first if they wanted the highest chance of landing anything. The old soldier gestured for Ной [he] and Мокси [she] to stand back, then readied his walking stick.

Годрик [he] nodded to Нейр [he], and the other Исполнитель [he] moved to the side, starting to flank Визен [he]. “Throw me the key. You can’t win this.”

Визен [he] arched an eyebrow in response. “What makes you so sure?”

“This is a path to mutual destruction. The key isn’t worth all this. You’re a powerful mage, Визен [he]. You could progress without standing in the path of the entire kingdom. This isn’t the right path. Even if you somehow manage to defeat us, the reward isn’t worth the cost.”

Визен [he] reached into his robes and pulled free a large dagger. Ной [he] caught a glimpse of a key embedded into the blade’s handle as Визен [he] turned it over in his hands. “You cannot believe that I would go through all this trouble simply to hand the key back over, do you?”

“It’s that or death,” Годрик [he] said grimly. “I’m not dumb enough to think that we can take you out without taking even more damage, but we’ve got more Исполнители on the way and you’re one bad move away from death. Using that key is impossible — it requires too much power. You are doing all this work for nothing. Is it really worth it?”

A quiet laugh echoed from Визен [he]’s lips. “Yes, noble dog. It is. Heel.”

And that was it for their discussions.

Нейр [he] and Годрик [he] shot forward as one. Сильвертид [he]’s magic flared and he sent a blurred line of gray metal hurtling through the air toward Визен [he] with such speed that Ной [he] could barely even track it.

A wall of flame roared up from the ground in front of Годрик [he], forcing him to fling himself out of the way to avoid getting melted on the spot. Визен [he] twisted, somehow managing to spot Сильвертид [he]’s magic coming. He carved down with the dagger in his left hand and a red disk split the air, swallowing the attack before it could touch him.

At the same time, Визен [he] thrust his other hand toward Нейр [he]. A wave of gray magic leapt from it and slammed into the Исполнитель [he] with blinding speed. The magic picked him up and slammed him into the wall with such force that he was embedded straight into the stone. Dark energy hissed and popped around his body and his head slumped forward.

Ли [she] drew in a sharp breath. Her eyes were locked on the burning red portal that floated beside Визен [he].

“Нейр [he]!” Годрик [he] yelled.

“You were incorrect on every count. I still have more than enough energy left to fight. There is nothing that any of you could offer me that would give me even a second of pause.” Визен [he]’s eyes burned like two icy flames in the sea of darkness beneath his hood as he turned to look straight at Ной [he]’s group. “And the key’s powers are already within my grasp.”

Chapter 451: The Weave

Thin strands of metal hissed like a furious snake, shimmering around Сильвертид [he] as he leapt into the room and darted for Визен [he]. A pillar of fire materialized above the old soldier and crashed down toward him.

Threads of metal crossed over each other in a spilt second, forming into a shield above Сильвертид [he]’s head and blocking the blast of flame. It roared past him harmlessly, licking across the floor, scorching tile black.

A thick beam of silver blurred toward Визен [he]. The cloaked mage raised a hand and a wave of earth rolled up from the ground and the metal drove into it, grinding to a halt before it could pass through. It flicked back to Сильвертид [he], who was forced to dodge to the side as a ball of fire materialized where he’d been standing.

Годрик [he] slammed his hands together, pulling them apart to reveal two long blades that hummed with dull white energy, and burst into motion to join Сильвертид [he]’s fight. Брейден [he] flickered and vanished from view, reforming in the room with his huge sword in his hands.

Ной [he]’s violin materialized in his hands as the three mages bore down at Визен [he] from all sides. Ли [she] took a step forward but Мокси [she] grabbed her, pulling the demon back.

“We fight from the back,” Мокси [she] said, vines crawling out from her robes and working their way into the ground. “Визен [he] isn’t someone we can risk getting close to. Look at him.”

She was right. Ной [he]’s attention was focused on pouring power into his song as he prepared a Formation, but it was abundantly clear that Визен [he] was nowhere near outmatched. Even with three powerful mages attacking him, he was holding his own.

Swirling red energy danced around the man’s body, absorbing Сильвертид [he]’s blows before they could reach him, and every part of the room seemed to have come alive in Визен [he]’s defense. Great swathes of stone ripped themselves free of the ground and formed into spikes and blades that jabbed at the Исполнители, forcing them to keep their distance.

Fire materialized in the air and lit the room with loud roars, and blades of wind whistled around Визен [he] with such intensity that their screaming nearly made Ной [he]’s ears bleed. Fortunately for him, they also meant that he could play his violin without having to worry about volume.

Even though the violin was capable of repressing its song, being able to hear what he was actually playing as it was meant to be heard made things a lot easier. The bow flitted across the strings of the violin and Ной [he]’s fingers blurred as he poured magical power into the instrument.

The fight in the room below had grown more intense. What had once been a few individual strands of silver was now a veritable sea. Сильвертид [he] had filled nearly a quarter of the room with his rippling magical thread and it swirled around his body like a cloak, blocking Визен [he]’s strikes before they could land.

Годрик [he]’s swords seemed to sing a song as they danced through the air. He carved through fire, wind, and stone alike as he pushed to grow closer to Визен [he], but the nearer he got, the more powerful the cloaked man’s magic seemed to grow.

Брейден [he] vanished in a shimmer of purple — only to reform in the exact same spot as Визен [he] thrust a hand in his direction, his own fingers crackling with the exact same purple energy.

“Damned Plains,” Мокси [she] breathed. “How is he doing that? He’s casting four or five completely different kinds of magic at the exact same time. That shouldn’t be possible.”

Визен [he] didn’t seem concerned with what was or wasn’t possible. His robes flapped furiously around his body like he was caught in the center of a violent storm. For an instant, his hood pulled back far enough for Ной [he] to catch a glimpse of his lips, curled down in displeasure. “Is this all Исполнители have to offer? I suppose I should have known.”

Годрик [he] pressed his swords together. A deep thump ripped through the room and white mist curled up around his body. A second thump followed after it and another came after — heartbeats, magnified like Ной [he] was hearing them through a stethoscope.

The mist curled around his body and formed into ghastly armor. Tendrils of it reached out and gathered at Годрик [he]’s feet — and he blurred, vanishing.

He reformed directly in front of Визен [he]. The strands of white mist shot out like sword strikes, driving for every part of the cloaked man. Визен [he] clapped his hands together and the spines pierced straight through his body. Годрик [he]’s sword followed after the spikes an instant later.

They carved a huge X straight through Визен [he]’s body, passing clean through him and coming out on the other side wreathed in white mist.

Визен [he] didn’t so much as flinch. Shimmering particles curled away from the path that the swords had followed as his body pulled itself back together like fog parted by the hand of a curious child.

A bolt of purple energy leapt from Визен [he]’s hand and struck Годрик [he]’s armor, but it disintegrated as it touched him. Сильвертид [he] leapt at his back, sending a wave of metal crashing down toward him.

Визен [he] vanished, reforming behind Брейден [he]. Брейден [he]’s huge sword crashed down for his head and he lifted one hand, stopping the blade in its path with his palm. He thrust the other into Брейден [he]’s chest and grey magic crackled around it — only to dissipate as Годрик [he] appeared right beside Визен [he], his white misty tentacles swirling around him.

“Better,” Визен [he] said as Годрик [he]’s blades passed through his body once again. “I was wondering why you were holding off on using your domain. Not the most impressive I’ve ever seen, though. Rather small, isn’t it?”

The tendrils of white magic around Годрик [he] screamed forth, driving into Визен [he]’s body from every direction. They pierced through him, sending foggy particles up into the air. The mage’s body transformed into a stream of black that flowed past Сильвертид [he]’s rippling ocean of metal and away from Годрик [he], reforming back into his normal body in the middle of the room.

Ной [he]’s violin continued to sing as he pushed to finish the Formation. Визен [he] hadn’t paid him any attention yet. The man was either too caught up with the other mages or hadn’t heard the music because of the loud humming of Сильвертид [he]’s metal ocean.


I don’t know what’s up with Визен [he]’s magic or what he’s capable of, but if I can hit him with Разлом [he], it’ll probably cut through whatever protection he’s got that stops them from hitting him with magic.

Мокси [she] hadn’t tried attacking with her vines yet, but that was probably for the best. It didn’t look like they’d be able to do much to him, so biding their time to wait for the right moment was the best chance they had at helping the others.

“What about you?” Визен [he] asked, looking to Сильвертид [he]. “No Domain? I was hoping to see more of your famed abilities.”

Сильвертид [he] didn’t respond. He brought his cane down and the waves of glistening metal leapt slithered out in dozens of different streams. Визен [he] carved his dagger horizontally before him, ripping open a long red portal.

He grabbed the edge of the portal with his other hand and pulled it over himself like a blanket. Сильвертид [he] yanked his hand back and the silver averted its path, parting and into the floor before it could touch the portal.

It slithered back to Сильвертид [he] as Визен [he] released the portal and let out a low chuckle. “Is that really it? One mage with a below-average domain and the other none at all? The Rank 4 doesn’t count — he’s barely even a mage.”

Notes swirled around Ной [he], laden with thick magic. He’d already poured out over half of all the energy Natural Disaster had to offer, layering it so he could use the full might of Разлом [he]. There would be no second chances with the Formation. He had to put every ounce of power he had in if he wanted to be able to hurt a Rank 6 as powerful as Визен [he].

He was nothing like Эвергрин [she] — and he hadn’t even drawn his own domain yet, as far as Ной [he] could tell. Визен [he] wasn’t taking the fight seriously at all. It almost seemed like he was just wasting time with them.

The three Исполнители bore down on Визен [he], hurling magic and metal alike at him as they fought to find an opening in his defenses. Nothing worked. They were pressed back again and again, their magic failing to do anything more than pass through him.

It should have been impossible. Визен [he] had used enough magical power to wring three or four mages over dry, and yet he was still fighting at full force.

Maybe Визен [he] is conserving energy by avoiding using his domain? That could be it, but even so, how is he still going? He’s used so much power, but I don’t think he’s a Rank 7 or this fight would have been over before it started — even if he was just screwing around.

Ной [he] didn’t let his mind wander too far. His Formation was nearly complete. Power gathered around him, swirling to life as he reached the final notes of the song. His bow danced over the strings and his lips pulled back in a snarl. He poured power from Разлом [he] into the Formation in the closing notes, interweaving it with the structure he’d built.

Визен [he] glanced up, then let out a sigh. “Ah. Finally.”

He thrust his hands out. A wave of purple energy ripped out of his body and slammed into everyone in the room, hurling them back like children. They struck the walls with three loud bangs.

Мокси [she]’s vines erupted from the ground, forming into a thick barrier at the entrance of their hall. Purple light ripped through them. Мокси [she] raised another wave of vines even as the first ones fell, only managing to just barely stop the energy before it could reach them — saving Ной [he]’s formation in the process.

Shreds of them rained down all around Ной [he]. His concentration didn’t falter. The song was nearly complete, and getting distracted now would only waste all the power he’d poured into the shimmering notes of the Formation that had taken form around him. He just had to trust that the others would keep Визен [he] off him for a few more seconds.

Things didn’t look good. Брейден [he]’s arms trembled as he tried to push himself up and Сильвертид [he] tried to reach the staff that had fallen at his side. Годрик [he] had jabbed his swords into the ground at his sides and was up to one knee, but none of them could stand.

Ной [he] muted his music, pressing to play the last few notes in silence to avoid drawing Визен [he]’s attention until the last possible second.

Барба [she] dropped down from a passageway far above them, landing beside Визен [he] with a grunt. The hand that she’d lost back in Арбитраж [he] was still missing, but she cradled a bundle under her arm.

“Sorry,” Барба [she] said with an apologetic smile. “I lost some of my equipment and had to go looking for it. You know how it is.”

“Why do I tolerate you?” Визен [he] nodded to the fallen mages. “Finish these ones off. I’ve gathered enough—”

His head snapped around, his pale blue eyes locking with Ной [he]’s just before he could play the final note.

Визен [he] blurred, appearing directly before him, and reached for Ной [he]’s neck with blinding speed. Ли [she] slammed into him, driving her palm into his arm and bringing her knee up into his elbow in an attempt to break it.

Her strikes bounced off his body, but they managed to redirect Визен [he]’s hand just enough to stop it from reaching Ной [he] as he played the last note of the formation.

The air trembled. A black spear materialized, carved down, and slammed into the cloaked man’s shoulder with the weight of a falling mountain. Визен [he] snarled in pain and twisted. A sickeningly familiar energy swirled around his hand and gathered at his fingertips as he slammed them into the spear.

For an instant, the two locked in place. Energy screamed around Визен [he]’s body, sending arcs of electric black power scorching into the ground around him and turning it to glass. He let out a roar of defiance. His hand squeezed shut. The spear shattered. Визен [he] stumbled, blood trickling down from his shoulder as he spun toward Ной [he].

“Impossible,” Визен [he] breathed. “You have Weave?”

He snapped his fingers and the gravity seemed to multiply by a thousandfold. Sheer runic force slammed Ной [he] to his knees. Мокси [she] and Ли [she] crashed down beside him, unable to even muster the force to fill their lungs with air to speak.

Визен [he] reached down and grabbed Ной [he] by the collar, lifting him into the air. With his other hand, he dug the dagger into the air behind him and carved open a rippling red portal.

“I did not think anyone else possessed Weave,” Визен [he] said. His breath, only inches from Ной [he]’s face, smelled like rotting carrion. “But you have found something that I have not, haven’t you? That was a different way of using the Rune… or perhaps a different Rune altogether? It will be mine. Come, Барба [she].”

Барба [she] nodded and stepped through the portal and disappeared. Ной [he] tried to draw on his magic, but it was like breathing underwater. He couldn’t even muster the energy to blow himself up. Визен [he] had completely suppressed him, body and runes alike.

Визен [he] took a step toward the portal to follow after Барба [she] — and a cry split the silence. Ли [she] burst into motion and launched up from where she’d fallen, driving her shoulder into Визен [he]’s chest. A single red horn curled from her right temple, the left one broken off at the root.

A flicker of surprise passed over Визен [he]’s face and he lost his footing for a brief instant. Ли [she]’s fingers, sharpened into long claws, dug into the skin of his wrist as she hurled her full weight into the mage.

Визен [he]’s fingers loosened. Ной [he] crumpled to the ground, still completely unable to move, as Ли [she] threw both herself and Визен [he] into the portal to the Damned Plains.

The world seemed to drag to a crawl as Визен [he]’s body pitched into the red light. The instant he disappeared, Ной [he]’s body fell back under the control of his own mind.

“No!” Ной [he] screamed, lunging for Ли [she] as she fell into the portal. His hand managed to catch her by the ankle — but the pull of the magic was immense and far greater than anything he could hope to resist.

There was nothing he could do to stop her from falling in. He didn’t even have time to think about his options. There was only a flicker of an instant to make a choice, and but he didn’t even need that long.

His grip tightened. The portal yanked Ной [he] off the ground and into its churning depths alongside Ли [she]. He felt something wrap around his own legs, but he didn’t get a chance to see what it was.

The roaring crimson light of the infernal passage swallowed the world, and the Damned Plains waited beyond it.
==========
Chapter 452: The Damned Plains

All the air was knocked from Ной [he]’s lungs as something punched into his stomach. The red energy of the portal vanished with a sizzle as he doubled over, coughing, and slammed into the ground. Rough dirt pressed against his cheek and a dry, acrid stench worked its way into his nose, something between sulfur and burnt bread.

It felt like his body had been stuffed through a sausage grinder. Every single one of his muscles ached and a furious headache pounded in a temple. Even though his eyes were still squeezed shut, the world shuddered, spun, twirled like he was on a carnival ride.

One of his hands was still wrapped around something. It took his reeling mind a moment to remember what it was. He forced his eyes open and shoved himself up with his free hand, ignoring the sharp earth as it pushed into his palm.

Ли [she] laid before him, her form back to normal. Her claws and horn had receded. He still had a vice grip on her ankle. Red dirt stretched out all around them, a ruddy color that would have looked right at home on the surface of mars. Ной [he] coughed some dust out of his lungs.

Something shifted behind him and he jerked his head around, only to find Мокси [she] pushing herself up. Her hair was covered with a fine layer of dust and her clothes were streaked with reddish-brown streaks from the ground.

A vague memory of something snagging onto his leg before he’d entered the portal passed through his mind. She’d done the exact same move to him that he had to Ли [she].

Ной [he] tried to speak but ended up coughing up more bitter dust instead. He doubled over, heaving and coughing in an attempt to empty his lungs. Мокси [she] joined him in his coughing fit. By the time the two of them had managed to gather themselves again, Ли [she] had started to stir.

She sat up and looked down at the ground, rubbed it between two fingers, then let her hand drop once more. Ли [she] blinked heavily several times to get the dust out of her eyes, then wiped her face with the back of her arm.

“Ной [he]? Мокси [she]? Why are you here?” Ли [she] asked. She blinked again, then rubbed at her eyes once more. “Are you here?”

“As far as I know, yes,” Ной [he] replied. His throat was dry and scratchy, but at least he could breathe properly again. He ran his tongue along his lips and grimaced in distaste. The bitter taste of the ground had still yet to leave his mouth. “Is everyone okay?”

“I’m alive, and it looks like the two of you are as well.” Мокси [she] pushed her hair away from her face. “I think that’s the best we could have possibly hoped after that shitshow.”

“I don’t get it. Why are you here?” Ли [she] asked, a note of panic entering her voice. “Why did you follow me? Don’t you realize what happened? We’re in—”

“The Damned Plains,” Ной [he] finished. He directed his gaze upward. A vast expanse of black stretched above him, entirely devoid of clouds or stars. Swirls of red energy slithered through the sky like serpents, passing over an enormous, light blue moon. “I know, Ли [she]. Визен [he] got the key working.”

“If you knew, why did you follow me in?” Ли [she] demanded, then doubled over coughing as she accidentally inhaled some of the dust floating around them. She wiped her mouth off with the back of a sleeve. “I pushed you out of the way so you wouldn’t fall in!”

“Which I deeply appreciate,” Ной [he] said, casting his gaze around them. There was nothing but rolling red hills. Of Визен [he], there was no sign. “You saved me from getting dragged along by Визен [he]. He wasn’t holding onto us when we fell into the portal, so it looks like we got sent somewhere else.”

“Maybe some god felt pity for all the stupid shit we’ve been through,” Мокси [she] muttered. She started trying to comb the dust out of her hair, and Ной [he] caught a faint tremble in her fingers.

He could feel the same shaking in his own hands, a mixture of fading adrenaline and worry swirling its way through his bloodstream and winding around his chest. They were in the Damned Plains.

“If you knew, why did you do it?” Ли [she]’s gaze bored into his head and her hands tightened in the red dirt.

“Because there was no damn way I was going to let you get sucked back here alone. When I realized that pulling you back out wasn’t an option, there really wasn’t any path left but forward.”

“Fortunately, I was close enough to do the same,” Мокси [she] said. “I don’t even want to think about the shitshow that would have happened if I left you two idiots alone in the Damned Plains. The whole place would probably be burned to the ground in a month.”


Ли [she] let out a choking mixture between a laugh and a sob. “You’re both so stupid.”

Ной [he] braced his hands against his knees and rose with a grunt. He pulled Ли [she] to her feet and pulled her to his chest with one arm, ruffling her hair with the other. “Stupid enough to get it patented. It’s not fair to expect someone to change who they are, you know.”

It was a few seconds before Ли [she] gathered herself enough to respond. “Thanks. You’re still stupid. You should help Мокси [she] up before she gets jealous.”

Ной [he] let out a bark of laughter and turned to Мокси [she], who was watching them from the ground with a small smile that did little to hide the creases of concern in her brow. He held his hand out.

“You don’t think I can get up on my own? I was giving you a moment while I pondered our situation in hopes of finding a way out of it.”

“I’m confident a woman of your caliber is more than capable of standing on her own, but I suspect you appreciate the offer anyway — especially when it came at recommendation of Ли [she]. And I don’t suppose you’ve managed to figure out a solution to that problem?”

Мокси [she] snorted and took his hand, letting him pull her up.

“Did we happen to steal the dagger off Визен [he] while we fell through the portal?”

Ли [she] shook her head and pulled away from Ной [he]. She wiped her nose with the back of a sleeve — a sleeve that had already seen a fair bit of wiping that day and was starting to get rather stained. “No. I wasn’t trying to hold onto him. We lost contact halfway through the portal.”

Мокси [she] nodded sagely. “That’s honestly probably for the best. As for my solution — well, I think that’s pretty simple. All we have to do is track Визен [he] down and steal the dagger back from him.”

“You make that sound easy,” Ли [she] said with a small laugh. She kicked the dirt at her feet and paused to watch the resulting cloud roll across the ground. “You don’t know what it’s like here.”

“You’re right,” Мокси [she] agreed. “I’ve got no damn clue. And if I’m honest with you, I’m fucking terrified.”

“Then—”

“But I’d be terrified a hundred times over before I let either of you try to deal with this on your own,” Мокси [she] said. Her gaze sharpened and she gave Ли [she] a flick in the forehead. “Don’t even try to suggest that we should have left you behind again.”

Ли [she] swallowed and nodded. “Okay.”

“So,” Ной [he] said, turning in a circle to see if there was literally anything around them. The only thing he found was swathes of sandy red dirt. “I suppose we’re your guests now. Is all of the Damned Plains like this? A crash course could be useful.”

“It’s pretty varied. Not as much as the human world but varied. It’s just that every part of it is awful,” Ли [she] said. She sniffed at the air and grimaced, rubbing at her nose. “A lot of it is like this. They’re called Wastes. This is where many of the lowest level demons and bottom feeders hide. I spent a lot of time in places like this.”

“They hide?” Ной [he] looked around the sand, then drew on his наполнение [he]s to see if there was anything nearby. There didn’t seem to be any movement around them that was out of the ordinary. “Where?”

“Not usually in the ground,” Ли [she] answered. “There are other places. Caves. Cliffsides. All over. This area is just even more barren than most.”

“Any plants?” Мокси [she] asked hopefully.

“Not really. Not here, at least.”

“That’s fine. I brought my own.”

“What else should we know off the bat?” Ной [he] asked. “I vaguely recall you mentioning the existence of roaming demon cities. Can we—”

“No. It’s too dangerous.” Ли [she] shook her head firmly. “I know the mortal realm was different, but the limit here isn’t Rank 6. There are Rank 7 demons in many of the cities. They don’t just let you in. You need to prove your worth to them.”

“And how do we do that?” Мокси [she] asked. “Kill a bunch of people?”

“Not too far from the truth,” Ли [she] admitted. “You need to be of high enough rank or have someone vouch for you, and then you need to bring a suitable sacrifice to the ruler of the city you’re trying to enter. That’s usually some part of another demon you ran into. The stronger, the better.”

“So we just need to find a demon that acts like an asshole and we can head over to one of the cities?” Ной [he] asked. “Because that seems like it would be the most logical first step. I’m sure the demons have some sort of information exchange, so we could try to learn about Визен [he] and what he’s up to.”

“You’re forgetting something,” Ли [she] said. She poked Ной [he] in the chest. “You and Мокси [she] are human. There isn’t much more valuable to demons than that. You’re a walking source of food. Humans don’t just walk around in the Damned Plains.”

Ной [he] winced. That was a pretty good point. “Never? Is it really that obvious? I never thought that much about it, but if you just feast on emotion… can you really tell who’s a demon and who isn’t? You didn’t even have horns until recently.”

“Well… your emotions taste better. You can’t really tell immediately, but demons and humans have differences. You know that. You’ve seen me and Азель [he]. We don’t have domains and stuff. We also act really differently. A human would get spotted really fast.”

Ной [he] tilted his head to the side. “That’s it?”

“What do you mean, that’s it? That’s a lot.”

“It’s definitely a problem, but if I’m understanding this correctly, you’ve just told me that as long as we act like demons and don’t reveal our domains, the other demons won’t have any way to know that we aren’t demons. Am I right?”

“Well… yeah. I guess,” Ли [she] said with a small frown. “I haven’t put that much thought into it, but powerful demons can take on human forms.”

“Then I think we should go find that sacrifice and the nearest city,” Ной [he] said, a determined smile pulling across his lips. “Because if there’s one thing I’m really damn good at, it’s bullshitting.”
