Chapter 460: Move And Die

Айлин [she]’s eyes flicked from the stranger to the pile of food on the ground. His stomach twisted and clenched like it was being sewn into knots. Йог [he] hadn’t even lasted half a second against the demon. The idea of trying to run was so laughable that it wasn’t even worth considering.

“I — can the others eat? Without incurring debt of their own? I will take you to Голон [he].”

Вайолет [she] was right. I’m already fucked, but if they can get something out of this, then maybe it’ll give us enough energy to do… something. I don’t know what, but something.

“Huh? Go ahead,” the stranger said with a dismissive wave. “There’s too much for one person anyway.”

Too much? I could eat everything here and a thousand times more if I had the opportunity. Was something done to this food? Shit. I really should have listened to Вайолет [she]. But now if they don’t eat, won’t we offend him?

Айлин [she] hesitated for a second, then clenched his jaw. He was already dead. There wasn’t any point being cautious about it. One death was no different from another. “Is it safe? I want them to live.”

“It’s food,” the stranger said. “As long as you don’t choke on it, I can’t imagine it’ll be very dangerous. Just get eating already. I wasn’t lying about being impatient.”

Вайолет [she] exchanged a look with Айлин [she]. She carefully picked up a strip of dried meat and lifted it, hesitating for a second before biting down. With her unspoken assent, Эдда [she] and Торик [he] both dug into the food as well.

Айлин [she] finished the piece of bread he’d already started, but he didn’t bother taking any more food despite how badly he wanted to. There was no point wasting it if he wasn’t going to live through the day.

Even if I somehow managed to escape, the stranger will just come back and take one of the others. I’ve got to play along.

Айлин [she]’s remaining time depleted together with the food. They soon finished every last scrap, polishing the floor clean. Their efficiency was a mixture of hunger and fear, both of which made deeply effective motivators.

As soon as they were done, the stranger looked to him and nudged Йог [he]’s body out of the way with the tip of his shoe. “Come on, then.”

Jaw clenched, Айлин [she] nodded. He started toward the end of the room — and Вайолет [she] followed after him. He paused and sent her a baffled look, waving her away.

“What are you doing?”

“I’m coming with you.”

“What? No!” Айлин [she]’s voice raised and he flinched, glancing back at the stranger before returning his gaze to Вайолет [she]. “You said it yourself. This is my fault. Just take the energy from the food and do something with it. I fucked up.”

“Sure did,” Вайолет [she] agreed with a nod. “But I’m not letting you out there alone. You’ll just get yourself killed.”

“Do you not realize I’m already dead?” Айлин [she] hissed under his breath. “I died the moment the stranger showed back up. The others need you.”

“He didn’t say he was going to kill you. That means you need someone to watch your ass so you don’t do something stupid again,” Вайолет [she] said. She glared at Айлин [she], daring him to challenge her words. “They’ll stay here until we come back.”

“Are you an idiot? What are you talking—”

“She’s welcome to tag along. It won’t change anything. Actually, it might make things easier,” the stranger said, his words driving the final nail into the coffin forming around Айлин [she]. He nearly ripped the hair out of his own head as a wave of dread washed over him.

Damn it. Not like this.

Вайолет [she] gave Айлин [she] a small shove. “Come on. There’s no point making him wait. Price for everything, remember? We’ll be fine.”

She sounded a lot more confident than she looked. It didn’t matter. There was absolutely nothing that Айлин [she] could do but give Вайолет [she] a stiff nod. He looked over her shoulder to the others and sent them a sharp look.

“Don’t you dare move an inch from this house. We’ll be back soon. I promise.”

Liar.

Торик [he] and Эдда [she] both nodded. He saw the doubt in Торик [he]’s eyes, but Эдда [she] was too young to even question him. Айлин [she] still hadn’t actually figured out how she’d managed to get into Трэдон [he] in the first place. She’d never told them, and now he probably wouldn’t get a chance to find out.

He turned back to the stranger, who waited at the exit of the house. Then, together with Вайолет [she], he headed outside. The red light of the Damned Plains sky bore down on them as they all emerged onto the streets.

“Tell me about Голон [he],” the stranger said as they started walking. “He’s… what? The boss of this area? What Rank is he?”

“He’s the streetlord, but we don’t live in his territory,” Вайолет [she] said, her lips twisting in derision. “He just pretends that we do.”


“You don’t care for him.” The stranger’s words weren’t a question.

“He just steals from everyone weaker than him,” Айлин [she] said, surprised to find that the words flowed easily to his lips. There was something oddly liberating about knowing what he said didn’t matter. If the stranger planned to kill him either way, he could speak without worrying about pissing the demon off — at least until they reached Голон [he]’s territory, that was. “He’s a Wastelicker, but he’s Rank 3. There’s nothing we can do.”

“Wastelicker?” A note of amusement tinged the stranger’s words. That was probably a good sign. Вайолет [she] sent Айлин [she] a sidelong look and he coughed into a fist.

“Uh… someone who licks the salt crystals that form in the caves beneath the Wastes because they’re not strong or competent enough to get food for themselves. I know. Ironic. Вайолет [she] says I should use it less,” Айлин [she] said, then cut himself off as he realized that he’d started to ramble nervously. He hadn’t expected to have to explain childish insults to someone that had just turned Йог [he] into a burnt steak without so much as a thought.

The stranger chuckled. “I see. And that’s interesting. You have a name? What is it?”

A flicker of hope wound in Айлин [she]’s chest before he could crush it down.

Why would he be surprised that I have a name? But the only reason to ask the name of someone you plan to kill is if they’re worth remembering. I’m not anywhere near strong enough for that. Is there a chance he plans to let us live?

“I’m Вайолет [she]. He’s Айлин [she],” Вайолет [she] said, answering to fill the momentary silent void as Айлин [she] got lost in his own thoughts. He sent her an appreciative look and she just shook her head.

“Both of you. Hm. Interesting,” the stranger mused.

They turned down an alleyway. There was a distant scuff. Айлин [she]’s ears twitched and he glanced up. A flicker of movement on a rooftop above them marked one of Голон [he]’s spotters. Айлин [she] hadn’t gotten a chance to figure out who it was, but they’d doubtlessly be sprinting back to warn the streetlord of their approach.

“They know we’re coming,” Айлин [she] said nervously.

“Oh, great. That makes things a lot easier,” the stranger said. “Are they coming to escort us?”

“We’re arriving unannounced and with someone Голон [he] doesn’t know. They’ll be coming to take us into captivity so we can speak with him. If he doesn’t like what you’ve got to say, we’re all dead,” Вайолет [she] said.

“Hm.” The stranger shook his head. “I don’t much like the sound of that. I get you aren’t a large fan of Голон [he], but what about the rest of his people?”

Айлин [she] shrugged one shoulder. He didn’t see why it mattered. “They’re… demons, I guess. They do what they have to in order to survive, even if it’s stealing from everyone. I can’t say I like them, but I understand them.”

“I hope they rot,” Вайолет [she] said.

“I see. And how many people does Голон [he] have working for him?”

“Maybe twenty or thirty?” Айлин [she] guessed. “More than enough to make him completely unstoppable. He treats his own men well. They like him.”

“Why didn’t you join up?”

“Because we don’t want to be Wastelickers. I’ll starve before I work for that ass,” Вайолет [she] said. “At least I know that I’m not living by standing on the backs of the starving. Also, he’s vile. His top people like him, but the rest let him do what he wants to them so they can survive. I’m not that desperate.”

Айлин [she] was pretty sure that just about everyone that had joined Голон [he] had probably said something along the same lines in private at some point. The difference between Voilet’s words and theirs was that she hadn’t gotten to the point where she’d tagged on the not yet, at least to the end of the sentence.

Everyone seemed to, eventually.

They slowed as they drew to the end of the street and approached a large, open square. At one point, it had been a marketplace. Now, it was Голон [he]’s ruling grounds. Dozens of leather tents were strewn about surrounding a large, circular one at the back of the square.

A line of demons stood at the front of the tents, and Айлин [she]’s ears picked up on twice as many of them standing on the rooftops all around them. They were completely surrounded. His throat clenched.

“Who are you?” A large demon asked, stepping out from the tents and pushing past the line of demons. Айлин [she]’s stomach clenched even tighter. It was Робон [he], Голон [he]’s second in command.

Робон [he] stood nearly five heads taller than the stranger and held a huge axe in his hands like it was a dagger. There were a lot of stories about Робон [he], and none of them were good. The demon was Голон [he]’s personal executioner and had more kills under his belt than anyone in the camp other than Голон [he] himself.

“You can call me Паук [he],” the stranger replied. “Would you happen to be Голон [he]?”

“Me? No. I am Робон [he].” Робон [he] snorted in laughter and nodded to another demon, who stepped out with a large pile of heavy chain links in his hands. “Don’t move. If you do, you’ll die. Once you’re bound and restrained, you can speak with Голон [he].”

“Oh. No, I don’t think that’ll work,” Паук [he] said. “Just go get Голон [he] and send him out here, would you?”

The demons around them burst into uproarious laughter. Паук [he] watched silently until they all gathered themselves.

“There’s a serious misunderstanding here,” Робон [he] said. “A random demon doesn’t just come in here and start making demands of a streetlord. You’re on our territory. You play by our rules if you want to live.”

“You know, given what I know of this place, I really should have guessed you’d say that,” Паук [he] said. “But you don’t have the power here. I do.”

What is Паук [he] doing? There are like thirty demons here! Is he trying to kill all of us? It doesn’t matter if he can kill one demon if he pisses off Голон [he]’s entire group.

The gathered demons all stared at Паук [he] in a mixture of derision and disbelief.

“He’s just asking to get killed,” one muttered, his voice reaching Айлин [she]’s sensitive ears from a rooftop to their side.

“Just give him what he wants,” another said back.

“You?” Робон [he] asked. “And tell me, how is that true? Have you not looked around? The only reason you still live is because we haven’t killed you and the scrawny rats that led you here.”

Паук [he] glanced back at Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] and lowered his voice. “Don’t move an inch. Stay exactly where you are.”

Айлин [she] gave him a stiff nod, completely lost as to what the demon’s goals were. Once Вайолет [she] did the same, Паук [he] turned to Робон [he].

“That works.”

“What?” Робон [he]’s brow furrowed.

“You’re so powerless you don’t even realize how weak you are,” Паук [he] said with a chuckle. “Allow me to expand your horizons. Every single one of you that dares — come try your luck. Come try to kill me or the weak children behind me. You won’t even step within five feet of them.”

And, just like that, all the hope that had been building up in Айлин [she]’s chest vanished like a snuffed candle. He exchanged a terrified look with Вайолет [she], but they were trapped. If they stayed after a challenge like that, Голон [he]’s men would kill them. But, if they tried to run, Паук [he] would assuredly kill them instead.

A murmur of anger passed through the demons. Робон [he] smirked and hoisted his weapon. “Don’t mind if I do. Голон [he] doesn’t need to waste his time on someone like this. Kill them.”

The decision was simple in the end. Паук [he] was closer to them than Голон [he]’s people were, and so Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] remained frozen in place as thirty odd demons charged toward them, death in their eyes.

Chapter 461: Orders

Demons bore down on Айлин [she] from every direction. He didn’t even dare to flinch. It was impossible to tell just how literal Паук [he] had meant his command of not moving. Every single breath he took felt like it was drawn on borrowed time.

Айлин [she]’s heart leapt into his throat as he heard a rooftop behind him crack. A demon sailed through the air above them, aiming to land directly on top of their heads. Despite his best efforts, his eyes flicked up.

He couldn’t bring himself to stare straight ahead as he died. At the very least, he’d see his killer and bring the knowledge of their face with him into the afterlife. He wasn’t sure if it was the terrified adrenaline pumping through his veins or if it was just someone he hadn’t run into before, but Айлин [she] didn’t recognize the large, gray demon hurtling down toward them.

“I’m sorry,” Айлин [she] whispered, hoping Вайолет [she] could hear him over the cacophony.

Then the demon vanished. An instant later, there was a loud crash. Айлин [she]’s eyes flicked to the far side of the square, where the gray demon’s body slammed into the ground with enough force to crack the ground beneath him.

Паук [he] lifted a hand toward the demons running toward them and then clenched his fist. For an instant, nothing happened. Then, almost in unison, the demons’ eyes widened. Their runs faltered as their hands shot up to their throats, eyes bulging, hands clawing at nothing.

The demons behind Айлин [she] didn’t know what he did. They couldn’t hear the muted, choked wheezing. They couldn’t see the bulging eyes full of horror and disbelief.

“Cowards,” Робон [he] snarled, spinning the axe at his side and striding toward Паук [he]. “I told you to kill them!”

He lunged, and the demons that could still move all attacked. Айлин [she]’s skull pounded and his ears throbbed. For the second time, the streets spoke in sounds he didn’t recognize. He had heard the sigh of death before. He had seen the crunch of bone and the scuffle of a brawl.

But nothing like this. More than twenty demons bore down on them from every direction. Bows twanged from afar. Arrows whistled and feet pounded against stone. Every instinct in his body screamed for him to run.

He didn’t. Even if he’d wanted to, there was nowhere to run. The street whispered death, but death did not come.

For the first time, the street lied to Айлин [she]. The arrows dropped from the air of their own volition and tumbled to the ground harmlessly. Demons were ripped from the sky and slammed to the ground as a blur danced from one to the other, and Айлин [she] realized he must have been going insane.

Nothing else would have explained the muted giggles that danced in back of his head. Nothing else would have made the form that slipped from the shadows, tripping demons and yanking weapons from their hands, make sense.

More of Голон [he]’s men pressed forward. They never made it. The square itself seemed to have come alive at Паук [he]’s behest.

Айлин [she] watched in growing disbelief as he watched grown demons — some of whom had terrorized him for years — start to fear. The confidence in their eyes faded as the crack of their limbs rang into the air, their weapons shattered, and the howling gales pummeled them.

Some still pressed onward. Робон [he] bared his teeth as he pressed through the sudden howling wind, raising his weapon to bring it down on Паук [he]. He trudged forward until the two were face to face.

They stared at each other for a brief instant. With a roar, Робон [he] brought the axe down. Паук [he] still didn’t move. Робон [he]’s hand vanished.

His axe rang as it bounced off the ground beside Паук [he]. Робон [he]’s hand splattered down beside it with a wet thunk. Паук [he] tilted his head to the side, then curled his fingers inward. Робон [he]’s eyes bulged.

“What is this?” Вайолет [she] whispered.

Every single one of Голон [he]’s demons laid on the ground around them. Not one had managed to step within ten feet of them, much less five. Not so much as a single droplet of blood had made it onto the stone at their feet.

Demons clawed at their throats and scrambled back from Паук [he] as if he were the manifestation of death itself. They all remained on the ground, not so much as daring to rise to their feet.

Айлин [she]’s ears twitched. His eyes went wide as his skin chilled. The sounds of the street hadn’t dimmed. More than thirty demons had begun the fight, and more than thirty demons still remained.

Паук [he] released his hands. A dozen demons drew in desperate breaths and stared up at Паук [he] with wide, terrified eyes.

Not a single one of them had died. Паук [he] had broken them utterly and thoroughly, but even the demon that had been pelted into the ground had somehow survived the blow.

Айлин [she] nearly took a step back before he managed to catch himself. Паук [he] hadn’t said he could move yet.

“Who are you?” Робон [he] demanded through gritted teeth as he clutched the stump of his missing arm. “

What are you?”

“I am Паук [he].” The stranger raised his voice as he continued, “Where is your leader? He should be out here with his soldiers, not cowering while you bleed for him. I see no streetlord here. Only a Wastelicker.”


The word sounded so odd coming from Паук [he]’s mouth that a terrified laugh nearly slipped past Айлин [she]’s shock. Almost.

A murmur of discontent passed through the demons that were still in enough shape to actually speak. Just because Паук [he] hadn’t killed anyone didn’t mean he’d left them all in good shape. More than a few were definitely unconscious.

The entry flap of the large tent at the back of the square moved. Even despite Паук [he]’s evident strength, Айлин [she]’s heart skipped a beat as a towering demon stepped out from within it. Голон [he] rose up, standing over twice Паук [he]’s height even in the distance.

Four, muscled arms emerged from his red-skinned chest and horns jutted out of his head every few inches, curling up like a crown. Each hand carried a jagged, deadly blade nearly as tall as Айлин [she].

The Rank 3 Demon’s body was positively rippling with danger. Every single ounce of him was a weapon. A killing machine that had brought this area of the streets under his control. Айлин [she] had never seen the monster in action, but he knew beyond a doubt that Голон [he] had earned his title of streetlord through blood.

Голон [he]’s angular jaw flexed as he took in the state of his men. His pitch black eyes settled on Паук [he] and he strode across the square in his direction. “Trampling over Rank 2s is no feat to be proud of, wretch. Only a fool glories over his power when compared to the weak.”

Айлин [she] almost released a snort of laughter. Even though the words were completely true, they couldn’t have possibly been more hypocritical.

“I take it you would be Голон [he]?” Паук [he] asked, not bothering to address anything the other demon had just said.

“You remember my name, then.” Голон [he]’s lips curled back into a sneer. “Then you will remember the name of your killer as you pass on into the next life. It is unfortunate. Everyone here will have already forgotten—”

A loud crack split the air.

Golen swayed in place, his mouth still halfway open as his eyes drifted down to where an enormous bolt of lightning had just slammed into his chest with enough force to crush both muscle and bone. Arcs of electricity raced across his blackened skin and into the ground, joined by a river of blood trickling across his charred body.

The demon’s lips trembled. He took a step, pitched forward, and crashed to the ground with a wet splatter. His swords clattered from his hands and laid at his sides as blood pooled around him.

Айлин [she]’s ears rang, and it wasn’t from the loud noise.

It should have been impossible.

It was impossible — and yet, his ears and eyes did not lie to him. Йог [he]’s ruined corpse. The wind. Demons collapsing without so much as a chance to fight back, the forms in the shadows. And now Голон [he], dead in the same way as Йог [he].

Not to semi-external magic, but to true magic.

Паук [he] walked up to Голон [he] and squatted at the dead streetlord’s side. “I came to ask if you minded if I took over your operation. You don’t, do you?”

To absolutely nobody’s surprise, Голон [he] didn’t respond. Паук [he] nodded and rose back to his feet. He adjusted the lapel of his jacket and turned to the dozens of demons still sprawled across the ground.

“If your legs aren’t broken, get up.”

A little over three quarters of them scrambled to their feet with such speed that it would have made a member of the guard proud.

Вайолет [she] and Айлин [she] exchanged a look. Айлин [she] wasn’t even sure what the look was meant to be, other than to make sure someone else was actually present to confirm his eyes and ears weren’t lying to him.

“Correct me if I’m wrong,” Паук [he] said, his gaze sweeping across the gathered crowd. “But I believe this would make me the streetlord, yes?”

Nobody said a word.

“That was not a rhetorical question.”

“It does, sir,” Айлин [she] stammered.

The wrapping covering Паук [he]’s face shifted, giving Айлин [she] the sense that he was smiling.

“In that case, if you’ve got issues with my election, I’d like to welcome any challenges right now. All at once would be preferrable. My patience is thin.”

Silence wrapped the square as the demons froze, not even daring to draw in a breath and potentially garner any further interest from Паук [he]. The obscured demon waited for a few seconds before nodding.

“It sounds like nobody has any issues,” Паук [he] said. “I believe that means you obey my orders now, correct?”

“We will do as you order,” Робон [he] ground out, his voice shrouded in fear. The blood flowing from his arm had stemmed, but the pain in his posture was still evident.

Айлин [she] doubted the demon was put out about Голон [he]’s death as much as he feared for his own future. A streetlord’s second had to be a warrior capable of fending off pointless challenges. There wasn’t much use for a crippled second.

“Then I look forward to working together. As I suspect you are all intelligent enough to surmise, I am a busy man. I don’t have time to waste with petty squabbles or fools. Are you all certain you don’t want to challenge me?”

The only person here that would even dare breath in your direction is already a burnt splatter at your feet.

Паук [he] nodded to himself when it became abundantly clear that absolutely nobody was stupid enough to speak up. “Good, good. A few things to get you all started. First, I want everyone here to find every single person living in the area that I control — how far is that, by the way?”

When nobody answered him, Паук [he]’s eyes flicked to Айлин [she].

“Up from the alleys behind us until Snakemouth tavern,” Айлин [she] stammered. “After that is the area under streetlord Rocci’s control.”

“Everyone in my area, then,” Паук [he] said. “I want you to gather them and bring them here. Distribute food to all of them in exchange for information.”

“Information about what, streetlord Паук [he]?” Робон [he] asked, finally finding his words again.

“Everything relating to the other streetlords in the city, especially the ones near us — but I’ll take anything that seems valuable as well. I want knowledge, not goods. Stop taking food from them as well. It’s worthless to me. We’ll have enough.”

If anyone else had given that order, they probably would have been challenged on the spot. Giving away food was the same thing as giving away life.

But it hadn’t been someone else. It had been Паук [he] and, with Голон [he]’s body still at his feet, everyone dared to do nothing but nod.

“We will do as you command. Not a word will pass from this square of your powers,” Робон [he] promised.

He was clearly doing his best to keep his spot as second in command. Айлин [she] had no idea if the demon’s efforts would last long, but nobody in their right mind would speak up while Паук [he] was still present.

“On the contrary. Let everyone know,” Паук [he] said. “I want every single streetlord in the city to know.”

A nervous air built in the square.

“Know what, streetlord Паук [he]?” Робон [he] asked hesitantly, as if scared to hear the answer.

“To know I’m coming for them, of course. Let them know that they can either bend the knee or I’ll kill them and their entire guild.”

Plains. He’s going to try to bring every single streetlord together? Why?

Паук [he]’s eyes traced through the air and landed on Айлин [she]. He stiffened at the sudden attention as every single demon turned to look in his direction. His stomach sank.

“One more thing,” Паук [he] said. “I’ve got too much work to stand around here constantly wasting time. So, while I’m gone…”

Please, no.

“You’ll be taking orders from Айлин [she] over here.”

Chapter 462: Blur

The next few minutes were a blur. Айлин [she]’s blood pounded in his ears so hard that he could barely even hear himself think. He vaguely remembered Паук [he] leading him and Вайолет [she] past the other demons and into Голон [he]’s tent.

He was pretty sure he passed out at some point, because when his brain finally started working properly, he found himself seated beside Вайолет [she] in a throne so massive that it had room enough for both of them. The tent around them was completely empty.

Granted, calling a large stone chair with bones littered across the ground at its feet a throne was a bit of stretch, but a throne was made by the one sitting upon it, not its material. This had been the spot where Голон [he] had ruled. Where he had made Айлин [she]’s life agony for years, for absolutely no reason beyond that he could.

And now Голон [he] was dead. Айлин [she] sat on his throne, and he would have traded almost anything he had to be literally anywhere else. Вайолет [she]’s hand found his on the cold stone and she clasped it, her face several shades paler than normal and her eyes locked straight ahead. Her shoulders were stiff and jaw set.

Айлин [she] couldn’t remember the last time he’d seen Вайолет [she] this scared. He couldn’t remember the last time he had been this scared. Голон [he]’s death had somehow made things even worse for them.

Despite everything, an amused thought flickered through his mind and his lips moved before he could stop them.

“I bet you wish you stayed back now, don’t you?”

Вайолет [she] snorted. “And miss this? No way. I’m having the time of my life.”

The intensity that their hands clenched each other told Айлин [she] that Вайолет [she] most certainly was not having the time of her life. But, even though Вайолет [she] was just as powerless as he was, her presence somehow made the terror a flicker more bearable.

Maybe it was just comfort he wasn’t going to die alone.

Both of them flinched as the tent flap opened. Паук [he] stepped inside, followed by another demon. Her face was wrapped in the same way his was and she carried a huge leather box on her back.

As the tent flap fluttered closed behind them, the ground at their feet twisted. Shadows warped and a third demon rose up from within them. She couldn’t have been much taller than Айлин [she]. One of her two red horns was broken off at the base and there was a mischievous grin on her face.

There are three of them. Are they all that strong? I don’t know if there are any gods listening, but if there are, please save me.

“You’ve scared them half to death,” the taller female demon said, a note of irritation in her voice. “Are you trying to give the poor children a heart attack?”

“They’ll be dealing with a lot scarier things than me pretty soon,” Паук [he] replied. “And they’re doing great. Just look at them.”

The tiniest corner of Айлин [she]’s mouth quirked up as he attempted to give them a nervous smile. Паук [he] had assigned him to be the streetlord. If he couldn’t look the part, it wouldn’t just look bad on him.

It would reflect on Паук [he] — and demons as powerful as he were not well known to be the forgiving or understanding types.

“See?” Паук [he] asked. “He’s thrilled.”

“They’re just hungry,” the short demon said. She reached into spider’s bag and pulled out two strips of jerky. She eyed them, then fell through the floor. Айлин [she] nearly leapt into the air and screamed as she shot up from the ground directly before the throne. The demon thrust the jerky toward him and Вайолет [she]. “Here! Eat up!”

Semi-external magic, but on the border of actual external magic. She’s probably as strong as Паук [he].

Айлин [she] didn’t dare refuse. He and Вайолет [she] both followed her orders, and he had to admit that the food was welcome. It probably would have tasted less like ash if he wasn’t so focused on survival.

“Better?” the demon asked.

Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] give her a stiff nod.


“See?”

“You’re both idiots,” the female demon said. “You’re lucky I like you.”

The short demon vanished back into the shadows and reappeared beside Паук [he] as he and the female demon drew up to stand a few paces away from the throne. Паук [he] raised a hand and Айлин [she] stiffened. If it wasn’t for Вайолет [she]’s hand wrapped around his, he suspected he might have dove for cover.

“Relax,” Паук [he] said. “I didn’t bring you all the way here just to kill you. That would be kind of pointless, don’t you think?”

Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] just stared at him. Паук [he] blew out a sigh and tapped his foot on the ground.

“I command you to speak with complete honesty, and I swear that I will not get mad at you for anything you say. Frankly, do you really think you’d be able to offend me? Why would I care about your opinion or get offended by you making a mistake?”

That… was a good point. Паук [he] was so much more powerful than Голон [he] that he couldn’t even comprehend it. To Паук [he], he and Вайолет [she] were probably little more than bugs. To Айлин [she]’s surprise, that actually did help.

A god didn’t care what a bug thought of it. There was absolutely nothing he held the power to do that could ever threaten Паук [he]. As long as they didn’t fail to obey his orders, Паук [he] would be expending more effort killing them than not.

“I — I understand,” Айлин [she] said, forcing his numb lips to move. “But we’re going to die anyway.”

“What? Why?”

“We aren’t strong enough to be streetlords,” Вайолет [she] said as she found her own voice. “The moment you leave, we’ll both be killed. Even if the terror you instilled into the demons here is enough to hold Голон [he]’s men back, it won’t hold back others. They haven’t seen what we have.”

“The other streetlords aren’t that much stronger than Голон [he], are they?” Паук [he] asked, tilting his head to the side.

“They’re mostly around the same strength, I’d think. If they were stronger, they’d have taken his territory,” Айлин [she] said. “But we aren’t like Голон [he].”

“That’s a good thing, because I’d have killed you already if you were,” Паук [he] said. “Oh, by the way, I had some demons go retrieve your two friends. They’ll be safe. I just didn’t want to leave them alone. That’s how some idiot finds them and kills them, starting a whole problem I really don’t want to deal with right now.”

“You… aren’t going to kill them?” Айлин [she] asked hesitantly, not entirely sure what Паук [he] was talking about.

“Why would I kill children?” Паук [he] asked. “No. They’ll be fine. I’m more concerned with the two of you.”

“Even if you somehow killed every single streetlord, someone would eventually show up to challenge Айлин [she] when you left,” Вайолет [she] said. “Being streetlord without power is just a death sentence.”

“Well, logically. I’m well aware of that.”

“So… you do plan to kill us?” Айлин [she] asked. He was somewhat surprised to find that he actually had the boldness to speak the words, but it was too late to take them back.

“No. I already said that would be a waste. After all the effort I went through to get you two here, why would I do that?” Паук [he] held a hand out and the female demon took the huge block of leather off her back.

Айлин [she]’s eyes widened as Паук [he] split the block open, and they widened even further as he saw what was inside of it.

Paper.

It had to be. He’d never seen paper, but it looked exactly like what he’d heard. Crinkly and thin, far lighter than vellum. And it just wasn’t just a single sheet. The box was no box. It was a book, and the book was completely stuffed full.

He couldn’t even begin to comprehend how expensive it was. Enough to feed everyone on the streets for years and then some, most likely. Вайолет [she]’s hand gripped his own even tighter as she came to the same realization.

Паук [he] wasn’t just a random powerful demon. There was only one explanation as to how he’d just be strolling the Damned Plains with a literal treasure horde. Паук [he] was from the upper echelons.

Does he work for an Archdemon? Is he an Archdemon himself? Why would someone like that ever care about us?

“You know, I just realized I really don’t know anything about how this works,” Паук [he] said, his face wrappings creasing as he straightened back up and looked away from the enormous book. “What kind of demons are you lot? Not hunger, I hope.”

“What… kind?” Айлин [she] asked, blinking. “I’m not sure I understand your question. Do you mean what our Demon Rune is?”

Паук [he] nodded. “Yes, that — and also what emotion do you consume.”

Айлин [she] almost laughed, but it didn’t sound like Паук [he] was joking. “I’m not strong enough to consume emotion yet. Neither is Вайолет [she]. We wouldn’t be on the streets if we could. Right now, we can only process pure energy from eating food. I’ve got one Demon Rune. So does Вайолет [she].”

“Just a single Demon Rune? Nothing else? No name?”

“Yes. We’re only Rank 1,” Вайолет [she] said, shifting uncomfortably. “That’s why we stand no chance as streetlords. They’re just Demon Runes. Plain ones. We can’t reach Rank 2 unless we get stronger or richer, and we can’t do that because we don’t have anything to build off.”

“Nasty cycle,” Паук [he] said with a small nod. “Well, that’s simple enough. At least you don’t have bad runes.”

“Simple?” Вайолет [she] asked, a flicker of irritation entering her words. Even in their situation, Айлин [she] couldn’t help but feel the same.

They’d both fought tooth and nail to rip every dreg of life they could from the Damned Plains, and it hadn’t netted them so much as a single rune. Getting stronger wasn’t a luxury they could afford when even making it through the next day came at a steep cost.

“Quite,” Паук [he] said. He ruffled through his bag, then blew out a breath. “Only have one of these left. I really should have bought more. I hope there are some apothecaries in the area.”

Before Вайолет [she] or Айлин [she] could ask what the demon was talking about, he reached into his bag and pulled out a vial full of glistening blue liquid. His eyes crinkled in a smile as he popped a wax seal off its top and held it out to Айлин [she].

“Drink.”
==========
Chapter 463: & Announcement

One drink and exactly thirty minutes later, Айлин [she] died.

At least, a portion of him did. A demon was their soul, and their runes were them. It was difficult to state exactly where the mind started and the soul ended, but it was a common belief that every step toward the peak of power brought one farther away from their former self.

He’d just taken over a dozen.

Паук [he] had stuffed him like a pig on the table of some Archdemon, ripe to be eaten. He had been polite but relentless, summoning rune after rune in the air before Айлин [she] and waiting until he absorbed it before moving on to the next. Паук [he] seemed to have a limitless supply.

It had taken Айлин [she] minutes to draw every single one, and he feared to think what would have happened if he’d taken to it faster. He’d had thought it would end when Паук [he] produced the sixth rune in a row, but the moment Айлин [she] had absorbed it, Паук [he] had given him strict instructions on how to combine it and what to focus on.

And, by some miracle, it had worked — but Паук [he] wasn’t done. Even as Айлин [she] had stared at his newly forged Rank 2 Rune, Паук [he] did nothing but summon yet another rune to Айлин [she]’s soul. Then he’d shattered it, commanding Айлин [she] to draw the power into his newly made rune.

Паук [he] repeated that until the rune was full — and yet, somehow, they still weren’t done. When Айлин [she] finally managed to fill his rune, Паук [he] did nothing but summon yet another rune and stare at him expectantly.

Then they’d repeated the cycle.

It wasn’t a miracle anymore. The shock and disbelief had turned into awe. Паук [he] was no mere demon. He couldn’t have been an Archdemon either — no self-respecting Archdemon would ever have been caught dead passing away so much power to a streetlord, much less a starving child.

There was no doubt that the runes came with so many strings that Айлин [she] may as well have been woven into a tapestry, but there was no refusing Паук [he]. Even if he’d wanted to, he wasn’t so sure he’d have had the willpower to.

And so the old Айлин [she] died at the lip of the glass vial with nothing but a single ratty Demon Rune to his name. In his place woke a newly forged Rank 3 demon. The energy pumping through his soul wound into his body and made every single muscle burn like it was on fire.

“Айлин [she]?” Вайолет [she]’s concerned voice broke through the ringing in his ears and the blood pounding in his skull. “Are you okay?”

He wasn’t so sure he knew the answer to that question. Everything felt so hot. So… different. It was his body, but it wasn’t. Runic energy worked its way through him and reforged the flesh in its wake.

His stomach filled out and the little muscle he had hardened and thickened with power. His dirty fingernails darkened to an ashy gray and he felt his teeth sharpening. His ears lengthened and narrowed at their tops. The burning heat started to abate, replaced by a comforting warmth deep within him.

A flicker of fear that he might turn into a lumbering hulk like Голон [he] passed through him, but no such thing happened. His tongue ran along his lip.

He could taste the world, and its flavor was vibrant. So full of energy and potential — but that wasn’t all. Айлин [she]’s ears twitched. Everyone was so… present. The panicked thump of Вайолет [she]’s heartbeat beside him mixed with the flavor of her fear and concern.

He could taste her emotion. Even without looking in her direction, he knew exactly where she was. Her thoughts were so loud and flavorful that he could tell exactly what she was thinking.

So this is what power is? I feel like I know everything. Like I’m in control for the first time in my life. It’s incredible. I —

Айлин [she]’s thoughts ground to a halt. It wasn’t just Вайолет [she] he could detect.


All the newfound power flowing through him seemed to freeze to a halt as his senses passed over the others in the room.

The short demon, her youthful features seeming to place her as not much older than he, tasted like an ocean of blood. Айлин [she] reflexively flinched back as his instincts took over. Looking at her felt like gazing down into the open maw of an enormous, crazed beast a thousand times his size.

The taller female demon wasn’t much better. Instead of blood, she just tasted… wrong. Айлин [she] couldn’t place the flavors enveloping her properly. It was a strange mixture of what he could only describe as sweet and earthy that might have been pleasant if it hadn’t been for the lingering aftertaste of rot.

And then there was Паук [he].

Айлин [she]’s senses had always been sharp. He hadn’t been the strongest. He hadn’t been the smartest, nor had he been the fastest. The only reason he’d survived as long as he had was the whisper of the streets. The warnings that he could find where no other could.

And, for the first time in his life, Айлин [she] wished his senses hadn’t been quite so good. Bands of terror constricted around his chest and started to squeeze.

Паук [he] was ancient death. The inevitable end that came for all. He tasted like rubble and crumbling civilization. The demon was so old that the city itself felt like Трэдон [he] was a child in comparison. A creature that lived as long as he had could barely even still be called a demon.

He’d never met an Archdemon before, nor did he have the slightest desire to, but if Паук [he] had claimed to be one, Айлин [she] would have believed him without a flicker of hesitation. His soul was so ancient, so immense, that he couldn’t even begin to pick up on what else had gone into it.

“Айлин [she]!” Вайолет [she] said again, more urgently this time. She grabbed him by the shoulder and he drew in a sharp breath, blinking furiously. The overwhelming flavor assaulting him finally relented as his attention diverted.

“I’m fine,” Айлин [she] rasped, his eyes flicking back to Паук [he] despite his best efforts.

The ancient demon took a step back, scooping his huge book off the ground handing it back to the taller female demon.

“You did well,” Паук [he] said. “I’d say that should be sufficient to get you started. I don’t think you’ll have too much trouble early on, so it’ll give you time to get used to things.”

Айлин [she] couldn’t muster words to respond. He wasn’t sure what he possibly could have said, even if he could. He’d dreamed of getting just a single extra rune, moving just a step up the ladder so he might have a better chance at survival, nearly every single night of his life.

And, in a flicker of an instant, Паук [he] had dragged him up to the level of a streetlord without so much as a second thought. Like it was nothing. It almost felt unfair — but little about life was, and Айлин [she] was all too aware that the gift hadn’t come for free.

“I’ll do everything in my power to live up to your expectations. I don’t know much about being a streetlord, but any command you give me will be done.”

“Just try not to be too much of a prick,” Паук [he] said with a dry laugh. “Focus on getting stronger. I can only take you so far, and there are others I have to work on as well. All you’ll have to do is be my face.”

“If any of the other streetlords try to challenge me, I’m not sure I’ll be able to do anything. They have much more experience than I do.”

“Leave the other streetlords and their gangs to me,” Паук [he] said with a shake of his head. “Your only job is to keep this one under control. Trust me. They’ll fall in line easily enough. My power will be enough to hold any fools off for the next few days, and by that point, you’ll have come into your own well enough to hold your own.”

Вайолет [she] glanced from Айлин [she] to Паук [he] in confusion. She’d clearly picked up on the shift in how they spoke. She knew there should have been no way for Айлин [she] to ever be able to hold his own against anyone in the gang, much less even consider fighting a streetlord.

She wisely chose to avoid voicing her confusion. No matter how openly Паук [he] beckoned them to speak, the taste of the man’s soul still made Айлин [she]’s tongue feel like it was coated in a layer of ash.

“I’ll remain in this area for a short amount of time. If someone does end up causing trouble that you can’t handle, then call me. I will deal with them. But, if you’re capable of it, I’d suggest trying to deal with it yourself. It’ll be better for the long run.”

Айлин [she] nodded his understanding. “What should I have the gang do? You said to spread word about your presence, but how? If they go to other streetlords and threaten them, they’ll just be killed. A challenge like that isn’t something a streetlord can ignore if they want to keep their power.”

“Wait a day — ah, a short while,” Паук [he] advised after a second of thought. “Don’t send anyone out yet. Just focus on getting used to your changed self and preparing for the future. I will lay the framework for messengers. I’m pleased that you’re already thinking like a leader. Well done.”

I’m more just trying to keep us from all getting slaughtered. Would Паук [he] even notice if that happened? I’m not sure I want to know the answer.

“Then I’ll do as you ask,” Айлин [she] said.

“Good. I’ll be taking the tent beside yours. If you need me, come to it. Just make sure you actually need me.”

With that, Паук [he] swept out of the room. The other two demons followed after him, leaving Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] in silence.

“Айлин [she]?” Вайолет [she] whispered. “What just happened?”

It was several seconds before Айлин [she] responded.

“I think I just became a streetlord.”
==========
Chapter 464: Mussenger

Ной [he] left Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] in their new tent as he led Мокси [she] and Ли [she] over to their temporary new lodgings. The tents really weren’t much, but they were better than ducking into an alleyway to speak.

“You make a really good demon,” Ли [she] said in a low tone once they were inside the tent.

“I’m going to avoid taking that as an insult,” Ной [he] said. They all sat down, taking advantage of the momentary respite to relax as much as they could. “Aside from you, I haven’t really been a fan of any demons I’ve met.”

“Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] seem nice,” Мокси [she] said. “When you aren’t traumatizing them, that is.”

Ной [he] winced. “I’d love to be nicer with them. I really would — but I’m pretty sure that would be even worse, wouldn’t it? Like this, they can assume I’m just some powerful asshole with an agenda that they fit into. If I was acting nice, they’d be terrified. They’d spend all their time trying to figure out my motives.”

Мокси [she] paused, then blinked. “You know, that’s surprisingly perceptive of you.”

“I am a perceptive man.”

“So you are. I just need reminders sometimes,” Мокси [she] said, leaning her head against his shoulder. “I can’t say I love the strategy, but you’re probably right that it’s the best option. What about you, Ли [she]? Any thoughts?”

Ли [she] shrugged. “They’re alive. If they’d made it this far in a city, then they’re desperate to make it farther. Terrifying or not, Ной [he] is probably their best chance. Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] were both starving to death when we first met them. They’d probably have both been dead in a few weeks. A month or two at most.”

“And now one of them is Rank 3,” Ной [he] mused. He glanced at his grimoire, which was now apparently more than pleased to let Мокси [she] carry it around.

They’d both been taken slightly by surprise when Ной [he] had been first dressing himself up as Паук [he] and, while Мокси [she] was helping him look as mysterious as possible, she’d absentmindedly lifted it straight off his back.

The book was definitely far more intelligent than it had been when he’d first gotten it. It wasn’t just taking power from the runes he gave it. It was growing. Ной [he] wasn’t sure how he felt about that, but the book had been playing along as of late, so he had no complaints.

“How many runes did it take to brute force that?” Мокси [she] asked. “I can’t imagine it was a low cost.”

“It wasn’t,” Ной [he] admitted. “I sacrificed two existing Rank 3s just to break apart for energy. Айлин [she] wasn’t very experienced so he lost a ton of power, but considering he’d literally never made a rune before, I don’t hold it against him. He seemed pretty intelligent.”

“What Rank 3 does he have now?”

Ной [he] looked at her out of the corners of his eyes. “No idea, Ли [she]. I can’t read demon runes. I gave him a bunch of Fire and Earth runes and guided him on combining six Rank 2s, but the seventh one had his Demon Rune as part of the combination so he had to do that one on his own. When they all combined, the Demon Rune swallowed everything and now the whole thing is unreadable. The final result felt pretty solid, though.”

“I can ask him at some point,” Ли [she] said. A small frown passed over her features before she crushed it. “You were smart to stop before he hit Rank 4.”

Ной [he]’s lips pressed thin. “Yeah. I remember Азель [he]’s warning — and I haven’t forgotten your situation. We’ll find a way to make a Rank 4 without changing who you are, Ли [she]. This is the absolute best place to do that. We have a lot of test subjects.”

“They’re people too,” Ли [she] said. “They aren’t just subjects.”

He paused. They were people. He knew that. It was apparent enough that Айлин [she] and Вайолет [she] were really no different than Изабель [she], Тодд [he], and all the others back in Арбитраж [he]. Now that he’d spent a little time with Айлин [she], he had to admit he didn’t want to see the young demon die.

But the other demons in the Damned Plains… they might have been people as well, but when he weighed their lives against Мокси [she] or Ли [she]’s — Сильвертид [he]’s words rang through his head once more.

“I haven’t forgotten that,” Ной [he] said softly. “But you and Мокси [she] are infinitely more important to me than any of them are. I’m not going to try to go around killing demons, but I think we’ll be running into more than enough of them that stand in our way for me to do a little experimenting. I can’t afford mercy to our enemies when so much is on the line.”

They all fell silent for a few moments.

“Thank you,” Ли [she] said. “I didn’t mean to make it sound like I don’t appreciate what you’re doing. I was just thinking back to my time here. Before I met you and Мокси [she] and everyone else. There are so many other demons that never got to escape. Demons that just had to adapt or die.”

“Anyone that we can help, we will. But not at the cost of your life. Not at Мокси [she]’s either,” Ной [he] said. His eyes drifted to the gourd at Мокси [she]’s side and his lip curled up in a small smile. “Mine… well, mine is a bit cheaper. I might be willing to sell a few of those.”


Ли [she] snickered and Мокси [she] rolled her eyes.

“Just don’t sell them for too cheap,” Мокси [she] said. “You’re like an addict. Don’t forget that killing yourself is not the best solution to every single problem.”

“Hey, I’ve been good about it recently.”

“Which is why it’s even more important to stop you from relapsing.”

They all fell silent as a demon passed by the tent outside, but they continued on without stopping. It seemed that the camp was too scared to try and challenge anything thus far. That was good.

Granted, the first step of the plan was probably the absolute easiest. It almost made Ной [he] feel a bit scummy. Rolling up to a group of Demons far weaker than he was and just blasting them to kingdom come made him feel like a bully.

Fortunately, they’d been assholes first. That made things much easier. If he’d managed to take over this gang without killing the former leader, it would have been harder to solidify power later.

If the only thing that demons respected was power, peaceful takeovers probably weren’t going to be too convincing. They’d learn in time. Even if one of the streetlords was strong enough to fight against him or if they banded together… the end would be the same.

“Do you really think Айлин [she] is going to be able to keep control of the demons here?” Мокси [she] asked with a note of concern in her voice. “He’s got the power now, but he’s still a kid.”

“I think necessity drives people to do great things, even when they aren’t ready to do them yet,” Ной [he] replied. “And he’s got some time to get used to his new strength. If he’s smart, he won’t waste it.”

“We’ll help him, right?” Ли [she] asked.

“Of course,” Ной [he] said. “It would be a complete waste of his life, not to mention all our efforts, if he just got killed the moment we stopped paying attention. We’ll help him. He just can’t know how much we’re helping him or he’ll start to rely on us. For this to work, he needs to be strong on his own. If he isn’t, he’s dead the moment we leave.”

Мокси [she] and Ли [she] nodded.

“So… what next, then?” Ли [she] asked. “I doubt anyone is going to do much here, but it won’t be long before word spreads — especially since you didn’t try to restrict people from talking. The nearest streetlord probably already knows that Голон [he] is dead.”

Ной [he] smiled. “Oh, I’m counting on it. We’ve just been killing a little time to make sure the message has time to spread. I suppose it’s been long enough now.”

“So…” Ли [she] trailed off, sending him an expectant look.

“Oh, go ahead.” Ной [he] rolled his eyes and shook his head. “Just be careful and make sure not to get too carried away.”

“Okay,” Ли [she] said with a cheerful smile. “I’ll bring you back something to eat!”

“Please—”

Ли [she] vanished into a shadow.

“Don’t,” Ной [he] finished, wincing. “Damn it. She’s totally going to bring back a corpse.”

***

Врит [he] was having a good day for one reason alone — Фрот [he] was not.

Ever since they’d been born, her brother had always seemed to have the upper hand. Фрот [he] stumbled into the best runes. He’d gotten the most training. When they’d taken over a gang together, Фрот [he] had become the streetlord.

Врит [he] didn’t mind taking the backseat. She didn’t mind working from the shadows — but she did mind getting absolutely no recognition for anything she did. It wasn’t easy corralling a small horde of demons and making sure they obeyed Фрот [he]’s commands. It wasn’t easy training the youths they brought in, nor was it easy watching Фрот [he] take credit for every damned thing she did.

Unfortunately, while Фрот [he] was lazy, he was also powerful. Powerful enough to protect their gang, and powerful enough to keep Врит [he] from doing anything other than following his orders.

It was rare that Фрот [he] had a bad day, but today was one such day.

“Who does this Паук [he] think he is?” Фрот [he] snarled, his furred fist clenching in fury at his sides. His lips pulled back in a snarl, revealing a row of pointed teeth. “What a ridiculous demand. Killing one streetlord and he goes around acting as if he’s the new lord of the city.”

For all the bluster, Врит [he] knew Фрот [he] more than well enough to recognize when he was scared. Голон [he] wasn’t the strongest streetlord, but he’d been a respectable opponent. If he hadn’t been, they’d have taken the territory from him long ago.

There was no doubt in Врит [he]’s mind that Паук [he] hadn’t killed him nearly as easily as the panicked rumors claimed. Rumors were just that. Rumors. They always exaggerated. They always changed reality to twist it into something more interesting — but there was truth at their base. Паук [he] was a formidable opponent, and he was likely coming for them.

“I want him dead,” Фрот [he] snarled. “Before he even has a chance to show his face here.”

As if anyone’s going to do that. If he’s strong enough to handle a streetlord, then he’s strong enough to deal with any of our subordinates, especially when it’s his own camp.

“Врит [he], handle it.”

And just like that, Врит [he] was no longer having a good day.

“I — what? I can’t beat him. He killed Голон [he]!”

“Голон [he] was strong, but he was an idiot. It’s been a long time since you tried your hand against another Rank 3,” Фрот [he] said, a hand clenching around the armrest of his seat. “You should be able to kill him before he even realizes you’re there. You’ve done it before.”

“Not against someone like this!” Врит [he] exclaimed. “Rumors are rumors, but we can’t just completely ignore—”

“I am the streetlord,” Фрот [he] snarled, cutting her off midsentence. “Are you refusing a direct order?”

Damn it. He’s terrified. Idiot is putting more stock in those rumors than he should.

“Фрот [he], sending me is a waste. Don’t buy into the rumors so badly,” Врит [he] said. “Паук [he] doesn’t know what we’re capable of. Our best chance of killing him is together, not by going in alone.”

Фрот [he] hesitated. His hand unclenched and he leaned back, blowing out a slow breath and shaking his head. “You may be correct. I am being hasty. Yes. It would be impossible for someone that powerful to truly be here. A wise call, Врит [he]. It is a good thing I have kept you as my advisor.”

A relieved sigh silently slipped from Врит [he]’s lips. Her brother was rash, but he wasn’t an idiot. Now, all they had to do was —

“Excuse me?”

They both spun. A short female demon stood at the entrance of their throne room, chewing on a large chunk of roast meat. Врит [he]’s blood ran cold. She hadn’t noticed anyone entering, and the door was still closed.

“Who are you?” Фрот [he] demanded, rising to his feet. “How did you get in here?”

“I’m a muss… mess… uh, something,” the demon said, trailing off as she chewed thoughtfully on the meat. “I forgot. Anyway, I’m here to bring a message.”

“What message?” Врит [he] asked, flexing her fingers. Claws pushed out of the beds of her fingertips.

“Паук [he] sent me to get your answer on if you’d decided to surrender yet.” The intruder held a hand up. She stuffed the rest of the food into her gullet and swallowed it in one bite. “I can wait if you need to think about it, but if you don’t have one soon, I’m going to have to kill you.”
