Джален [he] reformed in a room that didn’t belong to him. There were rudimentary наполнение [he]s on it to prevent anyone with space magic from entering — наполнение [he]s that he ground out with a flicker of thought, not even bothering to try to slip by gracefully.

He blinked in surprise.

The room was covered with paper. It had been tacked to the walls and strewn about the floor, covered with beautiful, flowing script that would have been far more in place if it wasn’t clearly the ravings of the mad.

Theories and drawings covered the papers, each one trying to break down a movement or different type of strike. He went to peer closer at the papers, his interest piqued.

“What in the Damend Plains?” a woman standing in the center of the room demanded, her voice coming out as a terrified squeak. “How did you get in here?”

Ah, yes. I forgot there was a person here.

Джален [he] tore his gaze away from the papers. “I teleported. Nobody told me you were insane.”

“I — what? It’s impossible to teleport into this room. It’s warded,” the woman said, her eyes narrowing as she dropped into a fighting stance. “Who are you?”

“Do you really not know?” Джален [he] tilted his head to the side. “You should control the insanity. It’s only useful when properly applied. I am not to be forgotten.”

The woman paused. Then she took a step back. “That arrogance. Magus Джален [he] of the Линвик [they]s? What the fuck are you doing in my room? And why is your hood up? It’s hard to figure out who you are when I can’t see your face.”

“You had some dealings with Вермил [he], yes?”

The woman stared at him. Then, slowly, she nodded. “I did. What does—”

“His students need your help because he’s currently off killing some demons,” Джален [he] said through a yawn. “They are progressing, but I want them to progress faster. I imagine you should be able to help me with that.”

The woman’s eyes narrowed. “I owe Вермил [he] nothing. We had a business relationship and nothing more.”

Джален [he] tilted his head to the side. Then he waved his hand around. “Does Отто [he] know about what you’re doing here? All this research? Something tells me he doesn’t, or you wouldn’t have those rudimentary Наполнения [he] on your room. They’re too shit to be his, meaning you’re doing this on your own. Отто [he] isn’t a fan of missing information.”

The woman hesitated. “I’m not hiding anything from him. I am simply verifying it.”

“Right,” Джален [he] drawled. “What is it that you go by nowadays? You change your name too often for me to bother remembering it — not that I’d have remembered it if you kept one.”

“Бёрд [she].”

“Well then, Бёрд [she], either you come help Вермил [he]’s students or I will shamelessly blackmail you with Отто [he]’s annoying ass. Good luck researching shit with him pestering you.”

Бёрд [she]’s eye twitched. “What do you want me to do?”

“I haven’t figured that bit out yet,” Джален [he] admitted. “I’m sure you’ve got something you can offer them, though. Some Runes, perhaps? The treasurer of the King family has access to quite a bit of power.”

“You want me to steal from Отто [he]?” Бёрд [she] demanded, taking a step back. “I won’t. That oversteps both of our boundaries. You’re the head of the Линвик [they] family. Why don’t you—”

“Don’t feel like it, and I don’t know them well enough to give good runes. I’m not saying to steal from Отто [he] — his nose is too sharp for that,” Джален [he] said with a shake of his head. He blurred forward, prodding Бёрд [she] in the forehead. “I’m saying to use your own privileges and access to get them something. I’m more than aware you’re capable of it. You’re young, but Отто [he] hasn’t been shy bragging about your abilities and role in the family. Granted, I did burn the majority of the letters he sent, but I’ve glanced at a few.”

Бёрд [she]’s lips pressed thin. Then she sighed. “Fine, but only if you promise to keep this secret. I will not be blackmailed by the same thing twice. I need to fully research this style before I tell Отто [he] about it.”

“Whatever you want,” Джален [he] said with a wave of his hand. “I really don’t care as long as I get what I want.”

“I’ll see what I can do,” Бёрд [she] said wearily. “Can you get out of my room now? You’re ruining my practice.”

I rather like this helper of Отто [he]’s. Too bad she’s so loyal to him. She’s got balls, even if a big part of them is knowing I can’t mess with the Kings too much.

“Just one more thing,” Джален [he] said.

“What is it?”

“Put some damn clothes on before you find the students. Вермил [he] is going to be pissed if he finds out I sent a nudist after them.”

Бёрд [she] glanced down at herself and her cheeks went bright red as she spun in search for clothes. “Shit! I forgot I was practicing. Why in the Damned Plains didn’t you say anything earlier?”

There was no response. By the time she found them and looked back, Джален [he] was gone. Бёрд [she] pinched the bridge of her nose between her fingers and let out a defeated sigh.

Chapter 472: Вайолет [she]

Ной [he] and Вайолет [she] came to a stop before a red brick building right at the edges of the slums. It wasn’t quite all the way into the nicer parts of Трэдон [he] — if such places even properly existed — but it wasn’t completely overrun by streetlords and starving demons either.

The building stood two stories tall, nestled in the shadow of a rickety tower. All but one of its windows were boarded over with large pieces of what looked to be hard leather tacked in place with metal spikes.

There was no sign to mark its purpose and the door was crafted from a single piece of roughly carved stone. It looked like it should have been far too heavy to remain in place with just a few hinges and, judging by how it had broken off at the top hinge and was leaning against the ground instead of properly suspended, it was.

“This is an apothecary,” Вайолет [she] said. She cleared her throat. “I think. I’ve never gone here. Эдда [she] got really sick once when she ate something she shouldn’t have, but they wouldn’t let us in. I’ve seen people coming out of here with vials before.”

Right. So this is either a potion shop or a drug dealer. Actually, I suppose those are basically the same thing. If you can mix some fancy demon meth, I’m sure you can find a way to make me a mind meld potion.

Ной [he] put a hand on the door. It was about as mobile as it looked to be, which was to say it was a giant slab of stone that had absolutely no place anywhere near a doorway. That was mildly problematic.

He was nowhere near as physically strong as a demon even half his rank. There was no way for Ной [he] to move huge things around without just straight up destroying them, and blowing up the door of a merchant didn’t really seem like a great way to make a good first impression.

“Is something wrong?” Вайолет [she] asked, chewing on her inner cheek. She glanced up at the door. “I swear an apothecary was in here. I haven’t been in the area a while but it looks exactly the same as it did when I last came by.”

Ной [he] let his tremorsense sweep across the ground. It instantly picked up on a form standing just a few feet to the side of the door. They weren’t moving beyond their breaths, but that was enough to outline a blobby shape about a foot taller than Ной [he].

His eyes narrowed. The figure was in a position where Ной [he] wouldn’t have seen them until he stepped inside, which was generally not the location a shopkeeper stood if he wanted to meet a potential client.

That’s more like somebody preparing to ambush me. Tremorsense doesn’t give me enough detail as to specific shapes and forms when they aren’t moving more.

Ной [he] activated his domain. There wasn’t going to be anyone able to feel it out in the boonies of Трэдон [he] anyway. His magical senses passed through the large openings at the bottom and side of the stone door, brushing through the front portion of the store.

It only took him an instant to get a considerably better feel of the demon on the other side of the door. They were holding a rough blade at their side. Even though Ной [he] couldn’t see their face or make out any detail about their expression, he could practically feel the tension rolling off them.

Scared? Angry? Something in between? I don’t think anyone here should have any reason to be pissed at me yet unless we got unlucky enough to find the one apothecary that happened to be related to someone I’ve blown up.

I can’t just stand around here forever, though. Вайолет [she] is going to get confused. I don’t know if I want to buy potions from someone trying to kill me either though. Leaving could work… but leaving without finding out more just feels lame.

“Nothing’s wrong,” Ной [he] said with a shake of his head as he came to a conclusion. He nodded to the door and raised his voice slightly. “I’m just waiting for the good apothecary to open the door for us.”

Вайолет [she] blinked. Then her cheeks colored. “Uh… Паук [he], sir, they don’t open the doors for you here. You have to do that yourself.”

“You might have before,” Ной [he] said, tapping a foot on the ground impatiently. “But the kind apothecary lying in wait with a little toothpick in their hand is going to open this door for us so I don’t destroy it and his building along with it. Isn’t that right?”

The demon on the other side of the door froze. His head tilted down slightly as he looked at the weapon in his hand. It looked like he needed a little bit of extra motivation to get moving.

Ной [he] sent a tiny ripple of energy from Natural Disaster out through his feet, making the ground beneath them shudder slightly. The demon hurriedly set the blade down and grabbed the door. Ной [he] let his domain fade away as the door ground open to reveal a male, purple-skinned demon with mushroom-like growths running along his back.


The demon stared at Ной [he] with wide, white eyes completely devoid of an iris. His dark tongue slipped out to wet his lips as he took a step back, holding his hands above his head to show he was unarmed.

“I — I didn’t know who it was,” the demon stammered. “I meant no offense.”

“He knows you?” Вайолет [she] asked in shock.

“Not personally. I wouldn’t dare to claim such a thing. But I’ve heard the runners going around today. It would be hard not to hear about what’s going on. There isn’t anyone connected to a streetlord on this half of the city that doesn’t know yet.” The apothecary’s eyes lowered to meet Ной [he]’s. “You’re Паук [he].”

“Very good,” Ной [he] said with a nod. “And I have it on good word that you may be able to help me. You are an apothecary?”

“I have been called such,” the demon said, swallowing and stumbling over his words in his haste to force them out. “I thought you were from the — uh, from another gang. I did not realize Паук [he] himself would come to my door. If there’s anything I can do for you, consider it done. Free of charge, of course. A gift.”

Ной [he] glanced over the apothecary’s shoulder at rows of shelves behind him stuffed chock full of ingredients. There weren’t any glass vials sitting around in plain sight, but it definitely looked like the type of store he was looking for.

“Have you heard of a Mind Meld potion?” Ной [he] asked.

The apothecary blinked. His eyes flicked to Вайолет [she] before returning to Ной [he]. “Of course. Is that what you seek?”

“It is. How many do you have?”

Coughing into a fist and pointedly averting his gaze, the demon backed a step into his shop. “Five, I believe. Would that be sufficient? I have not known any who can manage to use more than three in a row. Not to doubt your prowess, Master Паук [he]. I—”

“Just… give me the potions,” Ной [he] said.

What is this guy on about?

The apothecary gave him a series of short bows as he continued backing up. He bumped into a counter at the back of the store and hurried around it, digging through his stores before locating a bone crate. He set it down on the counter with a grunt and pulled the top off to reveal five glass potions.

Each one was full of a sparkly pink liquid. Flowing swirls ran across the surface of the glass in an oddly artistic manner for what should have been a pretty mundane potion and the caps of the potion were some form of bright pink gemstone.

That is not a Mind Meld potion.

“What is that?” Ной [he] asked, tilting his head to the side. “I asked for Mind Meld potions.”

The apothecary paled. “I — I apologize. These are what you request. Their quality may not be to the standard that you are used to, but I assure you that they work perfectly. All sensations and effects are the absolute best that you’ll get in this area of Трэдон [he].”

Sensations? What the hell do the demons use Mind Meld potions for? Actually, I think I’ve got an idea — but come on, guys. These things have so much potential. Is that really the best you can do with them?

Ной [he] grunted. There was no way to verify the apothecary’s words here, but he could ask some of the demons back in the camp. He flicked a gold coin onto the table and took the vials from the demon, piling them into his bag.

“Is there anything else—” the apothecary started, but Ной [he] was already walking out of the store. Вайолет [she] hurried after him.

They strode down the street in silence for a minute. Ной [he] caught Вайолет [she] sending glances at his bag and suppressed a sigh.

“That’s not what they’re for.”

Вайолет [she]’s face paled. “Can you read—”

“No. Your face was just really obvious. Just because everyone here is a degenerate doesn’t mean I am too. You’d do well to keep in mind that nothing is limited to a single purpose. Especially magic.”

Вайолет [she] nodded hurriedly. She’d reacted too quickly to have actually considered his words, but with any luck, she’d think over them when she was a little less terrified.

Ной [he]’s tremorsense prickled and he looked up, making eye contact with a demon crouched at the top of a low roof near them. The demon froze in place as Ной [he] made sure they knew he’d seen them, then slunk back and out of sight.

Definitely not the only one watching. We’ve got a fair amount of attention now. Probably shouldn’t talk about anything too important until we’re back at camp.

“How’d you get your name?” Ной [he] asked to break the silence. “Not that it’s a poor one, but it’s a bit… different. Айлин [she], Эдда [she], Торик [he]. They’ve got a… style, I guess.”

A small smile pulled across Вайолет [she]’s face as her mind drifted off in thought. “That’s because I gave them their names. Айлин [she] gave me mine. It’s because my eyes turn violet when I’m really concentrated on something. It took him nearly a week to decide on it. I swear he watched me like a Sand Wyrg for an entire week. I was expecting some really in-depth and fancy name. He decided on Вайолет [she].”

“You don’t like it?”

“No, I love it. Our names were the only things we’ve had for a long time,” Вайолет [she] said absently. She spoke casually, seeming to have lost some of her fear of Ной [he] — or perhaps her fear receptors had just burned out. “It was just funny. After all that research, he chose what I would have chosen after about ten seconds looking in a mirror.”

“If you ask me, ending with a simple answer after doing a lot of research shows understanding, not lack of effort,” Ной [he] observed. “That speaks well for it. Вайолет [she] is an excellent name.”

And that’s quite interesting. When I was in Айлин [she]’s mind, he wanted to know about how a lot of things work. I wonder if he’s figured out what he feeds on yet. I should ask when we get back to camp.

Ной [he] glanced down at Вайолет [she], whose smile had grown slightly at his words. There was an undeniable comradery between her and the other young demons. It was mildly surprising. He hadn’t expected to find anyone that cared so deeply for each other in the Damned Plains, but that went to show just how little everyone truly understood about demons.

I can’t shake the feeling that the key to figuring out Ли [she]’s Runes is determining how to help these kids as well. That’ll rely on making sure they grow strong and get the confidence and power to defend themselves.

Speaking of which… I wonder how Айлин [she] is doing with Врит [he]. I hope she isn’t making things too difficult for him.
==========
Chapter 473: Trade Offer

“So fear is the best way to stop a fight before it starts?” Айлин [she] asked, his eyes fixed intently on Врит [he]. “That makes a lot of sense. It’s why you focus on attacking quickly and utilizing shadow-related runes. If your targets couldn’t see what was attacking them, they’d make things up and be more scared than they would be if they knew who they were up against — ah! That’s the feeling you eat, isn’t it? Fear?”

Врит [he] groaned from where she sat slumped against the throne beside him, her head cradled in her hands. “Please stop. You are literally sucking me dry. How is your damn mental force so powerful? Didn’t Паук [he] literally just make you a Rank 3? You shouldn’t be able to take energy from me like this!”

“Sorry,” Айлин [she] said with a wince. He’d asked his last question about thirty-five seconds ago, but this one had just slipped out before he’d managed to stop it. The more he spoke to Врит [he], the more he wanted to know.

He wanted to know how she worked. How she fought — how she thought. And not just about her. He wanted to know everything. Every scrap of information just felt like it added to the growing avalanche of desire.

The world had been so small before. So constrained. But in just a few minutes, Врит [he] had taken those boundaries and ripped them free to show the horizon beyond. Unfortunately for her, Айлин [she] had taken more than a few mistaken nibbles out of her soul in the process.

In his defense, he hadn’t meant to. It just happened. Not every question drew energy, but the more exited and invested he got, the harder it was to avoid draining Врит [he] even further.

“Do you want something to eat?” Айлин [she] offered meekly. He didn’t need someone to tell him that constantly snacking on someone else’s energy was not considered polite by any stretch of the imagination.

She was a lot more patient than he’d expected, though the threat of Паук [he] hanging over both of their heads had definitely helped stay her hand.

Врит [he] let out a garbled groan. “Please. I’m too tired to stand at this point. Someone needs to teach you how to speak to others without sucking down all their energy by peppering them with stupid questions.”

“Maybe you could—”

“If you ask me one more thing, I might keel over and die,” Врит [he] said. “That was not an exaggeration. Please. I am quite literally begging you. Don’t ask me anything. Just get food. I can’t consume energy from you, so we have to do this the old fashioned way.”

Айлин [she] sheepishly hopped off the chair and hurried out of the tent. His new gang — they didn’t have a name yet, but he’d get to that soon enough if Паук [he] hadn’t chosen one already — had already distributed a fair amount of it.

Fortunately, they’d kept more than enough for everyone here, pushing it all into a few different storage tents. Айлин [she] approached the closest one, exchanging a nod with the demon on guard before stepping inside.

It was a strange feeling to walk into a tent and find it completely stuffed to the brim with meats and cheeses and breads. There was enough to feed him, Вайолет [she], Торик [he], and Эдда [she] for months. Maybe more, if they ate carefully.

Айлин [she] shook his head. He scooped up a large loaf of bread and a palm-sized wheel of cheese. That already felt like too much. But, after a second of hesitation, he grabbed a long strip of jerky as well before striding back out and to the leader’s tent.

“I got some food,” Айлин [she] said once he’d returned to Врит [he]’s side. He crouched beside her. Врит [he] opened her mouth.

She actually wants me to feed her? A bit weird, but sure. I suppose it’s kind of my fault she’s this exhausted.

“Wh—” Врит [he] started, only to get a loaf of bread stuffed into her mouth. She let out a muffled grunt of surprise, but no demon’s instincts would ever let them waste energy, especially when they were as worn out as Врит [he] was. She bit down, chewing wearily before swallowing.

A tiny amount of energy visibly returned to her body as her posture straightened slightly and her lips parted once more, only for Айлин [she] to stick the bread straight back in. They stared at each other for a second.

Then Врит [he]’s shoulders slumped.

That’s odd. She should be getting more energy from eating, but she somehow looks even more tired. That doesn’t make sense.

Айлин [she] nearly asked her what was going on before he caught himself. That would be asking another question. He wasn’t very confident he’d be able to avoid accidentally stealing more energy from her in the process.

Thus, the only option left to him was to continue feeding Врит [he]. Her eyes bored into his, but she let him feed her the rest of the bread without saying anything. Айлин [she] broke a piece of cheese off as soon as the bread was finished.

Врит [he]’s eyes flicked to it as she finished chewing the bread. One of them twitched. Then she let out a sigh and opened her mouth, letting Айлин [she] put the piece in. They made it all the way through the rest of the cheese and half the jerky before the tent flaps parted behind them.


The streets whispered to Айлин [she]’s ears.

He glanced over his shoulder, his hand halfway to Врит [he]’s mouth with a piece of jerky between his fingers, as Робон [he] stepped into the tent. The large demon froze in place. Врит [he] muttered a curse under her breath as her cheeks brightened, only to get another piece of jerky stuffed between her lips while she wasn’t watching.

Робон [he] nearly choked on his own saliva. He coughed into his remaining fist and quickly averted his gaze. “Forgive me, streetlord. I didn’t realize you were busy.”

“I’m not,” Айлин [she] said. “Врит [he] just asked me to feed her because I ripped a bit too much energy out of her on accident.”

The back of Врит [he]’s head made an audible thunk as she smacked it against the side of the chair. Айлин [she] fed her another piece of jerky. She hadn’t spoken yet, so she clearly still needed to recover more energy.

“I… see,” Робон [he] said, sounding like he didn’t see at all. A small tremor of fear ran through his voice. That was response the action that any rational demon would have had at seeing the former urchin turned streetlord stuffing food into the mouth of one of the most dangerous demons in the area without so much as a flicker of worry. “I have reports with regard to Паук [he]’s orders. Is now a good time?”

“For anything to do with Паук [he]? It always is,” Айлин [she] said. “What happened?”

“Three gangs have responded so far. One has completely surrendered and will be reporting to our camp tomorrow. The second said that they want to see Паук [he] themselves before they give in, and the third wanted to speak with you directly. They’re sending a representative.”

“Who? How strong?” Айлин [she] asked.

“Рекеба [she], the second of the Silent Silvertooth,” Робон [he] said through a grimace. “She’s a Rank 3, and there are rumors their streetlord is actually halfway through Rank 3. They’re a powerful gang. I’m not sure if it’s lucky or not that they’ve responded to Паук [he]’s threat so quickly.”

“Is she coming alone?”

“Unlikely. Representatives usually come with protection if they aren’t coming to issue a direct challenge. I’d expect three or four others with her.”

The back of Айлин [she]’s neck prickled and his arms tensed.

I have to deal with another one so quickly after Врит [he]? I don’t suppose I’ve gotten lucky enough for Ли [she] to handle everything for me this time. Although… this isn’t the same. I’ve got Врит [he] on my side now. I can — I have to — handle this.

“Thank you for letting me know. How long until they arrive?”

“An hour, I suspect.”

Айлин [she] nodded and rose to his feet. “I’ll get ready. Make sure the camp is prepared to greet them. Politely, that is.”

Робон [he] inclined his head and hurriedly left the tent. Айлин [she] glanced down at Врит [he]. She still hadn’t said anything. That was worrying.

How much energy do Rank 3 Demons need if all that food didn’t fix her? And more importantly, how much energy did I take?

“Can I open my mouth now?” Врит [he] asked warily. “Or are you going to stick more food into it?”

Айлин [she] blinked. “What? You asked me to feed you.”

“I told you to bring me food,” Врит [he] said, running a hand along the back of her scalp and letting out a long-suffering sigh. Then she paused for a second. “Though I can’t deny it was nice getting fed. Фрот [he] had a servant feed him once or twice. I never had the chance. It makes you feel… important.”

“How long have you had enough energy to do things normally?” Айлин [she] asked, narrowing his eyes. “Were you just letting me feed you that whole time?”

“In my defense, you didn’t give me much choice.” Врит [he] snickered at the expression on his face.

Айлин [she] paused as a thought struck him. “Does that mean I can keep asking you a bunch of questions if I get you more food?”

“Are you checking if you can bribe me into getting drained repeatedly in exchange for getting fed?” Врит [he]’s smirk fell away.

“Yes, I think that would be accurate.”

“I could just have a different subordinate do it,” Врит [he] pointed out. “I refuse to believe that Паук [he]’s plans for bringing my gang under you included turning me into a magical battery.”

“You probably could, but I’m pretty sure you got embarrassed when Робон [he] saw us,” Айлин [she] pointed out. “And I’m the one that controls the food supplies.”

Врит [he] stared at him. “You’re threatening to limit my food?”

“No, that would be awful. I’m offering more of it,” Айлин [she] corrected. “We definitely have enough. Голон [he] was hoarding it. I don’t need nearly as much as he did, so it’s my prerogative as to how it’s used as long as everyone in the gang gets some. I can choose to give you extra.”

That made her hesitate. Врит [he] lifted a finger, then let it lower as she chewed her lower lip. “I cannot believe I am considering this. If Фрот [he] was alive, he’d strangle me on the spot for being so stupid.”

“He didn’t sound like a very good brother from what little you’ve told me of him,” Айлин [she] said, scratching the back of his neck. “It didn’t seem like he ever considered what you wanted. You were just his servant, not his equal.”

“You have a vested interest in getting me to say yes.” Врит [he] paused for a moment and glanced at the entrance of the tent, looking over Айлин [she]’s head. “Don’t you feel embarrassment at all? You’re a streetlord. Feeding someone is beneath you.”

“Why? I fed my siblings all the time, and they did the same for me. It’s just a way to show you care,” Айлин [she] said with a frown. “We didn’t constantly do it, but it’s not like we had all that much food in the first place.”

They fell silent for a few seconds. Then Врит [he]’s cheeks colored. “Fine. Deal — but within reason. I’m not giving you literally all of my energy. You need to learn how to ask questions you’re interested in without draining people of every scrap of energy they’ve got.”

“So you’ll keep teaching me?”

“Yes,” Врит [he] said through a sigh.

“Great.” Айлин [she] grinned. “In that case, we should start with anything you know about Рекеба [she] and the Silent Silvertooth. I think I’ve got an idea as to how to deal with them, but I need to know a lot more before it has a chance of working.”

“Oh?” Врит [he] tilted her head to the side. “An idea? Already?”

“It’s based on what I’ve seen Паук [he] and his group do. I’m not nearly as strong as they are, but with your help… it could work.” Айлин [she] threw a glance over his shoulder, but his ears and tongue already told him everything he needed to know. The tent was empty and nobody was there to overhear them. His eyes narrowed and his features darkened.

“I’m going to break her, but I’ll need your help to do it.”
==========
Chapter 474: Everything

Айлин [she] sat alone on the ground in the center of the market square, Голон [he]’s chair empty behind him. He’d moved it from the large tent and set it up in wait for Рекеба [she]. Врит [he] was nowhere to be seen, but he could vaguely taste the remnants of her passing in the air. She was hidden in the shadows near a tent somewhere near him.

He braced his hands against his knees and focused on keeping his expression as neutral as possible. All the demons in the camp had already been instructed to remain in their tents unless something changed — that obviously didn’t go for Паук [he], but Паук [he] did what he wanted.

The masked demon had doubtlessly either overheard or figured out his plan already. He hadn’t made any moves to stop Айлин [she], so that was probably a good sign. It meant Паук [he] supported it.

That, or he just didn’t care.

As Айлин [she] waited, he went back over the last few things he’d discussed with Врит [he]. She’d known a lot about Рекеба [she] and her gang, the Silent Silvertooth. Too much to pass along in just a few minutes.

They’d had to focus on the core elements. Рекеба [she] was apparently something of a unique demon. Врит [he] had reluctantly admitted that she was beyond beautiful and equal parts strong, fast, and arrogant. She’d earned the right to look down on others through more feats than Врит [he] had cared to list, but it boiled down to her being a proud demon with little inclination to surrender.

According to Врит [he], confrontations between streetlords had a few hard rules that had to be observed if he was to avoid pissing off every single streetlord in the city.

There are two stages to a meeting like this. Because she announced her arrival and I haven’t made it clear she isn’t welcome, we’re locked into a talking stage first where neither of us can attack without cause before our conversation is complete or an hour passes. Рекеба [she] is a second, which gives her the same negotiating rights as a streetlord, so I’ve got to play by the rules.

Any promises I make during the meeting stage are binding. If I say something and can’t follow up on it, she is within her rights to attack me.

Threats are all on the table. So are bluffs. Anything works until it gets called out. So even though random fights aren’t allowed during the meeting, I can follow through on a threat. The second stage of this meeting is just an all-out fight at the end of the hour if we can’t come to an agreement — I don’t want to let it come to that.

Every streetlord is going to be watching this to see how I perform. On one hand, I’m a new streetlord without any reputation or feats. Nobody expects much from me. On the other, I’m representing Паук [he], so showing any weakness is an insult to him.

If he could have just had Врит [he] kill Рекеба [she], it would have made things a whole lot easier for him — and in the process, it would have shown he was too weak to stand on his own. The other streetlords would keep sending people to bother him for the rest of his life. He’d never get a chance to breathe.

There was no doubt that the meeting was stacked against him. Рекеба [she] was an experienced second and her gang wasn’t powerful for no reason. Even if she wasn’t the streetlord, she had more than enough practice dealing with people a lot more talented than him.

Рекеба [she] was likely counting on him being uncertain and unsteady in his position to keep him off balance through the whole meeting.

Врит [he] was pretty certain she’d do her best to humiliate me and crush my resolve through the whole meeting. I got the feeling she and Рекеба [she] have some sort of history. That doesn’t change anything.

Рекеба [she]’s experience does mean I definitely can’t play safe, but that works with my plan. I just wish she’d show up faster. There are so many other things I want to do. I just hope —

Айлин [she]’s ears twitched. Рекеба [she] was coming. It was so silent that he could easily hear four sets of footsteps approaching the market square even at a distance. He settled his nerves and plastered an uninterested look over his features as he waited for them to approach.

Just a few seconds later, four demons stepped out from the main street. Three of them strongly resembled Голон [he]. They had red skin, huge, bulky muscles, and scrunched up faces that made it look like they’d been dropped on their heads a few dozen times as children.

The demon at their front was, without a doubt, Рекеба [she]. Even though Врит [he] had given Айлин [she] a description of her appearance during their quick conversation, he still hadn’t been properly prepared.

Айлин [she] had seen beautiful before. Эдда [she]’s content face when she fell asleep with a full belly was beautiful. Вайолет [she]’s smug grin when she’d returned home with a few extra scraps of food was beautiful. Врит [he] was beautiful — but Рекеба [she] was otherworldly.

Her hair shimmered like a river of gold, framing faint pink skin. She had wide, inquisitive eyes and perfect lips curled up in the faintest hint of a smirk. Рекеба [she]’s form seemed to have been sculpted specifically to draw the eye to all the places it wasn’t meant to look — and every strutting step she took made it absolutely clear she knew it.

Айлин [she] hated her on the spot. No matter how much he wanted to pull his eyes away, he couldn’t. It was like a compulsion. The demon had an aura around her that made him want to leap to his feet and do whatever she ordered him to. His skin prickled. The more he thought about her, the more he felt his energy pulled away from him.

He clenched his fists, digging a small claw into the bed of his palm. Blood pumped in his body as his chest heated. He focused his thoughts on anything else — Вайолет [she], Врит [he], Торик [he] tripping over himself, Эдда [she] choking on a mouthful fruit. His eyes narrowed and he forced the unnatural influence from his mind, locking eyes with Рекеба [she] as she approached and making absolutely no move to rise.

She and her three guards stopped several feet away from him.

For a second, there was only silence.

“Рекеба [she],” Айлин [she] said in a flat tone.

“Where’s your streetlord, boy?” Rebeka asked, her words dripping with a honied tone.

You know damn well that I’m the streetlord.

“Right in front of you,” Айлин [she] replied. “Sit down.”

Рекеба [she] arched an eyebrow and tilted her head to the side as her lips curled up in amusement. “You seem to have forgotten my chair behind you— unless you were planning to offer your back?”

Айлин [she] ignored her taunt and gestured to the floor before him. “That chair is for Паук [he], should he choose to take it. Nobody else is worthy to sit in his presence — thus, the ground will suffice. Sit.”


He tasted a flicker of irritation in the air and fought to repress a smile. Рекеба [she] wasn’t pleased with his response. She’d definitely been expecting more of a reaction. Given what most streetlords were like, she was probably used to it.

“And if I refuse? I could just stand right here,” Рекеба [she] drawled. “Above you, as is my proper place.”

“If your group stands, I will shorten you — starting with one of your guards.”

Рекеба [she] lifted a hand to cover her mouth as a burst of laughter slipped from her lips. “Threats? Already? I already know how strong you are, boy. You were trembling in your scrappy sandals when you met that mangy cat. I’m stronger than she is, and unlike her, I didn’t come to beg at your feet.”

Айлин [she] didn’t respond. He just waited. Врит [he] knew the timing on these things a whole lot better than he did, and he wasn’t sure exactly how long they had to hold back before —

His ears twitched. There was a crunch, followed by a flicker of motion and a splash of darkness near the shadows at the edge of the square. Айлин [she] tasted blood in the air. The large demon to Рекеба [she]’s right let out a scream of pain and fell to the ground, blood pouring down the back of his legs. His hamstrings had both been severed.

Айлин [she] didn’t have to turn to hear Врит [he] come to a stop behind him. The taste of blood grew stronger. He kept his eyes locked with Рекеба [she]’s, not letting so much as a flicker of emotion pass over his features.

“Bitch,” Рекеба [she] snarled. Anger and surprise mixed in her taste. She was genuinely surprised. “Found a new master so quickly? Surrendering is one thing, but throwing your lot in with him? Pathetic.”

Врит [he] didn’t respond. Рекеба [she]’s jaw clenched and she dropped down, sitting cross-legged across from Айлин [she]. The remaining guards did the same, while the injured one squeezed his mouth shut and muffled his groans of pain.

That’s one point to us.

“You can only get so far using someone else’s power — though I wouldn’t expect a puppet streetlord to know that,” Рекеба [she] said. She didn’t even look in the direction of her injured guard.

Айлин [she] almost winced. She had a point.

And one point to her, then.

“Паук [he]’s decisions are his own. If you value your life, I suggest against questioning them. You’re here to figure out the legitimacy of his claims as well as my own ability, correct?”

Рекеба [she]’s lips curled up. She was back in her territory. “Yes, precisely. Not exactly the most difficult conclusion to come to, boy.”

“You didn’t have the most difficult of motives to discern. If you want to test me, then I propose a game.”

“Not the first time a demon has asked that, but I’m a good sport.” Рекеба [she] leaned forward and pulled her lips back in a sultry smile. “What game, boy? What do you think you want to challenge me in?”

“Questions,” Айлин [she] replied promptly. “You may ask me anything you wish about this camp. I have ten seconds to answer with complete honesty. I will then do the same to you, but only with relation to yourself and the demons present here rather than your entire camp. If either of us refuse to answer a question or lie, they admit the other is their better. The same rules also go for asking questions so neither of us can stall the meeting out until the hour ends.”

Рекеба [she] hesitated for a second as she thought over his offer. She might have been strong, but she wasn’t stupid. This clearly wasn’t a game of power. “You’ve stacked things against yourself. Hoping to bait me in?”

Айлин [she] shrugged. “I felt you needed the handicap, and I don’t truly care about you or your camp. Some random demon and their gang are irrelevant in the grand terms of Паук [he]’s plans.”

Рекеба [she]’s eyes narrowed. “Is ‘I don’t know’ a valid answer?”

Nice catch.

“So long as it’s true. Lying is against the rules of the game.”

“And how would you know? You have no way to validate my claims.”

Айлин [she] smiled and shrugged. “I suppose we will have to go by the honor system. As agreed, lying would be admitting that I am your better. I will not lie. I swear my life on it. If I speak a single lie, I’ll become your servant and do whatever you want me to for the rest of my life. So, unless you’re so pathetic that you fear speaking honestly to a mere boy simply asking questions about you, I expect you to do the same.”

“I trust you don’t expect me to agree to the same terms.”

“Those are mine alone. Just the first ones.”

“You could make things easier for yourself by lying off the start. I won’t hurt you too much that way — though too much may be relative.” She let out a ringing laugh, then bared her teeth again. It was all a show. She was just buying time to think, but Айлин [she] was all too aware of how tempting the bait he’d set was. Any chance to get information on the elusive Паук [he] — especially when the odds were leaned so heavily in her favor — was too difficult to pass up. Sure enough, Рекеба [she] came to her decision just a few moments later. “Very well. I accept your terms.”

Айлин [she] smiled. “You can start.”

“Who is Паук [he]?” Рекеба [she] asked without an instant of hesitation.

“The strongest demon I’ve ever met. I don’t know his identity because he keeps his face covered, but I suspect he could kill either of us with little more than a thought,” Айлин [she] said.

Рекеба [she] pursed her lips in displeasure. She’d probably heard much of the same from her scouts. He’d still technically answered the question, though.

“Fine. Your turn.”

“Tell me about what you consume to grow stronger.”

A flicker of confusion passed over Рекеба [she]’s features before she snickered. “You’re not the smartest, are you? It’s lust. I drink in all the energy idiots waste staring and drooling in my direction.”

Айлин [she] drank from the truth in her words. As obvious as it may have been, there was importance to the revelation. Revealing the concept a demon fed on was the same as baring a demon’s core personality — and there was power in such truth.

There wasn’t much for a relatively small revelation, but she was still a Rank 3 demon. A flicker of unease passed over Рекеба [she]’s features but she shook her head. She kept her mask of emotions raised and looked over Айлин [she]’s shoulder.

“How about Врит [he]? Did you make her scrape at your boots? Beg for her life? Tell me everything you did to her.”

Hoping to humiliate Врит [he] instead of me? They definitely do have some history.

“After we left the street, we went back to Голон [he]’s tent and talked for a while. Then I fed her some food. That was about it,” Айлин [she] said.

Рекеба [she]’s cocky expression twitched. “What? That’s it? You’re lying.”

“That’s two questions, but I’ll give you an answer anyway. I am not lying. Врит [he] is blushing. That should be proof enough.”

Рекеба [she] glanced back to Врит [he], then snorted. “Prude. Of course you ended up giving into the biggest pansy of a streetlord in history. Ask your question, boy.”

“What do you desire most in this world?”

“Are you trying to court me or something?” Рекеба [she] asked with a tittering laugh. “There’s no gift you could give that I truly desire. I want power. The adoring gazes of everyone in the Damned Plains — no, more. Everyone in every plane. I want them all focused on me and me alone. I want to drink all of that delicious energy for as long as I live. I—”

Рекеба [she] faltered as Айлин [she] drank energy from her words. She was actually easier to drink from than Врит [he], though that might have been because of how honest and upfront she was being. Everyone loved talking about their passions, after all. Рекеба [she] hesitated for a second, then opened her mouth once more. Then she narrowed her eyes. “That’s all. I don’t have anything else to add. Is your question done? I want to ask my next one.”

“Go for it.”

“What do you consume?” Рекеба [she] asked immediately.

“Ah. You should have asked that earlier. Knowledge.”

Рекеба [she]’s face paled and she shot to her feet. “You cheater! I—”

“Sit down. Unless you’ve surrendered and admit my superiority, the game is still going,” Айлин [she] snapped. Рекеба [she] froze. Her jaw ground and, after a second, she forced herself to sit back down. They locked eyes with each other. Айлин [she] smiled. “I believe it’s my turn to ask a question. I’m glad we’ve got an hour to keep playing, Рекеба [she]. I want to know everything about you. Every. Last. Thing.”

Chapter 475: Rekaba

An hour wasn’t a long time in the grand scheme of things. It was just a little longer than the time it took to stretch a meal and make it feel like there was more food than there actually was. It was how long it took to fall asleep on the days where a few too many things had happened. It was a blip in a day, which was nothing more than a blink in a lifetime.

To everyone else in the city of Трэдон [he], most of a mere hour passed by like any other. But time was funny like that.

To Айлин [she], it was a feast.

To Рекеба [she], it was agony.

It hadn’t taken her long to realize that the game was rigged. She’d known it from the start. Nobody offered a game with immense odds against themselves unless they had a card hidden up their sleeves.

That card should have been Врит [he]. All Рекеба [she]’s information had told her that the annoying woman had literally fallen at the puppet streetlord’s feet to beg for her life. Any idiot would have used the coward as a way to try and sway the scales in their favor.

When Рекеба [she] had arrived at the camp, it had been painfully obvious. Lust and hatred weren’t all that different of emotions, and she’d felt the disgust pouring off Врит [he] in the shadows as she approached Айлин [she].

Рекеба [she] had been so confident. She’d been so certain that Врит [he] was his card, and the game was already over. The original plan had been to toy with the idiot streetlord for a while before grinding him under her heel until the point where no self-respecting demon would ever follow him again.

That had been the plan — but the offer had been too sweet. The boy didn’t matter, but Паук [he] did. He had yet to show himself to her scouts. Any information she could glean about his powers would be invaluable. The opportunity to ask anything she wanted about him and his abilities had sunk its claws into her and held tight.

But now, as Рекеба [she] laid flat on the ground, arms trembling desperately to push herself back upright, breath coming in ragged gasps and her body wrung dry of energy like nothing more than a piece of laundry, it was painfully apparent that she’d misread the card entirely.

The grin on the boy’s face before her wasn’t that of an innocent, besotted child. It was the rictus smile of a streetlord. His lips were parted, but not in happiness. It was in hunger. He wasn’t looking at her like an opponent.

I’m just a piece of meat to him.

Рекеба [she]’s heart slammed in her ears. She’d long since given up the idea of trying to win the fight. As soon as she’d realized she was up against a knowledge demon, it had become apparent just how badly she’d misplayed.

Entering a contract to exchange questions with one of his kind was akin to slathering her entire body with honey before dancing naked into the den of a Dire Bear, slapping it on the rear to wake it from its slumber, and shoving herself down its throat.

No, Рекеба [she] had absolutely no delusions of winning any longer. Her only goal was survival.

“Is something wrong, Рекеба [she]?” Врит [he]’s voice was so smug that it made Рекеба [she]’s stomach twist in fury. “It kind of looks like you’ve prostrated yourself to me — but not even I got off my knees and laid completely on the ground.”

Рекеба [she]’s teeth ground. She’d just asked a question, but she couldn’t remember what it was. Айлин [she] answered it. She didn’t bother listening. Every scrap of her attention was on clinging onto the last power she still had.

Something about Айлин [she] was deeply, deeply wrong. He ripped power from her with ease that should have been impossible for him. It was as if she was up against someone an entire rank above her.

“I like that question. Would you like to surrender completely to me and Паук [he]?” Айлин [she] asked, tilting his head to the side. “That is the surrender position, right?”

“I don’t know,” Рекеба [she] ground out. Her voice was raspy and weak. It sounded bitter and pathetic to her ears.

I don’t know.

Those three words should have been her way out of the game. She’d been confident that they were the loophole that Айлин [she] had planted for himself so he could avoid giving away information that was too important.

She couldn’t have been more wrong. As it turned out, not knowing something was still part of the feeling that knowledge demons could feast on. None of the actual words she said mattered.

Айлин [she] wasn’t eating the words. He was eating the understanding. Рекеба [she] had tried lying. She’d tried speaking in half-truths and in mysticisms. Nothing worked. Everything new that he learned made him stronger.

Рекеба [she]’s fingers dug into the ground as her arms trembled in a mixture of humiliation and fury. The only winning move against a knowledge demon was not to speak. They weren’t demons meant for combat. Not in their younger years, at least.

But Айлин [she] had accounted for that. If she failed to answer within five seconds, it was the end for her. If she answered, it was the end. If she fled the scene, it was the end. Every single one spelled defeat.

Рекеба [she] refused to accept it. She was his better in every single way. There was no possible way for her to have lost this badly. Returning to Rakkor with her tail between her legs and head bowed in defeat was an inconceivable notion.

For years, she had been envied. She had been loved. She had been feared. She had clawed her way through the ranks of the Silent Silvertooth just so she could get to this point. So close to her true goals. So close to what had been promised to her.

It can’t end here. I refuse to let a child defeat me in a trap. I have crushed men ten times greater than him beneath my heel and had them come back begging for me to do it again. I am Рекеба [she] of the Silent Silvertooth.

I deserve victory. I am owed it!


Рекеба [she]’s hands trembled. She desperately pulled on her power and tried to gather anything she had left. Her guards stood around her, exchanging glances. None of them spoke. They didn’t need to.

She could tell what they were thinking. The doubt was clear in their eyes. More than doubt. There was derision. They watched her humiliation and found it amusing. Fury bit into Рекеба [she]’s chest.

There were rules against attacking Айлин [she]. She couldn’t make a move against him — not yet. Not without admitting defeat. Врит [he], unfortunately, was the same. The vile woman was safe from her.

But my own men…

Рекеба [she]’s lips pulled back in a cruel smirk. The way free of this had shown itself to her.

If they want to laugh, then they can join me on the ground.

She drew on her Runes, ripping what little energy still remained within them, and unleashed it. Her eyes erupted with energy as power poured through her body and snagged onto the buried thoughts of the men around her.

She latched onto the lust that drifted through their minds when they looked at her and drank from it greedily. The demons stiffened in surprise and pain, but they couldn’t let out cries of either pain or pleasure.

They’d been around her for years. Days on weeks on months of carnal desire had built within them. It had formed an ironclad connection to her. None of them had ever even considered quelling their vile thoughts. Perhaps they had thought they were safe.

Perhaps they’d thought they had a chance.

A laugh slipped from Рекеба [she]’s lips. Her men collapsed by her side, gasping weakly for air and energy, but they weren’t strong enough to resist. Рекеба [she] drank everything they had. Their skin dried and their gasps silenced as she pushed herself upright.

Power coursed through her body like a raging ocean. It filled her chest and raced through her limbs. She ran her tongue across her lips and let out a shuddering breath. The entire process had only taken seconds. There was still time for her question.

She rose to her feet, giving up on sitting, and her eyes lifted to meet Айлин [she]’s once more — but what she found gave her pause. His expression was unchanged. Interest, mixed with flat confidence. There wasn’t a flicker of fear or concern.

There wasn’t a scrap of feeling she could feast on.

Impossible. I just released my full strength. It wasn’t directed at him, but he doesn’t think anything lustful of me at all. How?

There was no time to consider it. She had to ask her question before the time ran out, or everything would be for naught. Her jaw tightened in irritation. She didn’t care to admit how infuriating it was to see that expression on the face of someone her inferior. It was one meant for an interesting insect under a rock, not the most beautiful woman Айлин [she] ever should have seen.

I refuse to let myself get put off guard by this brat. I need to take the offense.

“Where is Паук [he]?” Рекеба [she] asked. Паук [he] was the only demon that mattered, and it was clear Айлин [she] idolized him. That was a weakness she could exploit. “I would love to get intimately acquaintanced with him.”

“I don’t think someone like you would bear even the slightest amount of interest to Паук [he],” Айлин [she] said dispassionately. He jerked his thumb over his shoulder. “But the last time I saw him, he was in that tent over there.”

What? He’s here? Just… sitting around? Watching? Is this all a joke to him?

Рекеба [she] felt her confidence giving. She clenched her fists and squared herself, trying to draw Айлин [she]’s attention to anything other than her face. It failed. His eyes were like twin pools of ice, boring into the back of her skull incessantly.

“My turn,” Айлин [she] said softly. “Are you scared?”

“I — what?” Рекеба [she] asked, caught off guard once again. Her fingers twitched. “No. Of you? How could I possibly be scared of you?”

“That’s not an answer,” Айлин [she] said in the same, quiet tone. Рекеба [she] braced herself, preparing to resist him as he stole her power, but nothing happened. Айлин [she] just sat there. “But at the same time, it is. Your turn.”

The proper move was to ask about Паук [he]. To seek a weakness — but she’d already asked Айлин [she] about that, and his answer had been that he’d never seen anything that could so much as hurt Паук [he], much less kill him.

She didn’t believe that for a second. Nobody was immortal. The problem was Айлин [she] had played her yet again. The stupid boy barely knew anything about Паук [he]. Half of his own answers about Паук [he] had been admitting he didn’t know. There was nothing she could learn about him, so the only thing that left her was finding a weakness in the streetlord before her.

“You asked if I was scared,” Рекеба [she] said, stepping closer to Айлин [she] and leaning down so they were face-to-face and only a few inches apart. “But you didn’t say how you feel. What do you feel when you look upon me?”

By his own rules, he can’t lie. He’ll have to choose between dropping the barrier and admitting the truth or breaking his own rules.

“At first, I was awestruck,” Айлин [she] admitted. Рекеба [she] smiled, but he wasn’t done. Айлин [she] braced his hands against his knees and shook his head, blowing out a breath. “I can honestly say you were the most attractive demon I’ve ever seen. I didn’t think it was possible that anyone could look like that.”

Рекеба [she]’s smile faltered. Something was wrong. Despite Айлин [she]’s words, she felt nothing from him. There was no lust. No hunger in his eyes.

“But then I learned,” Айлин [she] continued. He pushed himself upright and brushed his knees off, rising to stand before Рекеба [she]. “You see, I don’t think there’s anything left about you to learn. You’ve already revealed everything… and nothing kept my attention. You don’t interest me anymore.”

Ice prickled at the back of Рекеба [she]’s neck and twisted down her arms to grip at her chest. He was telling the truth. Айлин [she] was no saint. There was lust in him — she could tell it was present — but not a single scrap of it was directed toward her.

Рекеба [she] couldn’t help herself. She took a step back. Her eyes darted around the market square. The only other demon there was Врит [he].

Her guards all laid dead at her feet, completely drained of life and energy alike. There was nobody to help.

“We can stop playing the game now,” Айлин [she] said quietly. “Feel free to ask me another question if you want.”

Врит [he] smiled beside him. She flexed her fingers and claws pressed out of their tips, glistening in the setting light.

Рекеба [she]’s words couldn’t make their way out of her throat. They lodged there like a rock, barely even letting her breathe. She took another step back. Айлин [she]’s gaze followed her. Watching. Waiting.

I was set up. I can’t win this after losing so much energy. Айлин [she] was supposed to be some trembling child, not a competent Rank 3. A couple Rank 2 demons isn’t nearly enough to let me fight him and Врит [he] at the same time.

Justifications flew through her head, but they weren’t enough to cloak the truth that she was all too aware of. For a second longer, she stood frozen in place.

“The hour’s just about up, I think,” Айлин [she] said.

If she stayed a second longer, there was no doubt about it. She would die.

The options were death or humiliation. Only one of those had potential for a future.

Рекеба [she] broke.

She spun, sprinting for the street as fast as her feet could take her. Her blood pounded in her ears as she ran. Врит [he] was easily as fast as her. The demon could have been in any of the shadows — but she wasn’t.

Nothing accompanied her retreat. Рекеба [she] glanced over her shoulder to see Врит [he] and Айлин [she] standing side by side, watching her retreat impassively. They didn’t even view her as a threat worth chasing.

Рекеба [she]’s chest clenched. Most demons would have sworn revenge on the spot. They would have shouted their fury to all that could hear, swearing that they would return to tear down their foes once they grew stronger.

She found herself unable to utter any such promises. Words like that required a spark of anger or a shred of resolve. Рекеба [she] had none left. When she looked back at Айлин [she], the only demon she’d ever met devoid of even the slightest hint of attraction to her, the only thing she felt was fear.
