Chapter 491: Of Use

The moment the words ‘Rising Moon’ slipped from Талил [he]’s mouth, Пиррена [she] realized just how badly she’d gotten herself caught in politics that she had absolutely no right being in. There were a lot of demons in Трэдон [he], and only a few of them had a name known to every single demon within the city.

Йоку [she] the Rising Moon was one of them. Her name was just about the only thing that anyone could agree on about her. There were more rumors about Йоку [she] than there were failed demons lurking in the Wastes.

Some said she was a towering beast devoid of reason and driven entirely by instinct trapped somewhere deep within the city. Other rumors said that she had strings running to nearly every single high-ranking demon in Трэдон [he] and had been controlling them for hundreds of years.

Пиррена [she] had heard talk of Йоку [she] being Лорд [he] Белкус [he]’ greatest foe and ally alike, and her age ranged from somewhere between a few hundred years old to being twice as ancient as Трэдон [he] itself.

None of it mattered. Пиррена [she] didn’t care if Йоку [she] was a force of nature or just a clever demon taking advantage of rumors to further her strength. The only thing she cared about was that she was being forced to meet her.

No matter what the truth about Йоку [she] was, there was no doubt that she was powerful. A Rank 6 at the absolute minimum, and possibly even a Rank 7. There had been a few rumors claiming that Йоку [she] was actually a Rank 8, but Пиррена [she] didn’t believe those in the slightest. A Rank 8 wouldn’t have had to lurk in the night and rely on mystery to manipulate people. They would have just taken what they wanted to by force.

But, as far as Пиррена [she] was concerned, a Rank 6 and a Rank 8 were just about the same thing. Both of them could kill her with little more than a thought. Паук [he] be damned — if Пиррена [she] could have turned and run for her life, she would have.

Талил [he] didn’t give her the opportunity. Even though the shadowy demon wasn’t looking at her, she could feel his attention prickling against her skin. Even if she could have slipped him now, he knew where she lived.

He knew where her children were. No matter how fast Пиррена [she] was, she wasn’t faster than Йоку [she] was powerful. It didn’t matter if she could escape if it cost her the lives of her children in the process. And so, Пиррена [she] did the only thing she could. She followed behind Талил [he] and let him take her to meet his mistress.

The exact duration of the trip slipped Пиррена [she]’s mind. She and Талил [he] wound through the shadowed streets as her panicked thoughts bounced through her mind — and then they had arrived.

Талил [he] pulled open a plain doorway in the side of a nondescript alleyway that looked identical to every other one in the city. Pale white light rolled out from within it and lit the city as if the moon itself had been trapped behind the door.

He looked back at Пиррена [she]. Not a word had to leave his mouth. The intention was clear. Пиррена [she] swallowed, her back as stiff as a steel rod, and stepped into the glow. She blinked as her eyes adjusted to the bright light.

A passageway stretched out before her, sloping down toward the center of the city. Талил [he] stepped inside behind Пиррена [she] and closed the door behind him with a soft click. She glanced back at him and he nodded, gesturing for her to continue forward.

Neither of them spoke for the next few minutes. Her fear and anticipation heightened with every step. Every rumor she’d ever heard of the Rising Moon lengthened in her mind like shadows in the setting sun. The pathway stretched on and on, making Пиррена [she] wonder if there was even an end or if this was just meant to be some form of torture.

But, finally, they arrived. As with her arrival at the door in the alleyway, she barely even realized when it happened. Пиррена [she] had been so focused on her own thoughts and the drumming echo of their footsteps in the pathway that she didn’t register a stone door before her until she was directly upon it. A crescent moon had been engraved into its front, but there was nothing else extraordinary about it.

“Do not look into her eyes. Do not look into the shadows. If you do, the one that leaves this room will not be you,” Талил [he] warned, his voice soft in reverence.

He didn’t give Пиррена [she] the chance to ask what he meant. He reached over her shoulder and pressed his hand to the door. It swung open soundlessly. An icy chill wrapped Пиррена [she]’s body and prickled against her scales.

A sea of pitch black stretched out before her. Its form twisted and churned like oil in water. Something lurked within it, and its presence squeezed Пиррена [she]’s heart like a ripe tomato. She jerked her eyes toward the center of the room.

The dark was broken by a gentle beam of silver light cascading down from somewhere far above. A young girl sat in the center of the room, long hair running from her head and covering the ground around her. She had two pale blue eyes, as flat as the surface of the sea on a windless day. Her arms were wrapped around her legs, hugging her knees to her chest. No horns graced the top of her head. If it weren’t for her eyes and hair, the girl would have looked to be completely human.


This is Йоку [she]? She doesn’t look anything like literally any of the rumors said she would. I’m not sure if that’s a good thing or not.

Пиррена [she] stood at the edge of the darkness, her entire body frozen in terror. Талил [he] gave Пиррена [she] a firm push in the back, sending her stumbling into the shadows. His words echoed in her mind and Пиррена [she] focused her attention the girl’s hands, unwilling to let her gaze stray.

“I brought the one you requested, mistress,” Талил [he] said as he shut the door gently behind them.

“Thank you, Талил [he],” Йоку [she] said. Her voice was so soft that it should have been impossible to make out, but it rang as clear as a death knell in Пиррена [she]’s ears. “Come forward.”

Пиррена [she] would have preferred to do literally anything else, but her body had long since stopped listening to her mind’s desires. Following any of them would only get herself and her children killed.

She advanced through the darkness, doing her best to avoid looking at the murky waves roiling through the sea of black around her. Йоку [she] said nothing until Пиррена [she] and Талил [he] stood just a few feet away from her.

“That is sufficient,” Йоку [she] said. “Did you face difficulties, Талил [he]?”

“I did not. It was as you said.”

Йоку [she]’s head inclined in the slightest of nods. She lifted a thumb to her mouth and chewed on its tip as her pale eyes scored over Пиррена [she]’s body like dull knives. It was another several seconds before Йоку [she] spoke.

“You are a coward.”

The words weren’t spoken in the way of an insult. They were nothing more than a mere observation from an impartial observer.

“I survive,” Пиррена [she] said. The faintest flicker of anger fizzled in her stomach. Every powerful demon was the same. They all looked down at her, even though she’d had nothing but scraps to work with. She’d dragged herself here, a path of her own blood in her wake, while half of them had just stumbled into or been gifted their power.

“You do,” Йоку [she] murmured. “And you wonder why I have sought you out.”

“What purpose could you possibly have for me? I am beneath the notice of someone like you.”

“I wished to see if you would be useful to me,” Йоку [she] replied. Her head tilted slightly to the side. “No demon is useless. All may serve a purpose so long as they have sufficient motivation.”

The icy hand around Пиррена [she]’s heart started to clench even tighter. It didn’t sound like one, but that had been a threat. She was certain of it. Motivation never meant anything else in the Damned Plains.

“This is about Паук [he], isn’t it?” Пиррена [she] asked. “I don’t know anything about him. I can’t hurt him. He just told me to get him access to the auction. That’s it.”

“I know.” Йоку [she] fell silent for several more seconds. Then she removed her thumb from her mouth and let out a dainty sigh. “How disappointing. You are not what I need. Remove her, Талил [he].”

What? She dragged me all the way here just to say she doesn’t need me? What was the point of any of that?

“As you wish, mistress.” Талил [he] asked. The back of Пиррена [she]’s neck prickled as her instincts screamed out a warning.

“Stop!” Йоку [she] ordered, her eyes widening slightly in surprise. Her voice had only risen by the faintest pitch, but both Талил [he] and Пиррена [she] fell to their knees as if a thousand pounds of force had slammed down on their backs.

The breath froze in Пиррена [she]’s chest and a wave of dizziness threatened to swallow her consciousness entirely. An instant later the sensation vanished, but the breath had been completely driven from her lungs. She dragged in a ragged breath, her heart hammering like a runaway horse.

“Mistress?” Талил [he] wheezed, confusion evident in his voice.

“Unexpected,” Йоку [she] said, her voice back to its gentle tone. Her head tilted to the side as she observed Пиррена [she]. “Forgive me, Талил [he]. I did not mean to hurt you.”

“I am fine, mistress,” Талил [he] said, sounding decidedly not fine. “You wish me to stay my hand?”

“Her weight shifted,” the childlike demon murmured. “She was worthless, but the instant you moved to kill her, her weight magnified — and yours vanished.”

Weight? What is she talking about?

“Should you order it, I shall still act, mistress.” Талил [he]’s tone had shifted once more. Fear and resignation had replaced the confusion, as if he was signing away his own life with his words.

“You are too valuable for that,” Йоку [she] replied. Her eyes lowered to Пиррена [she], who hurriedly focused her attention back on the other demon’s knees to avoid holding her gaze. “Пиррена [she]. I desire an explanation.”

“An explanation?” Пиррена [she] asked weakly. “For what?”

“If Талил [he] had killed you just now, he would have joined you in death.” Йоку [she]’s voice was as cold as her icy eyes. “Tell me why. Who protects you?”

What? Nobody. I have nobody but my children, and none of them are anywhere near strong enough to so much as scratch Талил [he], much less kill him. There’s nobody —

A thought prickled at the back of Пиррена [she]’s mind. And, despite the situation she found herself in, she nearly burst into hysterical laughter.

“Answer the mistress, demonling,” Талил [he] ordered.

“Паук [he] protects me,” Пиррена [she] said as a lifeline finally manifested itself before her. It was thin, but it was the faintest chance to survive the night. As she always had, she clung to life like a shipwrecked man to a plank of wood.

“Паук [he]? What care does he have for you?” Талил [he] asked. “You are not one of his men.”

Пиррена [she] had no clue what had happened or why Йоку [she] believed she was protected. It didn’t matter. If Йоку [she] didn’t know, then Пиррена [she] could do what she did best.

Lie.

“He doesn’t care for me,” Пиррена [she] agreed, a small smile pulling across her lips as the false confidence she’d called upon thousands of times before finally manifested itself once again. “But he would be quite displeased at the delay if I failed to carry out my task.”

“Паук [he] would kill one of my men?” Йоку [she] asked. “Purely because I inconvenienced him?”

“So it would seem.”

To Пиррена [she]’s surprise, a faint smile slipped across Йоку [she]’s lips.

“Then perhaps you may be of use to me after all.”

Chapter 492: Shudder

Айлин [she] dismissed the group of streetlords before Паук [he] returned. It would take some time for them to bring their gangs in line, and he had no desire to go around to every single camp and browbeat everyone into submission.

He also wasn’t certain that the streetlords wouldn’t get themselves killed by saying something stupid the moment they met Паук [he]. The masked demon seemed to be forgiving enough, but Айлин [she] wasn’t about to bet on it.

There was no realistic way for him to directly control every single gang himself, so he still needed the streetlords. After the display he, Врит [he], and Вайолет [she] had put on together with Ли [she], Айлин [she] was pretty sure they’d make sure the rest of their gangs didn’t step out of line as well.

He still felt a little sick about the orders he’d given Ли [she]. Dozens of demons were dead because of his order. Ли [she] may have been the one to kill them, but she’d done it at his request. She’d been a sword that he had swung to make things easier on himself.

And worse, it had been easy.

I don’t regret it. These old bastards never would have bowed head to me if I didn’t do something drastic. By killing an entire gang, I’ll have saved all the demons that would have tried to push our boundaries later. This was the path that resulted in the least destruction.

It wouldn’t come without cost. He was more than aware of that. The demons he’d had killed were nameless and faceless to him, but everyone had connections. Some would have survived. He’d made enemies today.

Айлин [she] didn’t know if it would be today or some time far in the future, but some of those enemies would come to try and take revenge. There was nothing he could do about that. All he could focus on was growing stronger and making sure he was capable of dealing with that when the time came.

Until then he had to make sure that their efforts thus far didn’t go to waste. He sat in the center of the market square with Врит [he] and Вайолет [she], watching the other demons in the Сеть [organization] resume their normal operations.

They were still there when Паук [he] returned. The crowd parted as he strode through them and into the square, then quickly started to disperse out of self-preservation. Айлин [she] and the others hurried to rise to their feet.

“Relax,” Паук [he] said, a note of amusement in his voice. “I’ve dealt with the Rank 5. It went well. We’ll have no problems from her. I hope everything at camp was similarly successful.”

“More than,” Айлин [she] confirmed with something between a bow and a nod. “Ten gangs have fallen to us. There aren’t many more, and any remaining holdouts will probably surrender or be destroyed by tomorrow.”

“That is good news,” Паук [he] said with a nod. “Well done, all of you. No significant issues, I hope?”

“Nothing beyond expectations,” Айлин [she] said. A droplet of sweat rolled down the back of his neck. He wished that either Вайолет [she] or Врит [he] would say literally anything so Паук [he]’s full attention wouldn’t be laid solely on his shoulders, but they had unified in being more than content to let him speak. Айлин [she] tugged at the hems of his shirt to occupy his hands. “We may have some issues in the future, though.”

“Issues? Of what sort?”

“Bringing this many demons under one banner is going to draw a lot of attention,” Айлин [she] said. “And they’re going to be expecting something. They won’t be able to fight with each other anymore. None of them will be happy giving up their resources for equality when the stronger ones used to be able to take from the weaker. If they don’t have something to focus on and grow stronger with, they’ll turn on us.”

Being this upfront with Паук [he] is more than a little dangerous, but I don’t think dancing around the topic is a good idea either. I’d rather him get annoyed now than him rip my head off when the gang collapses from under us.

“Logically. You can’t take a predator’s food source away and expect them to be content with it,” Паук [he] said with a knowing laugh. “I appreciate the foresight. They’ll have more than enough to deal with in the coming days. We—”

Паук [he] cut himself off mid-sentence. His hand shot up to point at one of the rooftops and whisps of white wind howled to life around his fingers, forming into a churning sphere in a split instant.

Вайолет [she] lunged at Айлин [she], tackling him to the ground and knocking the air from his lungs. He managed to keep his view of Паук [he] as a gray blur flew through the air. It collided with the swirling sphere of wind, which detonated with a howl.

It sent the streak tumbling back, its momentum stolen. A metallic clatter rang out across the ground as a dagger bounced across the stone and scraped to a stop against the base of a tent. Айлин [she]’s eyes flicked to the rooftop from where the dagger had come.

A black-clothed demon leapt to their feet and spun to flee. They weren’t nearly fast enough. Yellow light flashed and a brilliant crack split the air. A bolt of lightning ripped through the market square and slammed into the demon’s shoulder.

Bone crunched and flesh sizzled. The force of the magic spun the demon and threw them to the rooftop. Врит [he] blurred across the ground and vaulted up to the demon on the top of the roof.


“Don’t kill them,” Паук [he] ordered, his voice cold as he let his hand lower.

Айлин [she] couldn’t see if Врит [he] responded to that. Вайолет [she] rolled off him and pulled him back to his feet.

“You okay?”

“Yeah. Thanks,” Айлин [she] said as he brushed himself off. “I prefer caution to getting impaled. I didn’t think anyone would send assassins this quickly.”

“Wouldn’t be the first.” Паук [he]’s eyes were locked on the rooftop as Врит [he] dragged the would-be assassin over to the edge of the roof and dropped down together with them, landing on the ground with a thud.

The demon groaned in pain. One of their arms was completely destroyed. If the magic had hit them in the chest, they’d have died instantly. Врит [he] held their other in a vice grip behind their back, not giving them any way to fight back as she brought her prisoner over to Паук [he].

“Fuck you,” the demon hissed. “You’re all dead.”

“Should I know you?” Паук [he] tilted his head to the side.

“I won’t tell you shit,” the demon snarled. “I’m not scared.”

Айлин [she] sucked on his teeth. That was a lie. He could taste it, as vibrant as the rising sun. The demon was terrified.

“He’s not telling the truth,” Айлин [she] said.

Паук [he] gave him a small nod, but the masked demon didn’t even seem to care all that much. He reached into his bag and pulled out a featureless, pitch-black mask.

“You’re the fourth one, you know that?” Паук [he] asked, tossing the mask at the other demon’s feet. “Do you know what happened to the previous three? Or did your employer not tell you? And a dagger? Seriously? I’m honestly offended you thought that would kill me.”

The demon stared down at the mask. He looked back up to Паук [he], and Айлин [she] could feel his confusion even through the mask covering his features.

“A Shield? You want me to deliver this to my employer?” A bark of laughter slipped from the demon’s mouth. “You really think you can buy him off? Or is this meant to be a bribe? It won’t work. I’ll die before I give anything away.”

“Buy him off? No. Why would I need to do something like that? And I don’t need to bribe someone like you. There’s no information you could give me that’s worth the hassle. Let me guess. Your employer is a giant bloke that wears a mask and speaks with a rough yet noble voice. Sound accurate?”

The assassin hesitated for a flicker of an instant. “No.”

“Lie,” Айлин [she] said.

Паук [he] laughed. “Thank you, Айлин [she]. Put on the mask, demon.”

“Nothing you can do is worse than what will happen to me if I turn against a contractor,” the demon snarled. He tried to twist out of Врит [he]’s grip, but she dug her free hand into his wounded shoulder and he screamed in pain.

“Don’t move,” Врит [he] snarled.

“He believes that,” Айлин [she] put in.

Паук [he] nodded thoughtfully. “I see. Now put the mask on, demon. It’s just a shield. You stand no chance against me as you are. You aren’t even worth my time.”

“Arrogant bastard,” the assassin snarled.

“Arrogance is thinking you can kill me with a dagger,” Паук [he] drawled. “There’s only one thing I want from you, and it isn’t information. Let him go, Врит [he]. If he tries to run, I’ll destroy his other arm and put the mask on his face myself.”

Врит [he] released the assassin’s arm and shoved him forward. The demon stumbled toward the mask — then lurched into motion, yanking a black dagger from his side and lunging at Паук [he]’s neck with a burst of surprising speed.

A loud crack split the night. The assassin stumbled back, the dagger spinning from his fingertips, as Паук [he] drove his knee up into his nose. He fell to his back, coughing and choking on blood.

“Can’t say I didn’t expect that, but you really need to avoid telegraphing your movements so much,” Паук [he] said dryly. He put a foot on the mask and pushed it over to the fallen assassin. “Put. It. On.”

For a second, the only sound in the square were the assassin’s ragged breaths. Then, slowly, he reached out and grabbed the mask, sliding it onto his face. A dull hum filled the air as a crackling blue shield ignited and swirled to life around the assassin.

Айлин [she]’s Runes reached out, brushing harmlessly across Паук [he] but digging into the assassin and siphoning energy from him. The demon barely even seemed to notice. He scooped his dagger off the ground and Врит [he] moved forward, but Паук [he] raised a hand to stop her.

“No. It’s fine. Let him try.” Паук [he] raised his voice for a moment. “Ли [she]? Are you here?”

Ли [she]’s head popped out of her tent. “Yup!”

“Make sure we don’t have any more unwelcome guests, would you?”

“Kay,” Ли [she] said with a nod. She sank into a shadow and vanished.

Паук [he] turned back to the assassin and beckoned him onward. “Come on, then. Get back to it. I believe you had a job to be doing. Maybe you’ll be a bit better at it this time around.”

Айлин [she] swallowed. Паук [he] had given a powerful weapon to an assassin purely because the demon wasn’t even worth his time without it.

The assassin lowered his stance. Blood dripped from his crippled arm. Айлин [she] could smell it on the wind, mixed with the scent of fear. A droplet rolled off a finger and dripped to the ground. With a scream of defiance, the assassin blurred forward.

Паук [he] lifted a hand. The air before him crumpled, streaks of white energy swirling out like a spiderweb to meet the demon’s charge.

A loud, squelching crunch echoed through the market square. Айлин [she] joined the demon in staring at his chest, which had collapsed as if torn apart from within. The shield still hummed between him and Паук [he]’s palm, completely undamaged. Metal clattered to the ground once more as the assassin’s dagger clattered from his stiff fingers.

Then the assassin pitched back, the shield fading before crashed to the ground and laid still. The skin on the back of Айлин [she]’s neck prickled and his hair stood on end.

Паук [he] knelt, removing the mask from the assassin’s face and sliding it back into his bag. He glanced at Айлин [she]. “Get rid of this body somehow, would you? Check it to see if there’s anything useful, but I doubt there will be.”

Айлин [she] swallowed again before giving Паук [he] a sharp nod. “I will do as you ask.”

“Much appreciated,” Паук [he] said. “And after that, try to brush up a little bit. We’ll be going to an auction soon. We’re going to make it a memorable one.”

Айлин [she] repressed a shudder.

Somewhere across the city, back in an egg-shaped mansion and hunched over in a throne with her head in her hands and unaware as to why, Пиррена [she] did the same.

Chapter 493: The Greatest Fighting Style

Grass rustled at Джален [he]’s feet. The breeze curling past his hair and caressing the back of his neck carried the faint scent of sweet nectar on it. His nose scrunched slightly in annoyance.

“Well then,” Джален [he] said, crossing his arms in front of his chest and tilting his head to the side. “I think it’s starting to get a little crowded.”

As was becoming habit, he and Вермил [he]’s students had gathered for class once more. They’d absconded from Арбитраж [he]’s typical training areas and headed out to the Windscorned Plateau with a little help from Тим [he].

Джален [he] just hadn’t realized quite how many people Вермил [he] had actually known. Their group of temporary teachers, which had initially just been him and Брейден [he], had now expanded to include Бёрд [she] and — for some reason — Сильвертид [he].

That was rather odd, as Джален [he] couldn’t quite remember inviting Сильвертид [he], but the old man had a good relationship with the kids. And, despite being a Rank 5, he was an incredibly capable mage.

There were at least four different conversations going at once. Изабель [she] and Тодд [he] were speaking about their runes, Сильвертид [he] was showing Александра [she] some sword techniques, and Джеймс [he] and Эмили [she] were flirting with about as much aptitude as a pair of toddlers.

At least Бёрд [she] was silent. She just clutched a grimoire to her chest and glanced around the grassy plains, evidently wishing she was literally anywhere else. Брейден [he] wasn’t doing much better. He just stood at the edge of the group, watching over everyone with eagle eyes as if a monster was going to materialize behind someone and try to rip their head off.

Damned Plains. I’m bored. I wonder if Сильвертид [he] plays darts. Maybe I should —

No. I have a duty. I don’t like those, but I’ve got proof that Вермил [he] isn’t dead. He’d probably be pissed at me if I failed his little brats, so I’ve got to make sure they actually perform well on this exam. I want to play darts again. He won’t be able to play if he’s too busy with remedial training.

Джален [he] aggressively cleared his throat. Not a single person looked in his direction. He was pretty sure nobody had heard him. His eyes narrowed in annoyance. The one thing he was not used to was being ignored.

Power swirled within his chest and burst out from him, ripping across the grassy plains as his domain washed out over everyone. He repressed it enough to avoid doing any damage, but the sheer pressure from his runes was still enough to make everyone stagger. The only one that wasn’t forced to take a step back was Сильвертид [he].

Джален [he] coughed into his fist.

“What?” Брейден [he] asked, his hand shooting to the hilt of his sword. “Is something happening? Are we about to be under attack?”

“No.” Джален [he] dragged the word out, then cleared his throat. “The situation is far more dire. I am bored.”

“Did you happen to train Вермил [he]?” Сильвертид [he] asked, tilting his head to the side.

“No,” Джален [he] replied. “Why?”

“Because you have striking similarities. You’re like a more irritable version of him,” the old soldier replied, his lip curling up in amusement. “But perhaps we should actually get started. Тим [he]e is too valuable of a resource to waste much of it. I trust you called us here for a reason?”

“I didn’t call you here at all,” Джален [he] corrected. “You are correct, though. We’ve had enough fraternizing. The exam is… soon.”

Everyone stared at him.

“How soon?” Брейден [he] asked.

Джален [he] cleared his throat again. This wasn’t going the way he’d wanted it to go. “Soon.”

“You don’t actually know what day the exam is, do you?” Изабель [she] asked.

“That is hardly relevant.” Джален [he] glared at her.

“He was probably too busy kicking rocks and muttering about darts,” Тодд [he] said with a snicker.

Джален [he]’s eyes narrowed. Вермил [he]’s students acted all too familiar with him. He was the head of the Линвик [they] House. A Rank 6 older than the majority of their family tree. Those who knew him quaked in fear at his name, much less his presence.

The head of a house shouldn’t permit this abject lack of respect — but I’ll be damned if these brats aren’t interesting. I can’t bring myself to actually complain about them being mouthy. It’s so much more interesting than all the idiots that scrape the floor with their teeth when I walk into the room.

“I was busy gathering teachers for you, as I can’t be bothered to do everything myself,” Джален [he] corrected. “Perhaps we should take advantage of my hard work. I spent a great amount of effort on this, you know. You could at least be appreciative.”

“On bringing Сильвертид [he]?” Тодд [he] asked, glancing at the elderly soldier. “That couldn’t have taken much effort. He invited himself.”

Джален [he] sighed. “No.”

“Was the no to inviting Сильвертид [he]? Or was it to the not taking much effort part?” Тодд [he] kept a straight face, but Джален [he] could see he was desperately trying to avoid laughing.

“Both,” Джален [he] admitted with a smirk. “There aren’t many things in this world that I’m truly motivated to do. But Сильвертид [he] was not the instructor I kindly invited to assist you. That would be the woman trying to hide behind Брейден [he]. She has kindly volunteered to assist all of you.”

“I am not trying to hide,” Бёрд [she] said as everyone turned to look at her. “And I did not volunteer to do anything.”

“Then why are you here?” Эмили [she] asked.

“I blackmailed her,” Джален [he] said jovially. “Any further questions?”

“Yeah,” Isable said. “What did you—”

“That was a rhetorical question,” Джален [he] said, cutting Изабель [she] off mid-sentence. “No more questions. I don’t care. Now, shall we get on with this? I’ll be so kind as to introduce you all. Everyone, this is Бёрд [she]. Stupid name if you ask me. You can’t just choose a random noun to be your name. And Бёрд [she], this is everyone else.”

“That may be the worst introduction to someone I’ve ever gotten, and I’ve been through a lot of introductions,” Сильвертид [he] said dryly.

“Thank you,” Джален [he] replied without an ounce of sarcasm. “I take pride in my abilities — and Бёрд [she] takes pride in her Runes. She’s a member of the King family that has very kindly volunteered to supply all of the little brats from her own supply. Isn’t that sweet?”

Four pairs of eyes snapped over to Бёрд [she]. That had gotten their attention. Her face paled and she clutched the book tighter to her chest.


“You never mentioned Вермил [he] had this many students.”

Джален [he] couldn’t help but notice that Александра [she] didn’t look nearly as excited about the Runes as any of the others. His head tilted to the side. She was a Rank 3, but that was no reason to give up on getting new runes.

“There are just five of them. What’s the big deal?” Джален [he] asked.

“I can’t take any new runes right now,” Александра [she] said. “So there are only four of us.”

Does she have all seven of her runes filled in? Hm. I can’t remember if Вермил [he] mentioned anything about her abilities or not. I wasn’t really paying all that much to anything his students did other than their formations. Maybe I should have listened closer. Oh well.

“That’s fine,” Джален [he] said. He flickered, teleporting behind and clapping a hand down on her shoulder. She winced in surprise and he grinned. “Take some anyway. The King family is very generous.”

“These aren’t even the King family’s runes,” Бёрд [she] said, glaring at Джален [he]. “They’re mine!”

“Even more reason to be generous. No punishment for taking too much.”

“Why don’t you give them some yourself?” Бёрд [she] demanded. “You’re the head of the Линвик [they]s!”

“Because that’s a whole lot less amusing than making you do it. Now get on with it, unless you were planning to show them that fighting style of yours that you were practicing.”

Бёрд [she] choked on her own saliva and doubled over, coughing.

“What kind of fighting style?” Александра [she] asked, her interest suddenly piqued.

“Nothing that concerns you,” Бёрд [she] replied, managing to get her fit under control. She clutched her grimoire to her chest like a sailor clinging to a plank of wood after a shipwreck. “It is of no matter.”

“I’d say it was rather interesting, actually.” Джален [he] scratched his chin. “Something you derived from Вермил [he]’s fighting style, if those scribbles on your wall were anything to go by.”

“Вермил [he]’s fighting style?” Сильвертид [he]’s bushy eyebrows lifted and he leaned on his staff. A flicker of regret passed through his features. “What style are you referring to? Вермил [he] was a uniquely capable individual. Any instruction that could be passed on from him would be a fantastic resource. I didn’t realize Бёрд [she] knew him that well.”

“He is a capable individual,” Изабель [she] corrected. “He’s still alive.”

“I am not going to continue this conversation,” Бёрд [she] said. She slapped a palm against the leather bindings of her grimoire. “I’ve been forced to bring you all some Runes, and that’s what I’ve done. You may each choose one.”

“Two,” Джален [he] said.

“Why?” Бёрд [she] demanded.

“Three.”

“Oh gods — fine. Two,” Бёрд [she] snapped. “Happy?”

“Two and you teach them the fighting style.” Джален [he] could barely hold his laughter back at the incredulous expression on Бёрд [she]’s face. He flashed her a toothy grin. “Go on. Bargain more. We’ll see how many runes you’ve got in your grimoire after I’m done.”

“You can’t just blackmail me into giving all my runes away,” Бёрд [she] ground out. She clenched her jaw and turned her head to meet Джален [he]’s gaze. “Don’t treat me like one of your subordinates, Джален [he]. I agreed to give some runes, but not all of them. You can’t push me into doing whatever you want.”

I can respect that. At least, I could on most days. Unfortunately, this isn’t just about me. As much fun as I’m having with this, there’s a greater purpose to it.

“That’s where you’re wrong,” Джален [he] said. His smile slipped away and his hand tightened on Бёрд [she]’s shoulder. “I am very used to getting what I want, Бёрд [she]. I asked you to collect Runes because there are too many eyes on me, and pulling from the Линвик [they] reserves would have set off the spies that I haven’t bothered rooting out of my house. These kids don’t need that attention. They can’t afford it. I don’t have any Runes they can use myself — thus, you. So either you give the kids what I am more than aware you can afford given your salary from Отто [he], or the Линвик [they] family ceases all trade with him.”

Бёрд [she]’s eyes widened in disbelief. “You wouldn’t. That would do significant damage to both of our families. Отто [he] would be—”

“Furious,” Джален [he] finished. “Look me in the eyes, Бёрд [she]. Tell me if you think I give the slightest shit about the Линвик [they] family. It is a house of wretched cowards. The Kings are no better. I’d watch them both burn if I thought it would be amusing enough. Don’t tell me you giving away ten runes would break you. It’s a month of work at best.”

Бёрд [she] clenched her jaw. Then she blew out a short, angry breath. “Fine. Two runes.”

“And the fighting style,” Изабель [she] added. “If there’s something that Professor Вермил [he] did that you learned, I want to know how to do it too.”

“You heard the kid,” Джален [he] said with an unabashed grin. “And the fighting style.”

“I am not fighting naked in front of an audience,” Бёрд [she] snapped. She caught herself an instant later and cringed, but it was too late. She’d already spoken. It took every ounce of self-control that Джален [he] had to keep from howling with laughter.

“Ohhhh,” Тодд [he] said, his eyes lighting up in recognition. “That’s the fighting style you’re talking about? I guess we should have guessed.”

It seemed as if Бёрд [she] had only heard half the words that had just come out of Тодд [he]’s mouth. Her eye twitched. “What? He showed you?”

“Oh, yeah,” Тодд [he] said with a nod. “All the time, especially in the Scorched Acres. fighting naked is a pretty good way to put it. It really did feel like that. The style was really useful. Great at making me get over my fears and trust myself more. I did almost get ripped open a few times, though.”

“He did it with you?” Бёрд [she] exclaimed, pulling at her hair in distress.

It was Изабель [she]’s turn to nod. “We all did it together. He helped at the start, but after a while he just watched.”

“Is this the technique you used back in the first exam that you told me about?” Эмили [she] asked eagerly. “I want to learn how to do that! I don’t plan to stop using a shield, but being able to fight naked would definitely help me save energy. Can you show us?”

“There’s something seriously wrong with all of you,” Бёрд [she] said with a groan. “Is Вермил [he] a plague? A curse that infects everyone he gets close to?”

“Oh, most certainly,” Джален [he] said through a cackle.

“Does that mean the two of you… figured out exactly how the style works?” Бёрд [she] asked, a flicker of hesitation passing through her as she pointed to Изабель [she] and Тодд [he] in turn.

“I don’t know if we’ve mastered it, but I think we got a decent understanding,” Тодд [he] said as he scratched his neck. “Nobody did it as good as Вермил [he].”

Бёрд [she] swallowed. A second passed before she let out a defeated groan. “I can’t pass up the opportunity to learn more. I’ll show you what I’ve learned if you do the same.”

Тодд [he] and Изабель [she] shrugged as one.

“Sure,” Изабель [she] said. “If Вермил [he] showed you something, then I want to learn it.”

Бёрд [she] scratched the side of her neck. She glanced to Джален [he]. Then she sighed. “If a word of this ever leaves this field, I will make every single one of you regret it.”

“I’m not spreading Вермил [he]’s teaching anywhere he doesn’t want me to,” Александра [she] said, crossing her arms in front of her chest.

“Same,” Тодд [he] said.

“I wouldn’t share without his or Мокси [she]’s permission, and Джеймс [he] is too lazy to do anything,” Эмили [she] added. Джеймс [he] nodded sleepily in agreement.

“Fine,” Бёрд [she] said. She grabbed the hem of her shirt, her face screwed up in a grimace. “Let’s get this over with.”

“Whoa! What are you doing?” Тодд [he] asked as Изабель [she] lifted a hand to cover his eyes.

Бёрд [she] paused with the shirt up to her midriff. “Seriously? You’re going to make me explain this ?”

“Maybe her shield is beneath her shirt,” Эмили [she] offered, but she didn’t sound particularly confident in her own words.

“No, I’m not wearing a shield. I was getting naked,” Бёрд [she] said through a sigh. “You are making this a lot harder than it has to be.”

“Holy shit, you were being literal?” Тодд [he] asked. “Вермил [he] didn’t actually get naked to fight. He just doesn’t use a shield.”

Бёрд [she] stared at him. “What?”

“He still wore his clothes when he trained with us,” Изабель [she] said. “And thank any god that was listening for that. He never would have beaten the allegations against him if he didn’t.”

“Are you saying Вермил [he] fought naked in front of you?” Эмили [she] asked, her eyes narrowing. “Does Мокси [she] know?”

“I… no, I never actually saw him fighting. I made some educated guesses to fill some things in,” Бёрд [she] stammered. Her eyes darted around the clearing, then abruptly lit with understanding. “So that’s what he did.”

Ah, damn. I suppose the fun is over. I’m not sure how Вермил [he] managed to trick her this badly, but Бёрд [she] was always better at researching than thinking from what I recall Отто [he] telling me. I suppose it’s about time to get class started properly anyway. No more jokes.

“What do you mean?” Тодд [he] asked, Изабель [she]’s hand still over his eyes.

“He only showed you the first part of the technique,” Бёрд [she] said without so much as a flicker of hesitation. “My research has deduced the next stage, but perhaps you all aren’t ready for it yet.”

Джален [he] was unable to hold back any longer. He doubled over and howled with laughter. Despite a bit of naivety, Бёрд [she] had some pretty good observations written on her walls. Джален [he] was pretty certain her tutelage would actually be quite useful for the students so long as she didn’t lose her clothes in the process. That would just have to wait until he could breathe properly again.
