Chapter 539: This Isn'T A Beach, It'S A Book!

Ной [he] followed Аксиль [she]’s horrified gaze down to the grimoire resting on the ground before him. For a terrible moment, he feared that the book had decided to start plastering pornography across its pages again — but it wasn’t even open.

The cover was dormant, the eye design that adorned it inanimate and fast asleep. There was absolutely nothing worth gaping over. Ной [he] looked back over to Аксиль [she]. She was still staring at the book like it had just killed her entire family and offered her a thirty-course meal made from their bodies.

Did it draw something and then get rid of it before I could see it?

“What is that?” Аксиль [she] repeated, straining back in the chair in an attempt to get herself as far away from the grimoire as possible. Her features twisted with disgust and unease and she pulled at the vines, successfully trying to free herself from them.

“This is a book,” Ной [he] replied, failing to keep his confusion from entering his voice. “A big one. You’re not scared of reading, are you? Wait — do they teach reading in the Damned Plains? Do they even have schools here? Is that what’s going on? Are you scared of education?”

The small demon didn’t respond. It barely even seemed like she’d heard him speaking. Her gaze was firmly locked on the book, eyes unwilling to tear themselves free in spite of the horror in her features.

Ной [he] looked over to Мокси [she] and Ли [she]. “Did the book do something naughty? It’s still got some bad habits that I’m trying to work out of it. We had an understanding that it wouldn’t go around flashing people anymore, and I’m going to have to go discipline it if it’s ignoring me.”

The book flapped in protest in Ной [he]’s hands, but he ignored it. He trusted the book just about as far as he could throw it — which, ironically enough, depended entirely on how light the book wanted to make itself at the moment.

“Your book is flashing people?” Ли [she] asked.

“Аксиль [she] is a face-ripping demon,” Мокси [she] said flatly, crossing her arms in front of her chest. “Do you really think seeing a pair of tits would be enough to do this to her?”

Ной [he] looked back over to the small demoness. She was still squirming in her chair. Мокси [she]’s vines kept her from running, but the mask of horror on her face hadn’t so much as budged.

“Maybe they don’t have a very good sex ed program in the Damned Plains,” Ной [he] said. “It could have been Аксиль [she]’s first time seeing them. Could certainly be quite the surprise. You never know.”

“Mirrors exist.”

“So do idiots. Maybe she’s never seen one.”

“And she’s never looked down either?”

“Okay, point taken,” Ной [he] said, scratching at the back of his neck. “And this is a bit much even if that was the case. They’re not that scary.”

“Maybe it drew a dick,” Ли [she] said.

“Why do you know what that is?” Ной [he] asked. “I don’t really know why, but I feel like you shouldn’t know what that is. Actually, don’t answer that question. I don’t think I want to know.”

Ной [he] turned the book around and flipped it open to an empty page. He arched an eyebrow and prodded it. “What happened? What did you do?”

Ink sketched across the book’s pages, drawing out a rather confused-looking stick figure. Ной [he] narrowed his eyes, but the book showed him nothing else. It seemed to be equally as confused as he was.

Ной [he] blew out a heavy sigh and pinched the bridge of his nose. This was a pain in the ass, but maybe there was a chance he could turn it to his advantage. He wasn’t above using the grimoire as a threat if it got Аксиль [she] to actually play ball.

“Wake up. I’m still here,” Ной [he] said, snapping his fingers in front of the small demon’s face. She blinked, finally tearing her gaze away from the grimoire, and looked up to him. “Are you ready to properly bargain yet?”

“It’s horrible,” Аксиль [she] muttered.

“I’ll take that as a no,” Ной [he] said. He tapped the grimoire, drawing Аксиль [she]’s eyes back to its pages. “New offer. You tell us just what Сиван [he] is willing to give us for my rune, or I leave you locked in a room with this thing and let it draw whatever it wants.”

The grimoire’s pages flapped.

Мокси [she] hid a sigh.

“I don’t think the book drew anything,” she whispered.

“Can’t rule it out,” Ной [he] replied in the same whisper. “You never know. It’s a sly one.”


“No!” Аксиль [she] exclaimed, cringing back into the vines behind her. “Don’t leave me with it!”

The eye on the back cover of the book snapped open and lifted to meet Ной [he]’s gaze. It squinted, then rolled as if to ask, what’s her problem?

Ной [he] almost felt bad for it. This was a bit of an overreaction — especially if it hadn’t actually drawn anything. He still wasn’t convinced that it was innocent, but the incident with Бёрд [she] had hopefully been a one-time thing. Ной [he] was pretty sure the book was too rune-hungry to risk its source of energy over some stupid pranks. Pretty sure, but not completely sure.

“Is it the book you’re scared of?” Ной [he] asked, watching Аксиль [she]’s expression carefully. “Or is it the forbidden knowledge within?”

“Tits are not forbidden knowledge,” Мокси [she] said. “Especially not poorly drawn ones.”

“I thought you didn’t think it drew anything. And how do you know they’re poorly drawn? This thing is pretty talented.”

The eye bobbed up and down in appreciation of the compliment. Ной [he] glared at it, and it jerked to a halt. Its eye sank back into the leather, returning to a plain design.

“Don’t encourage it,” Мокси [she] said. “Reinforcing negative behaviors is always a bad idea.”

“What is it, a child?”

“It is a wretched perversion of nature that should not exist,” Аксиль [she] rasped, finally finding the words to muster up an answer. “What kind of demon are you, to tolerate the presence of such a vile object?”

“I don’t think it drew anything,” Ли [she] said.

“Yeah, I think you’re probably right. Not even a huge prude would have a reaction this bad to art in poor taste. Аксиль [she], what exactly is your problem with my grimoire?”

“You ask me ?” Аксиль [she] asked, incredulously. “Do you seek to mock me? To unnerve me to the point where I fail Лорд [he] Сиван [he] and offer you what you wish? It will not work. Not even something as wretched as—”

“Tell me what or I’m going to hit you with the book.”

Аксиль [she] stared at Ной [he]. “What?”

Ной [he] lifted the grimoire. Enormous it might have been, but in his hands, the huge book barely felt like it weighed more than a piece of cardboard. The biggest problem hitting anything with it would be the air resistance.

“You heard me.”

“You would not dare. Your handling of such a vile instrument is already enough to fill my throat with bile. Such an affront to one of Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s followers would be like spitting on his face.”

“I am going to hit you with the book.”

“You will not—”

Ной [he] hit her with the book.

It wasn’t a particularly hard strike. It was more of a light thonk to the top of her head, like he was rapping it with a rather oversized ruler. Ной [he] couldn’t deny that it felt incredibly satisfying, but he would vehemently refuse any insinuation that he’d done it purely because he wanted to see what it would happen.

Аксиль [she] recoiled, letting out a catlike hiss. “You wretched—”

“I’ll do it again,” Ной [he] warned, lifting the book over his head. “I can do this all day. Literally. It’s very light.”

“You attempt to blackmail one of Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s own.”

“There’s no attempt in the picture. I’m quite literally doing it,” Ной [he] said. He hoisted the book. “I don’t even feel bad about this, which really isn’t saying much, but I figure I’ll mention it anyway. Nobody has ever died from getting konked on the head a few times with a few pieces of paper.”

“No! Get that away from me!” Аксиль [she] demanded. She writhed in the chair and the vines bound tighter around her, keeping the demon from escaping. “Do not touch me with that corpse!”

Ной [he] paused. He looked from Аксиль [she] to the book, then back to Аксиль [she]. “This is a book. I’m pretty sure we covered this bit already. I didn’t hit you that hard.”

“A book made of a corpse,” Аксиль [she] snarled, her head pushing against the vines behind her so heavily that they were starting to smush. “Don’t play coy with me, Паук [he]. You know what that is. Any demon would know what that is when their flesh came into contact with it.”

The eye on the book snapped open and swiveled down to stare at Аксиль [she].

“Humor me,” Ной [he] said.

Ли [she]’s picked this thing up more than once. She’s never mentioned a word about it.

“You play me for a fool,” Аксиль [she] spat.

Ной [he] hoisted the book.

Аксиль [she] paled.

“The book you sully your hands with is bound with the still-living flesh of demon-kind,” the demoness spat. “Its canvas is a broken, disgusting mess. It bears the souls of the demons that were withered, ripped apart, and forced together. Its leather is burnt demonflesh, the screams long since silenced. That is a vile abomination that lingers between life and death, any remaining desire that its constituents may have had withered and lost within its pages. It is an affront to both life and death, hovering between both but belonging to neither. It is the most hideous thing I have ever laid eyes upon. Remove it from my presence.”

Ной [he] paused. He looked up at the grimoire in his hands. Аксиль [she]’s claim didn’t exactly answer any unasked questions, but it did feel like it could make sense. He had wondered exactly how the book could just store infinite runes. Nothing like that ever worked through sunshine and rainbows. Squishing a bunch of demons into a blender and making a book out of them was definitely pretty evil sounding. More than enough of a sacrifice to make a powerful evil magical item.

“Can this be undone?”

“No. Their souls are shredded, their forms combined. That vile book is now what they once were. A new creature, one that can only be purged,” Аксиль [she] said. A smug note entered her voice. “I do not know how you were blind, but your eyes have been opened. You wield the twisted bodies of your bretheren. Лорд [he] Сиван [he]—”

Whelp. Can’t do anything about it, then. Bummer. Sorry. I’m keeping the book, though.

“Is not here,” Ной [he] finished. “Now start talking about what he’s going to give me for my Rune, or I’m going to smack you with the corpse-stick again.”

I really do have to figure out what the fuck this thing is when I get a chance, but now is not that time. Can’t lose the momentum I’ve built up. One problem at a time, thank you very much.

Аксиль [she] gaped at Ной [he]. “You know what that vile object is, and yet you continue to use it?”

“I’m about to set a record for the most times I’ve smacked someone’s head with a blended-up demon corpse in one minute.”

“You wouldn’t—”

Ной [he] did a remarkable rendition of Мокси [she] and arched his eyebrow.

Аксиль [she] swallowed. “Perhaps we can come to an agreement. Don’t touch me with that disgusting… thing. Please.”

Ной [he] smiled.
==========
Chapter 540: Keep Silent

As it turned out, Аксиль [she] wasn’t actually qualified to promise much of anything that Сиван [he] owned. Even with the threat of being forced to witness what was apparently the most hideous object in existence, she could do nothing but attempt to get him an audience. That was no surprise to Ной [he].

There was no way a demon as powerful as Сиван [he] would be sending someone actually powerful to retrieve a broken Master Rune. A soul only had so much room in it. Even with the growth that came through advancement, he really doubted that an immensely powerful demon would want to use anything less than the best Runes they could find.

It was far more likely Сиван [he] was just collecting the runes. His name and a threat were probably more than enough to retrieve everything he’d ever previously needed. Аксиль [she] had just been the closest to their area. The most convenient option for retrieval.

Someone like that wouldn’t have bargaining power. They couldn’t promise anything — and Ной [he] had almost been counting on it. While he’d have been more than happy to agree to a trade for a more worthwhile rune for himself, Ли [she], or Мокси [she], he was equally pleased to get an introduction to someone else who could help them.

And that was exactly what Аксиль [she] offered, straining in her chair and desperately doing everything in her power to get away from Ной [he]’s book.

“I’ll introduce you to Зат [he],” Аксиль [she] swore, her eyes screwed so tightly shut that Ной [he] feared her face was going to freeze that way. She jerked against the restraings holding her to no avail. “He will be able to speak on behalf of Лорд [he] Сиван [he]. You can come to an arrangement with him.”

“And what stops him from just deciding to try the same shit you did?” Мокси [she] asked, tilting her head to the side. “Are we going to have to fight every single person in your organization?”

“Лорд [he] Сиван [he] told me to use any means necessary to acquire the rune he seeks. Зат [he] will not interfere. Just let me go. I do not wish to be in the presence of that… thing any longer.”

This is a really strong reaction for what should amount to little more than a really ugly stitched-together corpse. I’m definitely not complaining, but seriously? I’d suspect Аксиль [she] was faking this if it wasn’t so disadvantageous for her to do so. If she just spoke to us normally and offered to play ball the first time around, it would have saved her a bunch of time and humiliation.

From what I can tell, Сиван [he] somehow gave her a way to see… death. Or something like that. Maybe it’s the equivalent of setting a stink bomb off next to a dog’s sensitive nose. It’s just fucking with her senses so badly that she’s willing to do anyting to get away.

Works for me. I’d rather trade with Сиван [he]’s underlings than fight them. If it gets me some leverage, maybe I could use that to find out where Визен [he] is or to get some other advantage over him. We definitely can’t take him out as we are now, and every step in the right direction is valuable.

That was the whole point of this whole Паук [he] shtick. This wasn’t how I planned on taking it, but I’ve always loved improv.

“Acceptable,” Ной [he] said. He crossed his arms in front of his chest “And where are we going to find Зат [he]? I hope you don’t expect us to just let you go free. I haven’t earned a reputation as a particularly magnanimous man.”

“I will call to him. For something of this level of importance, he will arrive. Personally.”

Eh. Can’t ask for more than that. Perfect.

“Then I believe we have ourselves a deal,” Ной [he] said.

“I want to keep the axe,” Ли [she] said.

“Don’t you already have an axe?” Ной [he] frowned. For that matter, he hadn’t seen Ли [she]’s axe in quite some time. “What did you do with it?”

She gave him a sheepish grin. “I left it behind on accident.”

Ной [he] blew out a breath and shook his head. “Don’t lose your toys, Ли [she]. Аксиль [she], we’re keeping the axe. I trust you don’t mind? It’s a bit too big for you now anyway.”

Аксиль [she] cracked an eye open and stared despondently at the huge weapon. “It was crafted from metal mined deep within the Black Reaches. It will not allow another to wield it. I bound it to my soul.”

“I don’t think you can wield it much yourself,” Ной [he] pointed out.

“I will eventually consume enough energy to rebuild myself to my proper size,” Аксиль [she] said. Her gaze caught on the book and she stiffened. Her features scrunched and she turned her head away. “Is this truly relevant?”

Ли [she] hoisted the axe. She gave it a test swing, which was somewhat concerning given that they were all inside the tent with her, then tilted her head to the side. “It seems to work pretty fine to me.”


Аксиль [she]’s gaze snapped to Ли [she]. She stared at the other demon in befuddlement. “You… swung my axe?”

Ли [she] swung the axe again.

“Careful!” Мокси [she] warned, stepping away from Ли [she]. “I am not trying to get chopped in half. Don’t swing sharp things in the tent. You could—”

The momentum of Ли [she]’s swing carried the blade around into the tarp behind her, slicing clean through it. She skidded to a halt, then cleared her throat and moved to stand in front of the newly made flap.

“Oops.”

“How are you doing that?” Аксиль [she] asked. She glanced back at the book and swallowed, then forced herself to look away from it. “You shouldn’t be able to swing that. It’s mine.”

“Does that mean I can have it?”

Аксиль [she]’s lips thinned. Her fingers flexed. The axe rattled in Ли [she]’s grip — but it didn’t so much as budge. They both stood still for a moment. Аксиль [she]’s eye twitched.

“It betrayed me? You shouldn’t be able to — oh, fine. Just take it. It will be so long before I can use it again that I might as well make a new one. Just… let me out of here.”

“Pleasure doing business with you,” Ной [he] said. “Just go ahead and introduce us to Зат [he] and you’ll be welcome to go on your merry way.”

Аксиль [she] blew out a defeated breath, but one more glance in the direction of the book was all it took for her to nod her understanding. Мокси [she]’s vines slackened their grip on her, and she used the opportunity to squeeze into them even farther, as if trying to sink in and escape the presence of Ной [he]’s grimoire.

Light filtered into the tent from the front flap. Ной [he] looked over to it. Annoyance flickered over his features. It froze as he spotted Айлин [she] standing on the other side, Врит [he] beside him.

“I’m sorry for interrupting, but this is urgent,” Айлин [she] said, his face pale. “We just picked up word from our network that Commander Зорин [he] is on the move. He’s not even trying to hide it. He’s coming here, Паук [he].”

The tone of Айлин [she]’s voice made it clear that this was probably a big deal. Unfortunately, Ной [he] had no blasted idea who Зорин [he] was — but that didn’t make it hard to guess. If there was someone with the title of Commander living in Трэдон [he], it was pretty easy to guess who they worked for.

“Белкус [he]’ man?”

“His strongest man,” Айлин [she] said, swallowing.

Shit. My magic is still gone. I can’t take a fight right now.

“Well then, I suppose we’ll have to see what he wants,” Ной [he] said, not letting any of his panic show on his features. That would just make the situation even worse. Filling the camp with terrified demons was the last thing he wanted to do, and it would completely ruin his persona. His mind spun. He wasn’t completely out of cards yet. People almost certainly would have spread word of his fight with Аксиль [she] by now. That could be used to his advantage.

“You’re going to fight him?” Айлин [she] asked, his eyes widening.

“I suppose we’ll find out,” Ной [he] said. “Мокси [she], Ли [she], keep an eye on Аксиль [she], would you?”

And get the hell out of here if things go wrong.

Мокси [she]’s lips thinned. She knew what he was doing, and she wasn’t pleased about it. But, with Ной [he]’s magic missing, it was the smartest move. They weren’t going to be able to swing a fight against someone far more powerful than him. Getting as many people to safety was far more important.

“Let me out first,” Аксиль [she] begged.

“No,” Мокси [she] said. “You’ve still got to take us to Зат [he]. We’ll let you out once this has been dealt with.”

“Sorry, Аксиль [she]. It shouldn’t take too long. Let’s go,” Ной [he] said to Айлин [she]. “It would be a shame to be caught off guard when our guest arrives. And Врит [he], would you grab Йору [he] for me?”

The two demons nodded. Врит [he] shot off while Айлин [she] led Ной [he] out of the tent.

While I can’t beat anybody in a magical fight right now, there’s more one way to win a battle — and magic kneels before the throne of pure, unadulterated bullshit.

***

Аксиль [she]’s mouth was as dry as parchment. She watched Паук [he] leave the tent out of the corner of her eye. The vines binding her infuriatingly weak body had relaxed, but they still held her fast.

Her eyes darted from Мокси [she] to Ли [she] to the dirt. They danced in an attempt to escape, but it was futile. There was no escape from the warped, destroyed canvas that swam in the center of the room.

There was no escape from the being that rose from it, its gaunt form composed of sickly, warped death energy, somewhere between rot and shadow. No escape from the ice-cold fingers that gripped her face. No escape from the sickness that dripped from its undulating flesh and rolled down her skin.

Nobody else could see it. They couldn’t see the slender form that was forced to bend in on itself and scrunch to avoid tearing through the top of the tent. They couldn’t see the empty, sunken eye sockets. Couldn’t see the mouth that floated in the darkness that was its visage, the crooked, too-wide teeth that twisted into a smile.

“Very good,” the Abomination whispered, its words squirming like worms burrowing into her ears. It turned her head to the side, then pulled its hand away, leaving a trail of slime on her cheek. “I’m glad we could come to an agreement, observant one. I would have been most displeased if you had said anything.”

Аксиль [she] swallowed. She said nothing.

“Keep silent, Servant of Death.” The Abomination’s smile grew wider, splitting its face like a weeping scar. “And remember. I can give you the true-death far faster than you can speak.”

The vile creature sank back, slithering into the pages of the book and vanishing from sight, but not from mind. Аксиль [she] could still feel its vile, paradoxical gaze burning into her skull. The warped hatred and power that twisted within the creature was so immense that it threatened to choke the breath from her lungs.

Аксиль [she] didn’t know what could have created such a monstrosity. She didn’t know what horrible monster could have trapped it within the book before her. In her years of life, she’d never witnessed such a thing.

She couldn’t tell how powerful the monster truly was. In her current form, she had no way to fight it even if she’d wanted to. There was absolutely nothing she could do but remain silent and pretend that it was the book alone that had ripped the visceral reaction from her. That it was the book which she feared, not the harbinger of sickly hell trapped within its pages.

And that was exactly what she did.
==========
Chapter 541: An Audition

Ной [he] stood by Йору [he] and Айлин [she] in the center of the market square as he waited for Commander Зорин [he] to arrive. Врит [he] stood several paces behind them in the shadows, shifting from foot to foot nervously. She looked painfully uncomfortable. Ной [he] didn’t blame her.

He wasn’t all that keen about the whole waiting bit either. As a general rule, Ной [he] didn’t like waiting. He especially disliked waiting for anything that he didn’t actually want.

But in this particular scenario, waiting hypothetically worked to his advantage. The longer it took Зорин [he] to arrive, the closer he got to getting his magic back and the more time he had to come up with bullshit.

“So,” Ной [he] said, his eyes scanning the sky in search of a demon flying in their direction. “Anybody know anything about what we’re up against?”

“He’s strong,” Айлин [she] provided, somewhat unhelpfully.

“Thank you, Айлин [she]. I had guessed that part,” Ной [he] said. He glanced over to Йору [he]. “And you?”

“Yes,” Йору [he] said. “I am aware of Зорин [he].”

“Perhaps it’s something you’d like to share with the class?”

“It is not.”

“And why would that be?” Ной [he] asked as he rifled through his pockets and scanned their surroundings, having just remembered that his face wrappings had been somewhat ruined during his fight with Аксиль [she].

It’s not like having face wrappings actually matters when I’m in the Damned Plains. Nobody knows who I am and I’m well past the point where I need to pretend to be weak. I’ve got a reputation, and having a fully human form can lend itself to that. But the wrappings are basically my calling card by now. It would feel disappointing if I show up without them. Like finding a certain magical mouse in a specific “happy” place on earth without any large, circular ears.

“Because I have not examined the outcome of this interaction with regard to you,” Йору [he] said. “I do not plan to interfere, so it is shrouded from me.”

“Maybe I should expand my question to ask why you are choosing to be useless,” Ной [he] grumbled.

“I have been testing your suggestion and limiting the use of my abilities,” Йору [he] replied with a small shrug. “Зорин [he] does not pose me any threat. I have already seen the future in which our goals align, and we have taken steps on that path. No significant weights should have shifted, so my desired future remains in place. I do not need to check on it any further, so I can avoid looking at specifics while I follow your and Вайолет [she]’s advice with regard to my powers.”

Ной [he]’s eyes narrowed. “I can’t speak for Вайолет [she], but I was saying that you need to start thinking for yourself and stop letting your magic completely control you.”

“Correct.”

“But you already believe you know the future we’re in right now,” Ной [he] pointed out. “Just because you haven’t looked recently doesn’t mean you didn’t look. The whole point of that advice was to occasionally take life as it was. You’re only technically not using your magic — and this feels like a scenario where your magic would actually be smart to use.”

“Technically correct is still correct. And I do not need to use my magic. I will survive.”

“How do you know that I won’t just start blasting things the moment Зорин [he] shows up? That could screw your plans up, and I’ve just decided to do it at the last moment.”

“You won’t,” Йору [he] said with complete confidence.

Ной [he] wouldn’t. He rubbed the bridge of his nose and let out a sigh. “Has anyone ever told you how annoying that magic is? It’s just probabilities, right? Not guaranteed futures?”

“Statistics can be manipulated. My desired goal can always be achieved when approached with sufficient alternative angles. Are you requesting that I change my plans to ensure that I properly weigh the approaching future to ensure an ideal victory for you? That would involve using my magic and placing you in my debt — a deal I would be willing to accept.”

Ной [he] studied Йору [he] for a second. Her posture seemed less confident than normal. Despite her decision to only suspend her use of magic on a scenario she mostly had control over, there was still a “technically” involved. She didn’t actually perfectly know what would happen.

Йору [he] was trying to get control of herself back from her magic. Small steps were a vast improvement over no steps at all — and while Ной [he] suspected he could have made an argument that she owed him at least a little bit for housing and staying in his camp, he was more than aware that argument wasn’t going to fly.

I’m not going to be the reason she falls off the veritable wagon. If it looks like Зорин [he] is going to go around trying to murder everyone, I still have at least one usage of Разлом [he] I can get off right when I die. It’ll do some serious damage to my body, but I don’t think Зорин [he] is just going to come swinging.

You don’t send a Commander to execute a thorn in your side. He’s probably coming here to bargain with or threaten me. I can handle both of those situations without Йору [he] pulling on everyone’s strings like little puppets.

“You know what? I think I’ll be fine,” Ной [he] said. “Thanks for the offer, though.”

Йору [he] inclined her head. “You are welcome. Айлин [she], stop trying to eat my energy. It tickles.”

“Sorry,” Айлин [she] said, his cheeks blushing a bright purple. “I’m not trying to. You’re just really interesting. I also understand so little about how your magic works that everything you say triggers my Runes and I get hungry.”

“You will get hurt if you continue that path.”

Айлин [she]’s features paled. “Is that a future you saw?”

“No,” Йору [he] replied. “It is because I will flick you very hard, and it will hurt. I do not need to weigh the futures to know that outcome.”


The threat sounded laughable until Ной [he] remembered that Йору [he] was an incredibly highly ranked demon, and her flick was probably strong enough to kill the average demon on the spot. He doubted she would actually murder Айлин [she] out of annoyance, but Йору [he] was still an immensely powerful demon. It wasn’t a complete impossibility.

“There will be no flicking,” Ной [he] said firmly. He glanced at Айлин [she] out of the corners of his eyes. “And you really should get that power under control.”

“I’m working on it,” Айлин [she] said. He coughed into a fist. “I wasn’t done about Зорин [he], though. I know more. He’s a Rank 6 demon, 104 years of age. He’d done a good job of hiding his exact abilities, but he prefers to fight at range with a bone bow. It’s been a while since he’s had to use it. His reputation is usually enough to end most fights.”

Ной [he] blinked. That was a lot of information.

“When did you figure all of this out? Is it common knowledge?”

“No,” Айлин [she] replied with a shake of his head. “Given you were going after someone who has some ties to Лорд [he] Белкус [he], I suspected it would be prudent to direct the information network that you had the Сеть [organization] set up in Белкус [he]’ direction. It wasn’t hard. He likes flaunting his strength.”

“What else?” Ной [he] asked. He and Айлин [she] both paused as they spotted a black spot in the sky.

“I think—”

“He’s not here yet,” Ной [he] said promptly, eyeing the approaching demon. There was still some time before they would arrive. “Come on. Most important stuff first, if there’s anything left.”

“I have a lot of general information, but I don’t know how much of it will be immediately relevant beyond his abilities,” Айлин [she] said, almost falling over his own words in his haste to get them out. “From the stories I gathered, I think Зорин [he] is known to follow Белкус [he]’ orders very closely. You won’t be able to bribe or distract him. He’s reported to be incredibly single-minded. If you need to convince him of something, it can’t go against what Белкус [he] ordered. Anything else is likely to fail.”

The approaching demon was close enough in the sky that Ной [he] could make out alabaster white armor covering his red form. He didn’t let his eyes leave the demon as he gave Айлин [she] a curt nod. That was information he could work with. As it turned out, leaving a Knowledge Demon in charge of finding out information was pretty effective.

If only I could take credit for being a genius instead of just getting lucky that I located the one demon that happened to feast on information.

A frown flickered across Ной [he]’s face.

Actually, now that I think about it, isn’t that a bit too convenient? How did I land the one Knowledge Demon out of sheer, dumb luck?

He didn’t get a chance to consider it any further.

Huge wings snapped out from the back of the demon — who Ной [he] could only assume to be Зорин [he]. Wind buffeted Ной [he]’s hair back as Зорин [he] alighted on the stone before him. His wings folded in to hang around his shoulders like a cloak.

The commander was not at all what Ной [he] had been expecting. Despite Айлин [she]’s mention of using a bow, Зорин [he] appeared to be unarmed. Aside from the heavy looking white armor covering his body, he was entirely without equipment. Зорин [he] actually stood just slightly shorter than Ной [he], with the lean build of a runner. His features were flat, but not aggressive.

He seemed more like a scholar in armor than —

“Паук [he],” Зорин [he] said, staring straight at Айлин [she].

Okay. Maybe not the sharpest tool in the shed.

“Wrong one,” Ной [he] said.

Зорин [he] turned to him, entirely unperturbed. “Паук [he].”

Was he planning on doing that to everyone he saw until somebody said yes? I kind of want to know what would happen if I say I’m not Паук [he] either… but it’s probably not worth antagonizing Зорин [he] when he hasn’t done anything yet. Might as well hear out what he has to say.

“Pleasure,” Ной [he] said. “And you would be Зорин [he].”

“Correct.”

“Why have you come?” Ной [he] asked, tilting his head to the side. He meant the question — he’d done enough to annoy Белкус [he] by this point that he genuinely didn’t know what the answer was.

“Белкус [he] calls you to audition.”

“…for what?”

What, is he trying to start a demon dance troupe?

“Not for. To speak. Лорд [he] Белкус [he] demands your presence.”

“Ah.” Ной [he]’s eyes lit up. “That kind of audition. Sounds interesting enough. He’s welcome to swing by. I’ll make time for him.”

Commander Зорин [he] stared at Ной [he], confusion playing across his face. “You… will make time for him?”

“I know, it’s pretty gracious of me,” Ной [he] said magnanimously. “But I believe making his acquaintance would be a worthy expenditure of my time. I’ll have a chair prepared for him. A soft one. We have some nice chairs.”

“You will go to him,” Зорин [he] said, his eyes narrowing slightly. “Лорд [he] Белкус [he] is not at your beck and call.”

Yeah, but I’m really not keen on strolling into enemy territory. That’ s a great way to get yourself executed, and I can’t even blow myself up right now. I’m not going on a playdate with Белкус [he] until I can blow myself up. Being able to detonate your skull in case of emergencies should be the bare minimum standard for any date, really.

“Beck and call? He’s the one that wants to see me,” Ной [he] said with a frown. “I don’t go around demanding people visit me just because I want to see them. It’s rude. There are much better ways to get what you want.”

Зорин [he]’s brow furrowed — and then he paused. For the first time, he spotted Йору [he]. The demon took a step back, his hand going to his side for a weapon that wasn’t there. A flicker of fear passed through his eyes.

“Why is Йоку [she] the Rising Moon in your camp, Паук [he]?”

“What?” Ной [he] blinked in apparent confusion. “That’s Йору [he].”

Зорин [he] hesitated. His head tilted to the side. “…the Rising Moon?”

“No. Йору [he]. She’s a stray child that I ended up picking up,” Ной [he] said.

The commander’s eyes narrowed. He studied Йоку [she] for several long seconds. Then he crossed his arms in front of his chest. “Are you Йору [he]?”

“I have been called that.”

“Oh,” Зорин [he] said. He scratched the back of his head. “I see. That’s no issue, then. Your allies may accompany you. Белкус [he] will provide sufficient compensation for your time as well as diplomatic immunity for the duration of your stay.”

Ной [he] almost missed a beat. Out of everything he’d been expecting, an entirely civil meeting offer had been at the bottom of the list. It almost felt wrong.

“What does diplomatic immunity cover?” Ной [he] asked.

“Your life. Most of your limbs.”

Eh. Fair enough. That’s actually a decent offer. Might as well see what Белкус [he] has to say. Maybe he’s reasonable.

Ной [he] opened his mouth to answer — and a crackle of energy split the air. Everyone spun as a purple blade carved free of the air to Ной [he]’s side and sliced through it, peeling reality apart like it was a chunk of butter to form a wide portal. Purple smoke poured out from the churning hole, rolling across the ground.

A black sabaton crashed down on the stone as a towering, gray-skinned demon emerged from within the portal. The demon stood easily two times as tall as Ной [he]. He was clad from head to toe in spined black armor, an imposing helm of solid metal covering the entirety of his face. A thin gap full of glowing purple ran across its eyeline. On the demon’s back hung a massive broadsword. It was chipped and cracked, but its material was the exact same one that had gone into Аксиль [she]’s axe.

Pressure slammed into Ной [he] like a punch to the gut. His stomach clenched and he staggered. Айлин [she] and Врит [he] both slammed to the ground with such force that they cracked the cobblestone beneath them.

Йору [he]’s head tilted to the side.

Зорин [he]’s muscles tensed.

For an instant, there was silence. The intruder looked over them, face and expression concealed by his helm.

“Who are you?” Зорин [he] demanded.

“I am Зат [he]. Harbinger of Сиван [he]. The Cracked Blade, the Breathless End,” the demon intoned, drawing his sword and driving it into the ground before him with a single hand. The weapon sliced into the stone like nothing was there. With his other hand, Зат [he] pointed at Ной [he]. “Паук [he]. You killed my subordinate. We have business.”

Chapter 542: A Solution

Ной [he] and Зат [he] stared at each other for a long second. The towering demon seemed to be waiting for Ной [he] to say something or otherwise respond. Unfortunately for him, Ной [he] was still trying to figure out how they’d been found so quickly.

Does Аксиль [she] have some way to telepathically contact the other members of Сиван [he]’s group or something? If she does, why wouldn’t she have tried doing that sooner? It really looked like this dude just showed up on a whim, so he could have popped out at any point while I was smacking her with the corpse-book.

“I think kidnapped would probably be more accurate,” Ной [he] said, breaking the silence before it could grow too long. “Your subordinate is still alive. I generally don’t count something as killing unless your victim stays dead. At best, that’s just attempted murder.”

“I think Паук [he] is right,” Зорин [he] said, scratching at his chin. “You can’t have killed someone if they aren’t dead.”

“You most certainly can. Death is temporary,” Зат [he] said with a firm shake of his head. “And a great number of things don’t know how to stay dead. I’ve killed quite a number of my subordinates myself, and none of them are dead.”

“Then what’s the issue?” Ной [he] asked, tilting his head to the side. “And I should note that Аксиль [she] attempted to kill me first.”

“She didn’t kill you?” Зат [he]’s head tilted to the side. “She’s normally quite good at that part, even for a Rank 5.”

“No, she killed me,” Ной [he] said. “I just didn’t stay dead.”

Зорин [he] stared at Ной [he]. He raised a finger into the air, as if to ask a question.

Both Ной [he] and Зат [he] ignored him.

“You are making fun of me,” Зат [he] said, his voice flat.

“A little,” Ной [he] agreed. “I don’t tend to appreciate it when any group tries to kill me, even when their efforts are largely ineffective.”

“She succeeded,” Зорин [he] pointed out.

“I didn’t stay dead,” Ной [he] replied. “I generally don’t. The idea of it generally displeases me. Ideological differences with the whole concept of passing on and entering the afterlife. I just don’t get on well with the idea of dying, so I don’t. You know the deal.”

“No,” Зорин [he] said. “I don’t.”

“This is understandable,” Зат [he] said with a nod. “You speak of a concept well known to me. A concept that should not be under your domain. The power to deny death is one that belongs to Лорд [he] Сиван [he] alone. A blessing that he gives only to his greatest followers.”

“There are more ways to power than through Сиван [he] alone,” Ной [he] said with a one-shouldered shrug. “But I am not interested in debating the source of my strength. I do not care when one of my bodies is cut down, but I don’t enjoy it. Your subordinate wasted my time. I hope you haven’t arrived to do the same.”

“I am here to retrieve the object that she was sent to seek. I have no desire to waste any more time here than you do,” Зат [he] said, crossing his arms in front of his chest and tapping a foot against the ground. “This was originally Аксиль [she]’s task, but Лорд [he] Сиван [he] informed me that it was likely she has failed.”

“Actually, we’d come to an agreement,” Ной [he] said. “An agreement that involved you. I was under the impression she’d had some way to summon you here.”

Зорин [he] looked from Ной [he] to Зат [he] and then back again, trying and failing to follow the conversation as the confusion spread farther across his features and into his body language. This definitely was not how the Commander had envisioned the meeting going.

There was more than a little trepidation in his eyes. Зорин [he] evidently recognized Зат [he]’s name — and probably not because they were just similar enough to mildly annoy Ной [he]. He had no idea how powerful Зат [he] was, but if a Rank 6 was this wary around him, then something told Ной [he] that the massive, black-armored demon was not to be trifled with.

Peak of Rank 6? Or could he be even higher? A Rank 7? That doesn’t exist in Арбитраж [he], but the Damned Plains are not Арбитраж [he]. I was pretty sure the reason people got stuck at Rank 6 back there was because their runes are so poorly combined.


Maybe the demons have found a different way to advance past Rank 6. It could have something to do with their unique biology with regard to Runes, or perhaps there’s something else entirely. If that’s the case… maybe he’ll tell me how he reached Rank 7.

Even if Зат [he] isn’t Rank 7, this Сиван [he] character is definitely that strong — if not stronger. The amount of fear his name commands makes it impossible for him to be a mere Rank 6… as ironic as saying ‘mere’ Rank 6 sounds when I’m only a Rank 4.

“Аксиль [she] cannot summon me,” Зат [he] said through an amused snort, breaking Ной [he] from his thoughts. “She lacks the power. Her only duty was to retrieve a rune, but it seems the task was too great a challenge for her. That would be a mistake on my part. I was unaware of your presence. Had I originally known the one who owned the Rune was one such as yourself, I would have approached to handle the situation personally.”

There was something in Зат [he]’s voice that almost bordered on respect. It was somewhere just between acknowledgement and interest, with just a little uncertainty mixed in. He didn’t know what Ной [he] was capable of.

Ной [he] also caught something else in the demon’s words. A thread of dishonesty. It didn’t seem like Зат [he] was used to lying, because something told Ной [he] that Аксиль [she] would have been sent to bother him no matter what. Despite Зат [he]’s words, the towering demon wasn’t intimidated in the slightest.

He didn’t see Ной [he] as a threat. Ной [he] just wasn’t sure if that was because Зат [he] was confident in his own abilities or Сиван [he]’s. If Сиван [he] really could just bring people back to life on a whim from wherever in the world he was…

A shiver ran down Ной [he]’s back.

That was power beyond even what Разлом [he] could offer. Far, far beyond it.

“No harm done,” Ной [he] said with a small shrug. “Well, not to me. Аксиль [she] might be on discount for the foreseeable future.”

“Discount?” Зат [he] and Зорин [he] asked at the same time.

“Half off,” Ной [he] replied, the corner of his lips quirking up. “But we can get right to the point. I don’t mind bargaining with you any more than I do with Аксиль [she] — and we were planning on finding you in the first place. I’m willing to sell the Rune you want.”

“Sell?” Зат [he]’s head tilted to the side.

“You don’t think I’m just going to give it to you, do you?”

“It is for Лорд [he] Сиван [he].”

“Who is more than capable of paying for it,” Ной [he] said with a flat smile. “Or is he so desperate for this rune that he has to resort to begging? Because that does not seem like the Лорд [he] Сиван [he] whom I have heard of.”

Ной [he] and Зат [he] watched each other for several long seconds. Then Зат [he] inclined his head.

“Perhaps we can come to an agreement.”

“Hold on,” Зорин [he] said, speaking up after his period of silence. The Commander’s features were thin with displeasure. “I will not interfere with Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s business, but I am not here on a personal task. I was sent here by Лорд [he] Белкус [he].”

Зат [he]’s head tilted to the side. “I see. I apologize for the interruption. Finish your conversation. I will wait.”

“We cannot conclude it here,” Зорин [he] said with a firm shake of his head. “Лорд [he] Белкус [he] has requested that I retrieve Паук [he] for an audience. It must be done immediately. He awaits our return.”

“You wish to make Лорд [he] Сиван [he] wait?” A dangerous note entered Зат [he]’s voice. “You ask the Лорд [he] of the City of Gold to sit and bide his time for his lessers?”

“Our Лорд [he]s have an accord,” Зорин [he] said tersely. Tension gripped the demon’s entire body, stiffening his back and tightening his fists.

Ной [he] didn’t blame him. A fight against an unkillable Rank 6 or 7 demon was difficult enough already. A fight when Зорин [he] hadn’t even brought any weapons along with him and preferred to handle tasks at a range was suicide.

A smarter demon probably would have pulled back on the spot.

But Зорин [he] was not a smarter demon. He was a single-minded demon. One who accomplished his task and let no distraction or deviation stand in his path.

“We will not take long,” Зат [he] said.

“Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s concept of time is renowned for being poor,” Зорин [he] said. He shook his head. “I will complete my task. This is Лорд [he] Белкус [he]’ city. The meeting must be held. Паук [he] has already accepted.”

Зат [he]’s helmeted head turned to Ной [he]. “You have?”

“My companions and I accepted the offer about a second before you popped up, actually. I feel like we’ve spent more time debating who gets to talk first than it would have actually taken to—”

“Ah. I see,” Зат [he] said. He tapped his fingers on the hilt of his sword, then inclined his head. “If you have already agreed, then it would go against Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s commands for me to insist otherwise. Then it is decided.”

Ной [he] and Зорин [he] looked at him.

“You will wait?” Зорин [he] asked.

“Wait? No. I will not wait,” Зат [he] replied. He grabbed the massive sword that he had planted in the ground and drew it free from the stone in a smooth motion. Ной [he] tensed, but the huge demon just slung the blade over his back and clapped his hands together. “His companions were invited to attend, yes?”

Oh, no. Please don’t. I do not need to get dragged into a geopolitical dick measuring contest between two Demon Лорд [he]s. Just sit here and watch the smoke in the sky or something.

Ной [he]’s telepathic thoughts never made it to Зат [he].

“Then this will be no issue. I can be counted among these companions,” Зат [he], the Harbinger of Сиван [he] and uncomfortable meeting atmospheres, said. “I will attend the audience.”

Chapter 543: Don'T Even Think About It

Зат [he]’s offer worked.

To say Ной [he] was surprised would have been an understatement. For some reason, he’d been convinced the demons would have jumped into some massive argument that eventually devolved into a city-wide brawl.

Instead, Зорин [he] just shrugged and nodded his assent.

And that was how Ной [he], half wondering if he’d somehow failed to wake up from a dream, found himself strolling through the streets of Трэдон [he] with Белкус [he]’ commander, the Harbinger of Сиван [he], a Rank 3 Knowledge Demon, and a masked future-seeing child that was most certainly not actually a child.

Ной [he] was still trying to figure out exactly how things had ended up going this way when the universe decided that they hadn’t quite added enough oddities to the group. Something soft and as immovable as a boulder lodged itself in front of his foot.

He tripped, stumbling and barely catching himself an instant before he fell flat on his face. Irritation played across Ной [he]’s face as he spun toward the source of his surprise attack, already more than aware of who the perpetrator was before he caught sight of them. There was only one being in the universe that consistently insisted on placing itself directly in front of his path when he wasn’t looking.

Маскот [he] sat curled in the center of the street, grooming his rear. He glanced up at Ной [he], the reddish-purple spines running along his back humming with faint energy, and tilted his head to the side as if to ask why the clumsy human hadn’t been watching their step.

“There is a creature,” Зорин [he] observed.

“Unfortunately, this one is my creature,” Ной [he] said, scooping Маскот [he] up and holding the cat out before him like a toddler with a full diaper. The cat extended, somehow nearly doubling in length as he stretched toward the ground. Маскот [he] glared at Ной [he]. Claws pushed free of his feet.

“I do not believe the creature is pleased with you,” Зат [he] said.

“The creature isn’t pleased with anyone,” Ной [he] said. He lifted Маскот [he] up to his shoulders. The cat clawed onto him, sticking to his shoulder like a prickly burr. He turned back to Зорин [he] and gestured impatiently. “Don’t mind the furball.”

“I have never seen a monster such as this one,” Зорин [he] said, studying Маскот [he] with undisguised curiosity. “Is it dangerous?”

“Eh. He’s done his best, but he hasn’t managed to kill me yet. Isn’t that right?” Ной [he] asked.

Маскот [he]’s head slowly turned so he could look into Ной [he]’s eyes, moving so slowly that he could practically hear stone grinding against stone in his mind.

“I do not think it is done trying to kill you,” Зат [he] said. “Your creature bears death on its breath.”

“Eh. It hasn’t killed anyone too important yet.” Ной [he] paused for a moment. “I think. I wouldn’t make bets on it. He’s a vindictive little shit. Isn’t that right buddy? You’re a vindictive little shit, aren’t you?”

He scratched at the side of Маскот [he]’s neck. The cat purred — and made absolutely no move to unlock its legs or remove its claws from his skin. Ной [he] glanced back to the other demons and gestured impatiently.

“You are bleeding,” Зорин [he] said.

“Thank you,” Ной [he] said. “I am aware. Can we get this on with? I’m a busy person. I have a schedule to keep.”

“Лорд [he] Белкус [he] may not allow the creature into his sanctum. He is a very neat demon,” Зорин [he] warned. “He despises mess of all sorts. If your creature does not behave itself, it may cause trouble.”

Ной [he] glanced at Маскот [he]. “He… he’s great at behaving himself. Very neat, too. Never once has he so much as made a single mes—”


The cat’s body contorted. Маскот [he] let out a hack, then spit a hairball out onto the ground. The group of demons stared at it. Зорин [he]’s eyes lifted back to Ной [he].

“Please don’t ask me to back you up on that,” Айлин [she] whispered, keeping his voice low enough that only Ной [he] could hear it. “It’s really difficult for me to lie.”

Ной [he] wasn’t sure if he wanted to laugh or sigh. He just inclined his head slightly, then cleared his throat. “Don’t worry about it. Fact of the matter is, I don’t think we could get rid of him if we wanted to. Маскот [he] goes where he pleases.”

Зорин [he] lifted a hand toward the cat. Йору [he]’ s head tilted to the side. She stiffened.

“Stop!” Йору [he] barked.

Зорин [he] froze. “What? I was going to remove the creature.”

“If you touch the furball, you die,” Йору [he] said flatly. “Hands off. Don’t even look in that thing’s direction. You can try touching it after we’ve met Белкус [he].”

“How do you know that?” Зат [he] asked, curiosity tinging his voice.

“I can touch the creature safely after we make it to Белкус [he]?” A confused frown creased Зорин [he]’s face. “What changes? Why does it matter when I touch it?”

“I just don’t care if you die after Паук [he] has been introduced,” Йору [he] said in a matter-of-fact tone.

Зорин [he]’s frown deepened. He studied Маскот [he] for a moment, then pulled his hand back and shook his head. The demon started back down the street, and the rest of them followed after him.

Blood trickled down Ной [he]’s arm and soaked into his sleeve as they continued. It wasn’t even like the wounds Маскот [he] made were that big. The cat just kept re-opening them. He was pretty sure the stupid thing had gotten fatter since they’d last met.

Probably eating something important.

Ной [he] wasn’t sure how he felt about Маскот [he] rocking up to a meeting at this level of importance, but it wasn’t like he could get rid of the cat even if he’d wanted to. Тим [he]e and time again had proved that the little monster generally had his best interests in mind, if only because it found them amusing. Trying to lose Маскот [he] would probably just end up in the cat returning with a bigger and badder monster chasing after it.

Fortunately, the rest of the roughly hour-long trip went smoothly. None of them spoke any more, though Зат [he]’s eyes lingered on Йору [he] more than once. The black-armored demon was definitely curious as to who she was — or perhaps Зат [he] had the same ability that Аксиль [she] did and Йору [he]’s canvas was really interesting.

Зорин [he] came to a stop at a black gate before an enormous, six-story tall cross between a mansion and a palace. Spires rose up into the air from the huge building, bulbous tops thinning to points like the barbs of a scorpion’s tail. It was made of black stone with twisting veins of wood running throughout it — an impressive display of wealth in the Damned Plains, where wood was hard to come by.

A guard by the gate pulled it open, granting them entry to the obsidian path that led up to a pair of massive, beautifully carved double doors. They depicted a scene from a battle that Ной [he] suspected he probably would have recognized had he known anything about the history of the Damned Plains.

“Come,” Зорин [he] said as he led them down the path. The doors slid open silently, each one pulled by a butler, and they stepped into a long hallway floored with soft, red carpet. There was no decoration of any sort on the walls or ceiling, which felt rather odd given the grandiose nature of the mansion.

What stood out the most to Ной [he] as he and the others followed Зорин [he] inside was just how clean everything was. There wasn’t so much as a speck of dust on the walls or in the corners of the doorways.

It was completely spotless.

Ной [he] sent a pointed glance at Маскот [he].

Don’t even think about it.

The cat just stared at him. Ной [he] repressed a sigh. There wasn’t any bargaining with Маскот [he]. He wasn’t sure why Маскот [he] had showed up in the first place, but the little monster only tended to appear when it got the feeling something amusing was about to happen.

And, as Ной [he] glanced around the group following Зорин [he] down the halls, he got the feeling he knew exactly why Маскот [he] had decided this might be an event worth witnessing.

The hallway opened up into a massive amphitheater-sized room. At its far end was a pair of huge double doors, strikingly similar to the ones at the building’s entrance. The massive room continued off to the side, its ceiling easily one hundred feet up in the air. It, like the rest of the mansion, was floored in red rug and had no further decoration aside from the carved doors. Even the walls and ceiling were plain.

“We have arrived,” Зорин [he] said as he came to a stop before the doors and braced his hands against them. “Лорд [he] Белкус [he] awaits you beyond these doors.”

Ной [he]’s eyes sharpened. No matter what company he’d inadvertently dragged with him, he couldn’t afford to let his guard down. Белкус [he] was a powerful demon — and a potential tool to dealing with Визен [he], if Ной [he] played his cards right.

Well, that or a powerful enemy. I did kind of steal the underground of his city from him and murder one of his subordinates. But that’s basically the equivalent of a demon ‘hello’, isn’t it?

Suppose we’re about to find out.

“Well then, we’d best get on with it,” Ной [he] said with a cold smile. “I’d hate to keep him waiting.”

Chapter 544: The Creature

Зорин [he] pressed against the huge wooden doors and they swung open soundlessly, revealing a massive room beyond.

Carpet stretched across the ground like a red sea. It was smooth and uniform, without any break or interruption from furniture or artwork. Torches flickered from their spots along the circular walls, casting the room in dancing shadows.

The ceiling loomed even higher in the air here than it had been in the rest of the mansion. Ной [he] wasn’t even sure what the purpose of such a massive room was — there were no chandeliers or displays of wealth hanging above to fill the space. It was just dark. As a matter of fact, there was only a single obstruction to the uniformity of the room.

At the very center of the room was a huge throne made of polished white bone. It was easily an entire story high, polished to the point where it shimmered in the firelight. Its back rose nearly two stores into the air, looming over even the enormous demon sitting upon it.

The demon could have been none other than Лорд [he] Белкус [he]. He sat at easily sixteen feet tall, clad in polished silver armor that caught the torchlight and sent it dancing in patterns across the carpet at his feet.

Белкус [he]’ skin was a bleached bone white, one that nearly matched the throne in which he sat. His eyes stuck out in sharp contrast, two pools of brilliant blue ice in a sea of snow. A pair of huge, ribbed wings jutted from his back and hung over the edges of the throne like a cape. He watched the group enter his throne room, his chin supported on the palm of a hand, fingers drumming against his square jaw.

Even from where Ной [he] stood, he could feel the power from the demon. It pressed into his domain and threatened to drive him to his knees. The sheer runic pressure rolling off Белкус [he] was almost as much as Ной [he] had felt from Джален [he].

That wouldn’t have been impressive if Белкус [he] was a human.

But Белкус [he] was not a human.

He was a demon — and demon magic was so tightly bound up within their physical forms that manifesting any external magic was magnitudes more difficult than it was for anyone else.

There was no doubt in Ной [he]’s mind. A strength like this could only come at Rank 7. No Rank 6 demon would be able to come anywhere close to Джален [he]’s power. For Белкус [he] to have a presence of this intensity meant that he was almost certainly one of the strongest demons he’d ever met.

Айлин [she] squirmed in place, his eyes darting around the room. He was doing a remarkable job of not looking completely terrified. A Rank 3 in the presence of a Rank 7 was like a fly in the face of a hurricane. The Knowledge Demon shifted to keep Ной [he] between himself and Белкус [he].

“Лорд [he],” Зорин [he] said, taking a step further into the room and inclining his head. “I have arrived for the audience that you requested.”

There were several long seconds of silence. Белкус [he]’ gaze bored into Ной [he]’s head, and Ной [he] returned the look. Neither of them budged an inch. Finally, Белкус [he] raised the hand that wasn’t occupied with his chin.

“That is apparent, Зорин [he],” Белкус [he] said. His tone, as smooth and flat as ice, echoed through the room like a roll of thunder. Despite its intensity, it was impossible to tell exactly what the massive demon was thinking. His features were a carefully controlled mask that allowed no emotion to slip through. “I am pleased that you were able to succeed. But I believe I told you to bring Паук [he].”

“I did,” Зорин [he] said. He looked back to Ной [he]. “This is Паук [he].”

Маскот [he] meowed.

“It is not Паук [he] that I question. It is the zoo that you brought along with him,” Белкус [he] ground out, a flicker of irritation passing through his icy eyes. He leaned forward in his throne and his features tightened. Белкус [he]’ stare bore straight into Зат [he]. “Who are the others, Зорин [he]? Look at them! Why have you invited these demons into my halls?”

“They are attendants, Лорд [he] Белкус [he],” Зорин [he] provided after a second of hesitation. “They are Паук [he]’s…”

Зорин [he] trailed off.

“Attendants?” Белкус [he] asked, disbelief tinging his words. “Attendants? Look at them, Зорин [he]! Do you really think those are attendants? Use your head, Commander. Who are they?”

Ной [he] kept his face impassive. He was fairly confident that Белкус [he] wouldn’t go back on his word — that would have made him look incredibly weak to every other demon in the city, and there had been more than enough witnesses of his promise to make sure Белкус [he] wouldn’t take it back.

That didn’t mean he trusted the Demon Лорд [he] to behave rationally, and Ной [he] had basically strolled into Белкус [he]’ house with the representative of a rival Лорд [he]. Белкус [he] absolutely knew who Зат [he] was. He’d asked Зорин [he] the most rhetorical question that had ever been uttered.

“What are you?” Зорин [he] whispered, looking back at Маскот [he].

Маскот [he] stared at him. Then, in an impressive display of acrobatics, he curled in on himself, still holding onto Ной [he]’s sleeve with his claws, and started grooming his ass again.

Зорин [he] waited for a moment longer, as if expecting Маскот [he] to actually answer him once he was finished. When it became apparent that Маскот [he] had no plans of finishing nor answering, the captain looked at Айлин [she].

“What are you?”

“A demon?”

“To Паук [he],” Зорин [he] said in a low hiss. “I know you’re a demon. What are you to Паук [he]?”

Айлин [she] flinched. His eyes darted to Белкус [he], who watched over them with impassive silence. It was like trying to wring information from a brick wall.


“I—”

“Quickly now,” Зорин [he] said. “Лорд [he] Белкус [he] does not like to be kept waiting. He wishes to know who you are to Паук [he].”

“I — uh, we’re not dating,” Айлин [she] stammered, stumbling over his own words in stress. It didn’t look like any actual thought had gone into them. His mouth was just moving, trying to get an answer out and pass the attention on to someone else. “Miss Мокси [she] is with him. I wouldn’t try to get involved in that. It’s way too dangerous, and he’s also a lot older than me. Not that much older, but older. A bit. Well, maybe a lot, but—”

“Айлин [she],” Ной [he] said.

“Yes, Паук [he]?”

“That’s enough.”

“Right. Sorry.” Айлин [she] adjusted his collar and swallowed heavily. “I’ve never met a Demon Лорд [he] before.”

“You never answered the question. You just said what you aren’t,

” Зорин [he] said. His voice rose slightly in annoyance. “Someone answer lord Белкус [he]’ question! He has requested an introduction!”

“Зорин [he], as much as I value your loyalty, I fear your comprehensive skills have not progressed in the hundreds of years we have known each other.” One of his hands clenched into a fist. “I am not a fool. Before us stands—”

“I am Зат [he],” Зат [he] proclaimed, his words tearing through the room like crashing thunder. “Harbinger of Сиван [he]. The Cracked Blade, the Breathless End.”

There was a long pause.

“I know who you are,” Белкус [he] ground out.

“Ah, I understand. You want to know my relation to Паук [he].” Зат [he] said, tapping the side of his helm. “I am also not dating him.”

Белкус [he]’ composure broke.

“I know you’re not dating Паук [he]!” Белкус [he] roared. “Why is the Breathless End in my castle? Сиван [he] did not announce your presence. This goes against our accord. Do you seek to challenge me?”

Зат [he] tilted his head to the side. “No. I would not waste my energy on such trivial things. I am here because Паук [he] and I have business. I am unwilling to stand around like a dog and wait for a meeting, so Зорин [he] was kind enough to invite me.”

“You broke a treaty because you did not wish to wait?”

“Yes,” Зат [he] said.

“I can respect that,” Белкус [he] said after a moment. His eyes narrowed. “Or, I would be able to, had you not brought a snake to my doorstep.”

Айлин [she] glanced around the room. His lips twisted into a frown and he leaned in to whisper to Ной [he]. “We didn’t invite Пиррена [she], did we?”

“I don’t think so,” Ной [he] replied.

“There is a snake?” Shock passed over Зорин [he]’s features and he spun toward Ной [he] and the others. “I will check them at once, Лорд [he] Белкус [he]. Allowing a lowly monster to enter your sanctum is a failing on my part. I will take full responsibility.”

“Not a literal snake,” Белкус [he] snapped, pinching the bridge of his nose between two fingers and sinking back into his chair. The bones jutting from its back caught on his shirt, but he didn’t seem to notice. He pointed at Йору [he]. “The Rising Moon, Зорин [he]. She is right there.”

Зорин [he] spun in the direction that Белкус [he] had pointed, fury covering his features. He spotted Йору [he] and froze.

Realization passed over his face.

“I see the issue, Лорд [he] Белкус [he],” Зорин [he] said solemnly. “I had similar difficulties. But this is Йору [he]. Not Йоку [she].”

Белкус [he] stared at them.

“You said the same name twice.”

“No. One of them is slightly different. Йору [he] has an ‘r’. Йоку [she] has a ‘k’. Subtle, but different. An easy mistake to make, Лорд [he] Белкус [he], I can assure you. I made it myself.”

“That is the Rising Moon,” Белкус [he] said flatly. “She has changed her name by one letter, Зорин [he].”

Зорин [he] turned back to Йоку [she], betrayal crossing over his features. “You lied to me?”

“No,” Йору [he] replied. “I have been called Йору [he].”

“Oh.” Зорин [he] returned his attention to Белкус [he]. “There you have it, Лорд [he] Белкус [he]. She did not lie.”

“Damnable Loyalty Demons,” Белкус [he] muttered, sinking even lower into his throne. “Have I ever told you that I would have had you executed had you not been so dedicated, Зорин [he]?”

“Three times this week, Лорд [he] Белкус [he].”

“Make it four.” Белкус [he] leaned forward, then rose from his throne. A shadow stretched out over the ground and passed over Ной [he] as the huge demon extended to his full height. The movement was joined by a slow, ripping tear as the throne clung to the back of the Demon Лорд [he]’s shirt.

Белкус [he] was so strong that he didn’t even seem to notice until he’d completely risen, leaving the back half of his garb attached to the jutting pieces of the throne behind him. The front of his shirt fluttered down to land at his feet, leaving him completely bare chested.

“You lost your shirt, Лорд [he] Белкус [he].”

“Thank you, Зорин [he],” Белкус [he] said, glancing down at the scrap. “I am aware. However, I find myself considerably more concerned with the Rank 7 Demon seeking my throne that you have led into my halls.”

“I have no interest in your throne,” Зат [he] said.

“Not you,” Белкус [he] said.

Зорин [he] and Зат [he] both turned toward Ной [he] at the exact same time.

“The creature?” Зорин [he] asked.

“I suspected it to be strange,” Зат [he] said. “It bears no presence, yet its canvas is… uniquely agonizing. I would avoid irritating it.”

“Not the gods-damned cat either,” Белкус [he] said. “Йору [he]. Йоку [she]. Whatever she wishes to be named — she is still the Rising Moon. I am aware of her machinations. I have seen what she has accomplished, using misdirection to manipulate people into obeying her desires. She seeks control of Трэдон [he].”

“You do?” Зорин [he] asked Йору [he].

“Why would you want to be a Лорд [he]?” Зат [he] asked with a befuddled frown. “It’s a horrible bore.”

“I am traveling with Паук [he]. He invited me,” Йору [he] said.

Ной [he]’s eye twitched.

Way to throw me under the bus, Йору [he]. I suppose my guess that you were physically older than you appeared was right, but what’s this they’re saying about ruling the city? Is that what your goal is?

“She has expressed no desire in ruling the city to me,” Ной [he] said. “I have no interest for ruling Трэдон [he]. I’ve just liberated some of your resources. You weren’t using them.”

Белкус [he] pressed his lips thin. “I suspect you and I will be able to find common ground, Паук [he]. But I called you here for one purpose — to ensure that you not fall into the grasp of the Rising Moon. She is a controller, one that will seek to set us against each other. She may not speak lies, but her truths are concealed in shadow. Do not trust her.”

Ной [he] studied Йору [he]. He didn’t doubt a word of what Белкус [he] said — but he wasn’t about to give up his advantage. If Белкус [he] was scared of Йору [he], then this was actually a benefit. He could leverage that.

“I am here only because Паук [he] invited me,” Йору [he] said. “This was the path he desired. It may lead to another in the future, but I am not here to fight you today.”

Белкус [he] blinked. “You… aren’t? You bring an army of powerful warriors, then claim not to seek to fight me?”

“Yes.”

“Then what is your greatest desire?” Белкус [he] asked, watching Йору [he] warily. “I know how you work, Rising Moon. Answer me plainly, or one of us will die today — and you are not powerful enough to fight me in direct combat.”

“My greatest desire is far too complex to answer plainly.”

“Your greatest desire that is possible to be accomplished during the duration of this meeting,” Белкус [he] said. “What is it that you would like to do most right now?”

Йору [he] tilted her head to the side. For several long seconds, everyone waited on her answer. Then she turned toward Ной [he].

“I would like to pet the cat.”
