Chapter 545: The Rising Moon

“The cat,” Белкус [he] repeated. His features were unreadable once more, blue eyes boring into Йору [he] like drills. “The Rising Moon’s greatest desire at this moment is to pet the cat?”

“Not a desire I would mirror, personally,” Зат [he] observed. “I’d sooner slit my own throat.”

“Is this a cypher?” Белкус [he] asked, tilting his head to the side. “A code to cover your true goals? I know of your distaste to outright lying, but I refuse to believe that the Rising Moon’s greatest goal is to spend time with a mere monster.”

“It is not,” Йору [he] replied. “I want to pet the cat.”

“Why?” Белкус [he] asked.

Ной [he] wanted to know the same thing. He still didn’t have the complete story, but Йору [he] — or Йоку [she] — was clearly a powerful demon. A very powerful one. He’d suspected that she’d been strong, of course, but he hadn’t quite realized the extent of it. If Йору [he] was really telling the truth, Ной [he] had absolutely no idea why her current greatest desire was to pet Маскот [he].

“Because, when I weighed the probabilities of the potential futures, the one in which I win is the one in which I desired to pet the cat,” Йору [he] replied simply.

“You imply that petting this… creature will somehow achieve the world you desire?” Зат [he] asked incredulously. “How would that possibly work?”

Белкус [he] looked a lot less doubtful than the other Rank 7 demon. He studied Маскот [he] intensely for several long seconds without saying a word. Ной [he] could practically see the thoughts going through his eyes.

The Demon Лорд [he] respected Йору [he]’s strength. They were enemies, and he was more than aware of what she could accomplish. But Йору [he] couldn’t flat out control the future. She could only see the most probable paths and take actions to achieve a path that had the highest likelihood of being the one she wanted.

That wasn’t absolute strength, and Йору [he] hadn’t refuted Белкус [he]’ words when he’d insinuated that he was stronger than she was. There was probably a very good chance that Белкус [he] would win in a direct fight. But at the same time, he had to realize that Йору [he] wouldn’t have come here if she didn’t think she had a way to win.

Part of Ной [he] wondered if the mind games that came from trying to fight a demon that could peer into potential futures were worse than actually fighting them. He’d be second guessing every single action he made. Wondering if every single coincidence was actually intentional — and a lot of them probably were.

“It is the future that I witnessed,” Йору [he] replied with a shrug. Her hand drifted up to the mask covering her features. “I will say no more. Do you plan on breaking your word, Белкус [he]? Will you attack Паук [he]’s entourage?”

Айлин [she] stiffened at Ной [he]’s side. Зорин [he] tensed and Зат [he] watched on, expression still hidden behind his helm. Out of everyone in the room, he was the least invested in its outcome. He was just along for the ride.

“You wish to trap me into fighting against Паук [he],” Белкус [he] said. “To force my hand and destabilize Трэдон [he] even further. Your games will not work on me, Rising Moon.”

Йору [he]’s head tilted to the side — a particularly threatening gesture considering what it meant.

“Do you struggle against the setting sun, Лорд [he] Белкус [he]? Do you attempt to hold it aloft in the sky to keep the night at bay?”

“Speaking in riddle will do nothing to alter my course,” Белкус [he] said. He raised a hand. Points pressed up against the inside of his arm. Blood dripped down his hand as bone pressed up, slicing through his skin and winding out like bleached vines. The bone intertwined, tightening into a shaft, rising up and blooming like a bloody flower to form a huge hammer head. Spiked growths emerged from all over the weapon, largely concentrated at its striking surface.

“Do you know why I do not lie?” Йору [he] asked, not even slightly perturbed by the gruesome display before her. “It is because I have no need to. I already know you will do exactly as I desire. The wielder of a pawn is not present on the board.”

Белкус [he]’ grip tightened around the bone hammer in his hands. The skin on the back of Ной [he]’s back prickled. He wished he could reach for his runes. He wasn’t sure what he could do directly against Белкус [he], but it would have been nice to at least be able to try.

It was easy to forget just how powerful Йору [he]’s magic was. If she’d peered into the future and already weighed the possibilities, then it was very possible that attacking here was exactly what Йору [he] wanted Белкус [he] to do.


Or perhaps this was what stopped Белкус [he] from attacking. Then again, Йору [he]’s words could have been meant to cause him to think that, which would therefore make him attack. Just the mere thought of it made Ной [he]’s skull pound and amplified his lingering headache.

Cold prickled against Ной [he]’s skin. It rolled from Йору [he]’s body in waves, bearing the weight of immense magic just barely allowed to slip through. Йору [he] may have been emotionally undeveloped, but her Runes were in control now.

She was not just a child.

She was not just a demon.

She was a calculated future.

One that had built itself. An uncomfortable thought passed through his mind. Йору [he] had said that the wielder of a pawn wasn’t present on the board. She hadn’t been lying — but Ной [he] was pretty sure she hadn’t actually been referring to herself as the wielder in her analogy.

Йору [he] was speaking about her own Master Rune.

“Do it, then,” Белкус [he] ground out. His hand snapped open and the bone growth emerging from his palm collapsed inward, slithering back into his body and flicking blood across the floor until it had completely retreated. His hand tightened into a fist. “Take the cat, Йору [he]. Pet it. Elsewhere. You are not welcome in my palace.”

I’m not so sure Маскот [he] is going to—

Claws dug into Ной [he]’s shoulder. Маскот [he] leapt off his shoulder, dropping to the ground and padding over to Йору [he]. The small demon bent, scooping the cat up, and placed him on top of her head like a fluffy hat.

“I enjoyed our meeting, Лорд [he] Белкус [he],” Йору [he] said, turning on her heel and striding toward the huge double doors at the end of the room. “Anticipate the next one. I will be there at the end.”

She slipped out the doors and vanished from sight. The throne room was silent for several long seconds. Then Белкус [he] lowered himself back into his throne, heaving a long sigh.

“Infuriating demon. I rue the day she entered Трэдон [he]. It has caused me nothing but trouble. We are all tools in her eyes. She has no respect for anything. No readable desires. The Rising Moon is a corruption that I cannot cut free without severing my own neck — and that is why I called you here, Паук [he].”

“Her goals and mine are not one,” Ной [he] said, still surprised that Маскот [he] had headed off with Йору [he] of his own volition. “Though I will not take a stance against her. We are not enemies at this time.”

“I did not expect you to,” Белкус [he] said with a bark of laughter. “She does not have enemies.

I have enemies. The Rising Moon has nothing but herself and those who lose their souls in her gaze. So, tell me, Паук [he]. You are not a friend to the Rising Moon. You are certainly not a friend to me. Then who are you? Why are you in my city? At first, I thought you to be a minor demon seeking to slice power for themselves. That no longer seems likely. You keep strange company — and the rumors surrounding you are stranger still.”

“You’re looking for a simple answer to a very complicated question,” Ной [he] said. “I do not believe I can give it to you.”

“A demon who slips past even the reaches of death,” Белкус [he] intoned, placing his arms on the rests of his throne and leaning forward. “And he uses that immense power to cause discord in my city for no apparent reason. Йору [he] believes that you somehow aid her plan. Сиван [he] sends his men to wait on you, one of which you kill. I trust one as unique as you will find a way to answer my question, Паук [he]. If not, while you not be enemies with the Rising Moon, you will be enemies with me.”

Ной [he] met Белкус [he]’ gaze without flinching. It certainly helped that the demon didn’t have a true domain. If he did, Ной [he] doubted he would have been able to remain standing. Even the power rolling off the Demon all the way from his throne was enough to push Ной [he]’s resilience to his limits.

“A simple answer will answer nothing, but if that is what you seek — I am a teacher.”

“A teacher?” Белкус [he] repeated, small frown playing across his lips. “What is it that you teach? And what is it that leads a teacher to Трэдон [he] and causes them to attempt to interfere with its goings?”

I was originally planning to try and build an army from the dregs of Белкус [he]’ society and then leverage that somewhere else to try and build a search party for Визен [he]… but maybe there’s a way around that. Could I get Белкус [he] interested in Визен [he] somehow? I don’t know if I want to reveal that Визен [he] has a key that allows for free passage into the mortal realm, but I need to get my hands on that damn artifact so I can get back to my students — and so Тим [he] can get the transport cannon back up and running properly.

“I teach whatever needs to be taught,” Ной [he] replied. “And I come in pursuit of a man.”

“One in Трэдон [he]?” Белкус [he] asked, amusement flickering across his features. “That is why you uprooted my gangs? I had heard you formed them into an information network. Was that purely to locate a single demon? You are not one for half-measures.”

“To locate a single person,” Ной [he] said, inclining his head. “And, once I have found him, I will leave.”

“To go to such lengths… he stole from you?”

“You could say that.”

“How curious. You are an enigma, Паук [he],” Белкус [he] said, drumming his fingers against the bones that made up his throne. “I still find myself bereft of the true measure of your power. You carry yourself like an ancient demon but bear the power of a young one. The rumors would make you a new power rising up to challenge me for control of Трэдон [he] and yet you show no interest in the city. Every action you have taken thus far, the moves of an invading force, were nothing more than a gambit to find a single man. Something about you is deeply unsettling.”

“Thank you,” Ной [he] said.

“It was not a compliment,” Белкус [he] replied. “Tell me the name of the one whom you seek. I am curious to know what kind of demon could be worth such effort that he could bring you from your hiding.”

Hook set. Now I just have to figure out what the hell kind of bait a Demon like Белкус [he] is going to bite.

“The one I seek is called Визен [he].”

And, for the briefest of seconds, something shifted in the Demon Лорд [he]’s features.

Recognition.

Белкус [he] knew who Визен [he] was.

Chapter 546: The Hunter

Визен [he]’s staff rang against bloodstained golden brick, punctuating his steps as he stepped over the wrung corpses in his path.

The smell of blood hung in the air like a vulture. Aside from the sound of his staff and the squelch of blood beneath his feet, the hall he strode through was silent. The demons who hadn’t yet died had already realized that to make noise was to seek death.

He moved past the body of a wiry demon, the blades that had once emerged from their body shattered and broken like fragments of glass. A flicker of power still burned within their chest, so little that it was barely worth noting. The demon held his breath, freezing in place in hope of being overlooked.

Визен [he] did not overlook him — but he stepped past the demon nonetheless. He wasn’t worth the energy that it would take to put down. There were more important tasks at hand, and he was already behind schedule.

A part of him had once been convinced that finding the City of Gold would have been the most difficult step of his plan. Getting into the Damned Plains alone was an immensely difficult task that had taken years upon years of preparation and research. Now that he had made it, everything should have been simple.

But, as it turned out, actually finding the one he sought was even harder still.

The City of Gold wasn’t just enormous. A single word couldn’t do it proper justice, but momentous may have been more apt.

Cities were large. Bastions, such as Арбитраж [he], were huge. But the City of Gold — it couldn’t even properly be considered a city. A world may have been more accurate. The huge, glistening city aboveground was deceptive. It burrowed deep into the incomprehensibly large turtle that it rested upon, each layer another city entirely on its own.

Even with his information network stretched across the city, finding anything useful was like digging needles from hay. Барба [she] and the others were scattered off in every and all directions, and all their combined efforts had barely gathered a few scraps of useful information.

Визен [he] had descended through three layers of the city already. In each one, no demon had been able to give him a good idea of just how deep it went. Finding information here was like wringing water from a rock. Possible, but exceedingly annoying.

His walk carried him up to a metal door embedded into the stone. There was no apparent way to open it beyond an embossed handprint in its center. Imbued runes covered the door’s surface, running out from the indent and traveling throughout its surface. A thin spike emerged from the center of the indent.

The corner of Визен [he]’s lip curled down. Blood magic — one that was meant to keep anyone but the bloodline of the person who owned the door out of the room beyond. It only took him a moment to determine that the Наполнения [he] continued off the edges of the door, vanishing where it touched the walls.

The entire hall is Runed, and a second layer of stone was built over the first to block the runes from view. Likely trapped as well. It seems my target is quite paranoid.

Good.

Perhaps this one will be of use.

Визен [he] lifted his hand and brought it up to the metal door, letting the pads of his fingers gently brush across its surface before they came to a rest.

Metal screeched in what could have only been described as agony. A horrendous shriek filled the air as the door crumpled in on itself like a piece of scrap paper. Наполнения [he] sputtered and flared, magic crackling and dancing through the air, but the metal had been destroyed so quickly that none of it had a chance to activate. The door folded itself into a crushed up ball, then clanged to the ground at Визен [he]’s feet.

Beyond it was a large meeting hall. A long table in the center of the room was lined with twelve seats on each side. It was covered with a tablecloth of extravagant white silk trimmed with gold. Plates of food and magical ingredients were strewn across its surface and spilled over the expensive cloth.

Demons sat around the table in expensive wooden chairs, frozen mid-meal with stunned looks of disbelief on their faces. Not a single one could have cared less about all of their men that Визен [he] had just killed. They’d been dining while he slaughtered their families.

At the far end of the table knelt a ten-foot demon with brilliant blue skin and a ropey

X shaped scar across the center of his face. Curled, blackened teeth protruded from between gray lips, so large that the demon’s mouth couldn’t even close properly.

His target.

Миктал [he], was it? I never do remember their names. There are so many, and they start to blend together after a while. What was the last one’s name? Arthur? What an odd name for a demon.

No matter.

Визен [he]’s domain swept the room in a split instant.

In that split instant, he judged every single demon before him. A mixture of Rank 4 and 5 demons, with the strongest one in the room being the blue-skinned Terror Demon at Rank 7. This wasn’t the first Rank 7 he’d killed in the City of Gold, but a large portion of him hoped it would be his last. He didn’t care much for wasting time.

“I seek Сиван [he],” Визен [he] said, before any of the demons could even fully finish processing his arrival. “Tell me where he is.”

“How did you get in here?” a large demon demanded, rising from his chair and reaching for his sword. He had little magic and couldn’t have been higher than Rank 4. “How—”

Визен [he]’s hand clawed into a fist.

The demon’s head collapsed in on itself. It popped like a cherry tomato. Blood splattered across his clothes and the table around him. Swaying, the body pitched back, catching on his chair, and both tumbled to the ground with a resounding crash.

“That,” Визен [he] said, “Was not an answer. Tell me where Сиван [he] is. This is not a request. It is an order.”

He batted the crumpled ball of metal that had once been a door to the side with his staff, then stepped further into the room. The demons leapt from their chairs, stumbling to put distance between themselves and him.

“We aren’t with Сиван [he],” another demon stammered. “This is the Screaming Saber’s tunnel system. We have nothing to do with Сиван [he].”

“You live in the City of Gold, and a merchant was kind enough to inform me that you have had dealings with Сиван [he] before,” Визен [he] said dispassionately. “I do not wish to waste time or energy. Give me the answers I seek and I will leave.”


“How do you know that?” Миктал [he] asked, lounging back in his chair. “And who are you to demand anything from us?”

Unlike the rest of the demons, the Rank 7 didn’t look concerned about Визен [he]’s intrusion. He was a Rank 7 demon — not many of those tended to be particularly timid. The confidence was only partially earned.

Миктал [he]’s runic pressure put him at the lower ends of Rank 7. He wasn’t strong enough to find a Walking City and become a proper Лорд [he], but he still commanded enough power to justify leading some weaker demons. Living within the City of Gold was generally safe — so long as one didn’t go against Сиван [he].

“I had a brief conversation with a merchant,” Визен [he] said. His quiet words echoed through the room. “He was kind enough to point me in your direction — along with that of a few of your compatriots. None of them were useful. I have high hopes that things will be different here.”

Миктал [he]’s expression flickered for a moment. “You’re the one that’s been attacking the other Dens?”

“Attacking is a strong word,” Визен [he] said. “It almost carries the implication that there was a fight. There was no such thing.”

A high-Rank 5 demon lurched into motion. The air around them popped and they blurred, streaks of wind peeling off their body as they shot toward Визен [he], claws reaching to rip out his throat.

Blood splattered across Визен [he]’s face.

It was the only thing that reached him.

A corpse rolled to a stop at his feet. Its head was gone, turned into fine, bloody mist. Both of its arms had shared the same fate. Визен [he] reached into a pocket and procured a handkerchief, wiping the specs of blood from his features.

“What I am doing,” Визен [he] said, folding the cloth square back up and returning it to its former place, “is hunting .”

Миктал [he] rose to his feet, but there was more unease in the demon’s posture than there had been a moment before. He couldn’t see the invisible magic swirling in the air around Визен [he]. He couldn’t feel the tendrils of Density magic that swirled around Визен [he], waiting to grind anything that drew his attention into tiny particles.

“I’ve never spoken to Сиван [he],” Миктал [he] said. “Whoever told you that information is wrong. It might be a rival. Arthon, maybe? He and I are enemies. He’d have sent you in my direction to—”

Визен [he] snapped his fingers. “Arthon. Not Arthur. Yes, I remember now.”

Миктал [he] stared at Визен [he]. “What?”

“I’ve already killed him,” Визен [he] said. “He put up a pathetic fight — but I really shouldn’t have expected much more. The entirety of your kind disgust me. To be a slave to your own magic… pathetic.”

It took Миктал [he] an instant to process Визен [he]’s words. The Terror Demon’s eyes widened in realization — and Визен [he] gave him a tiny fragment of credit for that. He’d figured things out faster than the past few annoyances had.

“You’re a human,” Миктал [he] said.

“One whose patience has long since run thin. Where is Сиван [he]?”

“I don’t know,” Миктал [he] said, setting his jaw. “Лорд [he] Сиван [he] does not share his location with the likes of us. There are many Rank 7s that serve under him. But I know someone who could help you!”

Визен [he]’s head tilted to the side. He could always pick through Миктал [he]’s skull with his Mind runes, but that would have been a bother. Using them on a Rank 7 would be exceedingly difficult and unlikely to yield fruitful results.

“Speak,” Визен [he] said.

“There’s an information Broker. Tixen,” Миктал [he] said hurriedly. “He’s the leader of the Eyeless Den. They’re not too far from here — I know he’s met Сиван [he] before. He would know where you can meet Лорд [he] Сиван [he].”

The corner of Визен [he]’s lips twitched. “Not a friend of yours, I presume?”

“We have our differences,” Миктал [he] said, words terse. The other demons in the room pressed back, trying to stay as far away from Визен [he] as possible. Миктал [he]’s body language didn’t seem nearly as reserved. He was good at controlling his fear — which, given the desire he feasted on — was not unsurprising. Миктал [he] swallowed. “He is a wily one, but if you’re powerful enough to break into my Den, you can find him easily.”

“I see,” Визен [he] said. “And you believe his information to be true? To be worth your lives?”

Миктал [he] swallowed again, then gave Визен [he] a sharp nod. “Yes. It is what you seek, is it not? That seems like a fair trade to me. I can offer nothing more.”

Визен [he] inclined his head. “Should your information be true, it is. Where is—”

“He’s lying!” A young voice split through the air.

Everyone, Визен [he] included, turned as one.

Standing in the corpse-covered hall was a tiny demon girl, a dagger clutched in her hands. Tremors of fear gripped her entire body and her features were pale — but still she stood. Still, she spoke.

It was the girl that he’d spared after dealing with a few pests.

What is she doing here? Her power is so weak my Domain barely even registered her. I thought she was one of the dying demons.

Визен [he]’s eyes snapped back to Миктал [he]. For the briefest of instants, there was a flash of recognition on the large demon’s features. Then he flicked a hand in dismissal.

“A street rat somehow broke in. Someone kill the brat,” Миктал [he] said, an air of weary exasperation in his words that didn’t match the instant of unease behind his eyes.

“I’m not lying!” The girl insisted, her eyes going wide as she took a step back. “He’s lying to you! Миктал [he] and Tixen are rival Dens. They’ve both met Сиван [he] before, and Миктал [he] knows who I am. I was part of his Den!”

“Shut up, street rat,” Миктал [he] said with a bark of laughter. “I can assure you, I’ve never seen this brat in my life. There’s no reason to—”

The rest of Миктал [he]’s words were replaced by a wet wheeze. The Terror Demon’s eyes went wide and his head rolled forward, looking down at the foot-wide hole in the center of his chest where his heart had been.

His gaze lifted up to Визен [he], whose hand was extended toward him. In his other palm, a key rested, humming with dull red energy. Gray smoke swirled around Визен [he]’s fingertips, pouring out from Миктал [he] and into his hand.

Disbelief washed over the demon’s face. His lips parted — and he pitched forward, crashing to the ground.

Визен [he] flicked his hand. The gray smoke exploded through the room, tearing through the ranks of the demons within it like a plague. They barely even got a chance to scream. Within instants, every single one of them had died, the gray smoke having ripped the energy clean from their souls and ferried it back to Визен [he].

And only then did Визен [he] turn. He looked down at the small demon girl. She trembled, locked in place and not daring to so much as look away.

“You followed me,” Визен [he] said, his words flat. “Why?”

“Y—you killed Миктал [he],” the girl stammered, her eyes going as wide as saucers. “Just like that. You killed a Rank 7 demon with one attack.”

“He wasted my time,” Визен [he] said. “And you seem to have saved it. That, I appreciate. I will not kill you for that reason. But why did you choose to follow me?”

“You didn’t want it .” The demoness swallowed heavily. “And if you didn’t want it, you didn’t need to kill me. You were also killing everyone that did want it.”

“

It ?” Визен [he]’s head tilted to the side. At this point, his curiosity was piqued. His domain washed over the girl as he scanned her. Buried deep within her chest, where her heart should have been, was a tiny core of magic. It was so small that it was almost not worth mentioning, but it was out of place enough to draw his attention when he searched. “An artifact in your heart?”

The girl’s eyes widened. “You do know about it.”

It seems I was spared a wasted trip back here to kill these fools for lying to me by a petty demon squabble over some useless tool. How amusing.

“I see,” Визен [he] said. “You said that you knew of this Tixen, yes?”

The girl gave him a jerky nod. “Yes.”

“Take me to his Den.”

Her eyes widened. “Me?”

“You are following me already,” Визен [he] said. “If you use me for protection, then you will earn your keep by leading me to one who can take me to Сиван [he]. I trust that is a fair trade?”

The demon inclined her head hurriedly. “Yes. Very fair.”

Визен [he]’s smile did not reach his eyes. He gestured to the girl, and she hurriedly turned to set off down the blood-splattered tunnel with Визен [he] following in her wake.

He was so close to his goal that he could almost taste it. Years and years of planning, only a few fools and some meagre days away from fruition. All for one meeting. For one chance.

He would not fail. He could not fail.

I am coming, love. You will not have to wait much longer.

Chapter 547: Cockroaches

“You know Визен [he],” Ной [he] said.

It wasn’t a question.

The perfectly clean throne room was silent for a long second. Белкус [he] sat in his towering throne made of bone, features unreadable once more, his massive form looming over them. He was a patch of white in a sea of red. Белкус [he] looked down on the group of demons and Ной [he].

“I do not know him,” Белкус [he] allowed. “But I do know of him. What relation do you have to him?”

“I came here in pursuit of him,” Ной [he] replied. It wasn’t technically a complete lie. He had come in pursuit. He’d followed Визен [he] into the Damned Plains. It just hadn’t been entirely intentional. “Once I have a way to deal with him, I have nothing more I seek from this area. You will not find me in Трэдон [he] again.”

“Your answers have done more to pique my curiosity than if you had said nothing.” Белкус [he] leaned forward, his features tightening. “What relation do you have with Визен [he], Паук [he]?”

“Enemies,” Ной [he] replied without an instant of hesitation. “I seek his life.”

Белкус [he]’ posture relaxed. The massive demon let himself lean back in his chair, then grimaced as the sharp bone dug into his back and shifted his position once more. He interlaced his fingers together.

“Good. Then perhaps you are correct,” Белкус [he] allowed. “There may be something we can aid each other with. I want you gone from my city, Паук [he]. I do not want you in a location in which you can aid the Rising Moon in her plots against me.”

“I think I would be amiable to that,” Ной [he] said. He wasn’t so sure that would actually do anything to Йору [he]’s plans. After all, if she was actually using her powers, she’d have already calculated that this was the most likely outcome of the meeting.

She’d chosen to leave, which meant that she didn’t think that the results of what happened here would hurt her. Either that or she was actually holding off on using her magic. There was a small — a very small — chance that Йору [he] actually didn’t know what Белкус [he] was offering.

Ной [he] wasn’t about to bet on it.

If she’s let things get to this point… I get the feeling Белкус [he] might not be fighting what he thinks. Her idea of victory and Белкус [he]’ might be completely different from each other. Either that or I just have absolutely no idea what she’s gunning at. Maybe a mixture of the two.

“Then I will give you what you desire,” Белкус [he] said. “Визен [he] resides within the Golden City.”

That name again. The place near the Black Reaches?

…the one with Сиван [he]?

“He does?” Зат [he] asked, his armored head tilting to the side in surprise. “That’s a surprise. I didn’t expect him to be so direct. It looked like he was planning on taking a far more roundabout manner. He must be moving quickly.”

Ной [he] looked back at Зат [he]. “You’re aware of him as well?”

“I am. Визен [he] sent a challenge to Лорд [he] Сиван [he] some short time ago,” Зат [he] replied with an offhand shrug. “But Сиван [he] does not accept duels. He has no reason to. There is no demon that resides within the Damned Plains that could ever hope to defeat him. Pointless challenges are nothing but a waste of time to him — but I must say, Визен [he] had a rather persuasive way of sending word.”

“And what way was that?” Ной [he] asked.

“He sent a Demon Лорд [he],” Белкус [he] said, a dangerous edge forming in his voice.

“Skolas,” Зат [he] said with a nod. Some of the easygoing air that had enveloped the intimidating demon slipped away as a cold aura seeped out from him and prickled against Ной [he]’s skin. “And Skolas delivered quite a message. I must say, Паук [he], I now find myself more interested in you. What history do you have with Визен [he]?”

“A lot,” Ной [he] replied. He forced himself to avoid swallowing. Визен [he] had managed to use his Mind Runes on a Rank 7 Demon Лорд [he]. If he got to more of them… the fight was just over. His whole plan had been to build an army that could match Визен [he]’s. If Визен [he] had the Demon Лорд [he]s from the Damned Plains under his thumb, the fight would be impossible. “More than I care to go through now. Are you telling me that Визен [he] is controlling a Demon Лорд [he]?”

“Not exactly,” Зат [he] replied. He studied Ной [he]’s expression for a moment. “It would be easier to show you. Do I have your permission, Лорд [he] Белкус [he]? I would not draw on my power in your castle without it.”

“I did not take you for a polite one,” Белкус [he] said dryly.

“It is not politeness. I would inconvenience Лорд [he] Сиван [he] if I were to kill you.”


Белкус [he] let out a snort, but there was more than a little displeasure in it. He waved a hand irritably. “Use your power. The sanctity of this meeting has already been violated enough. It may as well be put down like a sick animal.”

“With pleasure,” Зат [he] said. He clapped his hands together, and an echo resounded through the room. Ной [he]’s ears pulsed. A low hum filled the air as the huge demon pulled his gauntleted hands apart.

Strands of black lightning crackled between his palms. Smoke poured out from the churning energy and spilled across the floor in a wave. It rolled past Ной [he], chilling as it passed by his skin. The dark smoke climbed up the walls and rose over their heads, forming a rumbling storm above them.

Shapes started to form in the smoke. Walls of twisting, misty black magic rose to stand in the center of the room. Figures took shape in the darkness, initially nothing more than faint blobs, but quickly gaining detail.

Pressure roared around Ной [he] — but it didn’t crush him. It was if the power came from every direction, competing against itself and preventing it from becoming oppressive. That was no coincidence.

The demon was holding his power back.

Ной [he]’s hair stood on end. A demon powerful enough to use this much external magic at this level would have been powerful enough.

The scene continued to paint itself. Detail appeared in the walls to the point where he could make out the minor imperfections of the pitch black wall across from him. It was like someone had taken a video in black and white, then tossed Ной [he] right into its center.

A shadow passed over his head.

Ной [he] turned, then stepped back.

A fifteen-foot tall demon clad in destroyed armor loomed above him. He was made up of shadows and devoid of any color but black and gray, but the detail was so intricate that Ной [he] could have plucked a hair from his chin had he been so inclined.

The shadow passed right through Ной [he]. His figure parted into trails of smoke as he passed through Ной [he], then reformed just beyond him.

“Сиван [he]!” the figure roared, his words tearing through the room and making Ной [he] flinch. He hadn’t expected the shadow to actually speak .

A demon peered over the top of the towering wall. His face was a flat pool of shadow, devoid of any defining features or shapes. He moved as if he were yelling something back, but no sound emerged from him.

“I was the Demon known as Skolas,” the massive Demon Лорд [he] continued, entirely unperturbed by whatever the guard had called down to him. His voice echoed through the room like roaring thunder. The demon pounded a fist against his destroyed armor. “I bear a Challenge for you, Лорд [he] of Death, on behalf of Визен [he] the Lifeweaver. I seek your life. Meet me in battle, or I will rip your city apart brick by brick.”

Skolas raised a hand, then plunged it straight into his chest with a crunch and a squelch. Shadows splattered out like blood as the Demon Лорд [he] ripped his own heart clean free of his ribcage.

Rivers of darkness poured down his chest and arm. The Demon Лорд [he] lifted the heart into the air. He held it aloft like a torch, staring defiantly up at the city, and spoke no more.

“He died standing,” Зат [he] provided. He flicked his hand and the shadows vanished, pouring back into his body. “Визен [he] made quite a statement. This is far from the first time a Demon Лорд [he] has been killed. It’s not even the most brutal way it’s happened… but I have to say, a death like that leaves quite an impression.”

“Is Сиван [he] going to take him up on the challenge?” Ной [he] asked.

“No idea,” Зат [he] replied with a shrug. “Сиван [he] does not keep me partial to all his goings. I doubt it. He rarely accepts challenges. Killing a single Rank 7 does not make you strong enough to draw his attention… but if Визен [he] keeps at it, well, it’s possible. I do believe he’s currently attempting to draw Сиван [he]’s attention by making his way through the City of Gold and killing some of the Denlords that reside beneath it.”

“He is powerful,” Белкус [he] said. “And you possess a way to stop Визен [he], Паук [he]?”

No.

“Yes.”

I figure killing him should do the trick. Pulling it off might be the hard part.

Why is Визен [he] able to mow through demons like this? He was strong back in the mortal realm… but not like this. Could it have something to do with Mind Runes and how demons have linked souls and bodies? Or is it something else entirely?

“Either way, sending him over to Сиван [he] will get him out of your city,” Зат [he] said cheerfully. “Seems like a win to me.”

“You just want to end the audience so you can complete your task,” Белкус [he] said, his eyes narrowing.

“Correct,” Зат [he] said. “This has been interesting, but my time is not infinite. I have things to do — and kill.”

Hopefully he’s not doing both to the same thing.

“It seems I have a solution worked out before me. One that has laid itself out quite well,” Белкус [he] said, his eyes narrowing slightly. “Perhaps too well. You will leave Трэдон [he]?”

Ной [he] almost nodded, but caught himself right before he could. A thought struck him and he had to fight a smile off before it could take form.

Maybe I can get a bit more out of this.

“Eventually, yes. I can’t defeat him as I am now. I need more power. Once I have amassed the strength I need, I will seek Визен [he] out. This meeting with Сиван [he] is for unrelated reasons. He wants something I possess.”

Белкус [he]’ lips thinned. “And if I were to want you to leave immediately?”

“Well, I wouldn’t be opposed to it,” Ной [he] said slowly, as if he were turning the idea over in his mouth. “I am not an unreasonable man. You want me gone. I want Визен [he] dead. Perhaps we could meet in the middle. I will not say why, but my method to defeating Визен [he] involves a large number of Runes. Specifically, Mind Runes. I had been planning to amass them over some time, but if you were willing to expedite the process…”

“You are attempting to blackmail me with the promise of your own departure,” Белкус [he] said. He did not sound impressed.

“Correct,” Ной [he] said.

“Were you not with Йору [he], I would have crushed you on the spot… but I fear that may be exactly what she desires.”

Ной [he] shrugged. “Maybe. Getting crushed would be mildly annoying, but death holds no grasp on me. I would be back, Белкус [he]. I always come back.”

“Death demons,” Белкус [he] growled, the words rumbling in his chest like a curse. He squinted at Ной [he]. The corner of his lips curled up in something between a smile and a sneer. “Cockroaches, more like. Very well. Perhaps we can come to an agreement.”

Chapter 548: Vile Creature

Around an hour later, Ной [he] walked out of Белкус [he]’ estate with a large scroll tucked under his arm and a smug grin plastered across his face. The rest of the group, aside from Зорин [he], who had remained in the throne room, walked at his sides.

Йору [he] had rejoined them as they’d left the palace. Маскот [he] sat perched upon her head like a bird in a nest. He watched Ной [he] with lazy eyes, idly kneading Йору [he]’s hair as she ferried him. The small demon didn’t seem to mind.

“What is it that you believe several Rank 5 Mind Runes are going to do for you?” Зат [he] asked as they walked. The clank of his heavy sabatons punctuated his words as they headed down the streets of Трэдон [he] in the direction of the Сеть [organization]’s camp.

“A lot of things,” Ной [he] replied. “I have a number of runes myself, and I prefer to create all the runes I use. It lets me minimize the number of mistakes present in them.”

“Meticulous,” Зат [he] said with a small nod. “Лорд [he] Сиван [he] is of the same mind. It takes a great amount of time and wealth to progress in this way. Not something that most demons are capable of doing when the currency that buys life is power.”

That was a thinly veiled question. Зат [he] still wasn’t sure just how strong Ной [he] was. Even though he had no domain, Зат [he] could probably tell that Ной [he] wasn’t a Rank 6 or 7 demon — but he also knew Ной [he] had come back after dying and stood on near-equal footing with Белкус [he].

When something looked like a duck and quacked like a duck… it was probably a Demon Лорд [he].

“Meticulous is the only way to go about rune advancement,” Ной [he] said with a small shrug. “Anything else will do nothing but hinder you. There is too much power at stake to go bumbling around.”

“Very true,” Зат [he] said. He turned his head to glance back at Айлин [she] and Йору [he]. “Are all of your choices equally as intentional?”

“Some of them.”

They passed by a group of demons chatting in the street. The demons’ conversation ground to a halt as they spotted Зат [he]’s massive form lumbering through the street alongside Ной [he]. Their mouths dropped open and they stared in stunned disbelief, not so much as moving a muscle until they’d been left behind in the street.

“So,” Зат [he] said. “What exactly is your plan to deal with Визен [he]? Or was that just an excuse to fleece Белкус [he] of a few unneeded runes?”

“Do you really think I need to wheedle my way into getting some Rank 5 Runes?” Ной [he] asked, sending a flat look in Зат [he]’s direction. “Is your opinion of me that low?”

Зат [he] let out a low chuckle. “Fair enough. You do have a plan, then?”

Oh, not in the slightest. I was totally fleecing him. I don’t have the faintest goddamn idea of what I’m going to do about Визен [he]. The Mind Runes are just to give me a way to make sure he can’t somehow control me.

“What do you think?” Ной [he] arched an eyebrow.

“I would assume one who had been chasing Визен [he] for any amount of time would be aware of some weakness,” Зат [he] allowed with a curt nod of his head. “I will look forward to seeing just what it is, then. I suspect I shall enjoy watching the fight.”

“Watching?” Ной [he] blinked. Визен [he] was actively attacking the City of Gold. Even if Лорд [he] Сиван [he] wasn’t planning to interfere directly, it felt like one of the Demon Лорд [he]’s subordinates should have been more than willing to step in to stop the nuisance. “You mean you aren’t going to—”

“Help?” Зат [he] finished with a chuckle. “No. Of course not. Unless Лорд [he] Сиван [he] requests it, I will not. My powers are a little too destructive to be unleashed within Лорд [he] Сиван [he]’s city. Death is effective at great many things, but avoiding collateral damage is not one of them.”

Ной [he] glanced at Зат [he] out of the corners of his eyes. “You can’t control it?”

“I see you have not come against Death Runes in a direct conflict,” Зат [he] said. Some of the amusement left his tone. “We wield Death, Паук [he]. Not injury. Not pain. Death. Were I to unleash my Runes to fight someone that is powerful enough to take down other Rank 7 demons, then the damage to the city would be astronomical.”

Ной [he] nodded thoughtfully, but his mind was already shifting gears to a different thought.

If his runes lack that much control… it’s not because they’re so powerful that he can’t even fart without killing everyone in a ten mile radius. It’s because they’re poorly made. His combinations are bad.

I suppose it makes sense. Without Разлом [he], the chances of a Rune being bad increase exponentially with every rank. By the time you hit Rank 7, especially in the Damned Plains, if your runes aren’t completely screwed up, it would have to be a miracle. It looks like even Лорд [he] Сиван [he] has some limits to his power.

“I see,” Ной [he] said. “Is the same true for Сиван [he]? Is he unable to fight because the mere flick of his finger would mistakenly destroy the city?”

“No,” Зат [he] replied. A note of reverence entered his tone and he shook his head. “Лорд [he] Сиван [he] is different. His power is incomprehensible. He could do anything he wished, but he does not interfere in situations like this. He would only act if the city itself were at risk. As it is now, Визен [he] has done nothing but kill a few demons.”


“I do suppose some deaths wouldn’t mean much to the Лорд [he] of Death,” Ной [he] drawled.

“No,” Зат [he] agreed. “They would not.”

The rest of their trip back to the camp went largely in silence. Айлин [she] was still far too stressed to say much of anything, while Йору [he] was occupied with the cat that was in the process of kneading her hair into a frazzled mess.

Ной [he] was relieved to find that the camp was the same as how he had left it when they got back. Even though there would have been no point, there had been a part of him that feared some idiot would have tried to attack while he was gone.

They’d certainly gathered no shortage of stares on their way back. Hushed murmurs had followed them like a wake. News of Зат [he]’s arrival and subsequent meeting with Паук [he] and Белкус [he] had definitely spread through Трэдон [he], and the Сеть [organization]’s camp wasn’t exempt from that — especially with the information network that Айлин [she] had set up.

“Look sharp,” Ной [he] said in a hushed whisper to Айлин [she]. “You just had a meeting with a Demon Лорд [he]. Act like it.”

“I barely did anything other than mess up,” Айлин [she] whispered back.

“They don’t know that.”

The Knowledge Demon glanced to the side. His lips pressed thin and his back straightened. He set his shoulders and plastered a flat expression over his face, as if he couldn’t be bothered with all of the attention they were getting.

Ной [he] gave him a slight nod.

The odd group came to a stop in the center of camp, across from Ной [he] and Мокси [she]’s tent. Зат [he] strode right up to the hole in the ground where he’d planted his sword earlier that day, drew the huge weapon from his back, and slid it back into the ground like he was re-sheathing Excalibur.

“It is time for our business,” Зат [he] said. “Лорд [he] Сиван [he] awaits. You will deliver the Rune he has requested.”

“We will trade for the Rune he has requested,” Ной [he] corrected. He glanced down at the scroll under his arm, then back to Зат [he]. “I’m sure he wouldn’t mind waiting an hour or two, right? I’d like to get this handled.”

Зат [he] frowned. “You would keep me waiting? You would keep Лорд [he] Сиван [he] waiting?”

“Yes,” Ной [he] replied. “I can ask Мокси [she] to make you a nice chair. They’re really comfortable. Very soft.”

Зат [he] stared at Ной [he].

“Perhaps you should catch up with your subordinate before you leave?” Айлин [she] suggested from behind Ной [he], his voice wavering slightly. “She’s been waiting for you.”

Зат [he] tilted his head to the side. He was silent for a second, then blew out a short sigh. The demon reached up to the huge helm on his head and pulled it off in a smooth motion.

To Ной [he]’s surprise, Зат [he] looked absolutely nothing like what he had been expecting. For that matter, he wasn’t completely sure what he’d been expecting.

The Rank 7 Demon’s face was fairly handsome. He had high cheekbones and deep, green eyes. A long, black ponytail hung from the back of his head and disappeared into the back of his armor.

“Very well,” Зат [he] said. “I will wait.”

Almost as if on cue, Мокси [she] poked her head out of the tent. She’d definitely been listening in and waiting for a moment to make her appearance. Relief played over her features as she spotted everyone and saw that they had returned safely.

Her gaze caught on Маскот [he] for a moment, but she didn’t let it linger. She stepped fully out of the tent.

“The meeting went well, I trust?” Мокси [she] asked.

“It was enlightening,” Ной [he] said. He glanced at the scroll under his arm. “And profitable.”

“Of course it was.” The corner of Мокси [she]’s mouth quirked upward. “Зат [he] said he needed a chair? It might take me a moment to get something big enough for him, and it’s going to have to be outside. Is that fine?”

“It will be sufficient,” Зат [he] said.

“Great,” Ной [he] said, starting for the tent. “I’ll grab Аксиль [she] for you so the two of you can properly catch up. Please make sure she doesn’t go doing anything rude. It would be quite annoying to have to kill her again.”

Зат [he] inclined his head. And, as Мокси [she] fished a large piece of meat from her bag to start forming a chair, Ной [he] headed into the tent.

Ли [she] was perched on top of his grimoire, staring at Аксиль [she] with uncomfortably wide eyes. It was like a cat observing a trapped bird.

Аксиль [she], unfortunately for her, was still half-sized. The demoness’ eyes were squeezed shut in an attempt to look anywhere other than either Ли [she] or the grimoire. At this point, Ной [he] wasn’t sure which she was avoiding.

“Oh! You’re back!” Ли [she] exclaimed. Her eyes didn’t so much as flick away from their target.

“I am,” Ной [he] confirmed. “It went well. Are you… doing something?”

“I am watching Аксиль [she].”

“I see,” Ной [he] said. He drew up to Ли [she] and gently pulled the grimoire out from under her. She shifted to the side, letting him reclaim the book and not letting her gaze budge. Ной [he] tapped the grimoire with a finger. “Keep these runes.”

Ной [he] held the scroll out. A tongue of paper shot out in a split second, grabbing the scroll and yanking it into the book’s huge pages. There was a soft crunch. Then there was nothing.

Аксиль [she] let out a whimper.

“Good book,” Ной [he] told the grimoire, slinging it over his shoulder by the strap and giving it a pat. “I’ll get you something to eat soon enough.”

“What about me?” Ли [she] asked.

“You too,” Ной [he] said, ruffling her hair. He walked over to Аксиль [she] and lifted her by the back of her shirt like an unruly animal. “Come on. Your boss is here to collect you.”

Аксиль [she] didn’t even respond. She just hung limp in Ной [he]’s hands, swaying like a pinata.

“Ли [she], did something happen to Аксиль [she]?” Ной [he] asked, shaking the tiny demon slightly.

“No. I was watching her.”

“So you said,” Ной [he] said. He shrugged. “Oh well. Let’s go. Thanks for keeping an eye on things.”

“Yup!” Ли [she] fell in line behind Ной [he] and the two of them headed back out of the tent and into the main square of the Сеть [organization]’s camp.

In the brief time that Ной [he] had been inside the tent, Мокси [she] had already formed Зат [he]’s chair. It was really more of a giant beanbag-shaped bush. Зат [he] didn’t seem to mind. He’d lowered himself into it and was splayed out, a delighted grin on his face.

“Do you offer landscaping services?” Зат [he] was asking Мокси [she]. “I have never sat upon such a soft plant.”

“Not at the moment, but I wouldn’t be opposed to the idea,” Мокси [she] replied thoughtfully. “I didn’t think it was that impressive.”

“You downplay your abilities,” Зат [he] said through a contented sigh. “This is fantastic. You could make a killing. This is the most comfortable thing I have ever sat in.”

“Huh.” Мокси [she] scratched her chin. “Interesting.”

“I’ve returned with your subordinate,” Ной [he] said when it became clear that their conversation had reached a lull. He held Аксиль [she] up.

“I’m otherwise occupied,” Зат [he] said, glancing down at Ной [he] with one eye “Just toss her—”

His words ground to a halt. The huge demon’s head snapped up. Disgust and horror playing across Зат [he]’s features as he stared down at Ной [he].

“What manner of vile creature is that?”

Chapter 549: An Idea

“This would be your subordinate,” Ной [he] replied, hoisting Аксиль [she] slightly. “She’s a bit smaller than normal, but if you take a close look, you’ll see who it is. Ah — we did confiscate her axe. Spoils of war.”

“Not her,” Зат [he] snapped. “That is obviously Аксиль [she]. I am referring to…”

The demon’s words trailed off. His head tilted to the side. For several seconds, he said nothing. Then he arched an eyebrow and crossed his arms in front of his chest. Зат [he] tapped a foot on the ground, nodding slightly as if agreeing with someone.

Ной [he] and Мокси [she] exchanged a glance.

“What’s up with him?” Мокси [she] whispered.

“I was hoping you were going to have the answer to that,” Ной [he] replied. He rotated Аксиль [she] around so he could look at her face. The demoness’ eyes were still screwed shut and her face was twisted into a grimace. Ной [he] shook her slightly. “Oi. Wake up.”

“What is it?” Аксиль [she] asked, making absolutely no move to open her eyes.

“What’s your boss doing?” Ной [he] asked, glancing over Аксиль [she]’s head at Зат [he]. The demon now muttering something under his breath, staring at an empty patch of air in the middle of the Сеть [organization]’s camp.

Every single interaction he had with Сиван [he]’s men made Ной [he] suspect that there was something seriously wrong with all of their heads. Then again, there had to be something wrong with anybody that voluntarily decided that they wanted to serve the literal embodiment of death.

“He’s talking,” Аксиль [she] said.

Ah, yes. I couldn’t tell that bit.

“You disgust me,” Зат [he] informed the empty patch of air.

Аксиль [she] nodded in agreement, even though she’d yet to open her eyes.

“To whom?” Ной [he] asked in exasperation.

Аксиль [she] screwed her lips up. She crossed her arms in front of her chest and said nothing else. Ной [he] blew out a sigh. He glanced over his shoulder at Ли [she], who gave him a small shrug. She didn’t seem to have the slightest idea of what was going on either.

“I will not be doing that,” Зат [he] informed the air.

Ной [he] coughed into a fist. Зат [he] ignored him.

“That’s hardly a good reason,” Зат [he] said, now shaking his head. The disgust on his features had turned to mild curiosity, but there was still an edge in his posture that made it clear he was uncomfortable.

If anything, that was what started to ring alarm bells in Ной [he]’s own head.

A Rank 7 demon, one who served under Сиван [he], the literal Лорд [he] of Death in the Damned Plains, was uncomfortable.

Зат [he] had looked uncomfortable when he’d seen Ной [he] come back out of the tent with Аксиль [she], but he’d made it clear that the source of his disgust wasn’t the fact that Аксиль [she] shrinkflation-ed herself.

The only other change that had occurred in the span of Ной [he]’s departure and return from the tent…

His eyes lifted to the book on his back. Аксиль [she] had reacted horribly to it because of all the squished up demon corpses that made it up. But Зат [he] was actively talking to something. Unless he’d gone completely insane —

“Don’t even try to eat me,” Зат [he] said, his eyes sharpening in anger. “I swear to Лорд [he] Сиван [he], if you bring those disgusting paws of yours anywhere near me, I am going to rip you into shreds and stuff you into the nearest outhouse.”

Okay. Decent chance he’s insane. Pretty sure he has been from the start. But this is a bit much. There has to be more to it than this. Is there really something so special about my grimoire that it’s tripping up every single one of Сиван [he]’s group that sees it?

“Is it the book?” Ной [he] asked Аксиль [she].

Аксиль [she] didn’t respond. It looked like she’d decided that her conversation was done for the day. Ной [he]’s lips pressed thin. Whatever the book was, she was more scared of it than she was of him. Maybe it was something about the actual corpses that made the book up.

Do I have the equivalent of a bunch of religious figures stuffed in there? Maybe it’s like I’m accidentally defacing their culture. That would definitely be rude. Can’t imagine it would cause someone to start speaking to the air, though.

Does that mean there’s actually something there? Something only Зат [he] and Аксиль [she] can see?


Ной [he] squinted in the direction that Зат [he] was looking at. He extended his domain and drew on his tremorsenses, trying to see if there was anything there that was somehow evading his eyes.

Nothing he tried found anything. As far as Ной [he] could tell, Зат [he] was just speaking to nothing. But that couldn’t be the case. Зат [he] wasn’t insane in that way. There was something there, and he couldn’t make it out.

“I will not,” Зат [he] said. “Find your own runes, leech.”

Something that wants runes?

Could be the book. Could also be literally any other living creature in the history of the Damned Plains. Every single sentient thing in existence wants more runes. Gods, this is annoying.

“Who are you talking to?” Ной [he] asked. “You haven’t forgotten me already, have you?”

“Go do whatever it was you needed to do,” Зат [he] said, not so much as glancing in his direction. “You requested time to work with your new runes. I am giving it to you. Return once you have finished.”

Then he went right back to speaking to the air.

Ной [he] would have been offended if he hadn’t just gotten exactly what he’d wanted. He hesitated for a second longer, held in place by curiosity and unease. He did not like the idea of the book being… well, more than a book.

This wasn’t something he could just ignore — not in the long term, at least. For the time being, it was actually perfectly in his advantage to let whatever was going on play out. If it kept Зат [he] distracted, it would buy him time to let the effects of his headache fade away while figuring out what kind of Mind Rune he’d create. He had to take advantage of every second he had.

“Watch over me while I work?” Ной [he] whispered to Мокси [she].

She nodded.

“I’ll stay here and keep an eye on things outside,” Ли [she] volunteered. She stared intently at the space where Зат [he]’s attention was focused. “I’m trying to see who he’s talking to.”

“Let me know if you have any luck,” Ной [he] said. He passed Аксиль [she] off to Ли [she], who hoisted the other demon like she was a sack of potatoes. Аксиль [she] didn’t say a word. She didn’t even seem to register that she’d been moved.

Ной [he] and Мокси [she] headed back into their tent. Half of Ной [he] expected Зат [he] to suddenly get mad that the book had vanished from his sight, but he didn’t so much as address Ной [he]’s departure. He continued talking to the air as if nothing had changed.

If anything, that just confused Ной [he] even more.

Is it even the book he’s interested in?

He shook his head and pulled the grimoire off his back as he made his way across the tent and over to Мокси [she]’s bed of vines. He sat down on it, flipping the huge book open in his lap.

“I hope Зат [he] is very distracted, because it’s going to be a few more hours before my magic comes back,” Ной [he] said as Мокси [she] took seat in the viney chair across from him.

She rocked the chair onto its back legs and crossed her arms in front of her chest, giving him a slight nod.

“Sounds like a good opportunity to tell me what happened in Белкус [he]’ estate,” Мокси [she] asked. “I’m thoroughly lost.”

“Yeah. That and plan for what Rune I’m going to make. Just help me think of some excuses to stall Зат [he] out if he decides he wants to leave soon. But, with regard to the estate… let’s see. It’s kind of a long story, but I’ll try to summarize it. Йору [he] is also Йоку [she]. Our guess about her being older than we thought is right. She’s a Rank 7 demon. One that’s apparently in some huge conflict with Белкус [he]. Also, Маскот [he] showed up.”

“Gathered that bit,” Мокси [she] said dryly. “What did he break?”

“Thus far, nothing. Give him time. I figure he’ll get around to it eventually. But… more importantly, we’ve found Визен [he].”

Мокси [she]’s eyes widened slightly. “You have? Where?”

“He’s apparently trying to annoy Сиван [he] into fighting him,” Ной [he] replied with a shrug. “I’ve got no idea why — or how. He’s somehow taking out Rank 7 demons. He even killed a Demon Лорд [he]. I think that key has to be helping him against demons somehow. Визен [he] was strong, but he’s not defeating Rank 7 enemies strong.”

“The artifact should only form a connection between planes,” Мокси [she] said, her forehead creasing in a frown. “I read about it pretty thoroughly. I can’t really see how it would be making Визен [he] stronger. I’ll think over it and see if I can recall anything that he could be abusing.”

“It could also be his Mind Runes,” Ной [he] said. “With how connected Demons are to their runes…”

“Yeah.” Мокси [she]’s features were grim. “That could be it. I take it that’s why you were talking about Mind Runes when you got back?”

“Белкус [he] gave ‘em to me. He’s surprisingly reasonable. The only thing he wanted in return is for us to get lost and not partner with Йору [he] against him.” Ной [he] flipped through the pages of the grimoire. They were all blank, which was a surprise. The book was normally more responsive than this. He tapped its pages. “Give me those Mind Runes, please. I need them.”

A second passed. Then the pages abruptly flipped, as if the grimoire had just remembered what it was, and turned to a page covered with Rank 5 Mind Runes. Мокси [she] arched an eyebrow in question; Ной [he] shrugged in response.

His book was weird enough normally. He was just happy it wasn’t trying to draw anything inappropriate.

Мокси [she] looked down at the grimoire, examining the runes in its pages, then lifted her gaze back to Ной [he] as she tilted her head to the side. She didn’t quite look suspicious, but there was a note of discomfort in her expression.

“What are you going for with these? Mind Runes… they’re not really, well…”

“I know,” Ной [he] said. His features darkened. “I have no plans of becoming Визен [he]. I’m not using the vile shit he does, but I need a way to keep him from using those powers on me. I figure the best way to do that is with more Mind Runes.”

Мокси [she] nodded. Her expression softened slightly. There was no immense relief in her features, but only because it seemed she’d never actually held enough doubt about his actions to feel relieved over avoiding them.

“You’ve got a disaster in mind that somehow relates to the mind, then?”

Ной [he]’s expression tightened. His thoughts drifted back. To the line — to the agony that had ground down on his mind like a mill, ripping away memories and past until only the monotony remained. The mental torture of being able to do nothing but take steps in an endless walk, future unknown and past slipping away.

“Yeah,” Ной [he] replied in a grim tone, placing his hand on the surface of the grimoire. “I think I’ve got an idea.”
