Chapter 556: Planned

“You do not know for what you ask,” Сиван [he] said. Unlike every other sound, Сиван [he]’s words did not vanish into the endless void surrounding the obsidian platform they stood on. Every one of his words echoed through the air, commanding attention with the presence of a king. “You seek to steal from those whose power eclipses yours like a mountain to a grain of sand.”

Визен [he]’s lips pulled back in a cold smile. Sticky, who stood several feet behind him, swallowed nervously as Визен [he] met Сиван [he]’s gaze without flinching.

“The more I am told that something is impossible to attain, the more convinced I become that it isn’t. There is a manner in which a soul can be returned to life. I know it. I have seen records of it, spawned from the existence of your own followers.”

“There is a difference between preventing a soul from passing on and retrieving one from what waits beyond,” Сиван [he] said, crossing his arms behind his back. “They are not one and the same.”

“But it is possible. Not once have you said otherwise,” Визен [he] said. The key in his hand hummed with crimson energy and he pointed it at the Demon Лорд [he]. “It would be a trivial matter for you to open the path. I would prefer it that way, but I have brought sufficient power to challenge even you.”

“Yes,” Сиван [he] said, his head tilting to the side in observation. “I know of the artifact you bear. The power does not belong to you.”

“It does not,” Визен [he] agreed. “But I wield it, nonetheless. It seems our paths were already set. If you will not do what I ask, then I will take the power to do it myself. Step back, girl.”

Sticky glanced nervously from Визен [he] to Сиван [he]. She swayed slightly in place, then pressed a hand to her chest and winced. She slunk back a step, moving closer to the edge of the platform and farther from the rising tension in the air, and sank down, hugging her knees to her chest.

The air around Визен [he]’s key thrummed. Runic pressure exploded around Визен [he] with such force that the obsidian beneath him shattered. Large fragments of it snapped up around him and were lifted into the air, taking flight as they were caught up in a building maelstrom of power surrounding the mage.

Claws of crimson light cut through the air and crawled into Визен [he]’s arm, biting deep into his flesh. His veins burned with energy and Визен [he]’s teeth ground in pain.

Сиван [he] made no move to stop Визен [he]. The demon watched on in complete silence, his expression no different than it had been moments ago. It was impossible to tell if he was even watching Визен [he].

Wind howled through the void and Визен [he] lifted into the air. The inside of his body lit with brilliant flashes of red lightning that ripped out through his skin and filled the air with their buzzing energy.

Pressure roiled off Визен [he]. Loud cracks rang out as more of the obsidian beneath him shattered, but the power was entirely contained within a ten-foot sphere around Визен [he], not so much as getting close to touching Sticky or Сиван [he].

Визен [he] lifted a hand. Molten red whips of energy lashed across the ground and twisted around him like the tendrils of a burning eldritch being.

“You do not fear my magic,” Визен [he] said. His words boomed through the void and bolts of red lightning slipped free from his tongue and curled up around the sides of his face like smoke as he talked.

“No,” Сиван [he] replied. “I do not fear you, Woven Man. There is only one thing in life that I fear, and it is not you.”

“Then you are a fool.”

Визен [he] brought his hands down. Red tendrils shot forward.

They seemed to carve through reality itself. Jagged cracks raced out around them, sending brilliant white light spilling in from a void beyond.

Сиван [he] lifted a hand.

The energy vanished before it could reach him. Reality mended itself with a pop, returning to the same state it had been instants before.

“To you, I am Death,” Сиван [he] said softly. “Are you certain you wish to do this? Snuffing one lesser than me does not bring any satisfaction. It is a waste of what could be a worthy end.”

“There is no worthier end than this,” Визен [he] replied, his voice as cold as ice. “And you have not witnessed the full extent of my strength.”

“Then show me, Woven Man. Meet your end.”

Визен [he]’s hand lifted to his neck. He pulled a small necklace free from within his shirt. It was studded with six emeralds. Inky energy twisted within four of them, but the final two were dull and lifeless.


The necklace shuddered in the storm of red lightning surrounding Визен [he]. His hand tightened around the gems that still glowed, and ironclad determination etched itself into his expression.

“Weave. Give me my power,” Визен [he] breathed. “All of it. I release my bindings.”

A deep thrum echoed out. Визен [he] lifted his left hand, and four taut gray strands pulsing with immense energy materialized around his fingers. They stretched off into the void and vanished out of sight.

The air around Визен [he] shattered. White light spilled out from growing white cracks, illuminating him in its ghastly glow like an avenging angel descended from the heavens.

Black fire ignited along Визен [he]’s palm. It roared forth in a tsunami, swallowing half of the platform and crashing down over Сиван [he] in a split instant. The fire twisted away and vanished, drawn into the Archdemon’s palm, but Визен [he] was far from done.

The air split as gray lightning screamed down and slammed onto Сиван [he]’s shoulders. Сиван [he] staggered, a flicker of surprise passing over his features. Smoke curled from his suit, which had been slightly charred.

Red whips of light shot out from Визен [he]’s palms, leaving even more cracks in reality in their wake.

More black fire erupted from Визен [he] and rose hundreds of feet into the air before him, completely blotting out the void and roaring toward Сиван [he].

Сиван [he] flicked his hand. A wave of nothingness passed out from his fingers, demolishing every strand of Визен [he]’s power it touched, but Визен [he] didn’t so much as flinch. Even more magic poured out from him.

A sickly, pulsating beam of black light erupted from his palms and slammed into Сиван [he]’s chest, sending the demon sliding back across the platform. The Archdemon’s expression tightened and his hands clenched down on the power, shattering it.

Even as it vanished into motes of light fading into the air, more lightning crashed down on Сиван [he] from above. He staggered and Визен [he] sent his tendrils shooting out for Сиван [he] once more.

Сиван [he] snapped his fingers.

A pulse ripped out from his body and washed over the entire platform. Визен [he]’s magic vanished the instant his power touched it, but this time, not all of the white cracks in reality mended itself.

“You are a powerful mortal,” Сиван [he] said. “Stronger than any I have fought before. But you cannot defeat me. This does not have to end this way. Our other guests will arrive soon.”

“I am far greater than the sum of my parts,” Визен [he] replied. Blood trickled down from his nose and ran across his lips. “And I am no longer a patient man.”

His grip on the key tightened. Red light pulsed around him and poured out from his skin, lighting his body from within. The air around him shattered. Huge swathes of it evaporated, transformed to white portals that lead to nothing. Визен [he] clenched his free hand.

A gray strand emerged from within the void. It wound around Визен [he]’s wrist, digging into his skin. The world around Визен [he] thrummed.

His head flew back as a roar of pain and defiance ripped from his lips. Cracks raced across his skin and peeled back like he was a broken clay pot. White energy pushed out from within the gaps and poured from his eyes and mouth.

Сиван [he] extended his hand toward Визен [he].

Black smoke poured forth from the sky and formed into a massive palm the size of a three-story building. It crashed down on Визен [he], who thrust his own palm upward. White energy ignited at his palm.

A brilliant crack split through the air as their magic connected. There was a brilliant flash — and Сиван [he]’s magic evaporated.

Power roared all around Визен [he] and tore through the stage around him, but it continued to keep a wide berth from Sticky, who watched on in awe, eyes wide, lips parted in disbelief.

A mortal was holding his own against the Лорд [he] of Death.

“You wield powers that are too great for you to control,” Сиван [he] said. “You grow closer to my domain, Woven Man. It is not too late for you to spend what you have left.”

“I have already spent it,” Визен [he] snarled. He brought his hands together with a loud clap. Jagged white lightning tore out through the air from between his palms, swirls of black flame and gray energy twisting within it.

The strange magic slammed into Сиван [he] and launched the Archdemon off his feet with an earthshaking explosion. There was only a brief instant for Сиван [he] to look surprised before he vanished into the void.

Sticky’s mouth dropped fully open. “You did it?”

“No,” Визен [he] replied. “Not yet. He still does not view me as an opponent.”

“Because you are not one.” Сиван [he]’s voice echoed through the darkness. Streamers of black smoke poured out from the darkness and onto the stage. The Demon Лорд [he]’s body reformed. Smoke curled off his chest, and a tiny white crack glistened on his stomach where Визен [he]’s magic had hit him. “And you do not attempt to be one. You have only utilized a small portion of your strength, even as your body crumbles.”

“I’m saving the rest for something more important,” Визен [he] replied. “Fight me, Сиван [he]. In true. Let me witness your true strength, Лорд [he] of Death. Mortal I may be, but you will not be able to defeat me with anything less.”

Сиван [he] didn’t get a chance to answer.

A thrum ran through the air.

Bright purple magic shimmered, drawing a line in the air. It expanded outward to form a large, rectangular portal. A towering demon clad in black armor stepped through the portal, a massive, chipped sword slung over his shoulder.

Визен [he]’s eyes widened in disbelief.

Not at the demon, but at who came after him.

A woman with bright red hair and green robes.

A demon girl whose hands ended in slight claws — claws that Визен [he] had felt wrapped around his own wrist just a short time ago, back in the mortal realm.

And, after them, a man with a huge grimoire slung over his shoulder.

Визен [he]’s skin prickled. It was the other wielder of Weave.

Impossible. Сиван [he] planned for this?

“Ah,” Сиван [he] said with a satisfied smile. “It seems the rest of our guests have arrived.

Now we can get started.”

Chapter 557: Spent

Возрождение [she] interlaced her fingers and leaned forward. Сиван [he]’s domain stretched out before her and Декрас [he], splayed across a shimmering screen of magical energy. She reached out blindly and felt around at her side for a few moments before her fingers found a bowl.

The Богиня [she] of Reincarnation dug a piece of chocolate out from within it, not letting her eyes so much as break from the screen for an instant. Декрас [he]’ fingers brushed against hers as he claimed some food for himself. His own vision was similarly affixed to the scene playing out before them.

Тим [he]e had slowed to an absolute crawl around them. The figures within the Damned Plains moved so slowly that they might as well have been frozen in ice. It wasn’t that time had stopped moving — Возрождение [she] and Декрас [he] were simply processing it at a speed so heightened that the flow had functionally crawled to a stop for them.

“What is Сиван [he] doing?” Возрождение [she] asked through a mouthful of chocolate. “Why did he gather them all in the same room? Is he trying to kill both Ной [he] and Визен [he]?”

“He’s never had that much ambition before,” Декрас [he] said. “I’m surprised he’s even bothered meeting with either of them. He could have kept Визен [he] wandering through those halls for a thousand years if he’d wanted to. Those наполнение [he]s are quite old, and that little thief is nowhere near powerful enough to shatter them and have strength left to fight.”

“I wouldn’t underestimate Визен [he].” Возрождение [she]’s features tightened in displeasure. “I don’t like that mortal. He has harnessed things that humans should not harvest. Why am I unsurprised that it was with your rune that he pulled it off? Isn’t any part of you redeemable?”

“It’s hardly my fault. I can’t be held responsible for what little rats do with the scraps of my passing. He dug a fragment of my rune from an altar the Apostles managed to contact me through. At least I didn’t let a mortal take a bite directly out of my powers. Now that would be embarrassing.”

Возрождение [she] would have glared at Декрас [he] if that didn’t mean pulling her attention away from the slow-moving scene before her.

“And whose fault is it that a mortal was able to get magic like that in the first place? I’ll give you a hint — he’s leeching off my food.”

“Excuses,” Декрас [he] said through a snort. His tone grew more serious and he shook his head. “But I do not understand what Сиван [he] is aiming after.”

“Probably your runes.” Возрождение [she] huffed. “They’ve both got a piece. Сиван [he] is probably going to try to take those pieces for himself. He already knew about Визен [he], and I imagine he found out about Ной [he] somehow. I’m waiting for the reveal, myself. There’s no way this is a coincidence.”

“Pieces of my runes?” Декрас [he]’ forehead creased in distaste and he leaned back in his chair, interlacing his fingers behind his head and getting more comfortable. “Doubtful. dabbles in a bit of dramaticism, but only upon occasion. As I said, he could have killed Визен [he] ten times over by now. The moment Визен [he] set foot in the hallway leading to that little pocket of dead space, he should have been dead. You saw it too. Визен [he] was caught in a Space Loop. Every step he took moved him an identical amount backward. It only stopped because Сиван [he] released the binding on purpose.”

“He wants Ной [he] and Визен [he] to meet, then. Perhaps he likes drama more than you would care to admit.”

Декрас [he]’s expression thinned. He studied the screen in silence for several long seconds before moving one of his shoulders in what might have been a shrug. “Perhaps. But Ной [he] will not be able to defeat Визен [he]. The gap in their strength is too great, even with the advancements he’s made.”

“You say that as if he isn’t the only mortal in the entirety of the toy kingdom to make a Rune from intent,” Renwal said crossly. “He’s a prodigy. There’s no way he’ll die here.”

“He’s a suicidal idiot that manages to stumble his way into success through sheer dumb perseverance and luck,” Декрас [he] grumbled. “And he’s a thief.”

“Sounds like someone’s still bitter.” There was more than a little smugness in Возрождение [she]’s tone. “Don’t tell me that you’re still stewing over getting robbed blind by multiple different mortals. If we’re speaking about embarrassing, I think you might be penning the novel.”

“Am I the one that lost an entire avatar to a mortal who gave it — literally — nothing in return?”

Возрождение [she] let out something between a cough and a groan. She hurriedly cleared her throat and glanced down at the black cat curled in her lap.


“I suggest changing the conversation. I no longer enjoy this one.”

“Fine.” Декрас [he] snorted. He grabbed another chocolate and popped it into his mouth. “I’m of half a mind to break the rules and put Визен [he] down like a dog when he arrives.”

“Arrives?” Возрождение [she]’s head tilted to the side, but she was grateful for the redirect. It would be a few hundred years before she wouldn’t want to bury her head in the ground every time she saw Маскот [he]. “You were right about Ной [he] not being able to defeat Визен [he] — so you think Сиван [he] will open the way here? Surely not.”

“He will.” There wasn’t so much as an ounce of doubt in Декрас [he]’ voice. He was completely convinced he spoke the truth.

“Why? He’s powerful enough to defeat Ной [he] and Визен [he] working together,” Возрождение [she] said. She turned fully away from the screen for a moment to focus on Декрас [he]. “This entire thing makes little sense to me. How well versed are you on him?”

“Well versed?” Декрас [he]’ lips pulled up in the faintest hint of a smile, but there was something else in his expression. It was so faint that it was almost impossible to make out, but a flicker of regret smoldered deep beneath the black pools that were Декрас [he]’ eyes. “I am more than well versed. I made Сиван [he] with my own hands. It would not be inaccurate to call him my son.”

Возрождение [she] blinked in surprise. “He was the first demon?”

“The very first,” Декрас [he] confirmed. He leaned back in his chair and let out a long sigh. “Сиван [he] was the first — the most successful of the lot. The only one who held true potential. He flew through the ranks like he was born to do it. I watched him craft Flawless after Flawless Rune, all the way up until Rank 8. The only demon in history to succeed in such an endeavor.”

“Don’t tell me… you think he’s going to Ascend?”

Декрас [he] burst into laughter. “No, Возрождение [she]. He will not. Сиван [he] is a failure.”

“What? But you said—”

“The most successful. And, unfortunately, still a failure,” Декрас [he] said. He shook his head in disappointment. “I was crushed. Everything had looked so promising… but Сиван [he] is still a demon. I was younger when I made him. I cared more — cared too much. For hundreds of years, I tried to help him find a way to break into Rank 9, but it’s impossible. It stumped me for far longer than I care to admit, and still my inability stings. It is my greatest regret.”

“But you found out why,” Возрождение [she] said. “Don’t make me beg for it when you’re eating my food.”

“I was getting to it, you impatient woman. The answer is painfully simple. Сиван [he] is nothing but a fragment of myself. He was handcrafted from a portion of my runes, and that is all that he will ever be. A rune cannot become more than itself. Сиван [he] is nothing but a worthless shell. Every other demon is worse. I know the cause, but I cannot fix it. It is an impossibility in the very core of their creation. I have already said before. Demons are a flawed experiment. A race with no future. Any potential they may have is, and always will be, destroyed by what they are.”

Возрождение [she]’s eyes went wide in realization. “That’s why they get consumed by themselves. They’re living runes.”

“Correct. It was not what I wanted for them, but it is what they are. Сиван [he] went the farthest, but he is still nothing more than a rune. He cannot advance to godhood. No copy ever can.”

“Why did you let this ever come into being?” Возрождение [she] demanded, rising partially from her chair. “This is more than cruelty—”

The words died in her throat. Декрас [he] wasn’t holding her gaze. His hands had tightened around the armrests of his chair, knuckles whitening, and he’d turned his head to the side. The god’s jaw was as tight steel.

“You couldn’t bring yourself to kill them,” Возрождение [she] said, her voice softer. “You actually do see them as your children, don’t you?”

“I do not,” Декрас [he] snarled. He pounded a fist against an armrest. “They are a failed race, one unworthy of the effort it would take me to purge them. And if you want proof of that, witness the latest mistake in their long line of failures.”

He turned his gaze back to the screen. Возрождение [she] followed it. A frown crossed her features. Out of everybody in the room, Декрас [he] was staring at the tiny demon that had followed Визен [he] through the hallway.

“The little girl?”

“Hollow,” Декрас [he] said. “Not an uncommon condition. Her soul is improperly formed and not well connected to her body. In theory, that should make her more prone to creating a rune of her own. That isn’t what happened. Instead, she’s incapable of properly connecting with even the flawed, so called,

Demon

Runes. The result is a shell of a being that can do nothing but wait to die no matter how desperately she struggles.”

“There’s no way around it?” Возрождение [she] asked, but she already knew the answer to her own question. It only took one look at the girl to see how weak her lifeforce was.

“Ask Сиван [he],” Декрас [he] said through a snort, but there was no amusement in his tone. “He attempts to fix what cannot be changed. Sticky is one of many, and far from his first attempt. Ironic. The so called Лорд [he] of Death, unable to keep a child alive because her body would crumble under the force of even his weakest rune fragment. Сиван [he] attempted to delay her death by externally wrapping her in death energy — but that hasn’t saved any of the other demons he’s tried it on. All it has done is delay their end.”

“And you?” Возрождение [she] asked.

“If I possessed a way to cure my greatest mistake, do you not think I would use it?” Декрас [he] asked. “I brought every scrap of power I have to bear. The demons are nothing but flawed runes, and that girl is one of the most useless of them all.”

Возрождение [she]’s eyes flicked back to the small demon girl sitting on the cracked obsidian floor. “Then she—”

“Spent the power Сиван [he] put on her opening a door that should have been impossible to move,” Декрас [he] said with a shake of his head. “Now there is nothing left to spend. She will be dead before the sun rises.”

Chapter 558: The Plan

Ной [he] wasn’t quite sure exactly what had happened during the last few minutes. When he’d stepped out of his tent to find Зат [he] and tell him that he was done with his preparation, Зат [he] had already been ready for him.

It seemed the huge demon had finished his conversation with… whatever it was that he had been speaking to some time ago. The very instant Ной [he] emerged from the tent, Зат [he] had snapped his fingers and a portal had begun to trace itself into the air, sending sparks of purple light arcing off it.

Зат [he] had then herded them all straight into it with no room for argument. As much as Ной [he] didn’t want Мокси [she] and Ли [she] tagging along with him to meet the Archdemon, Зат [he] refused to accept any counterarguments.

Unfortunately, going directly against the Rank 7 was functionally impossible. All of Ной [he]’s strength depended on Зат [he] actually playing along and wanting something from him. Straight up opposing him was still beyond what he was capable of doing if he wanted everyone else to leave the camp in one piece.

Ной [he] had no idea why Зат [he] had suddenly decided that Ли [she] and Мокси [she] had to come along as well. The demon refused to explain. He’d just pointed at the fully formed portal and waited, his armored foot clanking away as he tapped it on the ground.

And that was how Ной [he], along with Ли [she] and Мокси [she], found themselves stepping into Сиван [he]’s domain.

A cool chill gripped Ной [he]’s shoulders as soon as he emerged from the portal — and he froze in place. An endless sea of darkness stretched out around him. A familiar, almost comforting, darkness. It was the very same as the shadow that made up his own soul.

But this was not a soul.

Beneath his feet was a cracked obsidian platform, its edges trimmed with plain gold. Ной [he]’s domain prickled as it brushed across what could only have been described as a sea of наполнение [he]s.

Everything around him was positively awash with magic. It felt like trying to breath through a lungful of honey. A thick silence ruled over the air to such a degree that Ной [he] could hear his own heartbeat. His footstep echoed through the room like a gunshot.

Мокси [she] and Ли [she] had both entered before him. They stood locked in place, frozen in the same shock that Ной [he] felt, but something was wrong.

They were barely moving. It looked like someone had locked the two of them in time and slowed their speed down by a thousandfold.

What the hell is this? What’s going on?

It was then that Ной [he] realized they were far from alone in the room. The immensity of the silent darkness had drawn his attention away from the man floating in the air, wreathed in a crackling storm of red energy and obsidian shards.

Визен [he].

His mouth was open in a cry of fury, hands thrust forward. Electrical power crawled from his fingertips, moving so slowly that it might as well have been frozen in place. A small demon girl sat on the ground behind him, her wide eyes half-lidded in exhaustion. She was similarly unmoving, locked in time and space.

What the fuck? Визен [he] is here?

Ной [he] nearly leapt out of his own skin in surprise. He ripped power from his runes and prepared for a fight.

“Hello, Паук [he]. I’m glad to see you were able to make it. I’ve been looking forward to meeting you.” A gentle voice cut through the air.

Ной [he] spun toward its source.

Standing before him was a plain man in a plain gray suit, a mop of brown hair on his head and hands crossed behind his back. And his eyes — his eyes were pure white, as flat and empty as the void.

The breath caught in Ной [he]’s chest as he met the man’s gaze.

There was something there, lurking deep within it.

Something he had never seen in anything other than a mirror.

It was more than familiarity.

It was understanding.

“Сиван [he],” Ной [he] said, knowing without a doubt who stood before him. “You’ve been to the Line.”

“I would daresay that all of us have been to the line, Паук [he].” A smile crossed over Сиван [he]’s features. “It’s just that nobody else is unfortunate enough to recall the experience.”

Ной [he] swallowed. He tried to find words, but his thoughts failed him and nothing came forth. He could do nothing but stare. Before him was more than a Demon Лорд [he]. It was someone who actually knew what came beyond life.

Someone who had remembered it.

Just like he had.

“Why did you call me here?” Ной [he] asked, finally finding his voice once again. “This isn’t about a Broken Master Rune.”

“No,” Сиван [he] agreed. “It is not.”

The Demon Лорд [he] lifted his hands. Smoke twisted up from the ground and formed into a pair of wispy chairs. A table formed between them, and all three pieces of furniture solidified into obsidian an instant later. Сиван [he] stepped around a chair and lowered himself into it without a word.


Over his shoulder, Визен [he]’s magic crawled through the air in a slow-moving march to nothing.

Ной [he] pulled his gaze away from Визен [he] and approached the table. He sat down across from Сиван [he], the cold obsidian biting uncomfortably into his back.

“How did you know?” Ной [he] asked, his mind still spinning in disbelief.

“As like many things in life, equal parts coincidence and intention. The Woven man made little effort to hide his power when he arrived in my domain. A power whose source I am very familiar with,” Сиван [he] replied, interlacing his hands on the table before him. “That heightened my attention — and when you passed from this world but failed to enter the next, I felt the very same power in you as well — unless I am mistaken?”

Ной [he]’s stomach tightened. Визен [he] had recognized Разлом [he] back in the mortal realm, but this confirmed it. He wasn’t the only one with a piece of Декрас [he]’ power. Визен [he] had it as well — and if Сиван [he] recognized that strength, then there was a possibility that Ной [he] knew exactly where the Лорд [he] of Death’s power came from.

He glanced up at Визен [he]. If Сиван [he] had the power to slow time like this… the demon wasn’t just powerful.

For all intents and purposes, he was a god.

Ной [he] was surprised to find that information didn’t scare him. It actually set him at ease. For one of the first times since arriving at Арбитраж [he], he didn’t have to hide who he was. He didn’t have to hide his powers.

There was simply no point.

“You are not,” Ной [he] said. “I wield Разлом [he].”

Сиван [he]’s expression was unreadable. He drew in a deep breath, then let it out slowly as he turned his gaze toward the darkness above them.

“And so Декрас [he] reminds me of my failure once more,” Сиван [he] breathed, letting his gaze fall back to Ной [he]. “Will you tell me of how you came about taking Разлом [he] into your possession? I will not force you if you do not wish to speak, but the story would mean a great deal to me.”

There was desire in Сиван [he]’s empty eyes, but not desire for power. He didn’t care about the rune. He cared about what it represented.

Ной [he] told him.

The story was a long one.

Frozen lightning coiled behind Сиван [he] like a dragon crawling across the sky as Ной [he] spoke. His words vanished into the silent maw of the darkness surrounding them as he told Сиван [he] of the Line. He told the ancient demon about Возрождение [she] and Декрас [he], and about his arrival in the mortal world. Ной [he] told Сиван [he] about Арбитраж [he]. About Мокси [she] and Ли [she]. He told him about the students still waiting for him, and about Визен [he].

Ной [he] said almost everything — but not everything. He didn’t share the details of his research on Runes or Formations. It wasn’t pertinent to the story, and those were secrets that Ной [he] felt no reason to give up.

Сиван [he] did not say a single word until Ной [he] finished telling his story. The demon barely even so much as twitched from his spot in the chair. His features were an unreadable mask, his eyes as flat and empty as an icy ocean on a still night.

“I see,” Сиван [he] said quietly. “We are not as alike as I believed.”

Ной [he] blinked. “What?”

“You walked the Line for eons. I have only witnessed it, and that alone was difficult to handle,” Сиван [he] said. “I cannot comprehend recalling every step upon that endless path. It would break me.”

“But you’ve been there,” Ной [he] said. “And the gods? They didn’t…”

“The gods are bound by rules. They cannot interfere so long as we do not,” Сиван [he] said, his gaze drifting from Ной [he]. “And Декрас [he] would not interfere with me. Not again.”

“It sounds like you know him.”

“You could say that.” Сиван [he] let out a small laugh. The smile slipped away from his features as he turned to look at the small demon girl sitting on the ground behind Визен [he]. “Tell me, Ной [he]. What do you see when you look at her?”

Ной [he] turned to follow Сиван [he]’s gaze. “A girl, I suppose.”

“I see failure.”

“That seems a bit harsh. She’s barely a kid. What did she do?”

“Not hers,” Сиван [he] said. “Our race’s. Mine. Demons are a flawed, broken people. We are controlled by the runes within us. We are the runes within us. They are broken, and thus, we are too. The harder we reach for perfection, the more that we rip ourselves apart from within until nothing but the rune remains.”

Ной [he]’s mouth nearly fell open. In a single line, Сиван [he] had told him exactly what was wrong with Ли [she].

Holy shit. That makes so much sense. That’s why demons get consumed by the feeling their runes represent. Their body and soul are so closely linked that they literally are their own runes. The rune takes over the body, making it more like the rune, until they lose themselves.

“And the girl? Why is she a failure?” Ной [he] asked, desperate for more information. If Сиван [he] had more information, perhaps there was a way to save —

“She is broken,” Сиван [he] said. “A living example of what is broken in my race. She possesses no runes. A demon without runes is nothing. It grows harder to keep her alive with every passing day. Her body consumes the magic that comes into contact with it, but no rune can take purchase in her soul. She has tried to delay the end by injecting magical energy into her own heart, but that does nothing but lessen the stress on her body. Her soul still crumbles.”

Ной [he] looked back to the girl.

“Aren’t you in control of death? Just bring her back.”

“I have nothing to bind to her with. Runes are the tether between soul and body, and she does not have anything I can call upon.” Сиван [he] shook his head. “I did not mention her predicament to ask for advice, Ной [he]. You told me your story. I tell you mine.”

“I don’t know if I follow.”

“My race is cursed. You search for a solution that cannot be found, because demons are broken. I, with all the powers of 7 perfected Rank 8 Runes, could not save a mere girl. And you believe you have a chance to save Ли [she]?”

“Yes.” Ной [he]’s eyes narrowed. Сиван [he] wasn’t giving him a solution. The demon was trying to make him give up — and that would never happen. “I’m not going to abandon my friend. Just because someone stronger than me couldn’t pull something off doesn’t mean you thought about every option.”

“Well said,” Сиван [he] said. His smile returned to his face as he rose to his feet. The obsidian chair beneath him disintegrated into smoke. Ной [he] hurried to stand before the table and his own chair followed suit. Сиван [he] looked up to Визен [he], then blew out a sigh. “I cannot slow time for much longer. We will soon rejoin the others. I am pleased that you were more amiable than the Woven Man.”

Ной [he] glanced up at Визен [he], who was still wreathed in a cloak of roaring magic. “That really wasn’t too difficult to pull off.”

“No,” Сиван [he] agreed with a small smile. “It was not. I enjoyed our conversation, Ной [he]. I am glad we got to have it before the end.”

“The end? I’m not sure I like the sound of that.”

“Few do,” Сиван [he] said. He turned back to Визен [he]. “But I have come to realize that I cannot ascend as I am now. I, like every other demon, am flawed. I cannot reach the next rank, and even as powerful as I am, my life is not eternal. The dying girl on the ground is no different than I.”

“You’re dying?” Ной [he] asked, blinking in surprise. The Лорд [he] of Death dying almost felt ironic.

“I am falling apart at the seams. I fear I never truly lived,” Сиван [he] replied with a smile. “But it struck me that I have not tried everything. There is one last thing that I can do to attempt to gain true control over my runes and become more than my shackles.”

“And what is that?” Ной [he] asked, but from the way that Сиван [he] was looking at Визен [he], he suspected he already knew the answer.

“I am going to die. I would appreciate your assistance in the matter.”

Сиван [he] swept his hands downward, and time snapped back into motion.

Chapter 559: Death

Red lightning screamed through the air and slammed into the cracked obsidian ground with an earsplitting crack. Fragments of black stone exploded upward and spun into the void, vanishing from view.

Ной [he] staggered, doubling over as a wave of nausea washed over him. He ground his teeth and forced himself upright, drawing on his Runes as the crackling roar of a storm filled the air. More and more magical power gathered around Визен [he] — far more than any single mage ever should have been able to wield.

Fire, lightning, gray matter, and sickly red tendrils all mixed together with blades of obsidian and other swirling forms of energy. Ной [he]’s skin prickled in a mixture of awe and horror. What Визен [he] was doing should have been impossible.

A mage could only cast a single spell at once unless they were using a Formation to draw from multiple runes. Ной [he] had broken that ironclad rule with the Violin Мокси [she] gave him, and even that only let him cast two spells at once. That alone was an enormous advantage.

Realization snapped into existence within Ной [he]’s mind as he finally put the pieces of information he’d been given together. Визен [he] had thought Разлом [he]’s name was Weave. Сиван [he] had called him the Woven Man.

Визен [he] doesn’t have Разлом [he]. His Rune is called Weave, and I’ll bet that it’s literally weaving people’s runes together like some form of zombie, letting him control all of them at once. How many mages worth of power does Визен [he] have?

A bolt of red lightning crashed down several feet away from Ной [he], ripping through his thoughts and snapping him back into the present.

Thick storm clouds had gathered over Визен [he]. They stretched out through the void like greedy fingers, staining the sky a ruddy crimson.

Ной [he] had no doubt that Сиван [he] could have killed Визен [he] by now if he’d wanted to. But the Лорд [he] of Death had no plans of doing that. He wanted to die — but Ной [he] couldn’t let the demon bring the rest of them along with him into the afterlife.

“Зат [he]!” Ной [he] screamed, grabbing his gourd and flinging it to Мокси [she]. “Get them out of here!”

The Rank 7 Demon didn’t miss a beat. He spun, scooping Ли [she] and Мокси [she] off the ground like they were children. Neither of them said a single word of argument. There were times when staying to try and help fight was a good idea — but in a ring together with Сиван [he] and Визен [he], the only winning move was to leave.

Зат [he] tucked them both under one arm before springing toward the small demon on the ground and reaching out for her.

“No,” Сиван [he]’s voice was gentle, but Зат [he] ground to a halt in an instant. He spun and dashed down the stairs, taking a dozen of them at a time as he made for a small pinprick of light far below them at the base of the stairs.

Relief roiled up in Ной [he]’s chest, but he didn’t let it distract him. He still didn’t know what it was Сиван [he] wanted. The Лорд [he] of Death said he’d planned to die, but he somehow wanted Ной [he]’s help with it.

Визен [he] seemed more than willing to take care of that on his own. There was something missing. Ной [he] hadn’t caught some piece of subtext that Сиван [he] had dropped for him, and it didn’t look like there was going to be much time to work it out.

Energy roared around Визен [he] as he let out a roar of fury, not so much as looking in Ной [he]’s direction as he thrust his hands toward Сиван [he].

A sea of power crashed down toward the Лорд [he] of Death from every direction. Lightning plummeted from the sky. Shards of obsidian shot for his body. Red and gray magic enveloped him in a swirling tornado with such intensity that the ground beneath him shattered, sending shrapnel flying in every direction.

Ной [he] darted forward, flinging himself between the demon girl and the explosion. He lifted his hands and summoned a wall of wind.

It was pointless.

Not a single fragment drew near to to him or the girl.

Roaring magic drowned out Ной [he]’s thoughts as Визен [he] rained down spell after spell upon Сиван [he], each one shaking the world with the ramping intensity of their might. It felt as if Визен [he] didn’t have any limit to his power, and ever passing minute only made him stronger.

“Is he winning?”

Ной [he] glance down. The demon girl squinted past him, her face pale and covered in a thin sheen of sweat. She looked like she had a violent fever. Her arms were trembling from the effort of keeping herself upright and her eyes fluttered with strain.

“Who?” Ной [he] asked.

“Both of them,” the girl replied. A tiny smile pulled at the corner of her lips. “Визен [he] wanted to kill Сиван [he]. Сиван [he] wants to die. He told me. I… just wanted to help. Did I help?”


Ной [he] looked back to the storming magic covering half of the platform. He could barely make out Визен [he] or Сиван [he]’s forms anymore. There was only an ocean of runic magic, so intense that he suspected he would have been vaporized the moment he tried to approach.

“I suppose you did,” Ной [he] said, looking back to the girl.

The back of his spine prickled and the breath caught in his throat as a realization struck him.

Сиван [he] had called her hollow. A demon without runes.

A demon without a Minuscule Fragment of Декрас [he]. Holy shit. She’s not broken. This girl is a pure demon. If she could make a Fragment of Self, I could learn how to help every single other demon do it. She’s the key I need.

“That’s good,” the girl said. Her features relaxed and she sank back to the ground, staring up at the cloud-covered void above. “Are you Сиван [he]’s friend?”

A loud crack of thunder split the air as another bolt of lighting crashed down. The girl barely even reacted to it.

“Something like that,” Ной [he] said over the crash of magic behind him. “Listen. I don’t know what you’ve been told, but I think you could be very important. I’ve been researching demons for some time now. I’ve discovered the problem with your runes, and I think I can fix it. You might be the key to doing that.”

“I don’t think so. You found the wrong demon.” the girl’s voice was weaker than before. “I don’t have any runes.”

“Exactly,” Ной [he] said, taking her gently by the shoulders. “What’s your name?”

“Sticky.” The demoness blinked, heavily, trying to muster the energy to look up at Ной [he]. “But I don’t have any magic.”

“You can,” Ной [he] said. He put a hand on the grimoire hanging from his back. “I’ll help you. I can come into your mind, and we can make you a rune. The others are wrong. You might be the most important demon in history. Just hold—”

A powerful blast of wind slammed into Ной [he]’s back. He staggered, nearly falling straight on top of Sticky. He yanked on Natural Disaster and blew himself back into position before he could crush her.

Ной [he] spun toward Визен [he] and Сиван [he] and the blood froze in his veins.

All the magic was gone. Визен [he] stood before Сиван [he], a sword made of woven red and gray energy clutched in both of his hands.

Its blade was buried directly in the center of Сиван [he]’s chest. Blood bloomed like a flower around it and soaked into the demon’s gray suit. For an instant, Ной [he] locked eyes with the Лорд [he] of Death.

A faint smile pulled across the demon’s lips.

Then Визен [he]’s voice tore through the room like the blast of a cannon.

“Open the way,” Визен [he] commanded. Mind magic poured from his words and slammed into Ной [he]’s stomach like a physical blow. He drew on Empty Proliferation as he felt the words worm into his skull, but they passed by harmlessly before they could take root.

The command hadn’t been meant for Ной [he].

Strands of gray magic wound out from Визен [he]’s palm. They wound around Сиван [he] and sank into his skin. The demon made no move to resist, even as Визен [he] ripped the sword free of his body.

“Very well.” The Лорд [he] of Death lifted his hands into the air. “It has been a long time coming, hasn’t it?”

All the energy in the air vanished with a pop. Ice crawled across Ной [he]’s skin and wound into his chest. His heart missed a beat and the breath stilled in his lungs. An immense pressure rolled through the room.

Black coiled through the air above them. It was sheer, unimaginable power. Horrifying and peaceful. Silent and omnipresent. The inevitable end for all mortals.

It was Death.

Сиван [he] clapped his hands together, but the sound made no noise. The void was utterly still.

A white rectangle split open between his palms as he pulled them apart. It expanded to float before him, twisting with whorls of smoke that faded away to reveal a distant, shimmering path of gold.

Ice gripped Ной [he]’s throat.

The Line.

Визен [he] let out a shuddering breath. Portions of his skin peeled back and floated in the air as if he were made out of confetti, but the man didn’t even seem to notice. His eyes were firmly fixed on the white portal before him. “Finally. Await me, Bella. Your father comes for you.”

He stepped into the void.

“Did he do it?” Sticky whispered, her weak voice just barely making it to Ной [he]’s ears. “I can’t see.”

His eyes jerked back to the girl. Ной [he] swallowed the fear twisting in his gut and carefully looped a hand around Sticky’s head, lifting it so she could see the portal.

“Yes.” Ной [he]’s throat was tight. “They did.”

“They’ll be happy now,” Sticky said, relaxing into Ной [he]’s hand. “I did something good, right?”

“You can do a whole lot more than that,” Ной [he] said, grabbing for the Fragment of Возрождение [she] with his mind and sending the magic flooding into her body. Power tingled at his fingertips as the rune worked into her. “Listen to me, Sticky. I can come into your soul and we can fix you up. You can save the entire demon—”

“Your magic is nice. So… warm.” Sticky’s lips twitched in a small smile, but she didn’t have the strength to keep it for more than a moment. “I’m sorry. I wish I could have helped you too.”

And there, lying in Ной [he]’s arms, Sticky died.

The magic pouring from the Fragment of Возрождение [she] evaporated. It could do many things, but it could not bring back the dead.

“No!” Ной [he] yelled, but death could not be reasoned with. It did not accept bargains.

Ной [he]’s teeth clenched. He lowered Sticky to the ground, brushing his hands over her eyes to close them, and turned toward Сиван [he].

The Лорд [he] of Death still stood where he had been run through, the white portal buzzing between his palms. A knowing smile was still present on his face.

“Fuck,” Ной [he] snarled.

Визен [he] had gotten through the portal and taken the key out of the Damned Plains with him. The best lead he’d found to help Ли [she] had died — and she’d been a child. Ной [he] had failed at every single thing he’d come here to do.

His hands tightened into fists at his sides.

The portal still stood.

“Hold on a bit longer for me, would you?” Ной [he] asked, striding up to stand before the Лорд [he] of Death.

Сиван [he]’s smile twitched wider. Blood trickled down from his lips and dripped from his chin. “Death waits for no man.”

“I haven’t been a mere man for a very long time,” Ной [he] replied.

Then he dove into the void.

Chapter 560: Infinity

The world was cold and silent. An endless void — the true void, not the replica that had existed within Сиван [he]’s domain — stretched out around Ной [he] like the maw of an ancient beast. Golden paths swirled through the emptiness like strands of hair as they converged in the far, far distance.

Ной [he] couldn’t see where they were going, but he didn’t need to. He knew what came at the end of eons of journey along the sprawling paths.

Faint, translucent motes of blue shimmered upon the pathways. They moved one ponderous step at a time to the beat of an endless march. There were no words. No desires. No goals. Souls that walked upon its surface seemed to feel nothing but the millstone of time grinding away at them until they finally arrived at its head, where Возрождение [she] would be waiting for them.

There was only the Line.

This was the one location in all existence that he would have given almost anything to never return to — but he had no choice. Визен [he] had the Key. Ной [he] and Мокси [she] weren’t demons. They couldn’t be summoned, even if they wanted to be. Returning to the mortal plane was impossible without it.

Cold space pressed in on Ной [he], and his domain churned as it fought to keep it back. There was no air in the afterlife. His lungs found nothing when he breathed in, and yet, his body sustained all the same.

The void was pure, unfiltered magic. Power permeated everything within the darkness, omnipresent and uncaring. Even if Ной [he]’s entire body had shut down, he got the feeling that he would have continued to exist.

This was a place in which the mortal concept of life did not exist. The beat of the heart, the breath of the lung, the pump of blood — none of it mattered. The afterlife was a misnomer. It was not a place of life or unlife. It was a place of existence.

And, no matter how badly someone wanted to live or do the very opposite, there was only one option for them here. It was to exist.

Mortals did not belong here.

Ной [he] did not belong here. It was a place reserved for those who walked the line and the gods that oversaw them.

Knots twisted his stomach and a deep sense of terror and unease clawed at Ной [he]’s heart. It begged him to turn back toward the only point of color other than gold in the void — the stark white portal that burned in the air behind him, held open by Сиван [he].

Ной [he] crushed the desire. He couldn’t leave. Not without the key. His eyes scanned the line in search of Визен [he].

Fortunately for him, mortals stuck out like a sore thumb in a land where the only residents were floating blue souls.

He spotted Визен [he] after mere moments. The man floated above the line, churning red and gray magic enveloping him like the tendrils of an eldritch god. Pieces of Визен [he]’s skin had peeled back. He was unraveling at the seams, but in his right hand was the key. The mage had bound it to himself with strands of gray magic.

Ной [he]’s lips thinned and he willed himself forward. To his surprise, the thought sent him zipping through the empty void like a rocket. He moved so quickly that he nearly slammed straight into Визен [he] before jerking to a halt a dozen feet away from him.

The Woven Man’s head snapped up toward Ной [he]. Surprise and anger carved across his features and he turned in his direction.

“You,” Визен [he] snarled. The void swallowed his words, barely letting them make it to Ной [he]’s ears. “Leave. I have no more need for your power. We have no quarrel.”

“That’s a load of shit and you know it,” Ной [he] replied as he drew on his Runes. Power carved through his body and reared back, waiting for his command. “You don’t get to do heinous shit and then go around claiming we have no quarrel once you get what you want.”

“I have done bad, and I would do worse. You could not understand.” Визен [he] turned toward Ной [he] and lifted his hand toward him, his fingers curling into the shape of a claw. “I have no energy to waste on you. Leave. This is your final warning.”

“Give me the key, and I’ll consider it.” Ной [he] pulled his lips back in a snarl. “What are you going to do? Mind control me?”

Визен [he] mind controlled him.

Or, more accurately, Визен [he] tried to mind control him.

His magic slammed into Ной [he] like a crashing river, driving into his mind in a spike and seeking to rip control of his body from him.


If they had been outside the afterlife or if Визен [he] hadn’t been holding his power back for some purpose, perhaps it would have been more effective. But they were not. By the time Визен [he]’s magic reached Ной [he], it had been severely weakened.

And, when Ной [he] felt the prickle of Визен [he]’s mind pressing against his own, he smiled. Ной [he]’s mind grabbed onto the connection the other mage had established.

Then he unleashed Empty Proliferation.

His mind slammed against Визен [he]’s, but Ной [he] didn’t try to overwhelm the other mage. That would have been impossible. Визен [he]’s runes were far stronger than his. It was impossible to defeat him as they were now — which meant Ной [he] had to change the fight.

And if there was one place where things were even, it was when magic was a battle of will rather than pure runic force.

Ной [he] ripped open his Mindspace.

The afterlife evaporated.

***

Gentle gold light burned beneath Ной [he]’s feet. It was a translucent path that he knew well, but there were no translucent blue souls joining him upon it. It was the endless path that led to Возрождение [she], but it was not the afterlife.

A black space stretched out in all directions around him. It was the void, but it was not the afterlife.

There was only one other being present upon the golden pathway that stretched out into oblivion. Визен [he] stood a dozen feet away from Ной [he], staring at him in stunned disbelief. They were on the Line, but it was not the afterlife.

It was Ной [he]’s mind — but it was more than that. A foreign presence burned within it. This place was Визен [he]’s just as much as it was his. Their minds had linked.

“What is this?” Визен [he] demanded. “What have you done?”

“You’re the one that established the connection to my mind. But the thing is, those things go both ways,” Ной [he] replied, cracking his neck. “Don’t you think it’s fair to even the playing field a bit?”

“You have Mind Runes? Since when… no. No, it does not matter. You are in my way. What is one more death?” Визен [he]’s jaw clenched and he thrust a hand toward Ной [he]. A sea lightning exploded from his hand.

It ripped through the air — and folded in on itself. The magic barely made it a foot away from Визен [he] before it had shrunk to nothing more than the size of a worm. It vanished with a blip, disappearing well before it could reach Ной [he].

“Whoops,” Ной [he] said. “No tantrums, Визен [he]. Your magic isn’t going to work here.”

Визен [he] clapped his hands together. He ripped them apart, and gray threads burst from his palms. They extended like the tendrils of Cthulhu reaching for Ной [he], only to collapse and disappear within feet once more.

“What is this?” Визен [he] demanded, disbelief gripping his features. “You are a Rank 4! How is this possible? I am not in your soul. I am a far greater Mind Mage than you. Neither of our mindspaces rule over this place. It is a common ground that you merely aided in shaping. You cannot control it.”

Damn. Визен [he] really knows his Mind Magic shit. I’m just glad this worked. I was a little worried Визен [he] would crush me with sheer strength.

“Maybe I’m in more control than you think.”

“You are not,” Визен [he] said flatly. He thrust his hands forward again and unleashed a storm of black flames. Once more, the magic sputtered out well before it reached Ной [he]. Визен [he]’s hands tightened. “This is impossible. I have fought other Mind Mages before. A mental connection like the one you formed is perfectly balanced. Our minds have equal control here — so how is it that you have snuffed my magic?”

“I’m sure your magic is fine, but it can’t do anything when it can’t get to me,” Ной [he] said with a small smile.

“I cannot waste time with the likes of you!” Визен [he] snapped, a note of panic entering his voice. He snapped his fingers. A magical storm ripped out from him in every direction. It expanded through the darkness — and vanished.

Not a single scrap of his magic drew close to Ной [he].

“It seems to me that you can,” Ной [he] said, trying not to show just how fast his heart was beating. His magical energy was draining away at an alarming rate. Empty Proliferation wasn’t a particularly large rune. He couldn’t keep it going forever. “My Mind Rune is the concept of emptiness, Визен [he]. The closer your power gets, the more space it has to cover to reach me.”

Granted, this doesn’t work anywhere outside of my own mind. But while we’re here… Empty Proliferation is built off the endless bullshit that is the Line’s waiting time. Anything passing from Визен [he]’s mind into mine is going to take a few thousand years.

“How can you possess a rune like this?” Визен [he] demanded. “It’s not possible. A concept like that isn’t something that the human mind can comprehend.”

“See, there’s the thing,” Ной [he] said. “The human mind is capable a lot of shit. Shit that it doesn’t want to do — but it can still do. Our minds can experience a lot of things. They just might not make it out in one piece. I know that from experience.”

Визен [he]’s gaze bore into Ной [he]. His eyes flicked down to the translucent gold path that shimmered beneath his feet, then out to the void surrounding them. When his attention returned to Ной [he], realization lurked within it.

“You’ve been here,” Визен [he] said in awe. “You’ve been to the afterlife.”

“We’ve all been to the afterlife. I just remember the experience. It did a lot of things to me, Визен [he]. I hate waiting — but I’ve had no choice but to become very good at it.” Empty Proliferation had no more than a few minutes of power left within it — and that number was even less if Визен [he] started attacking him again. And, thus, Ной [he] did what he did best. He lied through his teeth.

“How long can you afford to sit around, Визен [he]? Because I’m not letting either of us leave here until you give me that key. I hope you decide quickly. I doubt the Богиня [she] of Reincarnation is going to be pleased about intruders.”

“She would kill you just as surely as she would me,” Визен [he] said. “You seek to kill us both. Mortals cannot—”

“That’s the second time today that somebody associated me with the likes of you,” Ной [he] said interrupting Визен [he] as his lips thinned. “There is no more torture that can be done to my mind that has not already been done. I have been forced to bear witness to infinity. And if you don’t give me that key, your fate will be the same.”

Chapter 561: Визен [he]

Ной [he] fought to keep the strain from showing on his face. The golden light glistening at his feet reflected of his feet and faded into the infinite void that stretched out all around them. The world was silent and still.

His energy was depleting, the power within Empty Proliferation rapidly approaching its limits. He couldn’t keep himself and Визен [he] in the space between their minds for much longer. There were minutes at most left before he lost control and they returned to the afterlife. That couldn’t happen. Not yet. The only way Ной [he] could stand against Визен [he] was with Empty Proliferation keeping the other mage at bay.

The disbelief that had warped Визен [he]’s features slowly shifted to realization. His expression changed as he looked upon Ной [he] in a new light, connections forming within his mind. More pieces of his body peeled away, revealing pulsating gray energy beneath his skin. Визен [he] barely even seemed to notice.

“You have walked the Line,” Визен [he] breathed. “You survived the line. I knew it was possible. Who helped you?”

“Nobody,” Ной [he] replied.

Not intentionally, at least.

“Impossible. You are not powerful enough to—” Визен [he]’s words ground to a halt and his jaw clenched. He let out a hiss and his hands tightened at his sides. “No matter. I do not care. Hear me now. I have absolutely no care for you or the mortal plane. I only have a single desire in this life, and I will stop at nothing to achieve it. I cannot spare the magic to fight you. Release this prison, and I will give you the key.”

Ной [he] opened his mouth to reply, but the words died at his lips.

What?

“You… will?”

“I will have no need for it after this,” Визен [he] replied. “Quickly, now. Our time is thinner than hair. Once I have completed my task, the key will be yours. There will be sufficient strength left within it to open a path back to the Mortal Plane within it. I promise this.”

“…why?” Ной [he] asked, so stunned that his mask fell for a moment. “I really wasn’t expecting you to actually say yes. You aren’t actually planning to just waltz back to Арбитраж [he] and pretend you didn’t do anything wrong, are you? You’re a fucking monster. You mind-controlled people. You killed people.”

“I have done a great many things, and I would do a great many worse ones, all to arrive in this point in space. This point in time,” Визен [he] replied, grabbing the key attached to his palm by gray threads. He ripped it free. Magic crackled around him and Визен [he] staggered, letting out a snarl. “My real body mirrors my actions here. I will not give you the Key until my work is done, but you will have it. But I will not allow a single spare second to slip by. Either we both get what we want, or the Богиня [she] of Reincarnation ensures neither of us do.”

Ной [he] hesitated for a second longer, but Endless Proliferation was so low on energy that he really didn’t have much choice. His actual plan — as barely formed as it was — had mostly been hoping that Возрождение [she] would show up and kill Визен [he] before she killed him, giving him a chance to grab the key and hopefully slip out while she was scolding his soul for being naughty — or doing whatever it was that a Богиня [she] of Reincarnation did.

This option seemed like it had a slightly higher chance to actually succeed. The idea of working with

Визен [he] had never occurred to Ной [he], and he wasn’t so sure he liked the sound of it, but if it landed him the key, he got what he needed. At the end of the day, if he could save Мокси [she] and Ли [she], nothing else mattered. Nobody else mattered.

It’s the right move. But…

Something in Ной [he]’s stomach twisted.

Empty Proliferation gave out.

His magic winked out. The melded Mindscape collapsed.

With a roar, the true afterlife reformed all around Ной [he] and Визен [he]. Twisting paths of gold carved through infinity on their path toward the Waters of Life. Countless souls populated their surface, locked in the endless trudge through the great beyond.

Визен [he] spun toward the line below them.

“Wait!” Ной [he] barked, his words carving through the void like a hot knife. He shot forward grabbed Визен [he] by the shoulder, spinning the mage around. “I know the line better than you, Визен [he]. Better than anyone. Even Сиван [he]. I can accomplish far more than you. If you want to succeed, you’ll need my help. Why are you here?” Ной [he] asked. “The real reason, not some lie or whatever you might have told other people. Is it really—”

“I have never lied about my purpose. There was no need to. My daughter is in that line,” Визен [he] said, his hands clenching at his sides. He batted Ной [he]’s hand off his shoulder. “She was stolen from me. Stolen from life. There is nothing in this world that will keep me from righting that wrong. I will rip the world asunder a thousand times over to bring her back. Now step back. I will abide by our deal, and you will not interfere any longer. I have not the magic to waste on you.”

Визен [he] lifted a hand into the air. Large chunks of his fingers had peeled back and holes grew across the surface his palm. He clenched his fingers and red energy peeled away from his body, crackling into a vibrating disk.

The disk shifted. Its surface grew smooth and glossy like a still lake. It folded in on itself until it was the size of a marble, and a dim thread lit in the dark void. It stretched off through infinity, running parallel to the line.

“She waits,” Визен [he] breathed, his gaze lifting to follow the red line into the distance. “Still, she walks the afterlife. I was certain of it. I am coming, Bella.”


Ной [he]’s stomach clenched again. Going along with Визен [he] was the easiest way to get away with this. Even if Возрождение [she] showed up, Визен [he] would draw her attention and he’d have a chance to nab the Key and make a run for it.

It should have been easy. All he had to do was stand to the side and let it happen. Визен [he] seemed like he had a plan. He clearly had a way to find his daughter. Ной [he] just had to do nothing.

His hands tightened at his sides.

Fuck. I can’t. Out of everything I could stand back and watch… this might be the one thing I can’t allow.

“You can’t do this,” Ной [he] said.

“Idiot,” Визен [he] growled. His free hand turned toward Ной [he], but he hesitated. Визен [he] obviously needed every single scrap of power he had to pull this off. He couldn’t afford to waste any, an advantage Ной [he] fully planned to abuse. Визен [he]’s teeth clenched. “You still seek to stand in—”

“Shut up,” Ной [he] said. “Тим [he]e is of the essence. You were right about that. Do you know what you seek?”

“The same thing I always have. The return of my daughter—”

“The torture of your daughter. Do you know what the line did to me? Millenia upon millennia of agony seared into my brain. Thousands of years of hell. Everything since has been nothing but a blip in my mind. A flicker of existence in a sea of emptiness.”

“She has not been dead that long,” Визен [he] said, but there was an instant of hesitation before his response. “Four hundred and seven years.”

“Ah, yes,” Ной [he] spat. “Four hundred and seven years. Even if time flows at the same rate here as it does in our world, I am certain that four hundred and seven years of desolation will leave her mind unscarred. She will thank you for forcing her to endure another life, her memories of what comes beyond haunting her every living moment.”

“I — no. This cannot — she will recover. Humans are resilient,” Визен [he] said. Panic lit behind his eyes. “She will be fine.”

“You take her chances of reincarnation and replace them with a wretched, warped existence,” Ной [he] said. “And what of Возрождение [she]? Do you think the Богиня [she] of Reincarnation will look kindly upon what you do? Your desire to bring her back will do nothing but grant her a few short years of suffering before she returns to where she was, all too painfully aware of what she will have to endure again.”

Визен [he] flinched back with every word. Power stormed around him and twisted into the empty void, seeking release. Ной [he]’s gaze was unflinching as it bored into Визен [he]’s eyes.

I can’t let another person like me exist. I died hundreds of times before I reconnected with my mortality, and I was only able to because of my students. Because of Изабель [she]. Because of Тодд [he]. Because of Мокси [she] and Ли [she]. They tied me back to this world, but still the Line lurks. I’ll never be rid of it. Not as long as I live.

I will not let that fate happen to someone else.

“Look down,” Ной [he] said. “Look at the line, Визен [he]. It is silent. There is nothing. Nobody. You can’t speak to the other souls. It is utter loneliness in the crowd. All you can do is walk. It rips your being to pieces, so that when the time finally arrives for rebirth, you accept it with open arms. You would steal that from you daughter.”

Визен [he] looked down, and Ной [he] followed his gaze. He’d been avoiding looking directly at the line for as long as possible, but the movement was almost instinctive.

Both of them froze.

Standing near the end of the line was a familiar soul. Though she was translucent and her form muted by the other souls surrounding her, there was no mistaking the small figure.

It was Sticky.

“Why is she here?” Визен [he] whispered. He spun toward Ной [he], his voice turning to a roar that was swallowed by the void all the same. “Why is she here?”

“She died,” Ной [he] said. “She wasted the power Сиван [he] used to keep her alive so she could open that door to Сиван [he]’s room for you.”

Визен [he]’s arm trembled. His eyes flicked from the strand of red energy running from the marble in his hand down to Sticky.

“She wasn’t meant to,” Визен [he] said. Pain knitted through his words and his jaw clenched. “She was going to find a way.”

“We did.” Ной [he]’s fists tightened at his sides. “I believe I have a way to fix the demons, but she didn’t live long enough for me to use it.”

A distant shimmer of pearlescent light grabbed Ной [he]’s attention. It was so far that he could barely make it out, but a pink glow was washing across the horizon.

Визен [he]’s head jerked up toward it.

“She comes,” Визен [he] said. “The Богиня [she] of Reincarnation has sensed our intrusion.”

“If anything, I’m surprised it took this long,” Ной [he] said. “Give this up, Визен [he]. Don’t do this to your daughter. Give me the key.”

“Tell me something,” Визен [he] said, his voice going distant. “You processed the line? As you walk through it? You could not interact, but you knew what was present?”

“Yes,” Ной [he] replied. “Every last second.”

Визен [he] looked back down at the figures below them, locked in their endless march. Something in his expression shifted.

The pink light in the distance grew brighter. Ной [he] couldn’t tell how fast it was approaching. It was impossible to gauge distance in the void. The light simply was.

“I see,” Визен [he] said simply. “You will wait here.”

Ной [he] blinked. “What? Do you not see the light? Our time is—”

“Not yet up. You will wait. My task is not complete.”

Визен [he] flung the Key toward Ной [he].

Ной [he] lunged, grabbing it from the air before it could sail past him and into the void. He spun back toward Визен [he] in shock, but the other mage wasn’t watching him anymore.

Визен [he] was looking down at the line. He extended both of his palms toward it, his fingers digging into the air like claws. Gray strands peeled away from his entire body and flooded the air around him like he were the herald of an eldritch god.

Glistening blue energy burst free from within his body as it split apart. It burned like a flame in the night, growing so bright that Ной [he] was forced to squint.

“This is my final binding.” Визен [he]’s words were quiet, but the immense power they held threatened to shatter the darkness around him. He clapped his hands together, then ripped them apart.

A sea of grey exploded outward, tearing free from his body and driving into the line. Визен [he]’s own body unraveled in the process, pieces of him vanishing and transforming into the gray strands. His legs and torso crumbled away.

“I am coming, Bella. You will not be alone for much longer — but there is one more thing I must do first.” Визен [he]’s lips pulled back in a smirk. He clapped his hands together one final time, and then they too vanished into the sea of gray. The energy crawled up his neck and cracks reached across his face. Визен [he] looked down onto the huge bridge that his magic had formed between himself and the line. For an instant, a faint smile crossed over his expression. “Bear me witness. Twice now, your father steals from the gods.”

The pink light on the horizon grew brighter still, casting the afterlife in a faint hue, but Визен [he] didn’t so much as glance in its direction. He simply looked down at the line. Any expression his face might have retained was blocked from Ной [he]’s sight, visible to only the souls below him.

“

Weave .”

Chapter 562: Правосудие [she]

The word slammed into Ной [he] like a physical blow. He doubled over, the air driven from his lungs and the world spinning around him. Ной [he] barely managed to gather his senses and will himself to a halt before he was sent hurtling through the darkness and into oblivion.

And with that word, the final scraps of Визен [he]’s body evaporated.

All that remained of him was the glowing blue light that had been growing stronger with every passing second.

His soul.

There was a sound like a zipper ripping through the planes of reality. Every thread of grey magic tightened as if they had been pulled taut.

Familiar power roiled in the air. Power that Ной [he] had felt within Разлом [he] — and yet, unique enough to make it completely apparent that this was not his Rune. They may have been cut from the same cloth, but they were different.

A loud snap echoed through the void, and a soul was torn free from the line.

The magic wrapped around the soul, pouring into it to create flesh. Gray thread wove into the form of a small demon, her new flesh the color of cobblestone. Power thrummed from her body in waves, and though her eyes were closed, her chest rose and fell in faint breaths.

Sticky had a body once more. Coils of grey power slithered beneath her skin like a bed of snakes, slowly fading away as they found their places and settled in.

Ной [he] stared at her in disbelief. Разлом [he] had rebuilt his body countless times when he’d died back in the Mortal Plane, but Визен [he] had just ripped Sticky straight out of the Line itself. His final words had proven true.

Визен [he] had stolen straight from the gods.

I think I’m going to need a little bit more than just a fruit basket.

Ной [he] willed himself toward Sticky, but Визен [he] was faster.

His glowing blue hand pressed into the demon girl’s back, sending her flying through the void toward Ной [he]. She landed in Ной [he]’s arms limply. Sticky was wrapped in in a deep cloak of sleep. That was probably for the best. The less she remembered of the afterlife, the better it would be.

Ной [he]’s gaze lifted. For a moment, he stared into Визен [he]’s glowing blue eyes. The other man’s lips worked as he tried to form a word. Ной [he] had never had any difficulty speaking to himself as a soul after he’d been reincarnated, but it seemed that boon did not extend its grace to the afterlife.

Визен [he]’s finger lifted in to the air and he traced it through the air. A faint trail of energy followed in the wake of his finger as he wrote a single word.

Then he turned toward the red line that stretched out through the afterlife. A single strand of grey energy, the only remaining one, swirled up to wrap around Визен [he]’s wrist. He grabbed onto the strand of red and shot off, a streak of light fading into eternity.

Ной [he] stared at the final word that Визен [he] had left behind. He was all too aware of the growing pink light in the distance, but the other man wouldn’t have wasted time drawing a word for no reason.

And that was a problem.

The word made absolutely no sense.

Orlen.

There was no pattern to it. No sign that it might have been a hidden message or something else. It was simply a word.

Ной [he] couldn’t risk sitting around and waiting any longer to find out what it meant. He spun, his gaze turning to the burning mote of white in the distance. The portal back to the Damned Plain was still open. Even now, Сиван [he] held it for him.

With Sticky under one arm and the key clutched in a hand, Ной [he] flew toward the portal that would take him away from the Line.

He flew toward life.
